PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PARA.TAB: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PETITION.PARA: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PARA.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms

PETITION.PARA: Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia as our head of State.

PETITION.TITLE: Consumption Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
i) are alarmed by talk of a consumption (goods and services) tax which we feel would have a devastating effect on the lives of the people on low to middle incomes.
ii) call on the Senate to express its total opposition to the introduction of a consumption (goods and services) tax.

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: A humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Attention is drawn to Australia's increasing role in the militarisation of the Pacific region and in particular to the current Government-led arms export drive.

The arms trade is not only detrimental to Australians affected by the diversion of public money away from socially beneficial areas—for example, health, education and social welfare—but is an integral factor in the oppression and poverty of the people of the Third World.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:
Cease all military aid and training to governments engaged in repression of their own people.
Direct all Federal and State Government Departments and instrumentalities to withdraw from participation in and support for AIDEX and similar arms fairs in Australia and overseas.
Close down AIDEX 1991.
Establish a register of all applications for arms transfers and offset agreements which would be subject to public scrutiny.
Redirect all monies currently being used to promote the arms industry to socially useful research, development and production.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Reduction of Armaments
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia humbly showeth:
That currently Australia's military expenditure is $8,970 million a year, i.e. over $24 million a day:
That the 1989 Environmental Land Package allowed $320 million to be spent on the environment over the next ten years, but that this
is less than the cost of one Anzac frigate (initially $416 million)
or less than half the cost of one submarine ($644 million);
That Project Kangaroo 1989 military exercise cost $230 million in three months, more than two-thirds the sum allotted to the environment for ten years;
That, in the meantime we urgently need more money for
housing for the homeless,
safer and more efficient public transport,
more hospital staff and beds,
better health services, education, child care, etc.;

That while we recognise the need for legitimate spending on defence, we consider that current expenditure and projected development of Australian military capacity far exceeds that required to maintain Australian security;
That we believe a reduction in our military build up would, in fact, contribute to peace and security in our region.
That we therefore appeal to the Government to reduce expenditure on armaments and use the money thus saved for the needs of the community and the environment.
And we, your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child-care Fee Relief Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the Senators in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the two-tiered child care fee relief scheme to be introduced by the Federal Government from 1 January 1992 will discriminate against families needing child care for "non-work" related" reasons.
That fees for these families will rise to such an extent that thousands of parents will not be able to afford access to child care services.

That as a result the viability of many child care centres and services will be significantly affected causing increases in fees for families who need access to child care services for "work related" reasons.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Senate should disallow the Federal Government's new two tiered child care fee relief scheme.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology: Capital Funding

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SPINDLER

TALK.START.PARA: —I present to the Senate the following petition, from 4,189 petitioners, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form and does not contain a prayer at the end:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable P.J. Baldwin, Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services. We the undersigned students of RMIT are concerned about the level of capital funding allocated to the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology. RMIT is significantly deficient in both academic and recreational space.
Buildings are disastrously overcrowded and dilapidated. We believe that the capacity of RMIT to meet teaching and research commitments has been seriously impaired as a result.

The areas most affected by the accommodation deficiencies are access to the library, lecture rooms, tutorial and workshop rooms, laboratories, quiet study areas, student communal areas, catering outlets, meeting, activity and large function rooms, hallways, lifts and stairwells.
RMIT's space deficiency is not something that has arisen overnight, it is the result of historically inadequate capital funding.
We demand that the Federal Government establish RMIT as a capital funding priority.
We demand the restoration of $10.3 million necessary to fully fund the extensions to Building 8.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present to the Senate the following petition, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders, from 51 citizens:

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Tasmania sheweth:
that your Petitioners strongly object to AIDEX `91 and ask that it not be allowed to go ahead.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: SHERRY

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present to the Senate the following petitioning letter, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders, from 14 citizens:

SPEECH.PARA: 20th November, 1991
Dear Senator Sherry,

PARA.TAB: We, the parents of children using the Lipscombe Child Care write urging you to do all in your power to stop the Federal Government implementing changes to the fee relief system which operates in this Centre and all Children's Services throughout Australia.

The proposed new two tiered fee relief system is a social injustice of the worst kind. It discriminates against the non-working parent and single income earner. The changes will push the cost of quality child care beyond the capability of most users in Category Two.
The viability of services will be effected as utilisation drops and some services, particularly in the disadvantaged areas will close.

The Federal Government no longer recognises child care as a service to be provided equitably to all families. They have shown through this legislation that they are not interested in supporting the family as an important unit in society.

The legislation is to come before the Senate in the very near future and we urge you to support a motion Senator Harradine hopes to bring forward to block the section dealing with the two tiered fee relief system.

SPEECH.PARA: Yours sincerely,
Parents of the children at the
Lipscombe Child Care Centre.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —

(a)condemns the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Coulter), and the Australian Democrats generally, for seeking to dramatically increase the cost of food, clothing and shoes by stating that they want these items exempt from a goods and services tax; and

(b)calls on the Australian Democrats to read, understand and comprehend the `Fightback' package before making any other equally absurd statements that would deleteriously affect the less well-off in the community, while granting those on high incomes a windfall subsidised by the poor.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —
(a)expresses its amazement that the Federal Treasurer (Mr Kerin) has said that the Government should not adopt new policies, but rather should merely repackage what it is already doing;
(b)calls on the Treasurer to:

TAB.TAB: (i)outline in detail the policies he proposes to repackage, and to advise the Senate of the particular space we need to watch for the repackaging, and
(ii)explain why a repackaging of its existing policies would enable the Government to avoid a repeat of the disastrous effects on the Australian economy and society of their application to date; and

PARA.TAB: (c)notes that these do-nothing views of the Treasurer reflect a Government that is tired, old, divided and in urgent need of change.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —

(a)notes that the Government has already declared that it will take heed of the Hewson `Fightback' package by announcing the removal of the coal export duty, one of the seven taxes that a Hewson Government has undertaken to remove;

(b)while accepting that this is a step in the right direction, considers that it falls short of the Hewson alternative, because nothing is to be done in the way of rail freight rates and the government monopoly of rail networks; and
(c)calls on the Government to continue to reform the mining industry so it can compete internationally and lead a recovery from Australia's worst economic situation in 60 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate notes —
(a)that the tax and economic package announced by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) provides special benefits for older Australians;
(b)that there are 2.3 million Australians who are aged over 60, of which 1.4 million have pensions or part-pensions, 408 000 have service pensions and 500 000 are self-supporting;

(c)in the `Fightback' package, benefits for senior citizens will include wealth compensation up to $2500, tax-free savings on interest up to $1000 for individuals and $2000 for families, health costs reduced by zero-rating for the GST on health services, hospital queues reduced by health reforms, private health insurance rebates up to $600, pharmaceutical benefits concession cards for those with incomes up to $50 000 and cheaper petrol; and

(d)in the `Fightback' package, benefits for pensioners will include increases in aged and veterans pensions of 8 per cent, compared with a CPI effect of the GST of 4.4 per cent, and pensions increased to 28 per cent of average weekly earnings, compensation calculated on income rather than on spending and simplified pension reporting arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —

(a)condemns the poor administration of his department's Special Benefits Program by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), which has meant that a staggering 20 per cent of Job Search Allowance applicants have found their way onto special benefits in the one-week waiting period for the Job Search Allowance;
(b)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)the irony in the Minister's attempts to denigrate the Coalition's `Fightback' package, claiming incorrect costings where none exist, and when his own department's past costings have proved to be wrong to the tune of billions of dollars, and
(ii)the Minister's misuse of public funds in getting his department to cost the Coalition's social security initiatives, rather than getting his own office to perform his political dirty work; and

PARA.TAB: (c)calls on the Minister to clean up his own backyard, before he starts criticising Coalition attempts to get Australia back on the road to economic and social recovery.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate notes the support of the Real Estate Institute of Australia (REIA) for the Coalition's `Fightback' package and that the REIA endorsed the key elements of the package, including the exemption from the tax of the sale of established housing, provision of adequate compensation for home buyers for the increased cost of home purchase which would accompany the introduction of a GST, and the Coalition's proposal to reduce Government spending on the building of public housing, placing more emphasis on rental assistance for the needy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)that it is now 12 days since the launch of the Opposition's tax reform package and the Labor Party has yet to find anything on which to attack the Coalition,
(ii)the sad and pathetic attempts by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) on 2 December 1991 to find fault with the health proposals of the `Fightback' package,
(iii)that Mr Howe was forced to admit he was wrong, claiming his mistake was due to a typographical error, and
(iv)that Mr Howe's failed efforts have been compounded by his inability to provide any alternative to Australia's present health debacle; and

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on the Government to stop wasting its time trying to bring discredit on the Coalition's blueprint for Australia and instead to direct its efforts, as limited and as colourless as they might be, to more positive remedies for Australia's massive and multiple ills.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate supports the Liberal-National policies for education reform in Australian universities, including the —
(a)abolition of the centralism of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and the return of autonomy to universities;
(b)abolition of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training and its replacement with a genuinely independent Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission;
(c)extending to universities the ability to enrol additional students, the numbers currently being restricted by Government-imposed quotas;
(d)provision of an additional $245 million for university research;
(e)provision of an additional 200 post-graduate awards and the increase in their value by an extra $2000;
(f)retention of the Higher Education Contribution Scheme and the increased discount for `up-front' payment to 25 per cent, saving full-time students $225 per annum; and
(g)increase by 6 per cent in the rates of benefit for Austudy and Abstudy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —

(a)notes with concern the complacency demonstrated by the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) at his press conference on 2 December 1991, about the state of the Australian economy, as evidenced by his statements that:

TAB.TAB: (i)there is no need to get fussed about the latest balance of payments figures which show a further big deficit of $1.3 billion in October 1991,
(ii)the 6 per cent fall in manufactured exports in the September 1991 quarter is not significant, and
(iii)the Government is quite happy to stand on its record;

PARA.TAB: (b)urges the Government to recognise the need to take urgent action to address the underlying problems facing the Australian economy as a result of its eight years of policy failure; and

(c)calls on the Government to provide leadership, a vision for the future and hope for the Australian people, especially the one and a half million now unemployed or underemployed, by adopting the far-reaching `Fightback' proposals of the Liberal and National parties to rebuild and reward Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate, on behalf of the people of rural, remote and regional Australia, condemns —

(a)the Australian Democrats' proposal to reject, if they happen to be in a position to do so, the most beneficial aspect of the `Fightback' package for rural, remote and regional Australia, that is, the removal of excise from fuel; and

(b)the Australian Democrats for their posturing as a party concerned for the welfare of farmers, while at the same time proposing to oppose the removal of excise on fuel which would be of specific, real and lasting benefit to farmers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)the release of the final reports of the Ecologically Sustainable Development Working Groups,
(ii)that the nine working groups have produced extensive and detailed reports, involving hundreds of recommendations,

(iii)that the reports suggest the cost to Government of implementing these recommendations would involve some billions of dollars, including $26 million in agriculture, $55 million in forestry and $130 million in fisheries, and

(iv)that, given the parlous state of the Australian economy, many recommendations are financially impossible at the present time, but financial cost should not be examined in isolation from the many millions of dollars already lost from reduced productivity and soil degradation; and

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on the Government to examine the reports carefully and thoroughly, taking into consideration all the competing factors that contribute to the prosperity and viability of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate —
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)Australia's disastrous balance of payments deficit for October 1991, of $1.3 billion, announced on 2 December 1991, is largely the result of a further 9 per cent worsening in Australia's interest bill and other net income debits, which have risen to $5.8 billion in the first four months of the 1991-92 financial year, despite lower interest rates that should have reduced this burden, and

(ii)Australia would require years of record-breaking trade surpluses to offset this continuing interest bill disaster which has resulted from the Hawke Government's failed and discredited economic policies; and

PARA.TAB: (b)commends the Coalition's `Fightback' package for proposing a plan of action to resolve this crisis for which the Labor Government has no answers and provides no hope.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate notes the statement made by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) that his own health policy needs repackaging and his total confusion about the Coalition `Fightback' health policy.

DEBATE.TITLE: POLITICAL BROADCASTS AND POLITICAL DISCLOSURES BILL 1991

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 14 August, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I declare the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 an urgent Bill and move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be considered an urgent Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion standing in my name, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of standing order 142 be suspended as would prevent debate taking place on the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, it has happened again. The Government has shown no courtesy; it gave no advice to the Opposition of what it intended to do; and it has given no reason. Last night, the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator McMullan) came in and, with the support of the Australian Democrats, extended the period of the sitting of the Senate until 19 December. We were told that an extra week was wanted so that the legislative program could be properly dealt with. Yet this morning, the Government comes in here, no doubt with the support of the Democrats, and seeks to limit debate on what is a fundamental Bill—a Bill which is embarrassing the Government because its effect is to limit freedom of speech. Now, rather than have the Bill properly debated, rather than have the detail properly considered by the Senate, the Government comes in here and seeks to apply the guillotine, no doubt with the support of the Democrats.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, I remind you again, as I did last year, of what the Australian Democrats Whip said on 31 August 1988 when he wrote to the Parliamentary Liaison Officer to put down the position of the Democrats—the Party that came here to `keep the bastards honest'—in respect of the guillotine . At the end of the last session, Senator McLean said:

SPEECH.PARA: Packages of contentious legislation were declared urgent and debate was guillotined with our concurrence. We will not agree to such tactics again.

On 13 December last year the Democrats came in again, huddling with the Government to provide a guillotine to I think some 54 Bills, and said that special circumstances applied because Christmas was coming. Again, we had to chop debate. The Government comes in today and seeks to apply this guillotine in order that there might not be proper debate.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the circumstances. The explanatory memorandum for this Bill was delivered to honourable senators this morning, about half an hour before debate was supposed to start. That is the state of preparation of the Government in relation to this legislation. It not only expects it to be debated first thing this morning but also wants to limit the time for debate and consideration by the Senate. When were the Government's amendments put down? Late last night, 37 Government amendments, some of them incomprehensible, were put down by the Government to amend substantially its piece of legislation which it actually wanted to debate last night.

Yesterday morning at the Whips' meeting the Government said that we were going to debate the Bill all of last night if necessary until it was finished. That was before it had even given us the 37 extra Government amendments. The rumour around this place is that there are further amendments still to come. That is the way in which the Government wishes a very serious piece of legislation to be debated. Amendments which fundamentally change the nature of the Bill are dropped on us at the last minute: amendments that we should have the opportunity to consider properly and take to our party room if necessary; and amendments which affect the States, because State elections will be affected by this.

The Government is seeking not only to limit advertising for Federal elections but also to limit advertising for State and Territory elections. Is it giving the States and Territories the opportunity to look at the amendments which it put down last night—for example, the unprecedented `talking head' amendments which will be introduced for the first time? No, the States and the Territories will have to put up with that because the Government does not want to give them the opportunity to consider it.

We should be given the opportunity to consider it properly. In actual fact, the amendments and the explanatory memorandum that have been put down this morning demonstrate that the amendments should go to a Senate standing committee to be considered and dealt with properly. If it were done in the proper way, the whole Bill would be dealt with more expeditiously. But, instead of doing it properly, the Government wants to curtail debate. It comes in here and wants to apply the guillotine to ensure that proper debate does not take place. It conspires with the Democrats to ensure that proper debate on this important legislation does not take place. So we on this side of the chamber oppose, with all the vigour we can muster, this guillotine.

TALK.START.PARA: —That won't be much.

—I can do without your contribution, too, pipsqueak. We will oppose it with all the vigour we can muster because it is not in the best interests of democracy; it is unnecessary. The Bill should be debated properly and proper time should be allowed for the debate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just had the annual performance of phoney indignation by Senator Hill. As everybody knows, over there we have a whole lot of people who, if they had been on this side, would have gagged him so that he could not have even spoken on it.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Is Senator McMullan purporting to close this debate?
—I am speaking to this motion.
—So he was not attempting to close the debate the way he did yesterday?
—Order! Senator McMullan cannot close the debate. The debate for the suspension goes for 30 minutes or less.

—I have to say that yesterday I spoke only after checking that everybody had spoken, as the honourable senator knows. I then gave leave to the person who missed out by virtue of not being here. We know, on the basis of their track record, that if all the people in the Opposition were on this side of the chamber they would not have listened to that five-minute speech by Senator Hill because they would have gagged the debate as they always did. Every time they brought in guillotines they gagged the debate. Senator Walters voted for it and Senator Durack moved it. They did it every time.

PARA.TAB: Did the Opposition ever propose that we have two days to debate a Bill? No; it said, `We'll have sixteen Bills in two hours'—so we would have full and rigorous debate of 16 Bills into two hours! We are about to propose the world's most generous guillotine, because it says we will have two days to debate the Bill. Never before has there been a proposal as generous as that. On the timetable this Opposition used to apply we would have had 7 1/2 minutes.

Let us be realistic. Opposition members have to come in here and say all this because they think it is important that they make a show for the troops and shout and scream, but the fact is that two days of debate will be plenty of time for this Bill. This is the fourth or fifth time we have been around this track in this chamber. To pretend that we need to have another major debate going beyond two days is absolute humbug—and the Opposition knows it. It is an attempt to come in and whip up a bit of indignation, but from the Government's point of view it is just using up part of those two days. It is the Opposition members' two days. If this is how they choose to use their time, it is up to them. We are prepared to go along.

From 1975 to 1980 the urgency motion was gagged by the then Government, the now Opposition, every time it was moved. Apart from the fact that the coalition whacked through 16 Bills in two hours, it cannot say there is no debate, because we are giving it two days. In the Government's view, after this debate about whether we have a guillotine is concluded, assuming it is carried, the way in which the time available is used will be up to the Opposition. If it is the Opposition's desire to negate the adjournment tonight to continue the debate, we will agree to that. If it does not wish to do so, we will also agree. The sensible agreement we have reached for the MPI today to facilitate debate on this Bill is an example of how intervening business can be dealt with. That has been done in a cooperative manner.

Both Senator Lewis and Senator Harradine have made speeches in the last day or so on their concerns about the late sittings of the Parliament and the need to manage the proceedings in a manner that avoids that. This gives us the potential to do that. It is up to the Opposition, because the Government will cooperate with it in whichever way it chooses to play from here. This proposal gives us the potential to finish before 19 December. The great joke is the proposal that this legislation should now go to a committee so we can have the sixth debate about it instead of the fifth. It is all humbug and the Opposition knows it is all humbug.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not reflect, as Senator Hill has, on the marital state of anyone's parents, but nothing he has said this morning can be taken seriously. He knows full well that there have been extensive negotiations regarding the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill. The Bill was introduced in June. The matter has been referred to a committee. The Opposition had members on that committee and is fully apprised of the situation.

PARA.TAB: As Senator McMullan has said, we will have two days for one Bill. The Opposition knew this morning that this motion was about to be put, yet it has put forward an MPI today and no doubt tomorrow will put forward another MPI. Opposition members themselves are taking time out of the debate on what they, by their own definition and protestations, regard as an important Bill. The Opposition has 29 speakers on this Bill. Do Opposition members seriously say that by the time they get to the twentieth speaker they will still have something fresh to say? I very much doubt that they will. Two days for one Bill is more than enough time to fairly and exhaustively deal with every aspect of the legislation. Negotiation has gone on. Senator Hill spoke to me yesterday, and I asked the Government to put off this matter for a further day to give more time for consideration. His argument this morning is a hollow protestation and cannot be taken seriously.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of the most outrageous decisions by a government on one of the most outrageous Bills ever introduced into the Senate. As Senator Coulter said, the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill was introduced in June and the Government tried to whip it through. The only reason it did not do it, irrespective of Senator Ray's earlier objections, was that there was a leadership battle between the honourable member for Wills and the honourable member for Blaxland—Mr Hawke and Mr Keating.

PARA.TAB: When this Bill was introduced, it sought to absolutely attack the freedom of political expression and freedom of speech in this country. Both the Australian Democrats and the Government refused, first of all, to split the Bill, then they refused to refer it to a committee. I moved a notice of motion that, during the winter recess, that Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The Democrats opposed it.

One of the reasons that Senator Coulter is sitting over there is that Senator Powell was the one who made the deal with Senator Bolkus. Let me tell Senator Powell, sorry, Senator Coulter—he looks like Senator Powell, but the hair is in the wrong place—that he has made another deal. The Democrats have made another deal with the Government to attack the freedom of political expression and the freedom of speech in this country.

After that was done, we went out and advised the people of this country just what was in that Bill. No-one could imagine that a Bill would be introduced in a country such as Australia that would so outrageously attack the freedom of political expression in this country. Of course, what happened was that those people reacted. On the evidence given to our own committee, so ably led by Senator Olsen, and to me, everyone was opposed to this Bill. I think there was one exception, and that was the Australian Conservation Foundation.

Subsequently, Senator Powell decided that she would like to send it to a committee. So she wrote me a letter—the born-again Senator Powell—but only because her leadership was at stake. Who was plotting and scheming to get rid of her? It was Senator Coulter and everybody else. Stories were being spread about—by the Democrats, not by anybody else in the Senate. So she suggested that the Bill go to a committee, and the Government had no option but to send that Bill to a committee. There is no urgency for this matter—none whatsoever. There is no Federal election coming up until about March next year—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not until Keating gets in.

—Those opposite will probably have a new leader in Mr Keating, the honourable member for Blaxland. So all I can assume is that the Government and the Democrats do not want a repeat of what happened during the winter recess. What happened during the winter recess was that the public of Australia became aware of what was in the Bill. It caused the Democrats to change their leadership. It caused the Government to rethink it and to come up with some solution—to yet again make another deal with the Democrats. It made another deal with the Democrats!

—Senator Kernot should know better. She and I discussed this on radio in Brisbane and she was as embarrassed as anyone else. Now she should be more embarrassed than ever that she has been prepared to get together with the Government and guillotine a Bill which goes absolutely to the core of democracy in this country.

PARA.TAB: We were advised at only 6 o'clock last night of the amendments to this Bill—a Bill of 23 clauses with 37 amendments. It was at only 9.15 that the Minister had the courtesy to give us his explanatory memorandum. I say to honourable senators that the explanatory memorandum leaves an awful lot to be desired because all it does is to regurgitate the amendments provided by the Government without a satisfactory explanation.

Everyone in this chamber should be appalled at the actions of this Government in having come in here and guillotined a Bill which is of such profound importance and which will have such incredible repercussions on the future of this country and on the way in which we conduct our elections.

TALK.START.PARA: —The truth is, Mr President, that the Opposition loves guillotines. When we whacked 52 Bills through last year on guillotines, honourable senators opposite loved every minute of it. It put a bit of discipline in their ranks. It cut out all the extraneous, wasteful debate and made them concentrate on the main issue. Deep down, these masochists opposite love guillotines. The only reason that I resist the temptation of voting against this motion is that I do not want to deprive them of that much pleasure. They are going to love it. They will be given two days—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The last two speakers have been heard in silence.

—They will be given two days in which to debate this important Bill. I like to remind people of history, so Senator Dr Herron should get ready to put his hand up again like he did last time. We have heard honourable senators opposite troop into the chamber today and tell us they object to guillotines and that these are bad procedures. Let us go through the list of those sitting opposite who have voted for guillotines. The list is legendary. The great Senator Walters, time and time again, voted for guillotines when the Opposition had the numbers from 1975 to 1980. Senator Baden Teague voted for guillotines. Senator MacGibbon voted for guillotines. Senator Archer voted for guillotines. Time and time again, Senator Watson's name appears. Not only did they vote for guillotines; they voted to gag guillotines.

—On a point of order, Mr President: this is a very serious debate on a very specific issue. Senator Ray is rabbiting on about the concept of guillotines in general, which has nothing to do with this particular motion. It shows the bankruptcy of his approach to this issue. I invite you to direct him to confine his remarks to the motion before the Senate.
—There is no point of order.

—Of course there is no point of order. That is just a tactic to take up a bit of my debating time. The pity is that I had only a two-minute speech and Senator Alston wants to stretch it to five minutes and take time from himself.

PARA.TAB: Another couple of innocent looking characters are sitting here who thought they were not going to get hit. Senator Baume and Senator Short voted for guillotines in the House of Representatives when they were there and loved it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Never on a vital democratic issue.

—Never on a vital issue, says Senator Baume. Who is he kidding? To see whether the Opposition is serious, I ask honourable senators opposite—every one of them—by midday today to put in writing a guarantee that if they ever win government they will never move a guillotine. Who will be in it? Come on! Not one of the hypocrites is willing to do it—not one! They come in here with their moral pontificating—and I really did enjoy Senator Hill's Senator Chaney impersonation; he does it better, I will say that—but not one of them will guarantee that they will never move a guillotine.
—I will, on a vital issue like democracy. Absolutely.

—And Senator Baume will be judge and jury on what is important. He will slide out. What name will he put to it? Will it be Senator Baume or the alias from the newspapers, Steve Martin? What name will he put to that guarantee?

PARA.TAB: The thing about guillotines is that there are very fair guillotines, there are fair guillotines and there are unfair guillotines. This is in the middle process of being a fair one because it gives two days debate. We had all this over the war crimes matter when the Opposition decided it would sit the Parliament through until the end of February. We said, `Right, we will start with the weekend first off'. Then the Opposition came to a sensible agreement and it was one of the best debates ever conducted here because it had some discipline and construction. What the Opposition intends to do on this legislation is pure obstructionism, and that is why the guillotine has been moved today.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) in his defence of this position. What is clear here is that the Government does not want this matter to run on and neither do the Australian Democrats. The Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 touches on the right to freedom of speech, whether Australians have the right to be informed and whether people have a right to put a message to others. It reeks of the thought police.

PARA.TAB: With no doubt in my mind, this Government does not want to subject itself to the pressures that can build up over Christmas. Those opposite want to whack the Bill through quickly while people are thinking about Christmas. Only last week, volumes of committee reports were introduced into the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was only two and a half hours to debate them anyway.

—It is not only the people here who have a right to debate the reports—they have a right to debate them and they did so for two and a half hours—but what about the people outside who have the right to go through those reports and put a proposition to their representatives in this Parliament? Do they not have any rights? Do any of these groups, such as the National Farmers Federation, not have a right to examine committee reports? Do the constituents of Government senators, the union movement or the environmentalists not have a right to go through these reports and then come to their elected representatives and say, `We do not like this for this, this and this reason'? Those opposite are not going to allow that. They will not let those in the community have a look at this Bill.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite do not want to look at this Bill. They want to whack it through now before Christmas, when people's minds are on other things, such as holidays, getting their kids out of school and into jobs that they cannot really get because the Government has ruined the economy. People's minds are not on the Bill. The Government does not want to give anyone a chance to look at this legislation and then come back and make submissions to their representatives. It does not want people to look at what has happened in the debates in the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters.

The other reason I believe that those opposite wanted to put this Bill through quickly is that they have looked at the Fightback package and said, `We cannot attack it on television, it is too good; so we will not give the Opposition a chance to run it on television'. But if it had run the other way and the package had not been a winner, there is no doubt in my mind that the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill would not have been pulled out and used to attack the Fightback package. But now that they see that the Fightback package is a winner, they will use this Bill to attack it.

We are debating today one of the most important political issues. It touches on the right to freedom of speech and it goes against every attitude that this country has ever been brought up with and run on, which is the right for someone to put a proposition to the people through every avenue of broadcasting and television. Those opposite do not believe that we are changing the right of Australians to keep in contact with their representatives. They want to jam the debate and whack the Bill through before Christmas so that there will be no debate in the community. The results will have to be accepted as a fait accompli because the Government wants to whack the Bill through in two days.

There is no urgency in this Bill's passage. The matter should be taken out in the community and the Committee report should be debated. When Parliament resumes in two months, we can have an intelligent debate and represent the people who elect us to this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —This issue has been before this Senate and this Parliament for four years. In October 1987, Senator Robert Ray sent off a reference to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. It produced a report two years later in 1989. This is not an issue that has come up today, this year or this month; this issue has been around for four years.

PARA.TAB: Two years ago, the Joint Committee reported and recommended to the Parliament the adoption of the free time proposal that is before us here today. But it did not just end there. As I say, that Committee reported two years ago. At the start of this year, this Government put a proposal to do two things: firstly, to ensure that the process was transparent; and, secondly, to find a way of minimising the costs of campaigning. That Bill appeared before this place on 30 August this year, on which day it was sent off to yet another committee, which reported last Thursday. In its report, the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures did as good a job as the first committee.

This morning we are seeing precisely this: hypocrisy, intransigence and stubbornness. Those opposite, for all of their time in this place as an opposition, have had one thing about which they have been consistent: they have not wanted to address the issues of campaign costs and disclosure—not once. In every parliament where the Liberal Party of Australia has the majority—not only in this place but also in State parliaments—it has resisted the passage of legislation to make the process transparent, whether it has been to do with public funding, with disclosure or with minimising costs.

It is not an issue before us today. What is more, it is not a new issue in world terms. I refer those opposite to appendix 3 of this report and, more particularly, I refer the leader writers in the Age and the Sydney Morning Herald to appendix 5 which goes through international comparisons. When we look at what happens overseas and compare that with what is being proposed here, there is nothing radical about the proposal before us.
Senator Parer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Parer bleats about the amendments. Of the 37 amendments, 20 have been before this place since 13 August. The amendments were delivered to him yesterday afternoon and the explanatory memorandum this morning. The basic thing about this issue is that the concepts have been before us for a long time.

PARA.TAB: Let me just close on one point because I believe the time allocated to me to speak is running out. We have had bleatings about human rights from the Opposition. I will not go through recent history. What about the Opposition's promise in its `Fright' package? What is its promise? It is to cut back on legal aid for those who need it. What would happen to the civil rights of those people if the Opposition chopped the funding for the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, the organisation that the Opposition has supported so strongly in the past few months despite its having opposed entrenching the underpinning legislation for it. I understand that. What is the Opposition's commitment to civil rights when it cuts back the rights of those who cannot afford lawyers, when it cuts back funding to the Human Rights Commission and when it also wants to close the Office of International Law in the Attorney-General's Department and move it to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade?

Under the Opposition's proposals announced two weeks ago, the two areas in this country which do have some role in entrenching civil liberties in our system, the international law office and HREOC, will be cut back. The Opposition's commitment is shallow. It is hypocritical. All those opposite are on about is stubborn resistance and filibustering. Mr President, I believe my time is up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I am quite sure that the allocated time of half an hour for the debate has elapsed.
—I am in charge of that, and time has not elapsed.
—It started at 10.18 a.m.
—I have just checked with the Clerk, and the time ends at 10.48 a.m. There are 15 seconds left.

—I would like to give an assurance to the Senate's version of Kim Beazley, Senator Robert Ray—all he needs is a squeaky voice and a giggle—on a democratic matter of vital concern to Australian people. I would never support the sort of gag that the Government is moving on a Bill relating to the democratic rights of Australians, a Bill that relates to the very process that we are here to defend and that the Government is here to destroy. Government senators are here not to defend the Senate; they are determined to wipe out the Senate anyway. It is part of their policy.

PARA.TAB: Government senators are here to destroy the basic principles of freedom of speech, aided by the people who call themselves Democrats. What a corruption of the name `Democrat'! What a corruption! What a bunch of frauds! I will give this assurance, because the Government and the Australian Democrats will not. They will not do anything basically in principle because they do not understand the difference between guillotining ordinary Bills and guillotining a Bill that affects the democratic process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Time for the debate has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question now is that the motion moved by Senator McMullan that the Bill be considered an urgent Bill be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question put.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the time allotted for consideration of the remaining stages of the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 be till 7.30 p.m. on Wednesday 4 December 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: Everybody knows, whatever indignation they may have feigned during this discussion, that this is the world's most generous guillotine—two days. Given the amount of time available, it is very hard to see that the Australian public is going to think that for the fourth or fifth time—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I do not want to interrupt Senator McMullan, but in order that he can have adequate time to debate this important motion, I would move: That so much of standing order 142 be suspended as would prevent the motion being debated without limitation of time and each senator speaking for the time allotted by Standing Orders.
—Order! Senator Hill, you cannot move that while Senator McMullan is in the middle of his speech. You can move it when he resumes his seat.

—I am happy to say that I am sure there is half an hour of virtuous contribution I could make on this matter but I do not need it and I do not intend to do it. It would be very hard to persuade the Australian people that, on the fourth time the Senate debates this Bill, a two-day debate is not sufficient time. This Bill and its ramifications have been debated in this chamber, in the House of Representatives, in State parliaments and in public. It was introduced into the Senate in March of this year, almost nine months ago. It has been a very long gestation. I do not believe that anybody could think that debate is being inappropriately foreshortened.

PARA.TAB: This motion has as its characteristic, as Senator Ray said, the capacity to enable an organised, balanced debate rather than one which allows for what I think some people may acknowledge happens from time to time with Opposition senators—tedious repetition. It is true that if members of the Opposition so choose, they may still be able to have 27 speakers on the second reading debate; the time is available for that. That would then foreshorten the time they had available for the committee stage, but that is their concern.

We will not in any way impede their right to negate the adjournment and facilitate an extended second reading debate if that is what they choose. If they wish to shorten the second reading stage and give lengthy attention to individual clauses and use all the time on any one clause, that is a matter that is open to them and with which we will cooperate. All we are doing is saying that tedious repetition is not going to be allowed to endlessly defer the Bill and blow out the whole of the legislative program. Consistent with sensible management, we are going to press on to get this Bill dealt with within two days of debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have it examined by the committee, you nitwit.
—It has been examined by more committees than anything that has been before this Parliament in the time that I have been here or, I suspect, in the time Senator Archer has been here.

PARA.TAB: One issue which usually comes up in debate about whether we need a guillotine is whether we allow proper and due consideration of the legislation. That is a criterion that Senator Hill has set down in the past. It seems to me to be one that bears consideration here. It beggars description to say that two days of debate is not proper and due consideration of a Bill that is not being introduced for the first time and the concepts of which are very well known, have been very well debated and extensively considered. Legislation often comes into this Parliament with amendments being considered in the chamber. It happens to be what the Committee of the Whole stage is all about. The Senate has operated, until the last couple of years when we have had this committee stage, in that form for 80-odd years.

The Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters considered this Bill four years ago. The recommendations from that Committee were considered by the Government. Legislation from the House of Representative was introduced into this place in March. We had debates in the intervening period; we had public debate at that stage. We debated it for a couple of days in August. We then had another extensive committee stage, at which all members of the public had the opportunity—many of them took it—to make their representations. All of the parties and individuals represented in the Senate had an opportunity to participate in the debate of the consideration of the report. We then had an unprecedented situation in which we facilitated a 2 1/2-hour debate on the presentation of that report. There was some criticism along the lines that we should not have allowed that to happen. I believe that it was a generous consideration. It meant that all of the new issues were adequately aired on that occasion.

We now have an opportunity to debate this Bill for two days. Members of the Opposition will be able to express their view; Government members will be able to express their view; and the Independents and the Australian Democrats will also be able to express their views. How we deal with this debate from now on is essentially in the hands of the Opposition. The number of hours and the way the time is allocated is a matter on which the Government will cooperate with the Opposition. Moving the motion to allow debate until 7.30 tomorrow evening is far from being an unreasonable restriction of debate. The only criticism that people might have is that we are giving too much time. I have moved the motion confident in the fact that it is both reasonable and necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of standing order 142 be suspended as would prevent the motion being debated without limitation of time and each Senator speaking for the time allotted by Standing Orders.

SPEECH.PARA: It is ironic that the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 before the chamber concerns freedom of speech. The Bill is an attempt by the Government to limit freedom of speech in election campaigns, to curtail political parties and individuals from promoting their case before the Australian people. That is what the Bill is all about; that is what the Government wants to do. The Government wants to introduce constraints of this nature which would prohibit parties and individuals from promoting their case through the electronic media. This is not a matter that should go by without full and detailed debate. The Bill fundamentally concerns freedom of speech. It is being condemned by the independent bodies in this country that have the charter to protect such rights.

PARA.TAB: What is the Government seeking to do today? It is seeking to limit debate on whether the Bill to impose such further restraints should be carried. It is a double negative: the Government is seeking to limit the freedom of speech of this chamber to debate a piece of legislation which is designed to limit freedom of speech at election time. The Government should be condemned for that. Why does the Government want to limit freedom of speech in this way? We know. It is because it is broke. The Government no longer has the money to pay for advertising. Instead of coming clean on that failure and recognising it, the Government wants to impose a restraint on all Australians, both in the Territories and the States. In all elections—whether they be Commonwealth, State or Territory—there will no longer be the option of taking out paid electronic advertising. The ALP has been unable to handle its financial affairs properly and can no longer afford to pay for its advertising.

We have seen this demonstrated in the last few days by the New South Wales branch of the Labor Party. It is now some $7m in the red as a result of the incompetent financial planning of the Federal President of the ALP, Senator Stephen Loosley, who was at the time the Secretary of the New South Wales branch. So, instead of coming clean and recognising that the ALP cannot pay for its own advertising, it wants to prohibit all Australians from being able to advertise their particular arguments during an election campaign. It is not surprising, therefore, that we are upset by that. Never before has a government sought to do that to the Australian people—and we will fight it and continue to fight it.

We heard a moment ago from the Australian Democrats. It was they who said, `We will never be overridden by the Government; we have come into this chamber to ensure fair play'. As I have read to honourable senators, Senator McLean said, `We will never allow the gag; we will not allow it because this is the chamber for debate'. We all know there is no debate at the other end of the building. That is a chamber of the numbers where debate does not take place. But on important issues, fundamental issues, issues concerning freedom of speech, there is one chamber in which the Australian people can be confident that a piece of legislation will be dealt with properly—and that is this one.

The Australian Democrats say that they will ensure proper debate. But when it comes to the test, as it did last year, they are found wanting. But it is not only last year. What happened in 1983? The Sex Discrimination Bill was declared an urgent Bill by Senator Grimes; the motion was supported by the Democrats. In October 1984, Senator Button declared 14 Bills to be urgent; the motion was supported by the Democrats. In May 1987, Senator Gareth Evans declared 25 Bills as urgent; the motion was supported by the Democrats. On 24 March 1988, the Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill was declared urgent by Senator Evans; the motion was supported by the Democrats. In June 1988, Senator Evans declared 36 Bills urgent; the motion was supported by the Democrats. Last year—the one that Senator Ray boasts about because it is the largest number of Bills declared urgent in one motion in the history of this Parliament—Senator Ray declared 52 Bills to be urgent; the motion was supported by the Democrats. And that is keeping the bastards honest!

It is appalling that, when they are put to the test, time and time again the Australian Democrats will not be there when the pressure is applied; they will not be there to meet the assurance that they give at each election. They say, `Take no notice of big parties; we'll keep them honest'—and they do not. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is passing strange that a group of people who are so concerned that there is not enough time left by this motion to have adequate debate on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill keeps proposing things that are going to take up part of that time. Another half an hour of the time that could have been used debating the Bill has been diverted to an argument on procedural trivia, which we are prepared to respond to for as long as honourable senators opposite keep putting it up. But we do not believe that this is the appropriate way to do things.
—We have no right to protest at your disgraceful behaviour!

—Honourable senators have the right to do that. They can keep doing it all day; I am simply saying that it is their time they are wasting. The Senate has considered previously whether the procedures set down in standing order 142 are adequate for the consideration of a motion such as this and determined that it is. That standing order sets down quite explicitly—it is not provided for by some guillotined or gagged motion proposed by this Government—the procedure which has been essentially operating in the Senate for a very long time concerning how we should debate motions such as this. The standing order now known as 142(3) says:

SPEECH.PARA: On such further motion or motions with regard to the allotment of time, debate shall not exceed one hour, and in speaking, a Senator shall not exceed 10 minutes. . .

That is of the same genesis as the motion which says that we should have a half-hour limit on debate on motions of this ilk concerning the suspension of Standing Orders, with five minutes per speaker. So, just to remind honourable senators opposite, we are actually debating a motion that we should suspend so much of standing order 142 as would allow people to debate the timetable for the Bill, taking half an hour each. What a joke! Honourable senators opposite would move this only if they were absolutely confident it would not be carried, because they know it is absurd. We could take the rest of the day talking about whether or not we should talk about the Bill and what the timetable for it should be. It is a joke and a farce—and honourable senators opposite know it.

PARA.TAB: At some stage those opposite will start saying that the time that has been made available for this debate is not sufficient. Well, can I say that we could have been well into the debate by now. It is quarter past eleven; we could have been debating this matter for an hour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, so long as we go along and don't protest.

—Senator Walters is welcome to protest. It is her right to do so. I am just saying that it is not a very intelligent use of her rights. But she has a civil right to be stupid and she exercises it often.

PARA.TAB: The situation is that we now have people opposite who pretend to be concerned about rights. Their attitude is based on the essential protection of two rights: the right to make secret donations at elections; and the right, if one has a lot of money, to try to buy an election. Those are the two rights that those opposite are setting out to protect, and it has always been so.

The people who represent those with particular advantage and those with particular extra opportunity are those who always say that we should have freedom to buy as much speech as we wish, and those who do not have any money can exercise their right not to buy any. What we have here is a debate about the right of the privileged to continue to abuse their privilege. Most democratic countries have come to a recognition that, in some way or other, they have to regulate the use and abuse of that privilege. There is a need to regulate the use and abuse of the privilege to make brown paper bag donations; the use and abuse of a right to slide money under the table and buy influence, whatever party it is for which that influence is being bought—and I was stunned that a representative of the Queensland National Party would have the temerity to raise this matter; and the right then to be able to use ones particular political and financial advantage to buy electoral advantage. It is the right of the privileged to be able to use and misuse the privilege that is being defended so strenuously on the other side of the chamber. We will not facilitate an extended debate of this sort. It is a waste of time and a piece of humbug. Let us get on with the debate on the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McMullan has just made one of the most hypocritical contributions to this chamber that I have heard since I have been here. It was the ALP that bought more electronic media advertising time and had a greater increase of expenditure on electronic advertising than any other political party in the last Federal election. Senator McMullan talked about buying votes, buying elections and manipulating the electorate. But it was the ALP, in percentage terms, that increased its expenditure in the electronic media more than any other political party. The coalition parties almost maintained their status quo. This was not the case with the ALP which was responsible for a very substantial increase in expenditure. So I say to Senator McMullan: do not come in here with this nonsense about expenditure when we know his Party's track record, when it has debts of some $7m in New South Wales that have been exposed in the past few days.

PARA.TAB: It is fairly clear why the Labor Party wants this Bill to go through this place in a matter of days. State elections and a Federal election are coming up and it is broke in a number of States and federally. The business community has walked away from the Labor Party because the Government's policies have bankrupted this country and businesses, and have created one million unemployed in this country. The business community is not contributing to the Labor Party any more. As a result, Labor will have no money to buy advertisements come the next State and Federal elections.

So what will those in the Labor Party do? They want to put the clampers down so that nobody else can go out and communicate a message to the electorate, so that no-one else can go out and communicate a policy and a direction that contrasts with what is being done by the Australian Labor Party. That is what this legislation is about.

The Australian Democrats have walked away from maintenance of the principle of free speech. The Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Brian Burdekin, will be fairly interested to see the contribution of the Australian Democrats over the next day or two.

Senator Bolkus said, `This matter has been around for four years'. Well, if it has been around for four years, he has demonstrated his total incompetence as a Minister. He still does not have the legislation right, despite the fact that it has been around for four years. As a result of the recommendations of the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures, he comes in here with 37 amendments. These 37 amendments were given to us late last night and the explanatory memorandum was given to us this morning. Notwithstanding that, Senator Bolkus now wants to push this legislation through all stages in the next 36 hours. Contrast that with the sales tax legislation that is before us. Although this legislation was part of the March industry statement, it is still not through this House. It is important legislation because it gives half a break to the business community that needs a break to get up and start employing people again. But it has been put to one side because the Government wants to guillotine this Bill through.

Let us not forget that this legislation was introduced in the House of Representatives on the night of the Hawke-Keating leadership tussle, when the media was totally preoccupied with that. So this legislation was submerged and pushed under the carpet. It was the Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Brian Burdekin, the Law Council of Australia and the Australian Electoral Commission which blew the whistle on the legislation. Let us not forget that in the House of Representatives that night the Government gutted the Bill with its own amendment. It introduced the legislation and then it introduced an amendment to it which, in effect, said that it would, by regulation, set the amount that had to be disclosed and set, by regulation, those organisations in the community which would be exempt from this legislation. So the Government in fact gutted the legislation the night it was introduced in the House of Representatives.

The legislation then came to the Senate and, as a result of the pressure from the Human Rights Commissioner, the Law Council and the Australian Electoral Commission and as a result of the Australian Democrats leadership tussle, it was referred to the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures. There were no other reasons. Because of the Australian Democrats' leadership tussle, the Government had no idea what was going to happen with the amendments. It had no idea what the Democrats were going to do. So in order to buy time and allow the Democrats to sort out their leadership tussle, the legislation went off to the Select Committee.

It has come back from that Select Committee with 37 amendments. The principle and direction of the Bill are opposite to what they were when it was introduced. Minister Beazley and Minister Ray have put on the record in the last few weeks and months the fact that they are opposed to free time. This Bill is proposing free time. It is a totally different concept to that introduced back in May. Between now and 7.30 tomorrow night, the Government wants us to shanghai this legislation through the Parliament; to push it through so there cannot be community debate. The reason it does not want community debate is that it knows what the reaction of the community will be. Those opposite will be shown up for what they are—hypocrites. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a couple of points about the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991. The transparent disingenuousness of both Senator Olsen and Senator Hill in the points that they have made was really quite staggering in the extreme. Senator Hill spoke initially about freedom of speech and then went on to point out how the exercise of that freedom of speech had run up enormous debts for political parties, clearly indicating that freedom of speech can be bought only by those who have enough money to buy it. That is a very important principle.

PARA.TAB: One need not be surprised at the Opposition putting forward those arguments when one has seen its GST package—or `Frightpack' as it is called—which is designed to encourage its rich mates who, if this Bill is not passed, will have plenty of money to buy political advertising at the next election in a non-disclosure situation. So the argument about freedom of speech, who can exercise that and the costs involved is of course an absolute nonsense.

As Senator McMullan has pointed out, the substantive motion before us is to give a very generous amount of time for debate on this issue, which has been around for a long time. What the Opposition is doing this morning is simply using up some of that time. We are prepared to sit all night and to support any negation of the adjournment to give time for this legislation to be debated. As I said earlier, I do not believe that by the time we get to the twentieth or twenty-fifth Opposition speaker any new information will be coming into this debate whatsoever. There is more than enough time for this debate.

Moreover, last Thursday when the report of the Select Committee came before the Senate, the Government—unwisely, I thought—allowed the Opposition two hours in which to continue to filibuster on that report. Those opposite have already put on the record a substantial part of their argument in relation to this package. Quite clearly, by their actions both last Thursday and today, their intention is simply to filibuster. I support fully what the Government has said: between now and 7.30 tomorrow night is plenty of time in which to debate adequately all the aspects of this Bill.

I remind Opposition members that when the package of fisheries Bills, having been referred to a committee, came before the Senate with 80 amendments—on which I would have preferred a lot more debating time—they were the ones who sided with the Government and pushed the Bills through.
Senator Boswell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am absolutely staggered that every fisher in Australia is going down the gurgler and here we say that that is not an important issue. There are two days in which to debate this Bill, and that is more than enough time. I am staggered that the Opposition should continue with these delaying tactics.

—I would like to look at the history of this Government, particularly for the children and other people in the gallery. They will remember the Bill of Rights that the Government tried to get through until the people out there took great exception to it. They held public meetings and demonstrated to the extent that the Government backed off. Then what did it try? It tried the Australia card—the ID card. We all remember what occurred over the ID card. Once again, because the Government had the numbers, the people of Australia rose in righteous indignation and held public meetings until, finally, the Government backed off on the ID card.

PARA.TAB: On this occasion the Government is trying to gag the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill so that the people cannot respond. As has rightly been said, we sent the original Bill, which is totally different to the present one, off to a committee so that evidence could be taken. It has come back and 37 new amendments were brought in by the Government last night. We cannot possibly get across to the people of Australia what those 37 amendments encompass, but we do know that if this legislation goes through, the Government will succeed in stopping freedom of speech. In the run-up to an election this Bill will prohibit the Opposition getting across to the community what it wants for the people of Australia. That is exactly what the Government is opposing.

Senator McMullan says that we are wasting time now because we are staging our protest. I wonder whether the people in the gallery understand that it is not just the run-up to a Federal election that the Government is trying to stop; it is the run-up to every State election and also to local government elections. Local government members will not be entitled to go on television or radio and say—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I have to admit that I am not a great stickler for the procedures of the Senate, but I reckon it is a bit rugged for Senator Walters to be speaking to the gallery and turning her back to the Chair. I ask her to address her remarks through the Chair as we are always called upon to do.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, you can see from that phoney point of order that Senator Schacht is terrified of what the gallery will get out of this debate. We are at least attempting to get to some of the people of Australia, and he says, `Don't let her tell the people of Australia, make her tell you, Mr Acting Deputy President. The people in the gallery have no right to be addressed'. I tell Senator Schacht that the democracy of this country insists upon the people in the gallery being entitled to be addressed for them to understand what the Government is trying to do to them. There is no doubt at all that the Human Rights Commissioner—Brian Burdekin—the Law Council and a whole lot of people have said, `You are trying to suppress freedom of speech in this country'.

PARA.TAB: But the Government does not care. It is still going ahead and pushing the Bill through, with the support of the Democrats. The only way the Government will get it through is with the support of the Democrats. The Democrats have given up their complete democracy and taken up the Labor type of democracy that we have had in this place. We know the sort of democracy you have in your party room. You have a secret ballot, but it is a show and tell secret ballot.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I would appreciate it if Senator Walters would address the Chair more often.

—Government members have a secret ballot to say who they want as their Prime Minister and then they are forced by their factions to show it to their neighbour. That is the sort of democracy that this Government likes and that is the sort of democracy those opposite are trying to push on the Australian public. (Time expired)

—I have listened to this debate. The issue is the time that should be allowed for the debate on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991. If there were no limitations on debate in this House, many things that are said may be said much more sensibly and made more understandable. But we have time limitations in this House to which nobody has objected. There are time limitations on speeches. There are time limitations on debate itself.

PARA.TAB: Looking at the Standing Orders under which we regulate our affairs, we see standing order 142, `Limitation of debate on bills', and standing order 189, `Time limits on speeches'. The whole issue is not whether there ought to be a limitation on speeches or a limitation on time generally but what is a reasonable time to allow in any particular circumstance. That seems to have not really been addressed in this chamber today.

I have not heard from anybody who objects to a time limit of 36 hours, or whatever it is, as the proper time limit for debate on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill. Should it be limitless? Do we say it should go forever? In that case, that proposition should be put. But if one is going to say that, one should say why one needs all that time to debate this issue, especially when there are other issues to be looked at. If the argument has been made out, if what is sought is a reasonable request, if on all the evidence it is reasonable that the debate should go on in the way the Opposition proposes, then it ought to be looked at. Unless those propositions are put forward so that the debate moves to where it should be—that is, what is a reasonable time to which to limit the debate—we will achieve nothing. But simply to say that a limitation of debate is per se wrong is not a convincing argument, given the fact that the Standing Orders themselves contemplate that there will limitations as to time.

The real issue is: how much time is it reasonable to give to this debate? There is no doubt that it is an important issue. But it is an issue that seems not to have been addressed. Senator Coulter has been taken to task, but it seems to me that he is being very reasonable. He is not trying to curtail free speech. He is saying, `I have looked at this. A reasonable time, in my opinion, is until 7.30 tomorrow night'. That is what Senator Coulter is saying and nobody has met his argument. Nobody has got up and said, `No, you are wrong there, the time limit ought to be another 12 hours, another three hours or another three days'. It is no good to get up and simply pour scorn on him for putting forward a concept which we ourselves put forward in the Standing Orders—the concept of time limitations on debate. He simply extends that concept and he has been taken to task for doing that without somebody putting a contrary argument to show that his assessment of a reasonable time limit is wrong. That is what the debate should be getting around to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) in his motion. We are debating one of the most fundamental privileges and principles that Australia has, and that is freedom of speech. In this Bill we are losing the ability to enunciate policy and direction for the Australian people.

PARA.TAB: Senator Walters addressed the gallery, but many people will not be able to afford to come down here, sit in the gallery, and follow the debate of the Senate and the Parliament. Those people are not able, through circumstances and time or because they do not live in Canberra, to address their rights through radio and television. They deserve to be told what the two parties on this side of the House stand for, what their vision is for Australia and the direction in which they want to take Australia. These two parties want to be able to enunciate what they have in mind for the Australian people. We are asked to forgo all that in the debate on this Bill.
