Although I object strongly to the two days that we have for the debate, I object even more strongly to the indecent haste with which this Bill is being put before the Senate. The report of the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures came down only last week, and 36 amendments have come in here—

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirty-seven.

—I am corrected—37 amendments have come in here. When will the Law Society and conservation groups have the time and the capacity to understand what the legislation really means for them? The point is that they have not got the time. This Government wants to cut this debate off at the pass. It knows the heat that can build up on this.(Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question now is that the time allotted for consideration of the remaining stages of the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 be till 7.30 p.m. on Wednesday, 4 December 1991.

—In having to use tactics to get proper debate on this issue, the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats together have been shown up for precisely what they are: one is a party with no money; the other is a party which is unable to get any, simply because it does not enjoy support of the people. What we are seeing here is a liaison between a party which has no money and a party which cannot get any money because it has no support. What we had early on in the piece was the statement that a party that cannot govern itself cannot govern the country. Equally, it is true to say that a party that cannot handle its own finances cannot handle the nation's finances. We have seen the Labor Party put itself into debt and into bankruptcy. If a party cannot govern itself, it cannot govern the country; and if a party cannot govern its finances, it cannot govern the country's finances. What we have seen—
—You should have been on the Committee.

—We have a comment from Lurch over there. What we have seen is a conspiracy hatched in this place to get rid of freedom of speech. Today we are debating the guillotine. The guillotine is a pretty permanent sort of mechanism. It ends forever the right of freedom of speech in this nation. Is that the intention of this Government? However, the coalition parties have given an undertaking that when elected, we will repeal the legislation—if it is successful in being passed. So it will be a temporary piece of legislation.

PARA.TAB: Nonetheless, it is important to have on the record now the fact that we are utterly opposed and will remain utterly opposed to the banning of the freedom of speech. Not only does the Government want to stop every Australian having the right to have their voice heard by other Australians; it also wants to ban the right to speak in this chamber. Senator McMullan has actually said that the debate going on here is tedious. It certainly is tedious; we are getting very tired of hearing the Labor Party and the Democrats put the proposition that somehow a nation is well served by stopping its citizens being heard.

We heard a speech from Senator Coulter supporting, yet again, another guillotine—as the Democrats have done consistently through this Government's term of office. We have heard Senator Coulter say that, really, we will not have anything fresh to say—as if every senator, who is individually elected, is not entitled to have his words heard and his point of view put on the record. How outrageous it is. He, representing less than 4 per cent of the population, perhaps ought to have 4 per cent of the time. Yet he is in a position to stop the majority numbers in this place—that is, the coalition members—from each being able to have their point of view put on the record.

Quite clearly, a government which is both bankrupt financially and morally would have no qualms at all in preventing individual Australians from exercising their right to speak. Is it not interesting that the Government has determined that this is the most important Bill that it has presently before the Senate? Is it not interesting, as one of my colleagues pointed out, that the only reason it was referred to a committee, which spent two months investigating the matter, was that the Democrats were having a leadership stoush, and the Labor Party was unable to fix up a deal.

The Committee needed two months to let the Democrats sort out their leadership problems so they could stitch up a fresh deal. That is what we are seeing today. The fact that the guillotine is moved and is supported by the Democrats is, of its own, evidence that the deal has been stitched up. We have had two months of hearings; we have seen the damning evidence of Mr Sherry, who almost had to be given protection so that he was not lynched; and we have seen the spectacle of 37 amendments coming in last evening at nine o'clock—amendments which totally changed the nature of the Bill from when it was first presented in this place. They are 37 amendments which people have to analyse in terms of the report of the Committee of the Whole.

Yet we are told that we are supposed to get rid of the matter in 36 hours. This denies people's rights to voice their views and, indeed, their rights to have time to look upon those amendments as they have been moved. It does not allow people to see and point out to the rest of the Australian people the duplicity and the hypocrisy that is being worked by this Government, which is, as I said, both financially and morally bankrupt.

We are looking at a permanent ending of the right to speech, the right to have one's view put and the right to broadcast it. There is not much point in having the right to speak freely if one is not able to have it published. Television and radio represent the right of publishing what one says. In this Parliament we now televise our proceedings. My goodness me, what angst we had to go through in order to let these proceedings be televised.

This Opposition and coalition is asking that the 37 amendments be referred to a committee to be properly analysed so that there can be proper debate. The 37 amendments came after the Committee reported. The 37 amendments are new; they came in at nine o'clock last night. They need to be looked at.

TALK.START.PARA: —We went through that.
—Senator Schacht should go and put a tie on. We are told that we are somehow meant simply to accept the 37 amendments on face value without a proper examination of what they say. Freedom of speech—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! Senator Schacht and Senator Bishop's colleague Senator Kemp will have an opportunity to speak later; in due deference to her, they should allow her to continue without interjecting.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for the remarks of my colleague Senator Kemp. The colleagues of Senator Schacht are always lacking in substance, so I am pleased that you called him to order, Mr Acting Deputy President. The point is that we are debating the bringing down of the guillotine. It is like hanging; it is meant to be permanent. It is meant to cut off the right to put one's point of view; it is meant to deny individuals in the Opposition the right to have their view recorded; it is meant, in the end, to curtail the speech of ordinary Australians and somehow to advantage the bankrupt Labor Party, which is now unable to gain more funds, and the Democrats, who represent only 4 per cent of the Australian people, and who are unable to get funds. It is an awful conspiracy that we are seeing here today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by Senator McMullan. I emphasise the point that this debate has been going on in public in Australia since 1987 when this issue was first referred to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. There was a report in 1989. There was legislation introduced in May and June of this year which went to a select committee; the report has come back. The matter has now been going for at least four years. I do not know what more public debate one can get in a four-year period.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! I ask Senator Crowley to resume her seat. She was standing between Senator Schacht and the Chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am tall enough to go over the top of her, I think, Mr Acting Deputy President. I may not have many qualities, but I am the tallest senator.

PARA.TAB: I want to emphasise that this issue has been the subject of a public debate since the late 1980s. For four years or more it has been up and down and around. All sorts of propositions and arguments have been put. It is absolute hogwash to say that there will have been no opportunity for the community to express its views and the Senate will have had only two full days to discuss the Bill if the guillotine motion, by which the Senate has to complete the debate by 7.30 tomorrow night, is passed. The community has expressed its view in all its forms on and off for nearly four years.

As Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures for the last two months, I know that we had 120 submissions on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill. Everybody in the community had the opportunity to put a view forward. The Liberal Party went around doing everything possible to manufacture submissions. In the rural areas of Victoria, every local government organisation, under Liberal influence, put in one-page submissions. They were all basically the same; they had one paragraph consisting of one sentence which stated, `We oppose the Bill'.

We had plenty of public hearings. One of my colleagues, Senator Faulkner, even criticised me for allowing far too wide a questioning and a range of witnesses way outside the references for the Bill given to the Committee by the Senate. There was every opportunity for public debate on the ad ban and disclosure Bill. I am now astonished to hear some honourable senators opposite complaining that they have not had a chance.

I recognise that Senator Bishop is very disappointed that Senator Kemp and Senator Olsen beat her in the Liberal Party room ballot to go on that Committee. I have to say to Senator Bishop that just maybe this is one time her colleagues were wrong. They may have been better off putting her on the Committee because Senator Olsen and Senator Kemp—particularly Senator Kemp—were absolute duds. The only thing that Senator Kemp could do throughout the whole two-month period was ask incessant questions about trade union donations to the Labor Party. That subject was not really in the terms of reference, but he went on and on and he missed the main game. It was as though he had been picked to play on the wing in a football grand final at the MCG and instead turned up to play cricket at the Richmond ground. That was the level of his irrelevancy to the Committee. As a result, the cross-examination from people like Senator Kemp of the witnesses, many of them the Opposition's own witnesses, was very deficient. It did not bring out the evidence that the Opposition wanted. Now the Opposition complains that the majority report has been rigged on the evidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was rigged on the evidence.
—Senator Kernot said that.

—She said on a couple of points that she thought more emphasis was needed. But after two months of effort the two geniuses put up by the Liberal Party, Senator Kemp and Senator Olsen, could not bring down a minority report with one recommendation in it. They could not put one recommendation forward. That is how good they are. In my view, the Liberal Party room should never again select either Senator Kemp or Senator Olsen to serve on any select committee because they cannot do the job. They cannot make one recommendation. It is in the document; honourable senators should read the minority report. There is not one recommendation. All it does is oppose the majority report by tipping a heap of bile over it. There is no positive response anywhere. That is why they failed. That is why they are now trying to say that the process of debate is being restricted. They had two months and they failed. Duds, duds and duds again.
—Oh, Chris.

—Senator Kemp stands there and hits himself in the chin. His performance for two months did exactly that. What it proves is that even when he hits himself he has a glass chin. We have heard some of the speakers in the debate this morning going on about—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I have a point of order. On the question of relevance, what we are debating here is the guillotining of the Bill and the 37 amendments which came in at 9 o'clock last night, not the report which came in some weeks previous. What we want now is to hear reasons from Senator Schacht as to why he defends the legislation and why it is urgent, not an appraisal of a debate we have already had. I ask you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to ask him to be relevant.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—The debate should be relevant to the topic. Speakers on both sides have tended to wander. I take note.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the nature of the motion before us, but matters have been raised pretty extensively on the general issues involved in this Bill. In the debate so far great mention has been made of the fact that the Bill is an attack on free speech. The Opposition has made that point in the debate on this motion in the last half hour. I want to draw to the attention of people such as Senator Bishop, who describes herself as an acolyte of Mrs Thatcher and sees Mrs Thatcher as a role model for her own career in politics, that in the back of the report—and it has not been denied by anybody—is an appendix showing what other Western democracies do as far as advertising bans are concerned. This international comparison should be quite instructive for people such as Senator Bishop. In relation to the United Kingdom, page 113 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Summary:
. . . political advertising on the electronic media is banned by the Independent Broadcasting Authority under the Advertising Rules. . .

Senator Bishop's great hero Mrs Thatcher, in her 11 years as Prime Minister, never made one move to remove that complete ban on television and radio advertising. Canada, which some may say is a country comparable to ours, has a system in which all advertising is banned on television and radio from the day an election is called. France has regulations brought in by President de Gaulle, another person on the Right with whom Senator Bishop may find some comfort. There is no provision for paid political advertisements on French state radio and television stations. Norway and Sweden have complete bans; in Denmark, Austria and Israel, political advertisements are prohibited only at election time.

PARA.TAB: The evidence shows that not all but a substantial majority of countries in the OECD—the group of countries we describe ourselves as being part of, the Western democracies—have banned paid political advertising during election periods. That is what the report recommended. It is what is in the legislation and what the Opposition denied. If the Opposition thinks free speech—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind Senator Schacht that we are not debating the report; we are debating the motion moved by Senator McMullan, and I ask him to return to that debate.

—This comes to the very point of the motion, which is to allow two days of debate on this issue. We have been accused of restricting free speech. We have until 7.30 p.m. tomorrow to have the final part of this debate, which has been going for four years. It is a debate which has been undertaken in other countries without any query and has been accepted. It is extraordinary that honourable senators opposite think they cannot get their views expressed in the next day and a half. They have had four years. What we are really seeing now is angst because they are losing the debate. They have not won it after four years and now they are trying a delaying tactic as a last gasp effort; it will not succeed.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! Before I call Senator O'Chee, I remind honourable senators on both sides of the chamber that the motion we are debating is a motion moved by Senator McMullan relating to the time allotted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion that Senator McMullan moved in this chamber today is a motion to limit the opportunity of this chamber of review to debate not only the Bill which is before us, the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991, but also the 37 amendments which this Government produced last night. Interestingly enough, they were 37 amendments that this Government could not even introduce in time for the supposed 8 o'clock start last night of the debate of this Bill. This Government was so incompetent, so useless and so disorganised—or perhaps so distracted by its disgusting political bedfellows, the Australian Democrats—that it could not get its amendments into this chamber by 8 o'clock last night. What did it do? It brought them in here today and said, `Right, we are going to guillotine this debate at 7.30 tomorrow evening'.

PARA.TAB: Senator McMullan has the gall and the hypocrisy to stand up before this chamber and say that this is one of the most generous guillotines ever. It is like the axeman saying, `Look, I am particularly nice because I sharpened the blade on my axe'. That is what the Government and the Democrats are doing. It does not matter whether it is a sharp blade or a blunt blade; what they are doing is cutting off the debate in this chamber and cutting off the opportunity of the people's elected representatives to discuss this critical issue.

Of course, Senator Schacht told the Senate that this debate has been going on for four years and there is no need for any more. Quite the contrary: if the debate has been going on for four years, why is this Bill now urgent? The reason this Bill is now urgent is the Labor Party's urgent lack of cash, the Democrats' urgent lack of support and the urgent lack of principle of these parties which together are going to try to guillotine this debate through the Senate. That is what is urgent.

But what is really urgent is the need for an opportunity for the Australian people to discuss these amendments. Contrary to what Senator Schacht would have this chamber believe, many of the amendments brought forward do not even follow his own report. The people of Australia have the right to debate the matter. It is very interesting that last week we were treated to a display of the Democrats' spleen when we were told how outrageous it was that people were not allowed to demonstrate outside AIDEX in the fashion they wanted. It is outrageous that the people of Australia should not have the right to protest at the disgusting, appalling, grubby little deal that the Democrats have done with the Government.

Senator Coulter tells this chamber, `We were happy to have the debate and we will sit through all night'. Of course they will sit through all night, but they do not want the Senate to debate this matter during the day. Why do they not want it debated during the day? It is because the media will cover the debate and tell Australia what a fraud Senator Coulter is; what a fraud the Minister is; what a fraud the immoral and hypocritical little concertation by these two groups of morally bankrupt people is. That is what the Government and the Democrats do not want—they do not want the debate taking place during the day; they want to push this Bill through the chamber in the dead of night. They want to steal into this place like thieves in the night, and that is what they are; they are thieves in the night because they are going to steal from the Australian population the right of free speech.

The Government does not want to call the Bill the `ban on free speech Bill' but that is what it is. What it is going to do in these amendments is say that, unless one belongs to a political party, one does not have the right to go before the people of Australia and say that this is—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I thought it was customary when senators were speaking in this chamber to address the Chair. It is rather difficult for a senator to be doing so with his back turned to the Chair.
—I suggest that Senator West is right. All remarks should be made through the Chair.

—Indeed they were, Mr Acting Deputy President. For Senator West's sake I will repeat them: the Government and the Democrats are thieves in the night because they want to steal away the right of democracy. As I was saying, and Senator West was obviously very upset by this, the truth is that those on the other side of the chamber do not want a person in Australia to be able to stand up and say that one should vote for this party or that party. They are going to ban the right of any group other than a political party to have an advertisement saying, `We do not believe that you should vote for the Government'.

PARA.TAB: The Government is afraid of the fact that people outside this place do not like it—and of course they do not like it. There are a million unemployed who do not like it, and there are two million people unemployed or underemployed who do not like it. There are millions of Australians who are appalled by the hypocrisy of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and who do not like the Government. This Government, in this Bill, is going to take away the right of absolutely all Australians who do not belong to a political party to advertise their political beliefs.

The ALP's view of democracy is different from those over here because the ALP believes that one has to belong to a faction. The ALP believes that one runs this country with political parties and that, if one does not belong to a political party, one is a second-class citizen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Talk about brown paper bags!
—The point that some of us on this side of the chamber make is that some of the people in the political party over there are second-class citizens morally. Senator Collins had the audacity—
—How could a member of the Queensland National Party support democracy? You are a mewling, puking, hypocrite.

—One interjection at a time. I am dealing with Senator Collins's first interjection, so he might just like to keep quiet while I put him in his place. Senator Collins had the audacity to start talking about brown paper bags. Fine; let us talk about big black briefcases; let us talk about his mate Brian Burke. A brown paper bag is not good enough for the Government; it is not good enough for those in the Labor Party, ladies and gentlemen, because they cannot stuff enough money into it. Even after Terry Burke takes his 20 per cent off the top, a brown paper bag is not enough for those in the Labor Party. They cannot cram enough money into a brown paper bag; they need a briefcase. That is the morality of the people who are now trying to take away from the people of Australia the right of free speech. What is worse, if they had any pretension to principle and morality, they would at least allow this to be properly debated.

PARA.TAB: Not only does the Government want to take away free speech; it wants to take away the right of the people's elected representatives to speak on free speech. Who is going to aid them in all of this? It is their friends over there, the Democrats—their friends for the time being because they have extracted yet another disgusting and immoral little concession from them.

The real reason why Senator McMullan wants to make this Bill urgent is not the urgency of the election—there is no election; it is not the urgency of a principle—we have been waiting four years looking at it. It is the urgency of the Labor Party's finances. It is the urgency of the fact that those people over there, through Senator Loosley's brilliant leadership, are going bankrupt almost as fast as is this country. I suppose it is poetic justice indeed that Senator Loosley can bankrupt the ALP almost as quickly as Bob Hawke has bankrupted this country.

I have just one final comment. We have seen during this debate a number of school groups come into the gallery to find out about free speech. Is it not ironic that they come to Canberra to find out about free speech on the day that the ALP and its political bedfellows, the Democrats, are going to take it away? Is it not ironic that they come here to find out about free speech and they see appalling specimens of parliamentary behaviour such as those that sit opposite—who berate the Senate, carry on and try to steal away like thieves in the night with the right of Australian people to express their political preferences?

I will say it again to Senator Collins because five times is not enough for him: this Government and the Democrats are thieves in the night. We say that enough is enough and this terrible carry-on should not be allowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

PARA.TAB: It is the Australian Democrats, in the end, who will have to wear the odium that the Australian people will undoubtedly express if this Bill goes through. This Bill, as Senator Collins well knows—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Just a few moments ago your predecessor constantly reminded honourable senators on both sides of the House that we will have two days to debate the Bill. This debate concerns the guillotine motion.

PARA.TAB: When this Bill came in in its original form—it is now sharply changed from the original form, as it changes almost hour by hour—this is what Mr Beazley had to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Were the ban to apply only to Federal elections, the problems created by the need of political parties to raise huge sums necessary to advertise during an election campaign would be only partially addressed.

PARA.TAB: Some of my colleagues pointed out that this is why the Senate has to consider the Bill carefully and why it has to be debated carefully. TALK.START.PARA: —It is called self-interest.

—For the sixth time I will attempt to conclude on the point. Reference has been made during this debate to the state of Labor Party finances and the Australian Democrats' finances. TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion standing in my name, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of standing order 142 be suspended as would prevent the amendment being debated without limitation of time and each Senator speaking for the time allotted by standing orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —These are very strange tactics for an Opposition that wants to talk about the Bill.

—If there were not a million people unemployed in this country, Senator Collins might have a right to speak on something. But while there are a million people unemployed he ought to keep quiet. What he does not want in the next election campaign is advertising that will portray a million unemployed Australians. That is what he does not want. We are seeking to allow a reasonable period of time for this important piece of legislation to be debated in this place. The point is that important new items have been introduced into this debate.

PARA.TAB: For example, the recommendation of the majority on the Senate Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures said that the talking heads amendment should provide 17 minutes of free time on each station per day. The amendments that we received last night provided for only six minutes. It avoids the debate as to who is going to pay for it. The Government says it is `free time', which means that the stations pay for it. The view of those on this side of the chamber is that that is unreasonable—the stations should not have to pay for it—and it is not free time. The parties should pay for it, but of course the Australian Labor Party is bankrupt, morally and financially, and is therefore not prepared to have the parties pay for it as it should.

The stations should have the opportunity to look at what the Government is seeking to impose upon them. The Government does not want them to have the opportunity to do so. The recommendations of the majority say that it is reasonable for there to be graphs of different types, including bar graphs, and various other mechanisms to enable the so-called talking head to project his or her case reasonably. It is not in the amendments. We want to know why. We ought to have the opportunity to consider that. There is serious doubt as to whether the amendments that were introduced late yesterday adequately cover the Government's position in relation to radio. I think it is arguable, when it comes to the allocation of times and the obligations upon stations, that there has been a very serious omission from the amendment the Government put to us last night. It needs to be looked at carefully, not within the timeframe that the Government has allowed. One could go on.

Very serious policy issues are involved in this. The question of who should pay for these talking head advertisements should go to the parties. Our party room should have the opportunity to debate it. The sensible course of action, therefore, would be to send the detail to the Senate Select Committee to be examined and for that Committee to deal with the amendments in as efficient a way as it has been dealing with amendments all year. That is the time-saving method of dealing with this Bill. If we provide a timeframe that gives us until 13 December to deal with this Bill, we allow a reasonable time for the detail to go to the Committee to be examined, the Committee to report to us and, therefore, the Bill to be dealt with in an expeditious way. It will allow local governments to consider the obligations and the restraints that are being imposed upon them. It would allow the parties to consider it, as well as the television and radio stations. All we are asking for is a reasonable time for the processes to be dealt with properly. They can be dealt with properly within the amended time allowed by Senator Macdonald.

We are not suggesting that all the meantime be consumed by this Bill. We would suggest that the Government get back on to that legislation which has starting dates and which is important for the processes of government. This is only important for the processes of politics because the Government does not want advertisements projecting across the airwaves a million unemployed Australians in the next election campaign. That is what the Government wants to restrain; that is what it does not want at the next election, and that is why it is seeking to prohibit it. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! This procedure raises a difficult question of interpretation which has not arisen before. PARA.TAB: Senator Hill has now moved for the suspension of Standing Orders again, in effect without notice. If that were not so, the debate on the allotment of time could be endlessly extended. TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to canvass your ruling. I am going to move for a further suspension of Standing Orders. I would move: that so much of standing order 142 be suspended as would prevent the further consideration of the Bill. That would mean the time for consideration would be from 7.30 tomorrow night until 3.30 on 13 December 1991.
—Order! I am now placed in a situation where there are two suspension motions before the Chair. I have to put the first suspension motion, that is, the motion originally moved by Senator Hill.
—Contingent on my notice, I would seek to move that so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Harradine speaking for two minutes.
—Order! I have just ruled that that is not allowable, Senator Harradine. It is the same principle. You will have to seek leave to make a statement.

—by leave—I believe that if the time allotted for the Bill were two days, it would not be an inappropriate time for us to debate the Bill, but it is inappropriate for people who are affected by the amendments to the Bill. It does not give them time to give their views to us so that we can represent them in the chamber.
