TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade why the Australian Government will not recognise an independent Ukraine. What criteria for recognition have not been met?

—The Australian Government welcomes the results of the referendum of 1 December as the outcome of a democratic process which certainly reflects the legitimate aspirations of the Ukrainian people for control over their political and economic destiny. As I said in Kiev on 22 November when I was visiting, one cannot help but be struck by the real renaissance of Ukrainian national consciousness and pride and by the way in which that was being translated into a manifest desire to establish an independent state. The referendum was, of course, held to determine popular attitudes to the Ukrainian Parliament's own declaration of independence of 24 August. The Ukrainian Parliament will convene this evening, Australian time, to consider the referendum result and follow-up action, which is, of course, likely to include calls specifically for international recognition.

PARA.TAB: The whole international community, including Australia, is, of course, currently considering its response to such a likely call. The Canadians have already taken a position on that, perhaps not surprisingly given the reality of one million Canadians of Ukrainian origin and the obvious pressures there for very speedy action in this respect. The whole international community has an interest in ensuring security, particularly nuclear security, in minimising instability and in maximising the chances of successful democratisation and economic reform throughout the region. All of these are relevant considerations in determining our attitude.

On the recognition issue, a crucial threshold question, here as with the Baltic states and Yugoslavia, will be whether the accepted international criteria for statehood are satisfied, including in particular the question of effective control of territory in a situation where the Soviet authorities retain a very substantial military presence on Ukrainian soil, with the added complication in this case, unlike in the Baltics, of not just a troop presence wearing a Soviet uniform but also, of course, a very substantial nuclear presence including strategic nuclear missiles.

A number of other questions will be relevant to Australia's and the international community's consideration of the recognition issue. These would include the following questions: the security and central control of nuclear weapons, given Ukraine's stated commitment to become a non-nuclear state; acceptance and compliance with existing Soviet arms control commitments, such as START, CFE and the biological weapons convention; the commitment to internationally accepted agreements governing standards for the observance of human rights and to protect minority rights; and, finally, arrangements for meeting the Soviet Union's international obligations, particularly the Ukraine's share of the accumulated Soviet Union debt. The Australian Government will be considering all those questions in determining its attitude and having regard to the response of the international community generally, not just individual member states, in determining how we respond.

I conclude by saying that we, as a government, urge the leadership of the Ukraine—as indeed I did during my visit there—to engage in a constructive dialogue on all these issues with the authorities in Moscow and the other republics and to work together, so far as humanly possible, to achieve an agreed resolution of these and other inter-republic problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce announced yesterday that the Government would impose a tariff of $12,000 on second-hand Japanese cars brought into Australia in large numbers. Can the Minister advise the Senate if this decision in any way affects people importing cars into Australia for personal use or in low numbers?

—The implications in Senator Zakharov's question are true. As there is some querying from the Opposition about this issue, let me explain the background. In Japan there is a policy of charging high registration fees for motor vehicles when they get to their fourth or fifth years. That policy is in place in Japan on environmental grounds relating to exhaust emissions. That policy is also well regarded by the Japanese motor vehicle industry. In Japan the average car life is about seven years, compared with 13 years in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The effect of that policy is simply that at the end of the fourth or fifth year a Mazda 626, for example, could be bought for between $500 and $2,500. As those vehicles sell in Australia for something like $13,000 or $14,000, it is a very nice business for a potential importer to import a car bought at that price in Japan.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is exactly the same for tinned fruit.

—If Senator Boswell wants to ask me a question about tinned fruit, he should do so and we will talk about tinned fruit. I do not want any of his fruit cake interjections while I am answering this question. Three countries are the logical recipients of cars which are the subject of Japan's policy—that is, they can be sold virtually at scrap value after four or five years—if they are sold overseas. Those countries are Singapore, which has no motor vehicle industry; New Zealand, where the penetration of second-hand cars from Japan has increased from 14 per cent in 1988 to 53 per cent in 1991; and the United Kingdom. Those on the other side will remember the United Kingdom, where I am told a policy has been put in place to ensure that second-hand cars imported into the United Kingdom all have to be inspected individually at a very substantial fee. The inspection process is slow and allows 100 cars to be inspected per month.
—They learnt from the French.

—Precisely. That is the first interjection I can remember Senator Alston getting right. They learnt that from the French. That is the Poitiers route for VCRs, as it is called. That is the policy in place in the United Kingdom.

PARA.TAB: Australia, as distinct from New Zealand and Singapore, has a manufacturing automotive industry. The Industry Commission this year reported on that industry and the Government has adopted its recommendations. The report and the decision made by the Government would, of course, be substantially undermined if import penetration of second-hand cars from Japan were to increase at the same rate and with the same potential as in New Zealand. For that reason, the Government has acted to impose a substantial tariff on the importation of second-hand cars.

The position of the Government in respect of this is that we do not see why Australia should be a recipient of cars which are determined, by the policy of another country, to be essentially unroadworthy. Accordingly, we acted to stop those imports. If the action taken is not adequate, further action will be taken by the Government on this issue. Any importer or potential importer should understand that fact.

Senator Zakharov asked me in the course of her question whether this would affect the importation in low volumes of second-hand cars from overseas. The answer to that is no. The tariff will not apply to cars imported into Australia which are subject to the definition in the Motor Vehicles Standards Act, which allows importation of up to 100 vehicles in particular categories under the provisions of that Act. In answer to the honourable senator's question, the decision which was made yesterday by the Government does not apply to personal imports of cars or low volume imports such as are permitted under the relevant motor vehicle standards legislation.

In conclusion, this was not an easy decision to have to make. But I think it is an important one from the point of view of Australian industry. It is an important one from the point of view of a clear understanding being given to some of our trading partners about the appropriate relationships which exist in a trading partnership of the kind which we have.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Defence. I refer to reports that the Khmer Rouge is refusing to take part in the newly established supreme National Council for Cambodia until the United Nations forces are in place to protect them. In view of the fact that the Australian Government has decided to commit at least 500 Australian defence personnel to the United Nations peacekeeping force—that is, the full force—will the Minister guarantee that no members of that force will be used to suppress protests by the ordinary people of Cambodia against representatives of the atrocious Khmer Rouge when they are in Phnom Penh?

—I think that is a fairly easy guarantee to give because that would not be the role of Australian troops. As most honourable senators know, there are two potential commitments to Cambodia: one already in place, which is UNAMIC, and UNTAC, which is expected to follow. We do not know when it will follow, but we hope it will be in April at the latest. This latest setback has obviously put some doubt over that timetable. Before we commit ourselves to the second matter, certain matters have to be resolved between the Cambodian factions so that we can be assured that we will be going into what is always only a relatively safe environment because, as honourable senators know, for a variety of factors—
—You have to say that it is less safe now than when you proposed to send them there.

—Senator Hill says that it is potentially less safe now. It is potentially less safe now, because the events in Phnom Penh of a few days ago make things difficult. Nevertheless, as the honourable senator knows, the various factions are meeting now to try to resolve those questions.

PARA.TAB: The basis of Senator Durack's question was: would Australia's troops be used to suppress protests, et cetera? The answer is no. As the honourable senator knows, our commitment is in the general area of communications and not infantry. Australian troops should not be used for the purposes the honourable senator has outlined.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has said previously in answer to questions that the Australian role has not yet been determined. We are very anxious to know what that role is going to be. Is the Minister now saying he will ensure that there is no role possible of the kind I have mentioned for Australian troops?

—What I said previously was that the Australian Government had put its preferred position on UNTAC to the United Nations. That is still the position that is being sorted out, although, since I last spoke on the matter, there has been some progress made in terms of organisation.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Government would not be disposed to send infantry, for instance, to Cambodia. It is expected of countries with our military sophistication to provide the more specialist functions in Cambodia and not infantry. Many other countries which cannot supply the specialist areas that we are good at can supply infantry, if required. It is on those more specialised areas, communications being a prime example, that Australia would wish to concentrate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the productivity growth there has been under Labor in the 1980s? Has the Minister seen proposals suggesting strong employment growth on the back of dramatic productivity increases? Does the Minister accept these figures and, therefore, intend to change the Government strategy?

—Before Opposition senators giggle or interject, I invite them to look again at page 342 of the Fightback! document. It is a page that those opposite clearly have not looked at in terms of some of these issues. If they look at the question of productivity in the Fightback! document at page 342, productivity—
—Which version?

—That is a very good question. At page 342 the productivity figure for the period 1983-84 to 1991-92 is 0.70; at another page in the document it is 0.90, which is the OECD figure for productivity in Australia.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The Minister can talk about Australia's productivity and his Government's contribution to it, or whatever; he cannot talk about the coalition's Fightback package. That becomes debate which is specifically prohibited under the Standing Orders. I ask you to bring him to order.
—Mr President, on the point of order: I was asked a question about productivity in the 1980s and I am answering—
—Talk about it. Talk about it now.

—I will talk about it in a minute. I am answering the question at the beginning by pointing out that there are some different estimates of productivity in the 1980s. There are two different estimates in the coalition documents. That is a matter of legitimate concern in considering the issue of productivity in the 1980s.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bishop

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on the point of order: on Tuesday, 26 November last you ruled:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . questions to Ministers must relate to the subjects within their ministerial responsibilities. It has . . . been ruled consistently by me and by former Presidents that a question that invites a Minister to comment on Opposition policies is out of order, unless the question is linked to the Government's intentions or some other matter of ministerial responsibility.

Quite clearly, the way in which the Minister is dealing with the material is not in line with your ruling and I would ask you to direct him to answer the question only in terms of his own responsibility and to refrain from commenting upon that which he knows just as little as does Mr Howe.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Button was asked a question about productivity and I consider the remarks he has made so far to be relevant to the question that was asked.

—I am just making the point that in productivity, as in everything else, there is no gain without pain. That is true for honourable senators, too. Those opposite will get a bit of pain if they hope to get any gain out of this process. The 1980s was a period in which the Government oversaw a series of productivity-inducing changes in the way in which Australian industry and workers went about their business. I speak of the restructuring of firms and of government instrumentalities.
—What about the one million unemployed? What happened to them?

—I am not speaking about the idiotic interjections of Senator Kemp. If he has an intelligent question to ask, he can ask it. I am talking about making businesses leaner and more efficient. The outcome of those changes is that productivity in Australia has grown strongly over the whole period of the 1980s, although the Opposition continually seeks to assert that productivity growth has been flat.

PARA.TAB: A minute ago when I had a few words about their policy, Opposition senators took points of order because they did not want to hear what I had to say. When I am now giving an answer about our policies and their effects they do not want to hear that either. They all interject like a pack of aimless lemmings because they do not want to hear the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us your policy.

—Part of the credit for this rise, of course, Senator Lewis, has to go to industry for lifting its investment performance and for restructuring the way in which enterprises operate at the shop floor level.
—Haven't you seen the latest investment figures? They have fallen by half.
—Yes, Senator, I have seen the latest investment figures, thanks very much. I have seen the Opposition's figures too; I have never seen a more rubbery set.
—Why don't you get out of Canberra and see what is happening in the real world?

—Senator Parer has invited me to get out of Canberra. That is a really smart interjection from Senator Parer, lounging in this chamber like a lizard day after day doing nothing, as one would expect. Government policy continues to be aimed at increasing the productivity of both labour and capital through award restructuring and training, an enterprise based wages system and exposing industry to international markets. What is remarkable about Australia's productivity performance is the fact that its growth has been strong in the face of a number of factors that usually lower measured productivity.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If the children opposite listen for a minute they might learn a point or two. Factors which have militated against productivity are things like employment growth which, until 1990, had been very strong—outstripping production growth and creating the impression, as it does, that labour productivity was weaker than it really was. Secondly, there has been a steady growth in the service sector as a share of GDP, which in the Australian figures is not measured in terms of productivity calculations. In many other OECD countries it is.

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Generally it is in the OECD, Senator Alston. The third factor is wage restraint and the cost of capital.
—We are at the bottom of the OECD scale.
—Mr President, Senator Hill should stop his inane interjections for a minute and listen.
—That is right; it is correct.

—Senator Hill interjects that we are at the bottom of the OECD scale. If one looks at the Hewson document, which he has not done, one will see that we will be at the bottom throughout the 1990s if this Opposition is elected to government.

—Mr President, on a point of order. You have ruled that Senator Button is within the Standing Orders in making constant reference to page 342. But he cannot be allowed to misrepresent the position and suggest that our figure of 0.8 is somehow worse than the Government's because that very document shows that the Government's base is 0.4—in other words, half of what our prediction on productivity is. Unless he is prepared to address that, he is misleading the Senate.
—Order! You know, Senator Alston, that that is not a point of order.
—Mr President, I will be kind enough to say to the Opposition that, in respect of its high road figure for productivity, it factors in two years of high productivity—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Button was asked to relate his experience on productivity in the 1980s. He is not doing that at all. In accordance with Standing Orders, he should be brought back to answer the question that he was asked.
—Order! There have been too many interjections. I would, however, point out to Ministers that so far today there have been four answers in 24 minutes.

—I conclude on this note: it is a cowardly Opposition which interjects constantly when Ministers are giving answers but, when the interjection is answered by a Minister, takes a point of order. What a coward's castle of an Opposition it is when it behaves like this in the course of Question Time in the Senate.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Can market-based economic rationalism, which has driven Government policy and more particularly the Opposition's Fightback policy package—which does not address the issue of ecologically sustainable development—address the problem of anabaena in many of Australia's waterways? If so, how? Precisely what market mechanisms will the Government invoke to tackle this serious and spreading problem?

—As a general rule, the market supplies the strongest and best signals to business and industry in this country. But there are exceptions to that rule; there are clear limitations to that view as, for example, Margaret Thatcher found out in Britain, as President Reagan found out in the United States and, if those opposite were ever elected to government, as they would find out here pretty smartly. I do not think that many members of the Opposition share that view; I think they are a bit confused about it all—that is a different thing.

PARA.TAB: I have not applied my mind to how algae in the Darling River and other rivers can be fixed up by the market sector. But that sort of problem could be fixed up by the private sector—as distinct from the government sector—if it were provided with appropriate incentives. The private sector probably would do that if it were provided with appropriate incentives. The private sector is driven by profit motives—legitimately—and if the profits from those sorts of activities are clear, the private sector will undertake them. If the private sector is not persuaded to undertake those sorts of activities they have to be undertaken, as Senator Coulter's question implies, by government. The art form, of course, is finding the balance between those two processes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that reply. Clearly, he has indicated in it that the Government would intrude into the market to put the appropriate price signals into the market system so that private interests would address the problem. I return to the second part of my question: given that we have this serious problem, precisely where would the Government intrude into the market? What would the Government put into the market to address this very serious problem of the algal blooms in the Darling River and elsewhere?

—It is probably too early to answer that question, except to say that the resources of the Government, through organisations such as the CSIRO, have been made available on a large scale to try to find an appropriate solution to some of these problems. That is the first step which government or government organisations can take. What action is required subsequent to that will depend on their recommendations and views.

—I address my question to the Leader of the Government. No doubt he is familiar with the reputations of Dr Graeme Cheeseman and Sir William Keys, who represented the respective positions of the Australian Peace Research Centre and AIDEX at a debate in Parliament House last week. However, Senator Button may not be aware that these speakers, while presenting opposing views on the arms trade, both agreed that there was a need for full parliamentary monitoring of all military exports. Will Senator Button discuss this proposal with his colleagues, particularly the Ministers responsible for Australia's defence industry and foreign policy, so that there is a complete parliamentary disclosure of all military exports on a regular basis?

—I thank Senator Reynolds for giving me some advance warning of this question. As the Minister for Defence, Senator Ray, said in the Senate on 26 November, the key to the export of defence and defence related equipment is where one sends such equipment and the nature of what one sends by way of equipment. This comes down to what export controls are applied.

PARA.TAB: Senator Ray has also pointed out previously that Australian controls on the export of defence and defence related goods are amongst the most comprehensive and best set of guidelines in the world, providing a sensible balance between allowing Australian companies to participate in defence trade and ensuring that the important Australian strategic considerations are taken into account, together with external policy, and that human rights concerns are not prejudiced. There is full consultation between relevant departments in considering applications for exports through the standing interdepartmental committee on defence exports. Each application is subject to a case by case review in accordance with published guidelines.

Australia is a small player in terms of the sale of military equipment. Our defence exports comprise primarily non-lethal defence goods—mainly components, test and evaluation equipment, and training equipment. The overwhelming majority of defence exports go to the United States, New Zealand and the United Kingdom.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank Senator Button for his response, which is appreciated. His response is similar to that given by the Minister for Defence. The point of my question and, therefore, my supplementary question is: what discussions could take place on the suggestion made by Sir William Keys and Dr Graeme Cheeseman that there was a need for a parliamentary monitoring role of defence exports?

—Any question of monitoring in relation to defence exports is, I think, essentially an executive function of the government of the day. If Senator Reynolds would like me to have a chat with Senator Ray and Senator Evans about this issue—and I have, in fact, just arranged a short meeting with Senator Ray on this topic—I will talk to the relevant Ministers and see what further response can be given to the honourable senator.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. In a press conference last night, in reply to a question, Mr Howe stated:

PARA.TAB: I think it is not actually a contest about, I actually don't think Laurie, if I might say so, figures, at the end of the day are going to be—the last dollar and so on—are going to be the argument. I think I tried to make that clear at the beginning.

QUESTION.PARA: I ask: what did the Minister mean? If the argument about our health policy is not about figures, is it then about freedom of choice and quality of care?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I find it incredible that Dr Herron would ask a question concerning freedom of choice in relation to the provision of health care in the Australian community, when the package put forward by Dr Hewson would deny to GPs the possibility of offering bulkbilling as a service to their patients coming into their surgeries. The disciples of choice have decided to cut back on that very important and well-regarded feature of the provision of health care in the Australian community. The primary health care givers in this community, the general practitioners, are to be forbidden, are to be prohibited, from offering the service of bulkbilling to those patients who present to them, apart from pensioners or cardholders.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister was asked to clarify what Mr Howe meant. He is not answering the question. I ask you to bring him to order.
—Order! Senator Tate, answer the question.

—In addition, I will go to the substantive part of Senator Herron's question to indicate that, quite clearly, Mr Howe was pointing to the obvious feature of the policy put forward by the Opposition which is to transfer not tens of millions but hundreds of millions of dollars out of the pockets of ordinary families and into the pockets of the doctors, via the private health insurance firms.
—Rubbish!

—It is not rubbish at all. If those opposite do away with bulkbilling—except in the case of pensioners and cardholders—they will take the competitive pressure off GPs. Those opposite say that they believe in market forces. They know as well as I do that a cosy deal will be done between the AMA and the private health insurers so that the AMA schedule fee will become the fee that Australian families will have to pay. If they are to avoid having to pay that, they will have to take out private health insurance. So those opposite will be transferring money from the families of Australia, via the private health insurance funds, into the hands of the doctors. That is precisely what their plan is about and that is precisely what Mr Howe was referring to.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. When Mr Howe made his $2 billion error last night, he blamed the Department. Was the error from his own office rather than the Department?

—The $2 billion figure is based on the annex to the press releases which was compiled by the Department. Those particular figures which lead to the conclusion of a $2 billion blow-out in the health care bills for all Australians are based on the figures in that annex which are absolutely accurate. So far as the press release error is concerned, that is most unfortunate but certainly not deliberate. But it has no bearing on the figures leading to the conclusion that, under the health policy put forward by the Opposition, there will be a $2 billion blow-out in the health care bills paid by Australians.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has the Government set in train a strategy to reform the Australian construction industry? Does this strategy have the broad support of unions, employer organisations and State and Territory governments? Can the Minister advise honourable senators on what progress has been achieved in pursuing this strategy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning the Prime Minister launched a construction industry reform program. The launch was attended by 250 or more leaders of the Australian construction industry from all walks of life in the industry. The building and construction industry in Australia is a $40 billion per annum industry. It employs half a million Australians. It accounts for 60 per cent of gross fixed capital expenditure in this country. However, its export turnover ratio is at the level of only 2 per cent, compared to the OECD average of 14 per cent. It spends a low amount of money on research and development and, by and large, it is an industry that has been dispute prone in the past.

PARA.TAB: The Government has therefore embarked on a reform program. That reform program starts by setting out an in-principle agreement outlining the objectives of reform to which all of the principal organisations in the industry have now committed themselves by signing the IPA. It also consists of a code of conduct for the industry in which we rate the performance of companies across a range of indicators which will be used in ascertaining how companies are performing and whether they are eligible for government contracts, State or Federal.

A reform agency will supervise the reform process. That is headed at the board level by Mr Paul White, the chief executive of Concrete Constructions, a national builder, and at executive officer level by Mr Ern MacDonald, who was formerly the chief construction manager of Civil and Civic and is a distinguished and recognised figure in the industry. The directors of the board are Malcolm Kinnaird of Kinhill Engineers; Jack Ritch of the AMP Society; David Chandler of Fletcher Construction Group; Martin Albrecht of Thiess Contractors and Robert Milne of Hooker Cockram, as well as Martin Ferguson of the ACTU, Stan Sharkey of the BWIU and departmental representatives. Obviously, it is a balanced board representing major employers in the industry as well as the key unions.

The reform program involves the setting up of model sites in which new methods of doing work will be trialled and proven up, and perhaps will then be a basis for wider adaptation in the industry. We have also established a tripartite council of some 47 members from industry, unions and government. All of the organisations, ranging from quantity surveyors through to earth movers and heavy construction companies, as well as the key unions, are represented on that construction industry development council. Therefore, the Government proceeds down this course of quite historic reform in this key industry sector for Australia with the support of all the major players.

I am therefore disappointed to see a press release in the name of John Howard, the Opposition shadow Minister, attacking this initiative, which has such clear and widespread support in the Australian community. He laughingly heads his press release, `A cave in to union power'. Of course, all of the major industry associations have signed and committed themselves to the reform process that we have undertaken. Every industry association that has a place in this industry is part of the advisory council under which this program shall be conducted. Of course, among those are some trade unions.

But then, of course, this Government is committed to working with Australians from whatever walk of life, to pool their talents and abilities and to work together to reform our basic institutions. The fact that some of those are trade unions may be offensive to the Opposition. It is not offensive to us. Mr Howard's press release concludes with these words:

ANSWER.PARA: Pointedly, many key industry organisations, including the Master Builders Association, have declined to sign the agreement.
That is absolutely wrong. The Master Builders Association is a signatory to the agreement: it signed it this morning. And all of the key organisations are in fact party to this agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did they sign?
—When was the press statement?

—I have been interjected upon. I do not wish to delay the proceedings of the Senate by replying to interjections needlessly, but the press release was issued yesterday. The launch was today. Mr Howard tells the world that the MBA has not signed. The MBA has signed. I look forward to Mr Howard correcting the public record, but I am in the sure and certain knowledge that he will wimp it. He will not say he was wrong; he will not make the retraction. I am absolutely certain about that. Meanwhile, we will proceed to reform this $40 billion industry with the assistance of our social partners.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the Minister agree with the Treasurer's statement at his amazing press conference yesterday that, rather than come up with new initiatives, the Government should merely `repackage' what it is already doing?

—I did not see the Treasurer's press conference yesterday and I am not precisely familiar with what has been said. If, as I believe, the Treasurer was saying that the Government will not depart—in spite of many temptations to do so—from the disciplined approach which we have had in respect of fiscal policy, monetary policy and wages policy, then the answer to that question is: yes, I agree with the Treasurer. But in so far as the rest of the question is concerned, I am not in a position to answer.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Which of the policies that have caused the current disastrous recession does the Government intend to `repackage'? In that connection, I also refer the Minister to the Treasurer's further statement at his press conference yesterday when, upon being asked how the Government was going to repackage its policies, he said, `Watch this space'. Could the Minister also advise the Senate which space the Treasurer had in mind?
— The supplementary question asked me to say, in terms of the recession, which policies might be repackaged.
—And which space.

—Senator Short's question had two parts—if he can remember back that far—and I am dealing with the first part first. Senator Short asked me which of those policies relating to the recession might be repackaged. Senator Short has been around here for a long time, and the answer to that question, as he well knows, is that retention of tight monetary policy for too long was a significant contributing factor to the current recession, as were a number of other matters such as the inability of Australian rural exporters to obtain access to overseas markets. We, as a Government, recognise that. In terms of that policy relating to the recession, as Senator Short puts it, the Government has embarked on a series of interest rate reductions over the last 12 to 18 months, and those will have an effect on the recovery from the current recession.

PARA.TAB: As far as the remark, `Watch this space' is concerned, I recall hearing about the press conference and that Mr Kerin said that in answer to a question as to what the Government's response would be to the package which I am not allowed to discuss in here at Question Time—the forbidden package which we are not allowed to talk about, because somebody will take a cowardly point of order if we do. The Opposition has provided a document which I regard as a manifesto for the next election. I am delighted with it, because there will be plenty of opportunities before the next election to draw attention in the community at large to the problems which the country would be confronted with if that Opposition document were implemented.

I remind the Senate, as we are allowed to talk about it for a minute, that page 342 of that document shows what the scenarios for this country would be under an Opposition government. In the `High Road' column, the consequences of a goods and services tax are not factored into the model. That is the most deceptive piece of modelling, matching—or trying to—the most extravagant rhetoric from the Opposition that one has probably ever seen in this country since Malcolm Fraser told us he was going to turn on the lights. The Government has its function to perform, which it will do until the next election, and we will not be too bothered about this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support and concerns all of us who use our charter entitlements. Is the Minister familiar with the following steps involved in the see and avoid principle in general aviation, as outlined in a Bureau of Air Safety Investigation research report? First, and most obvious, the pilot must look outside the aircraft; second, the pilot must detect objects of interest; third, the object must be looked at directly to be identified as an aircraft; fourth, the pilot must decide what evasive action to take; and fifth, he must move the aircraft. Will this see and avoid principle still come into operation on 12 December? Does the Minister think this sort of principle really takes into consideration the human limitations which are present in all pilots?

—As I said in Tennant Creek about a year ago, yes, those principles do apply. Regrettably, in the lion's share of all aviation accidents, it is usually a combination of human errors that causes the tragedy.
—Pilot error.

—It is not necessarily just pilot error. Quite often it is a combination of human errors on both the ground and in the sky which can, for example, be triggered off by the improper closing of a hatch, as was the case with one aircraft before it departed.

PARA.TAB: I am glad to say that the responsibility for the safe operation of an aircraft has always rested at the end of the day, in terms of that human error factor, with the pilot and it will continue to do so. For example, a short time ago a near major tragedy at Sydney airport involving two aircraft on intersecting runways was successfully avoided by the skill and the professionalism of the Ansett pilot involved, who did precisely in those circumstances what a pilot is trained to do.

I am also pleased to say that Australian pilots have a very high reputation in international terms for being the professionals they are. But that key responsibility of a pilot to be aware of what is going on in his own aircraft and in the space around him has always been a principle relied on in the aviation industry, and it will continue to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I am not greatly reassured by that answer. The Minister makes great reference in this place to BASI. BASI concludes that `see and avoid' is completely unsuitable as a primary traffic separation method for scheduled services and that unalerted `see and avoid' has a limited place as a last resort means of traffic separation. I ask the Minister why the Government is persisting with the introduction of this principle.

—Mr President, I do not want to detain the Senate unnecessarily but can I just say that I absolutely agree with that conclusion of BASI. It is entirely consistent with the answer that I have just given.
—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer.
—Make it sensible.

—It would be a darn sight more sensible than Senator Cook's answers. Can the Minister detail to the Senate why he believes that a goods and services tax would be beneficial to industry and particularly a boost to exports, which, of course, would be tax free for the first time? Can he also detail why he has stated that it will provide a competitive edge to Australian exports in the world market?
—First of all, in relation to the last part of the question, I have not stated that.
—You did last week.
—If Senator Knowles wants to try to rely on something I have not said—
—You did last week.
—If Senator Knowles can tell me where I said that, I will deal with it at the appropriate time.
—It is under `g' for goods and services.

—I just want to give Senator Knowles some figures because I think they are useful. In respect of the goods and services tax and its effect on exports, I am not sure that many people who support a goods and services tax—and there are people who do, of course—take the view that it is necessarily highly beneficial to exports. For example, Professor John Freebairn, who has been a great supporter of a goods and services tax, doubts very much the wisdom of replacing a payroll tax, which he describes as a tax on employment, with a goods and services tax, which he also describes as a tax on employment.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, let me say that the argument about the effects on exports has been considerably overstated. Recent work by Treasury—I do not have the precise figure in front of me—suggests that the impact of a wholesale sales tax, which averages about 10 per cent and in fact provides 10 per cent of total revenue on export activity, has been much exaggerated and is probably in the order of 1 1/2 per cent—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry—1.24 per cent in terms of its burden on exporters. But let me also say that in terms of a goods and services tax there has been a lot of false advertising. The garrulous Senator Kemp tried to pretend in the Senate a couple of weeks ago that countries which had goods and services taxes had better export performances than a country like Australia. That was just an absolute furphy.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp quoted the shadow Minister for trade, Smart Alex Downer, who made the point that exports of manufactured goods in the Philippines had increased by 21 per cent; in the same period, manufactured exports from Australia increased by 24 per cent. So there is really no correlation between the existence of a goods and services tax and export performance.

I do not want to discuss legislation currently before the Senate but, of course, the important thing as far as possible in the tax system is to remove input costs from manufacturers who are exporting. That is what the legislation currently before the Senate will substantially do. The honourable senator should not be under any misapprehension that the goods and services tax will be a great bonanza for exporters, particularly in the way in which it has been presented by the coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Social Security whether he is aware of an allegation of a costing hole of $2.3 billion in his Department's administration of its responsibilities with regard to unemployment benefit and whether there is any truth in this allegation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a matter of fact, I am aware of such an allegation. Yesterday Senator Alston put out a press release—
—Oh, did he?

—He did. It was headed, `Richardson should dig in his own backyard if he wants to find some real costing holes'. That is what it said. Of course, I take these things very seriously and I was quite concerned about it. In fact, I was concerned enough about it to think that I would be standing up here acknowledging that sometimes our departmental Estimates are not necessarily exactly correct over the course of 12 months. I think that has happened a few times. But I could not actually recall where the administration of unemployment benefits was $2.3 billion out. I thought I would do the normal thing that one does in these circumstances and turn to the portfolio program Estimates for 1991-92—
—They are Estimates, you know.
—Oh, I know. I will first quote the allegation in this press release:

ANSWER.PARA: *the 1990-91 budget estimate of outlays on the dole was $4.7 billion. The actual figure was $7.0 billion.

When one turns to page 348 of the 1991-92 Estimates, I concede one does find a figure of $4.7 billion and one does find a figure of $7 billion. However, the 1991 actual expenditure is $4.7 billion and the 1991-92 estimated expenditure is $7 billion. So in fact there was a hole in the backyard but Senator Alston fell into it. I really do not think we ought to take that kind of thing too seriously. This is not just a small mistake; this is a whopper by any standard. In closing, I should say also that the only other statement in relation to this was the claim in this press release that:

. . . the fact is that in nearly every instance DSS offices do not investigate an applicant's circumstances but simply rely on an applicant's assertions regarding the level of his or her liquid assets. . .

The truth is we do ask for bank books and we do ask for statements. But I have had it confirmed that we do not strip-search the applicants, nor members of their families, nor do we search their houses.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and follows the answer he gave to Senator Hill about recognition of the Ukraine. Why did the Minister, during his visit to the Soviet Union last month, make a strong public statement rejecting Australia's giving any recognition to the Ukraine as an independent republic? Was the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, consulted before the Minister made the statement? Why was the statement rejecting recognition of the Ukraine announced in Moscow the day before the Minister first visited Kiev, thus before he had any discussion with representatives of the Ukraine? Finally, does he regret making this overbold statement and does he regret jumping the wrong way on this issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is based on a completely false premise. As I recall, all that I said in Moscow and all that even Senator Hill accuses me of saying in his public statement on this, fulminating about it, is that I had no present plans to move to recognition of the Ukraine. That was in the context of the pre-referendum situation and the situation that I described, and which is still applicable today, where there are many unresolved questions that need to be resolved before that whole issue can be seriously contemplated.

PARA.TAB: So, far from a robust rejection of the concept, when I was in Kiev I spoke in terms of being impressed by the flourishing revival of Ukrainian national consciousness, pride and cultural resurgence that is currently occurring, and went on to say this:

ANSWER.PARA: We acknowledge the way that that is also being translated in a political move towards independence. We regard it as perhaps just a little bit premature to be going down the road of full-scale recognition of this process at the moment. But we certainly acknowledge the aspirations of the Ukrainian people and the movements that are occurring.

That is what I said in Kiev and spelt out in a number of further questions and answers about particular issues governing centre-republic relations and the great issue of the control of nuclear weapons and other issues that remain to be addressed. I have absolutely nothing to apologise for in terms of the judgment that I made at the time, which was made in the certain expectation that the referendum outcome would be of the kind that it has been, because all the indicators were pointing to that at that stage.

PARA.TAB: The whole point about this recognition question, though, is that it is a very complex one that has to be very cautiously and sensibly approached by the international community. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) to a question without notice asked this day by Senator Childs relating to productivity growth.

SPEECH.PARA: During his answer today on a question relating to productivity growth in Australia, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, as he has done on several recent occasions, drew attention to page 342 of the coalition's Fightback proposal's main document. He has sought to portray the figures for various scenarios in the modelling given on page 342 as the figures for productivity growth and other factors that would occur in the event of the coalition's Fightback proposals being implemented.

PARA.TAB: I point out to the Senate that the Minister is being totally misleading in making that assertion. If he looks at the first page of the relevant chapter relating to this matter—that is, page 333—he will see a reference to the Access Economics projections, which are on page 342. It also states:

While a number of elements of the policy change underlying the "High Road" Scenario are similar to those embodied in the Coalition's policy package, the analysis does not purport to portray the outcomes which would be achieved by implementation of that package.

Indeed, since the extent and scope of reform contained in the Coalition's policy package is without precedent in post-war history, it is unlikely that models based on economic performance over that period would be able to capture accurately the outcomes which might be expected to flow from its implementation.

The Access Economics analysis summarised below must be seen primarily as providing a framework for the debate about medium-term solutions to our economic problems which must occur if we are to avoid a further decline in our living standards.

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing could be clearer than those words. Those words say that the scenario on page 342 to which Senator Button has referred are illustrative only. The `high road' scenario, which shows the higher scenario productivity paths, is obviously a major underestimate of the productivity growth that would occur as a result of the coalition's Fightback proposals.

PARA.TAB: Nor does it—this is the important point because this is where Senator Button is misleading the Senate—even vaguely purport to fully, accurately and adequately reflect the coalition's approach. It does not take into account all the factors in the coalition's proposals which would automatically lead to lower business input costs; therefore the scope for higher saving, higher investment and higher productivity growth in the economy.

It does not take account of all the tax reductions, such as the abolition of seven taxes: the abolition of the wholesale sales tax; the abolition of payroll tax; the abolition of the petroleum products excise; the abolition of the superannuation lump sum tax; the phase-out of all customs duties over the next decade; the abolition of the training guarantee levy; and the abolition of the coal export duty. I interpose to say that I am delighted to see that the Government today has had the brains to adopt one part, albeit a small part, of the Fightback proposals. Hopefully, it will be the first of many.

My point is that the productivity performance that would occur as a result of the abolition of those taxes on business inputs—taxes totalling almost $20 billion—would of course have an enormous impact on investment, on the cost of production and therefore on productivity growth in Australia. It would therefore impact on our ability to compete in export markets and against imports. That is not—nor was it ever—contained in the Access Economics scenarios on page 342.

The one thing that can be said is this: that table on page 342 shows the `base case' scenario should there be a continuation of existing Government policies. That figure shows that productivity growth over the period through to 1999 would be about 0.43 per cent. On the `high road' scenario, which is a gross underestimate of the productivity growth that would be achieved through the coalition's Fightback proposals, the productivity growth factor would be 0.8 per cent—double the figure that would arise under the maintenance of the Government's existing policies.

I ask that when Senator Button gets up and makes statements in this chamber and outside he at least pay his listeners the courtesy of stating accurately the facts and not deliberately distorting the material contained in this document.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —What has been said by Senator Short just confirms the point I have made here on several occasions in the last week—and that is that the Opposition's document does not match its rhetoric. The rhetoric appears at the beginning of this chapter; the document, the model, appears at the end.
—It does in the lead-in paragraph.
—Order! Senator Short was heard in silence.

—He cannot keep quiet because at the moment he is a bit excited after all these years. For certain purposes Senator Short relies on page 342—the table; the scenarios in relation to annual growth rates. When he wants to, he accepts the figure of two million extra jobs implicit in that scenario. But he says, `When you look at the rest of the table, no we don't accept that; we'll be better there; we'll be worse here; we'll be better somewhere else'. He accepts none of it because he is totally confused about the assumptions.
—The two million jobs do not come straight out of the scenario, and you know that.

—I beg your pardon; they do. Senator Short should do his mathematics. The employment projections—as I said the other day—are a straight line extrapolation of the employment performance of this Government through the 1980s up till 1990. Those figure are carried on till the end of the century.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short has not talked about the projections in respect of foreign debt under a government of which he might be a part, because that is a disgraceful figure in the extrapolation presented here. Another comment that Senator Short makes is that the high road projected in the Liberal Party document does not take into account the effects of the goods and services tax.

Senator Short, who has all sorts of warm assumptions about the behavioural consequences of a goods and services tax, comes in here and says, `Oh yeah, but when we look at the high road we've got to take into account all these vast behavioural benefits which will follow from the introduction of a goods and services tax and the abolition of payroll tax and so on'. TALK.START.PARA: —When did you announce it?
—I do not know; I think it was announced earlier this week. But the point is that it is—
—Before or after the package?

—If Senator Short knew anything about being in government—and he probably does not, except as a Treasury officer—he would know perfectly well that these things are, and have to be, considered for some time before an announcement is made; that is the Cabinet process. Senator Durack would remember that because he was in government. That issue has been dealt with for some time. Of course, it does not matter anyway because the export coal levy will not be removed until the next financial year.

PARA.TAB: All that Senator Short's maiden point displays is that all of his warm inner glow assumptions and the consequences that he says will follow from the implementation of this package do not always match the model. What he should say when they do match the model is, `Thank you, we will have those; they are good ones; we like those' and, when they do not match the model because they are bad ones, `No, we won't have those, thanks; they are not in the Hewson vision of the world'. All I am saying is that those opposite have to be very careful about making assumptions and indulging in rhetoric which are not supported by figures.

The more explicit figures which can be seen in this document are the ones about the proposed compensation for a goods and services tax—the tax cuts that will be allowed. They are quite clear. A person on $30,000 a year would get a $30 tax cut and a person on $80,000 a year would get a $140 a week tax cut. That is what it is about.

TALK.START.PARA: —He might have been working 100 hours a week, too.

—Senator Panizza is full of empty-headed rhetoric about `incentivation'. That is true. The assumptions are that there will be all sorts of good consequences, but the figures are clear as a bell. What the figures show is that this proposed compensation for a goods and services tax, which will impose burdens on every household in Australia, will be grossly inequitable.
—You will never sell it. You can't tell people who will be well off that they will be badly off.

—Senator Crichton-Browne, who makes a lot of noise here, would walk out of this place with $140 a week in his pocket under John Hewson's proposals and the person on $30,000 a year would get $30 a week. That is the difference. They both have to buy the same vegetables, shoes, shirts and clothes with the 15 per cent goods and services tax on them—all the necessities of life.

PARA.TAB: I have to listen to this rabble over here because they do not like discussing these issues when there is too much pain associated with them. But Senator Short had to be responded to because he has developed this confident little technique of taking note of questions—a brilliant device, if I might say so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indeed pleased that Senator Short has moved a motion to take note of Senator Button's answer, because the argument in Senator Button's response to the motion has shifted significantly from that which he adopted in answer to several questions. He has, unfortunately, committed several other errors. I will let those pass to the keeper.

PARA.TAB: Today we have seen a Minister incorrectly reading the Hewson Fightback! document in answer to a question raised during Question Time this afternoon. May I remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that that document presented three scenarios from a well-known, highly respected Murphy model. It followed the consequences of each of those scenarios. It is quite mischievous to suggest that the Liberal Party has got its numbers wrong or is confusing them. There were three separate cases presented and the consequences of following each of those cases were explicitly outlined in that document. There is no doubt about that.

What the Fightback! document did state was that the Liberal-National Party coalition in government would follow certain scenarios in adopting a policy of micro-economic reform, the consequences of which would be not dissimilar from those expressed in the Murphy model. The point is that implicit in the answer was an incorrect comparison between the OECD productivity data for Australia for the period 1983-90 and the figures used by Access Economics in the supplementary paper of the Fightback! document. The point is that the two sets of figures cannot be properly compared, as Senator Button somehow tried to do—this was a further furphy—because the OECD numbers relate to labour productivity in the business sector, while the Access measures refer specifically to the total real GDP per employee.

If one were to compare like with like, the productivity figures assumed under the high road scenario—which Senator Button chose to use—on the OECD basis would also be above the 0.9 per cent per annum figures realised for 1983 to 1991. My colleague Mr Reith said in the other place:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a sad truth that we would have to lift our game markedly just to exceed the experience of the 1980s.
Then there is the chart that was referred to by Senator Button:

As the Chart attached shows, productivity does accelerate under the High Road case, but since the Coalition will not be able to start implementing the necessary structural changes until 1993, the full benefits do not flow until the second half of the decade.

PARA.TAB: The Hawke "Low Road" scenario—which is generated by the Murphy model—would see productivity sag even further to average a dismal 0.4 per cent over the period.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, the high road—the preferred option of the Hewson plan—offers double the productivity of the Hawke Government's low road case during the last decade. Therefore, I think it is regrettable that Senator Button, representing the Government, this afternoon misconstrued the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleagues Senator Short and Senator Watson have drawn attention to Senator Button's misquoting and misuse of the figures for the various high road, medium road and low road scenarios for the current decade. I draw the attention of the Senate to another matter that Senator Button has focused on, that is, the productivity growth which occurred during the 1980s when Senator Button and his colleagues were in government. In the answers by Senator Button some play was made about productivity growth in this area. It may be enlightening to honourable senators and others to learn that during this period Australia enjoyed an average productivity growth of 0.9 per cent per annum. If we compare that with other countries—countries of world best practice, a term which has become commonplace—it is worth noting that in Japan, in contrast to the 0.9 per cent productivity growth for Australia, there was productivity growth of 3.4 per cent per annum. This was almost four times the productivity growth per annum that we enjoyed in Australia. In France the productivity growth was 2.3 per cent; in Italy 2.3 per cent; in Germany 1.7 per cent—almost twice the productivity growth in Australia; and in Canada 1.3 per cent. Australia was noted during the period of the Hawke Government for extraordinarily low productivity growth.

PARA.TAB: We have seen how a number of Ministers enjoy Question Time because, when the issue of the Fightback package is raised, they feel they can get a free kick, then cut and run after Question Time when of course these issues can be properly debated. Senator Button has pulled the same stunt again today. He made comments and allegations during Question Time while he was on TV. Then, when we got up and sought to debate these matters, of course, Senator Button, like so many other Ministers in this Government, cut and ran. He was not prepared to stay here and debate the issues.

We want the Labor Ministers to come in and give us their alternatives. We have been waiting for almost two weeks for Labor Ministers to come in and give us their vision of Australia's future, their ideas on what would happen to the growth of employment, what would happen to the foreign debt and what would happen to living standards under the alternative projections of the Labor Government. Of course, as Mr Kerin confirmed yesterday, there is no prospect of that because the Labor Government is out of ideas, out of time, and all it can hope to do is to repackage the stale, failed policies of the 1980s.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the answer which Senator Button gave earlier today he chose to refer to page 342 of the Fightback! document carrying the subtitle `The way to build and reward Australia'. In so doing, he showed himself to be yet one more floundering Minister. I think it is important, in case anybody feels sorry for him because he is not on top of the material and therefore finds himself floundering, that we perhaps read from page 345 and then reflect upon how his own department interprets the current situation. I think this passage is quite important. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The favourable economic effects of the lift in productivity under the "High Road" scenario are reinforced by a cut in government consumption spending that lowers government expenditure in 1995-96 to its 1992-93 level, compared with a 6.6 per cent increase under the other two scenarios. This allows both lower income taxes than the other scenarios and reduces government borrowing, and induces a lower exchange rate. This encourages net exports and results in a lower current account deficit to GDP ratio of 3.7 per cent in 1999-00, compared with 4 1/2 per cent under the "Low Road" scenario. Foreign debt is 54 per cent of GDP at the end of the decade and falling by 0.8 percentage points per annum.

The importance of that statement is probably recognised by Senator Button's own department and, indeed, by his own Deputy Secretary, Dr Bell, who, back on 23 July, made a very sensible speech which was reported in the Australian. He said that there was increased pressure on the Government for further tax reform. He increased this pressure by criticising the indirect tax system as `penalising exporters, while business is urging changes to promote long-term investment projects'. The exact words of the report are as follows:

PARA.TAB: Exporters are being penalised by the present "morass" of taxes, which cannot be rebated, according to Dr Bell, in contrast with competitors overseas who operate under "value-added taxes"—a form of consumption tax
Dr Bell also suggested the lack of an internationally `competitive' tax regime could make the difference between winning or missing out on big investment projects.

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Bell further stated:
DITAC calculations—
that is, the calculations of Senator Button's own department—
suggest that our current tax regime puts Australian exporters at a 5 per cent average disadvantage vis-a-vis their international competitors.

As I said at the beginning, lest anybody feel sorry for Senator Button getting it wrong, like Mr Howe, lest anybody feel that Senator Button has not quite had the opportunity to get on top of the material, understand that his own department knows only too well that reform is essential, and that his own Deputy Secretary has gone on the record saying that the current system of the wholesale sales tax and the other morass of taxes is penalising Australia to the tune of 5 per cent per annum. It is our Fightback package and our high road scenario which will enable us to achieve, in the words of the title of the report, `the way to rebuild and reward Australia'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too want to make a few brief remarks on the motion to take note of the answer given by Senator Button today to a dorothy dix question which was designed to create the impression amongst those people listening who were not economically literate—because Senator Button's answer would not have fooled anybody who was—that productivity performance under the Labor Government during the 1980s has not been too bad. The impression he tried to create was that this Government has been battling on fairly successfully against all odds.

PARA.TAB: I would like to put a slightly different suggestion—what I believe to be the truth—to this chamber, namely, that the Government has done an appalling job in relation to productivity growth. Those of us who are not economists can sometimes get confused by people talking about fiscal policy, monetary policy and `change this, change that', tinkering here and there with the mix of economic policies that are available to a government. But the bottom line is that what we want to come out at the end of the day from those policies is increased productivity. We want the nation to be producing more per hour worked and per employee. That generates the opportunity for more and safer jobs. It is something that I would have thought this Government should have been interested in.

It is perhaps germane to have a look at some of the remarks that Senator Button made. As I understand it, one of the claims he made was that this Government has been battling on against all odds, and that one of the difficulties in increasing productivity has been the price of capital. As I saw his face, he showed not a glimmer of embarrassment in offering that as a reason for not having the productivity growth we should have. Is it not those on this side of the chamber who have been saying since your Government got in, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the interest rate policy was too high, that the price of capital to manufacturing was too high, and that as a consequence people would not be shifting money into investment and into long term projects because they simply could not afford to do it?

Day in and day out in this place, those on this side of the chamber, and even perhaps the Democrats on occasions, have been trying to point out to the Government that one of the reasons for the failure to increase productivity growth was the cost of capital. We were pointing out that it was this Government's high interest rate policy that directly relates to the cost of capital. Yet we have one of the most senior Ministers coming into this chamber today and saying, `We have been battling on quite well against the tide of the cost of capital', as though his hands were not on any of those levers. But he was sitting in Cabinet with Senator Evans and Mr Keating. Senator Tate and all the others went along with these policies which pushed up the price of capital and made it too expensive for a businessman or businesswoman to invest in new plant and equipment. That is why investment in plant and equipment has dropped off very badly under this Government. What were people doing? They were investing in bricks and mortar, not in plant and equipment that can generate jobs for the workers that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, came into government to represent. That is why we now have in many sectors of industry outdated, dilapidated equipment.

We need a massive capital reinvestment in plant and equipment to bring us up to some sort of technological edge, at least, in some of these industries. That is the first point I wanted to make. It is a disgrace for Senator Button—who has now disappeared because he thinks he has better things to do—to come in here and offer as a reason for poor performance in productivity growth the cost of capital without even blushing and admitting that he has had a hand in pushing up the cost of capital and keeping it up.

The second point I want to make is that Senator Button in his usual jocular way says, `Look, between you and me, you cannot take too much notice of these productivity figures. There are different measures here, different measures there'. He is almost saying, `I don't know, it is all too complicated; no-one can work anything out'. Mr Acting Deputy President, why do you think the OECD and every other credible economic forecasting body makes a stab at productivity figures? Why do we bother looking at them if they are not worth anything? That is the question we need to put to Senator Button. Sure, there are different measures; I understand that. By and large, we use real GDP per hour worked, whereas the OECD countries use GDP per employed person. But we collect all those figures and we can make oranges with oranges comparisons. It is not as though there is some fruit salad of figures that every government finds totally incomprehensible. It is quite possible to make very sensible comparisons using the same sorts of figures.

Senator Button, who is supposed to be leading the Government in the Senate, says basically in his answers, `It is all a bit difficult. There are all different measures here and there and you really cannot compare. It is all too hard'. It is an outrageous admission basically of incompetence on his part. As to the impression he wanted to create, namely, that the Labor Government has not been doing too badly, let us have a look. We concede that there has been an actual fall in the rate of productivity growth in six of the last nine quarters since June 1989. The figures for another quarter are coming out at the end of this week, and I will be interested to see what the result is. I would not be surprised by a small rise in productivity. Why? Because more people are losing their jobs and so the productivity per person increases. There are fewer persons employed. That is a function of the policies of your Government, Mr Acting Deputy President, and the Government of Senator West and Senator Tate. There are more people out of work, and everybody opposite has had a hand in it. They are all going along with it.

We have had a fall in the rate of productivity growth in six of the past nine quarters. What does the Minister have to say about that? Why have we had that type of fall while other nations have not? What is the explanation? That is what we want to hear, not some gobbledegook about one set of figures being different from another. Just on the set of figures that we produced for this nation, we find that there has been a fall in six of the past nine quarters. I think we deserve at least an explanation.

I point out that the productivity increases in two of the three quarters which did not suffer a fall were generated by a loss of jobs, which is not exactly the smartest way to generate such an outcome. But it happens. If we lose people from the work force and the same GDP is produced, obviously there is a real increase because a smaller number of people are producing the same number of things. It would be much better if the same number of people were producing more. As I say, there has been a fall in six of the past nine quarters.

Since the Labor Government is so keen to compare its performance in the 1980s with the performance of Liberal governments, it might be worth looking at that as well. If we look at the changes in real gross domestic per hour worked—that is, productivity growth—we find that under Fraser it increased on average by 1.6 per cent while the Hawke Government has managed only 0.94 per cent. I suppose to some people who may be listening, there does not seem to be much difference between 0.94 per cent and 1.6 per cent. But when we are talking about the economy as a whole, they are not small figures at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is gigantic.

—In total, Australia's actual productivity in the Fraser years grew an impressive 13.7 per cent while the actual productivity under Hawke grew by a mere 3.2 per cent. There is no messing about here. We are not using different figures; this is a standard set of figures. I am comparing one set of figures so there is absolutely no confusion.

PARA.TAB: The third point I would like to draw to the Senate's attention is how we compare with other industrialised nations. Let me turn to a different measure of productivity. We have been looking at real GDP per hour worked. If we look at real GDP per employed person, we will see that, while the OECD nations have been speeding up their productivity growth, Australia has been slowing down. Senator Button has not given us an answer as to why that should be the case.

People in this country who are losing jobs can see that other countries are steaming ahead in terms of productivity growth while Australia is falling behind. That is what Australians want an explanation about. We do not want to hear about why Senator Button does not understand how to put the figures together.

Our total productivity during the Hawke era has been equally dismal. While labour productivity for OECD countries grew by a total of 16.4 per cent between 1983 and 1990, we managed only 8.5 per cent. We are way behind our major economic rivals.

Last, but certainly not least, it is worth looking at the productivity growth of some of the Asian nations. Our productivity growth, measured as changes in real GDP per employed person, has been below that of Korea and Hong Kong in every year except one. While we have been struggling to get growth rates of up to 4 per cent, the rates for both Hong Kong and Korea have jumped up to around the 10 per cent per annum mark. We have simply not been measuring up. We can see that the result of that is nearly one million people unemployed.

My final remark is this: it is most unfortunate if Senator Button wants to come in here and pretend that he understands productivity. Speakers from this side of the chamber have pointed out that he clearly does not. But whether or not he does is irrelevant. What is relevant is that our productivity growth has been dismal compared with that of the Fraser years, compared with that of OECD nations and compared with that of Asian nations. That is what we need an explanation of.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) in relation to a question without notice this day by Senator Faulkner relating to the unemployment benefit.

SPEECH.PARA: In answer to a question asked during Question Time today, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) referred to a press release that I put out yesterday. I was fascinated to hear the way in which he approached this issue. What is really of concern to the Australian public is the extent to which the Government, with its vast resources, is able to keep track of its own expenditure. Very much at issue, therefore, must be the capacity of the Department of Social Security, which administers something of the order of $28 billion a year.

PARA.TAB: In the course of his answer today, Senator Richardson effectively said that he concedes that his Department's estimates were something of the order of $718m short of actual expenditure. My press release referred to four particular examples of areas—not an exhaustive list by any means—in which there were discrepancies. Of course, Senator Richardson did not quarrel with three of the four, and, therefore, one can take it that he concedes those amounts—$178m, $14.5m and $10.9m.

In relation to the estimate for outlays on unemployment benefit-Jobsearch allowance, the figure in the 1991 Budget estimate was $4.2 billion while the 1991 actual outlay was $4.7 billion. In other words, there is a discrepancy of $514.6m. For Senator Richardson to concede a blow-out of that magnitude, without any explanation other—

TALK.START.PARA: — The error was much larger in 1982-83.

—If we want to go back to ancient history and talk about the capacity of the Department of Social Security at that time to get it right, if what Senator Walsh states is correct—I have no reason to doubt it—one would have thought that in all the years that have elapsed the Department would have been able to put its own house in order and get much closer to the real figure than it has apparently been able to do, as conceded by Senator Richardson.

PARA.TAB: One of the classic reasons that the Department has not been able to do the job emerges from Senator Richardson's answer the preceding day to a question from Senator West, who asked him about the waiting time for the Jobsearch allowance. Senator Richardson said:

SPEECH.PARA: A great many people are inconvenienced and do suffer hardship—
in other words, as a result of the Government's policies in failing to deliver any significant economic growth over the past eight years—
because of the waiting period.

In other words, Senator Richardson is conceding that there is a dramatic level of need in certain sections and yet he is absolutely refusing to make any significant funds available to voluntary agencies.

PARA.TAB: If Senator West can somehow pretend that that is a compassionate approach to the real needs of the agencies, she ought to think twice about the advice that she gives to Senator Richardson. For example, she only has to look at what the Brotherhood of St Laurence had to say, as reported on the front page of yesterday's Age newspaper.
