If she does, she can contrast the level of demand with the impecunious, parsimonious response of the Government. Senator Richardson went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of that—
hardship—

some 20 per cent of applicants now qualify under hardship provisions. The hardship provisions are pretty simple: if one has in the bank less than two weeks of the benefit, which is less than $300, one would qualify.

That is the hardship test as far as Senator Richardson is concerned. The fact is that the hardship test involves a great deal more than that. It involves the application of a liquid funds or available funds test, which involves an inquiry into whether people have payments available, payments from previous employment, cash on hand, money in a bank or other financial institutions, shares, debentures, other investments, other moneys available at short notice, income available but not yet paid, or instalments of income due within the fortnight from date of lodgment. Indeed, the manual says that the liquid funds of a partner or a bank accounts held on behalf of dependent children should also be taken into account.

PARA.TAB: In other words, a whole range of matters simply are not being taken into account by the Department in the administration of this test and they ought to be. This is clearly condoned by Senator Richardson, who says that it is simply a matter of whether a person has $300 in the bank. If a person does not, he can get the benefit.

How is that tested? My press release says—on the basis of inquiries made by me—that no checking is done. People simply fill in a claim form and the Department takes their word for it. In other words, it is a notoriously unreliable measure of actual need. What does Senator Richardson say today? He says, `We ask them to produce bank accounts'. Does that go anywhere near meeting the requirements specified in the manual? There have to be inquiries about all those other matters. One would have thought that the mere production of a bank account is nowhere near sufficient to meet those requirements.

Quite clearly, Senator Richardson has come into this chamber and admitted that the administration of his Department is notoriously lax, because intuitively it is very hard to believe that one in five people do not have $300 or more to sustain them once they lose employment. By definition, they have been in the work force, they have been earning money and they have a whole range of other entitlements, yet we are led to believe that one in five people do not have two sticks to rub together. That may or may not be true but one could have no skerrick of confidence that it is accurate.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you don't know whether that is true, how can you make assumptions in your strategy?

—Based on the proposition that Senator Richardson is conceding that his Department does no effective testing or scrutiny as required by its own regulations, it ought to be quite clear that there is a very big hole in the estimate of 20 per cent that he produced. Therefore, our estimate which takes account of moneys available to people through early retirement, termination payments, redundancy payments and the level of time they have been in the work force—which we estimate to be 18 per cent—is much more likely to be an accurate figure.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought that the least Senator Richardson could do is concede that all he is trying to do is mount a scare campaign. In what he said yesterday—not in his answer, but subsequently—he is pretending that 50 per cent of people who have lost their jobs and are out of work for four to five weeks would not have more than $300. Again, intuitively, that does not sound right, but if it is, it is a devastating indictment of the Government's failure to give people any more than a hand-to-mouth existence.

When we combine that with Senator Richardson's own admission in the Senate today that the Government's Budget costings are $718m out, acting on the basis of the Budget estimates of outlays on unemployment benefits—as they then were for 1990-91—it is quite clear that a tremendous amount of work needs to be done in Senator Richardson's own backyard before we can attach a skerrick of credibility to his costings. No doubt that is the major reason why the Government has backed off from its decision taken earlier this week for Senator Richardson to call a press conference to explain where the Fightback! document's figures are inaccurate. I can well understand why he has made that tactical decision to retreat. We will just have to wait until the end of the week to find out whether he can do any better next time round.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—The President has received a letter from Senator Archer proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

PROCTEXT.PARA: The hope given to Australian farmers by the Coalition's Fightback Program as compared to the misery of Labor's recession and failure to implement the fundamental reforms necessary to give farmers a fair go.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to limit the debate to 70 minutes with speaking times limited to 10 minutes for each senator. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the Clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to commence debate on this matter of public importance by reading the first two paragraphs of the `Executive Summary' in the Fightback! document. They state:

PARA.TAB: Australia, with the quality of its people and the advantages of its great natural resources, should be a nation of expanding economic opportunity, rising living standards and social progress. Yet, over recent years, it is clear that we are being held back from making the most of our opportunities and that many other countries with less natural advantages are achieving much more.
We can't go on like this.
It's time for Australians to fight back against the Labor Government's economic mismanagement and policy failures that have resulted in the worst recession since the Great Depression.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the basis on which we start looking at the rural industries of Australia. We must do something. We must take action. Overall, no farmers in the world are more efficient than the Australians. If they are so efficient, why are they not making any money? Income this year at $3.2 billion is half that of two years ago. Rural exports have now slumped to 23 per cent of the total, whereas in the 1960s it was over 60 per cent of total exports.

PARA.TAB: Senator Button makes much of the fact that manufacturing exports now exceed rural exports. That is nothing to be proud of. What we have to look at is why rural exports have plummeted to the level that they have. Farm costs have risen four and a half times since 1973-74. How can we cope with that? Unless something is done, and done drastically and urgently, Australian farmers face extinction.

The Australian farmers are efficient by world standards but they are not making any profits. They have increased their productivity to an enormous level but it has all gone in costs. Let us look at the suffering that has occurred between 1983 and 1991 under Labor and the effects on farmers of high dollar values, high interest rates, rising taxes and new taxes. We only need to look at a recent publication of the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics which says:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1990-91, 79 per cent of sheep specialists, 66 per cent of beef specialists, and 58 per cent of cropping specialists recorded farm business losses.
How can we go on like that? The publication continues:

PARA.TAB: At the Australian level, average farm debt is estimated to have increased by 9 per cent between 1989-90 and 1990-91.

SPEECH.PARA: The money problems of the farming industry are enormous and we must do something about them. Things are not going to get better under the present system; only by changing the system do we stand a chance of improvement.

PARA.TAB: The National Bank also produced figures showing the debt structure in its quarterly summary which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Average farm income in 1990-91 of $11,200 is around a third of the 1989-90 level of $37,180. The average farm income per work year of family labour is around . . . 5,800.

PARA.TAB: The ABARE survey shows that in 1990-91 over 25% of farms had negative cash operating surpluses. . . . Their problem is high costs relative to their receipts.

SPEECH.PARA: The main reason for those high costs, of course, is that they are costs which the Government has produced. We cannot blame the US or the EEC for many of these things. Most of the problems that Australian primary and secondary industries suffer have arisen from our own operations.

PARA.TAB: The farmers must turn to the Fightback! document and we must emphasise the fightback aspects of it. The farmers, generally, have supported the package very strongly and they are fighting on. Not only have they had to cope with drought, toxic rivers, locusts, crop failures, rabbit plagues, stock losses, price collapses, market problems and increasing costs; they have also had a Labor Government. It is not a picture for the lucky country and certainly not for the clever country.

What has 8 1/2 years of Labor Government given the farmers? Apart from the Government looking at the policies and saying, `We might repackage some' or `Watch this space for something to happen', I do not know what the farmers have been given. Minister Kerin, who operated the Department of Primary Industries and Energy for some years, has at least had the good sense to say that the main attack will be political, because the arithmetic will not be faulted. If we can start at that level, at least we know where to go in the future. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) pays out on the Public Service for his own incompetence; Mr Simon Crean is doing the Brer Fox act, lying low and saying nothing; and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), while he is flogging around looking for something to happen, has only signalled his incapacity and called for help. To whom did he call? The world's greatest Treasurer. What extravagant adulation we get around to in times of glory. The architect and co-architect of the mess that we are in are trying to work together—the blind leading the blind.

The continuation of the rural decline is stimulating emigration from the country to the town. About 0.75 per cent of farmers are leaving farms and moving to the towns every year. It is the worst possible thing that can happen to Australia at this stage. We need to get the support of the people in the cities for what is happening to the farmers; we need to get the support of government to understand that farmers are important. It is interesting to note the support that has come from the National Farmers Federation. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Coalition's economic package will be of enormous benefit to farm businesses and farm families.

PARA.TAB: All taxes on business inputs would be refunded, improving the competitive position of our export and import replacement industries.
Abolition of fuel excise would reduce on-farm fuel costs, the cost of transport of farm imports and farm products, and the transport component of all goods sold in regional areas.

SPEECH.PARA: In a press release of 26 November, the National Farmers Federation stated:

The National Farmers' Federation today rejected Treasury claims that the abolition of wholesale sales tax would be of little direct benefit to farmers . . . the abolition of wholesale sales tax would save the farm sector $170 million a year.
The Australian of 26 November stated:
It really gets on with attacking the inefficiencies in the community and I think that's good for all of us.
The President of the Tasmanian Farmers and Graziers Association stated:

This innovative and far-sighted package of urgently needed reform will boost the Australian economy; encourage development of industry and export sectors . . . for Tasmania these include the reduction in coastal shipping costs of 20%; reduction in farm to wharf transport costs of 20%; reductions in international freight of 20%—
and so it goes on. Mr John Crosby, of the New South Wales Farmers Association, described the package as:
. . . the first genuine, positive attempt by any political party to put together a package that substantially helps business, especially small and medium-sized business.

Under the coalition's proposal, seven taxes will go, there will be a 15 per cent goods and services tax and a 100 per cent business rebate. That is good for the farmers. The whole purpose of the exercise is to focus on excellence, individuals over institutions, personal responsibility, the creation of incentive, encouragement of investment and employment, reduction of foreign debt, less tax, an increased national productivity and a return to the better standards of living in keeping with our past standards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The technical description of the item before the chamber is a matter of public importance. The author of the words that have been framed in this matter of public importance is the Opposition and they are entirely its responsibility. The matter of public importance states:

PARA.TAB: The hope given to Australian farmers by the Coalition's Fightpack Program as compared to the misery of Labor's recession and the failure to implement the fundamental reforms necessary to give farmers a fair go.

SPEECH.PARA: It suggests that the best remedy to the problems of farmers is Fightback! or `Frightpack'—whichever way one wants to look at it. The trouble is that there is a huge credibility problem with this language.

TALK.START.PARA: —It beats `incentivation'.

—Yes, it beats `incentivation' as a corny phrase. The problem in the rural sector in Australia is that there has been a collapse of international commodity prices in most of our agricultural exports, over which this country has little control but which has tried to meet the needs of the rural community. The other problem is the drought.

PARA.TAB: The difficulty with the credibility of this motion is: how will anyone believe that the introduction of a new tax of 15 per cent on all rural produce will help resolve the international commodity price problem or the drought? How will a new tax of 15 per cent do that? One does not have to think very deeply or for too long to see that it will not. One can conclude therefore that this motion is beside the point and irrelevant. It is simply an attempt to try to make it appear that rural Australia somehow has a vested interest in supporting the goods and services tax of Dr Hewson, a goods and services tax which will impose a new tax of 15 per cent on every bushel of wheat, on every clip of wool and on every pound of meat sold off the farm. The price to consumers will be much higher and, therefore, buyer resistance will be greater. To define it as it really is, not as the motion tries to, is to describe the dilemma of the Opposition.

The Government acknowledges the pain that the Australian community has undergone during the recession—a recession which has severely hit all of the nations in the Western world. As the Australian economy has adjusted to the impact of the recession, there have been positive economic outcomes which will be maintained in the future. As the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, Mr Bernie Fraser, said in Tokyo on 26 November:

SPEECH.PARA: We will come out of the recession in better condition than we have been in for years—the recovery will be marked by lower inflation and greater productivity and profitability than we have seen in a long time.

Inflation has been curbed for the first time in decades in Australia. The consumer price index has been steadily declining since the December quarter 1990. The CPI in the September quarter 1991 stands at an annual rate of 3.3 per cent—the lowest increase since the March quarter 1970, after Medicare has been taken into account. This decline in inflation has been partly the result of deliberate government policies under the accord process, particularly the wage-tax trade-off at the beginning of this calendar year. As honourable senators will remember, that occurred in September last year. The drop in inflation that has occurred now puts Australia's inflation rate below that of our major OECD trading partners and below that of the OECD average. It gives Australia an edge in international competitiveness, a result which is very favourable to the export orientation of the rural sector.

PARA.TAB: With a decline in inflation, interest rates have fallen markedly. Since the beginning of 1990, short term interest rates have been halved, with cash rates declining from 18 per cent to 8 1/2 per cent. The drop in interest rates will significantly reduce costs to rural industry during a time of drought and intense international competition.

As well as that, there has been an ambitious program of micro-economic reform. The Hawke Labor Government has also been undertaking a program of massive micro-economic reform, much of which has benefited rural industries and, in the long term, will substantially lower their costs. For instance, the waterfront reform program has seen a 50 per cent reduction in the cost of grain stevedoring. The work force at grain terminals has been reduced by up to 70 per cent. Since 1988-89, the time required to turn around grain vessels has almost halved from an average of 4.52 days to 2.4 days. Overall savings to the grain industry are estimated to be at least $10m annually. No lesser an authority than the Australian Wheat Board has said:

SPEECH.PARA: Australian ports are now amongst the most efficient grain loading ports in the world.

The Federal Government is very conscious of the problems being experienced by many farmers as a result of the rural downturn, low prices in the world commodity markets and drought conditions. This rural downturn is particularly severe. The short term outlook for many commodities is bleak. Many farmers living in rural Australia face considerable financial pressures and have few alternative employment opportunities.

PARA.TAB: The Government recognises these problems. We are not sitting on our hands. We have developed a range of measures to assist farmers. These have been done quickly and to help those in most need. We have responded with a comprehensive targeted rural assistance package which includes, amongst other things, increased rural adjustment scheme funding, new social security provisions and assistance for farmers affected by the drought. The package has been well received by the farming sector. It demonstrates what this Government's commitment is to Australian farmers.

The rural adjustment scheme encourages structural adjustment in rural industry by providing assistance to individual farmers for farm expansion and development; it improves the efficiency of Australian rural industry and its international competitiveness. Depending on farmers' particular circumstances, RAS assistance is available to them to improve their farms or to maintain their farms, or to leave their farms where their enterprise has no long term prospects. The Federal Government announced in October this year an increase in RAS funding of $60m in a full year to a total of $173m for 1991-92. As well as that, from 1 December this year, eligible farmers will be able to claim Job Search and Newstart allowances of up to $13,078 a year for married people, with an additional $624 for each child. These benefits have replaced the former unemployment benefit.

The new arrangements mean that farmers in extreme circumstances will find it easier to claim these benefits. Until now, many farmers have found it difficult to obtain unemployment benefits from the Department of Social Security because they could not satisfy the work test criteria of being unemployed. This applied even if they were not actively farming their property and were doing some minimal farm maintenance. This arrangement will inject another $10m into rural assistance this financial year and an additional $20m for 1992-93. Some 2,000 farmers will be assisted.

The Government's policy on drought assistance is that drought is a naturally recurring feature of the Australian climate, an ongoing commercial risk associated with rural enterprise. We provide assistance for drought where it causes financial hardship, just as we do where the hardship is caused by other factors, such as low prices, which are beyond the control of farmers. The national drought policy will be considered by the Australian Agricultural Council in February of this year.

World agricultural markets are dominated by high production levels, high stocks and widespread agricultural support policies. This is why Australian farmers are experiencing low world market prices, with prices for wool expected to fall by 32 per cent in 1991-92, with falls of 13 per cent for sugar and 22 per cent for rice, and with cotton down by about 5 per cent. But there are some signs of price improvements for wheat and meat.

The Australian Government's attention has been directed towards reaching a favourable outcome for the Cairns Group of countries in the latest Uruguay Round of trade negotiations. The Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, Dr Blewett, recently led a delegation to Europe which included members of the Opposition and the National Farmers Federation. This delegation impressed on European leaders the need for substantial improvements in agricultural negotiations during the Uruguay Round. All these add up to a positive range of measures to assist farmers, in contrast to the Opposition's goods and services tax package which offers a chilling future for the rural sector.

I conclude by repeating that there are problems visited on the farm sector by the drought and by international prices. Because of that, we have put measures in to ameliorate the effects on the rural sector. But what would damage the rural sector in this country more than almost anything else would be the introduction of a new tax which would impose a cost of 15 per cent on all goods and services sold or produced off the land in this country. That would be the single most cold-blooded, devastating blow that could be delivered to farmers in this community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter being discussed is the hope given to Australian farmers by the coalition's Fightback program when compared with the misery of Labor's recession and failure to implement the fundamental reforms necessary to give farmers a fair go. That misery is being experienced in rural Australia cannot be denied. It is self-evident to anybody who spends any time in the country, where the transport contractors, the machinery agents, the stock agents—the commercial hearts of our country towns and cities—are all suffering because of the terrible pressures that our farmers are facing. That cannot be denied. One of the pressures our farmers are facing is, of course, the drought, for which the Government cannot be entirely blamed.
—What do you mean, `entirely'?

—No, not entirely, but to some extent we might debate that. Having taking the credit for one drought ending, the Government cannot get away from this one. The other pressures are entirely the result of the economic rationalist policies to which this Government is committed and which the coalition supports. That blind devotion of both parties to the philosophy of tariff reductions to achieve a supposedly level playing field is a monument to flat earth economics. That devotion has been responsible for much of the misery we see in rural Australia today. It has undermined our markets, it has threatened our infrastructure and it has reduced the viability of our country towns.

PARA.TAB: That devotion has recently been challenged by the NFF, the MTIA, the Australian Dairy Industry Council, the Queensland Cane Growers Association and by economic commentators in recent issues of the Bulletin, the Australian and the Age. Like me, these groups and individuals have become disenchanted with policies which have led to supermarket shelves being stuffed with overseas produce. The policies have led to dumped fruit juices flooding our markets; they have led to dumped dried apricots, which have been well described by some of our farmers as `bad lemons'; and they have led to the notorious situation which has been described only in today's Age.

In that issue, in the section headed `Epicure'—and I think it is quite appropriate that the front of that section displays beetroots and radishes, my regard for which honourable senators will be aware of—we are told right at the beginning of the `fight for 3 cents an orange'. In that article, by Rita Erlich and Richard Yallop, we are reminded:

SPEECH.PARA: There are about 700 citrus growers along the Murray Valley and last financial year each made a loss of about $3000. A big contributing factor was the competition—not always fair—from foreign imports.

PARA.TAB: First, orange growers saw their late-summer valencias competing in the Australian market against imported Californian navels—even though the United States refuses to let in Australian oranges—and then they watched the price of juicing oranges plummet as the Brazilians, who control 30 per cent of the world orange-juice market, drove down prices.

SPEECH.PARA: That situation which Australians find themselves in can be described as `misery' because it is a situation in which they have very little control. They can grow the best oranges around but, faced with that sort of situation and having little control over it, the reaction is one of misery. I have no disagreement with that word as used in this matter of public importance. But they are also miserable because they see no respite from their circumstances—and there is no respite being offered in the package that is being touted by the coalition.

PARA.TAB: About the only guarantee that is available to Australian farmers, as is available to all Australians at the moment, is the guarantee that the Australian Democrats have given that we will not permit the necessities of life to be taxed—certainly not to be subjected to a goods and services tax. The coalition package offers neither the respite that Australian farmers need nor the hope which is claimed in this matter of public importance. The package that we have constantly heard about in the last couple of days could be better described as a `Flightback'—a flight back to the prehistoric mumbo jumbo of the failed theories of economic rationalism, the dogma which says that money is king, that money is God and that money rules.

We see evidence of this at page 308 of the `Flightback' package. There John, Valerie and their three children are used as an example of a farming family in Australia. That page is all about money. There is a promise there which John and Valerie—and I believe all Australian farmers would reflect this attitude—will believe when they see it. It is a promise which suggests that John and Valerie will be better off in three years time by some $30 a week. They would be well advised, as would I, to believe that when they see it turn up.

That is the great hope. That is the best that is offered in this package. There is no mention of anything else other than money. Page 308 is solely concerned with money. What really concerns our farmers is reliability of markets; fairness in competition, both here and overseas; access to infrastructure and community services, such as education and health; productivity of their land and its continued productivity; and the continued fertility of their land—in other words, soil conservation. That is a hint that most of Australia's farmers have been traditionally concerned with being able to hand on to their descendants fertile, productive properties. They are concerned with a lot more than cash money. They are concerned with heritage values and with the traditional values, which enable them to admire the goodness that they can get out of their soil and its continuation.

Do we see any of these concerns reflected in the Fightback! document? We certainly do not. We see about three-quarters of a page of cursory comment about the environment, a few platitudes about how wonderful it is and how we ought to encourage a few more tourists to come and look at it. That is the clue to the coalition's attitude here. It sees the environment as something that is separate, something outside the window to be looked at. The environment is what we live in and it is what farmers work with and nurture to earn their living and ours. By using and nurturing the environment, farmers are able to add to the prosperity of this country.

The economic rationalist gurus that are worshipped by this mob—that is, both major parties—can provide no indicators, no direction and no incentive to help our farmers nurture their environment and to sustain their future and ours. In Question Time, Senator Button was unable to provide us with a list of measures which the economists would implement to prevent a recurrence of the problems of algal bloom in our river systems. He was unable to offer any suggestion. He said it was too early to ask and that they had to think about it. I suggest that it is too late to think about it; we should have acted several decades earlier.

However, there is hope. There is a successful model which does guarantee the productivity of our soils now and in the future. It is not as though I am particularly praising the Age, but in yesterday's Age we are able to see on page 3 the very good news of a group of some nine farmers who, for several years now, have been working the land in a sustainable organic manner. This year they have produced some 13,500 tonnes of A-grade organic oats, wheat, barley and safflower. I commend the article by David Porter in yesterday's Age because it is most enlightening and that is the sort of model which we should be following and emphasising. Those are the sorts of farmers who are fighting back against the economists' gobbledegook which has served us so poorly in delivering the situation we have now in rural Australia. These people are nurturing their land and instead of insulting them with the sort of verbiage that we have before us today, we should be congratulating them and we should be helping others to follow their examples to provide the entire country with a sustainable future instead of one which is so bleak and has no offer of respite from either the coalition's `Flightback' package or the continuation of the Government's present policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this very important matter of public importance raised by Senator Archer today, I remind honourable senators that I have made many speeches in this place about the plight of those in rural areas. The Australian Labor Party likes to talk loudly about social justice, but apparently rural people are not part of its social justice program. Its economic policies have already been ruinous to anyone trying to contribute to the productivity of the nation.

PARA.TAB: Labor's policies devastated the farm sector during the 1980s, squeezing farmers and their families with exploding costs, crippling interest rates, unfair and discriminatory taxation and a lack of urgently needed reforms in the transport, waterfront and handling industries. A major rebuilding of the economic environment in which our farmers—the most efficient in the world, as Senator Archer has said—have to operate is now critically important. As Senator Archer said, the Opposition's Fightback package will enable farmers to cope with their worst downturn in 60 years—a downturn presided over by our current Treasurer, Mr Kerin, when he was the formerly ineffectual Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. It amazes me that this Government is so intent on its factional deals that it rewards a man who has achieved what no other Minister in Australia's history has achieved—the destruction of our rural sector—by giving him the reins on all Government economic policy.

Our Fightback package—I am sure that all honourable senators have seen it—will ensure for rural industries that, in the medium to long term, recovery will be both assisted and locked in place by lower costs, cheaper interest rates and stable, sensible dollar levels. Above all, a revitalised economy resulting from these reforms outlined by Senator Archer, and also our industrial relations policy, will deliver an environment in which long term prosperity can be generated. It will ensure that farms are better able to cope with the seasonal and market vagaries that are part and parcel of farming life.
Fightback! is an entire package. It is not just a GST. It is a tax which the Premier of Queensland, Mr Goss, supports because only two years ago in the Business Review Weekly he said:
I supported the consumption tax at the tax summit because it is so efficient. That sort of tax could sweep away a number of inefficient and expensive ways to collect taxes. . .

SPEECH.PARA: This is an entire package which will assist all corners of Australian society, especially our rural industries, which we are focusing on today. It will ensure that farm families will stay together.

PARA.TAB: There are numerous advantages for the rural community resulting from this visionary package. In addition to its overall benefits for the rural sector, this package will help rural women and their families in particular. It will help them with the abolition of petrol excise, which will dramatically reduce the cost for rural women to access services for themselves and their families, and it will significantly reduce transport costs, which will benefit rural women living in remote areas and Aboriginal communities with reduced costs for food and clothing. The package includes zone rebate increases of at least 25 per cent which will help women and families in remote areas, as will our proposal to increase family allowances.

There will be improved health access, especially with mobile units, which will provide mammography and testing for osteoporosis; the establishment of a training course in a rural centre, which will give nurses additional training to prepare for a career in isolated areas where there is little or no medical back-up; medicare rebates will be available from retail pharmacies; and the reform of the assets test will ensure that people in genuine need, such as retired farmers living on the family farm, are not precluded from the age pension, and I believe that is something of great importance. The package will ensure that all reasonable cases of hardship are fully considered in determining eligibility for the age pension. For example, following the death of a spouse, when the combined married rate of pension would cease after three months and there is demonstrated hardship—perhaps funeral expenses—payments of the married pension rate could be extended by up to six months.

Furthermore, this package will improve assistance to isolated children and their education. The assets test on the assistance for the isolated children's scheme will be abolished. An additional $10m will be spent under this scheme to raise the value of the boarding allowance, raising the level of the non-means tested boarding allowance to $2,300. The assets test on Austudy will be set aside in cases of extreme hardship. Is it any wonder then that the Queensland Farmers Federation President, Mr Lyndsay Hall, was quoted in a press release yesterday, as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Conservative Parties Fightback Program provides the opportunity for Australia to have a real choice about its future direction.
Mr Hall said that the Fightback Program was a comprehensive blueprint which would ensure the return of incentive and encouragement for productive sectors such as agriculture.
"I believe farmers will be better off under the coalitions package because it is aimed at efficiency and productive activity.
"It goes well beyond the introduction of a goods and service tax.
"It provides for a fundamental reform of the structures of our society.
"It will provide direction for the economy and the efficiencies in taxation reform, real micro economic reform and cutting back on Government waste will benefit farmers.
I think Mr Hall is a very wise man. He said that farmers would benefit from a range of specific initiatives. He continued:
"The abolition of wholesale sales tax, payroll tax and petroleum products excise will be amongst the most significant benefits for farmers.

Two issues which are hurting rural women and their children, in particular, these days are education and health services. Already, rural women and children are significantly disadvantaged. Without question, they have reduced opportunities for education, health services, cultural experience and, of course, future employment. Those of us who inhabit this nation are all Australians. But we are two nations in terms of educational and health opportunities: those who are fortunate enough to live in metropolitan Australia and those who are discriminated against for living in rural or remote Australia.

PARA.TAB: This Government has done nothing to try to bridge this rift. Indeed, its policies have contributed to a disturbing widening of the gulf between these two nations. This Government has demonstrated that it has no interest in those non-metropolitan Australians. Its neglect effectively punishes those who, for a variety of reasons, choose not to live in the cities and big rural towns. To be a non-metropolitan Australian under this Labor Government is to be second class—a member of the B team, a reserve grade Australian.

We would all be aware that, despite a perceived general oversupply of doctors and health practitioners in Australia, rural areas are reaching crisis point, with doctors refusing to practise in remote areas. This Government's continual attempts to socialise medicine have led to a situation where country surgeries are closing and hospitals are downgrading services. Already, country people have reduced opportunities to receive specialised health services, as they either have to forgo the service or spend excessive amounts of money to travel to cities for their health care.

There are many other examples of the way this Government has treated people who live in the country. I believe there are many problems with schooling for the children who live in the outback. So many of them have to be assisted with their schooling by means of correspondence. Certainly, many parents have had to withdraw their children from boarding school because of the problems which have arisen. Parents have to drive their children excessive distances mornings and afternoons in order to catch a school bus.

From what I have said, we can see many of the problems which have arisen because of the way people in rural Australia have been treated by this Government. The situation reflects the incapacity of remote families to cope with the financial burdens associated with living in rural areas and it is set to worsen. It is not as though this Government has simply turned its back on rural problems, letting them fester by callous neglect. It is worse than that: its policies have worked actively to make things worse.

TALK.START.PARA: —The figures on farm income quoted earlier in this debate—and they can be expressed in about four different ways—are not strictly comparable with income figures for other Australians. They are always understated compared with any realistic comparison. However, having said that, the fact remains that right now farm incomes are at extraordinarily low levels, as they have been periodically in the past—most recently probably in the mid 1970s, but also in the early 1970s and, in the case of the wheat industry, in the mid 1980s or in 1986.

PARA.TAB: The fluctuations of farm incomes or of the prices of farm commodities, particularly for an exporting nation like Australia, are cyclical factors which have been around for as long as Australian agriculture has been around. At present, this has been aggravated for a significant number of farmers by drought and by the policies which were adopted with respect to the wool industry, at the recommendation of the wool industry itself, about three years ago—for which all members of this Parliament on both sides, including the Australian Democrats, ought to take some responsibility.

The circumstances of some individual farmers have been aggravated by excessive borrowings to make imprudent purchases of overpriced land. Whether one is a high flying paper entrepreneur or an anonymous farmer, if one continues borrowing money to buy overpriced assets one will ultimately become insolvent.

However, having said all of that, about one-third of Australian farmers presently have no debt; about one-third have debts at fairly moderate levels between zero and $100,000; and about one-third have debts in excess of $100,000. I hasten to add that not all of those with debts in excess of $100,000 are necessarily in financial trouble.

Unfortunately, from time to time we see not very well-informed beat-ups. There was one in the latest Weekend Australian which predicted disaster looming for Australian agriculture because only 112 combine grain harvesters and only 800 tractors had been bought in the previous 12 months or something like that, and this was a turnover of capital stock which occurred once in 100 years. The underlying reality behind that, at least with regard to grain farming, is that gross over-investment in plant and equipment is the norm.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on! You tell us that every time. That's not right.

—Senator Panizza knows that very well. Like me, Senator Panizza grew up on a wheat farm in Western Australia and, like me, he has planted 25 or 30 wheat crops and he still has some contact with the industry. He knows very well that gross over-investment in plant and equipment is the norm in grain growing and in some other agricultural industries in Australia. Therefore, while it would be undesirable for other reasons, and for sectors other than agriculture, if there were a moratorium on plant and equipment investment in Australian wheat farming for five years the impact on efficiency would be barely measurable. Let us get that into perspective.

PARA.TAB: However, the matter of public importance that has been submitted refers to the alleged hope for farmers contained in the package that the Opposition released a couple of weeks ago. Where is the hope? I will be objective about this: yes, there is one bit of good news for farmers, or at least for farmers who are exporters. Because the value added tax—which the Opposition calls a goods and services tax—will not apply to products that are ultimately exported, there will be an advantage to all Australian exporters in this tax system. But keep it in perspective. It probably amounts to little more than a 1c change in the exchange rate. That is about what it is worth to exporters.

Let us look at some of the negatives. Nobody denies that there will be an increase in the consumer price index in the order of 5 per cent. Some would put it higher than that, and I suspect it will be. Some people believe that that will be a one-off increase. It may not be. If everything the Opposition says is to be believed, the chain of cause and effect will go something like this: if this package is introduced, the consumer price index will go up by 5 per cent overnight.

In order to stop that sharp overnight increase in the CPI settling down into a new, continuing and higher level of inflation, the Opposition, if it is in government, will have to do one of two things: it will have to tighten either fiscal policy or monetary policy. It has already ruled out the fiscal policy option. It has undertaken that all its expenditure cuts—nebulous though some of those are—and all the increased revenue from its value added tax will be delivered back in income tax cuts, or so it says. In other words, the option of tightening fiscal policy has been closed off by the Opposition three years in advance.

What is the other weapon left with which the inflationary surge could be contained? The answer to that is monetary policy—high interest rates which, among other things, push up the exchange rate. It would not take a very significant increase in interest rates to push up the exchange rate by more than the 1c gain, or perhaps the 1 1/2c gain, that exporting agricultural industries, or all exporting industries, would gain from the changeover towards a value added tax which would be rebatable on products exported.

Senator Bjelke-Petersen read out a list of alleged benefits to various people in the country. One or two of them may have been justifiable. One was that petrol would no longer have the present excise applied to it. But we know that, for the Opposition to deliver on its commitment to land transport reform, if petrol were not taxed at its present level the Opposition would have to tax something else. The Opposition has not fixed the hole in its arithmetic that arose from that. As I understand it, and nobody has contradicted it, there is a rort here—a typical old Country Party-type rort—that would enable farmers to use excise-free petrol not for running the farm, because the amount of petrol used in agriculture production is negligible, but for running to town, to the city and all over the place. That is a rort. Farmers might welcome it, but they are not entitled to it and they should not get it.

Senator Bjelke-Petersen spoke especially about rural women—farmers' wives and mothers. But what we did not hear from her was anything about the 15 per cent tax that they would pay on all the groceries, the kids' shoes and the kids' clothes. Members of the Opposition continue to demonstrate that they do not understand their own proposition.

Yesterday in this place Senator O'Chee was complaining, with some justification, that the existing wholesale sales tax is applied on the freight component of goods delivered to the country. If the wholesaler invoices the goods in that way, Senator O'Chee is correct: the wholesale sales tax, at whatever rate, is added not just to the cost of the goods ex-factory, wherever it is, but also to the cost of the freight to transport the goods to their retail destination. But what he obviously does not understand is that, once this value added tax were brought in, a 15 per cent tax would be applied, not only to the freight costs of the small minority of goods that are subject to a wholesale sales tax, but to the whole lot.

I doubt whether Senator Boswell understands this either. Part of this package is that a 15 per cent tax would be applied to the cost of moving goods from the point of production to the point of final sale—not on a few items, but on everything. I leave it to Senator Boswell or Senator Bjelke-Petersen or Senator Panizza to explain to people in the country, whether they are farmers or not, why that will be in their interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nowhere is the decaying Hawke Labor Government's neglect of its responsibilities to the Australian community more evident than in its demonstrated lack of concern for the plight of rural Australians and rural industry. Nothing that we have just heard from Senator Walsh in any way ameliorates the lack of concern that this Government shows for those people.

PARA.TAB: In contrast, the Liberal and National parties' Fightback program has given strong hope at last to Australia's hard-pressed farmers, who are suffering more than those in any other sector in the community because of the current disastrous rural recession. That is why the following matter of public importance has been proposed today by Senator Archer and supported by Senator Bjelke-Petersen and me, on behalf of the coalition:

SPEECH.PARA: The hope given to Australian farmers by the Coalition's Fightback program as compared to the misery of Labor's recession and failure to implement the fundamental reforms necessary to give farmers a fair go.

Not only will our economic reform package restore viability to farms by providing very specific reductions in production costs for farmers, but our overall policies and reforms will give a boost to business generally and put our languishing economy back on track—something that this Labor Government has consistently failed to do.

PARA.TAB: The two key elements of farm viability and survival are, firstly, the input costs to produce a commodity and, secondly, the commodity's selling price. Time and time again this Hawke Labor Government has tried to explain away and wash its hands of the plight of Australian farmers on the basis of poor prices on overseas markets. We heard that again today from Minister Cook in his response to Senator Archer's opening of this debate. Of prices and costs, costs are the most significant. Detailed studies have shown that over 60 per cent of farm viability depends on domestic economic decisions—decisions which the present Hawke Labor Government, failing as it is, has continually avoided.

The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics has recently forecast that the average farmer will be drawing on savings or borrowings this year, not only to cover farm operating expenses, but also just to meet normal day-to-day family living expenses. In what other sector of our economy do workers actually work for less than zero income? This is happening in our rural sector to thousands of Australian farmers and their families.
At the recent Outlook Conference held on 16 October this year, the Bureau made the following prediction:

SPEECH.PARA: By many measures, farm incomes in 1991/2 are expected to be the lowest on record.

Farmers in my own State of South Australia have been hit harder than those in other States. Although there has been a slight rise in wheat and beef prices, mostly at the expense of those farmers hit by the drought in New South Wales and Queensland, the Bureau concluded:
The outlook in the South Australian farm sector continues to be bleak.

The Bureau's figures highlight that the value of South Australia's rural produce fell by nearly one-quarter in the space of one year, while returns for some major commodities were halved, compared to a fall of just under 10 per cent Australia-wide. While farmers have been hit by drought, poor commodity prices and the international trade war, these are not the main reasons for their difficulties. It is the Labor Government's high interest rate policies and the failure to implement the reforms necessary to reduce costs that have plunged the agricultural sector into financial ruin.

PARA.TAB: Real interest rates are still high and many farmers in South Australia are still paying overdraft rates in the high teens and low twenties—considerably higher than the current prime lending rates available. While prices are falling, production costs are escalating and are further increased by wholesale sales tax of between $4 billion and $6 billion on industry and agricultural production costs, tax of $1.7 billion on exports and $6.8 billion of fuel excise. High transport costs for road and rail and on the waterfront are contributing to the rural sector's misery.

The Liberal and National parties' Fightback program presents a thorough and comprehensive scheme to redress these problems which Labor is either unable or unwilling to face. Firstly, the coalition proposes that the removal of sales tax, payroll tax and fuel excise will dramatically cut costs for farmers. These are taxes which, under this Labor Government, have to be paid, regardless of taxable income—and farmers pay them, even if indirectly. In contrast, the goods and services tax will be fully refundable on all goods and services used in farming activity, including on vehicles.

We live in a vast country and removal of fuel excise is one of the most significant and far-reaching reforms in the Fightback program because it affects every aspect of our economy and every sector of the community. However, for farmers, who are so reliant on transport for their very survival, it will have an even greater benefit. The present Labor Government has admitted that road transport is taxed 3 1/2 times more than other industries, yet it has done absolutely nothing about rectifying the situation.

With the coalition's package, however, farmers will not pay excise on petrol or diesel, whether it is for off or on farm use, and any goods and services tax on consumption which is for business purposes will be fully refunded. This will give farmers a total reduction in fuel tax of around 26c a litre for business purposes and 19c a litre for private use. This reduction in fuel costs applies equally to the trucking industry and to rail transport, so the costs of transporting farm goods to market will be reduced, as will be the costs of goods that farmers have to purchase.

Land transport, of course, is only one element affected by the removal of fuel excise. Farmers have other significant excise costs related to running the farm, such as reliance on aircraft for both transport and agricultural practices such as crop spraying. The costs for all of these will be reduced. As I mentioned earlier, the removal of wholesale sales tax will greatly benefit farmers because, despite a view to the contrary, farmers do pay wholesale sales tax on a whole range of items they buy, and the effective rate they pay is almost 7 per cent.

Payroll tax too affects farmers, as it does everyone, even if they do not pay it directly themselves. The total payroll tax bill of $5.8 billion is a direct cost on, and a disincentive to, employment and, as a consequence, is passed on to the consumer. Labor governments have consistently refused to remove this iniquitous tax, while at the same time declaring the need for the creation of more employment. Instead, Labor policies have led to more than a quarter of a million people losing their jobs in the last 18 months, pushing the rate of unemployment over the 10 per cent mark.

In government, the coalition will actually do something about it, and removing payroll tax is just one element of getting Australia back on the road to recovery. In the meantime, those farmers who are hardest hit by the recession will be given real assistance under a coalition government. Where the current Labor Government has ignominiously meted out only superficial bandaid treatment to suffering rural families—and, again, we heard some of this from Senator Cook—the coalition has recognised their very real, immediate needs.

Family allowance will be doubled for families with combined incomes below $30,000 and the family allowance supplement will be increased by 6 per cent. The assets test will be replaced by an income test in cases of extreme hardship for all family and welfare benefits as well as for Austudy recipients. In addition, the coalition has made a commitment to increase funding to voluntary non-government agencies by $50m to assist with family crisis care.

For those who are fortunate to be earning enough income to pay income tax, personal income tax will be slashed by about 30 per cent by raising the tax free threshold and lowering marginal tax rates. The dependent spouse rebate for families with children will be increased to $1,679 and the remote area allowance and zone rebates will be increased by at least 25 per cent. The assets test will not apply to retirees who wish to retire on the family farm.

Education is a major expense for many farm families who have to send their children away to school. The goods and services tax will not apply to education and a basic 20 per cent grant for all non-government school pupils will be restored. There will be no assets test for isolated children's allowances and the means test free boarding allowance will be increased to $2,400—an increase of some 55 per cent.

So the benefits of the coalition's Fightback economic package are spread across the whole community and farming families will benefit immeasurably. It is a sad reflection on this Labor Government that it has, for the past decade, deliberately promised more than it could ever deliver. So we will shortly see a change of government which will introduce significantly changed circumstances for Australia's farmers. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today one makes the assumption from listening to Opposition senators that they were the only ones who cared about Australians, and rural producers in particular. This is an absolute falsehood, as we have heard many times before. Australian farmers—we have heard this before and I will repeat it—are the most efficient in the world. They are also the most exposed to the international markets of the world's farmers, yet they are not well placed to exploit markets to their advantage. They do not hide behind the common agricultural policy like the EC farmers or hide behind the export enhancement program like the US farmers. Our farmers are out there competing in the open market.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Government was one of the leaders in ensuring that farm production was put into the GATT negotiations. Until recent times primary industry and primary products have not been included in the GATT talks. We have succeeded in doing that. This will bring about some changes and some breakdown in these very restrictive practices of the common agricultural policy and the EEC.

We have also brought about substantial reforms in statutory marketing authorities and research and development corporations and have made them bodies through which market research, product research, marketing strategies and quality control programs for industries can occur. This is the way we have to go.

Let us look at the meat industry. We have opened up the Asian markets, particularly Japan, Korea and Taiwan. There have also been some improvements in Europe and the US. Our exports of beef to Japan have more than doubled since 1983. Our exports to the US have risen by 40 per cent since that time. We have increased our exports to the EC by 20 per cent, which has very restrictive practices. Our sheep meat export has also increased by 50 per cent, despite the significant problems with Saudi Arabia. These matters are being addressed and meetings have been held recently with officials from Saudi Arabia. We have set up better bodies to investigate markets and disseminate market intelligence. These are the sorts of things that will enable primary producers and their organisations to see where they should be going.

Bulk grain handling has been reformed under Labor to save the grain industry $10m a year. It has cut labour inputs by 50 per cent to 80 per cent. Domestic food standards have been rationalised and standardised. Agricultural and veterinary chemicals now have a national clearance process and by the middle of 1992 we will have a national registration process. This will remove duplication and inconsistency and speed up the process of registering useful chemicals.

Animal quarantine and inspection services have been greatly simplified. This is no litany of neglect. We have taken action to protect the productive base of agriculture through land and water programs. These programs have been a success. A fundamental change has happened in the attitudes of land use and land use practices that are occurring in the bush. A recent report of the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee states:

The landcare movement is undoubtedly the most exciting and significant development in land conservation in Australia. Local communities are becoming involved in land conservation all over Australia, playing a more active role in determining the direction of land conservation efforts and taking greater responsibility for tackling land degradation than at any previous time since European settlement.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the Hawke Government established the first national program to combat land degradation in 1983, Federal funding activities to rehabilitate degraded lands and to develop and promote practices that will lead to sustainable land management have increased from $1m to nearly $25m in 1991-92. And this is a Government that does not care about primary producers! What a load of rubbish.

PARA.TAB: The growth in funding to the national soil conservation program has been matched by the enormous growth in the number of landcare and related groups. In June this year it was estimated that there were in excess of 900 landcare groups. This Government enables primary producers to meet together, to work together, to solve the problems that are specific to their local area. We know that wool and wheat growers have had a hard time. Why have they had a hard time?

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the Government, of course.

—It has nothing to do with the Government. The Opposition tends to neglect, or omits to acknowledge, that overseas factors play some part in the primary production aspects and sale of produce from this country. The Opposition has failed to recognise what is happening to our wool in the USSR. The USSR has traditionally been one of Australia's large purchasers of Australian wool. The main bank in the USSR has been bought out—Russia is offering to bail it out. The USSR is in a state of huge crisis. If people think this will not have an impact on our marketing of wool and wheat to the USSR, they must be living in cloud cuckoo land.

PARA.TAB: That certainly has a major impact, and it is the same with our wheat. We have seen the effects of the actions of the EC and the US in dumping. I have to say, though, that there has been an increase in the guaranteed minimum price that has been offered to wheat producers this year. It is now $155 a tonne, and that is estimated to be the break-even point. So things have improved for wheat producers.

Let me turn to the coalition's Fightback, or should I say `Frightpack', package. One of the key implications of this proposed GST is its inflationary impact. We have seen a number of figures touted around as to what this impact would be. One needs to think very carefully about who inflation impacts upon the most. It especially impacts upon low income households. It is quite obvious that currently farming families are low income households. Therefore, the major impact must be upon those families, those people with large families and those who are retired and living off their savings. These groups cannot adjust easily to the changes in price levels. They consume a large proportion of their disposable income. Many farmers would certainly fall into this category at present.

But the Opposition takes no notice of that. In fact, Senator Chapman talked about zero income for some farmers. I ask him: what use is this great tome I have in front of me? Of what use to people who have little or no income are the income tax cuts spelled out here? I suggest that they are of absolutely no use.

We also know, as Senator Walsh pointed out, that, when there is inflation, one of the ways to cut it—the only way that would be left to the Opposition—is to hike up interest rates. We know that the impact that this would have upon primary producers would be very significant.

We have also had the Opposition attempting to divert attention from the whole GST picture and its `Frightpack' package by trying to focus upon the reduction in farm inputs. But it is not prepared to talk about and admit that there are costs in actually running a house on a property. Senator Bjelke-Petersen was very concerned about the effects upon women in primary production. I want her to know how the GST—or the VAT, I should say—will impact upon things such as the price of food for primary producers, the price of their vegetables, the price of their meat, the price of clothing for their children and the price of pens and paper that their children need to take to school. The GST will have a major effect on all these things. Fifteen per cent will be added to the cost of them.
We also need to look briefly at fuel tax and road spending. I do not have the time to read out all of page 82, but it states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it would be irresponsible to allow road users to have a free ride at the expense of the general taxpayer by funding road expenditure entirely from general revenue.
That is wonderful. Honourable senators opposite want to make sure they get the price signals right, but they do not tell us how they will implement this. They say `down the track'.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by saying that members of the Opposition admit, on the last page of their `Frightpack' strategy, that they have been high stake players in putting this forward. This country is not a prize in a poker game, as the Opposition would have us believe, and this Government will not be gambling with Australia's future. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australia Council is a very important Council. Over $50m of Government funding for the arts goes through the Council. About $60m or so is allocated to the Australia Council and about $8m is involved in administrative expenses of one kind or another and in the undertaking of some functions which may or may not be appropriate to the Australia Council. Whether they are or not, the fact remains that about $8m of the funding to the Australia Council for the arts does not end up going to the arts or, at least, to arts groups in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Obviously, this means there are some controversies involved, as there will inevitably be, in the distribution of funding for the arts. In fact, we have seen in recent times some very critical remarks about the Australia Council from the Sydney Theatre Company, as well as criticism of it from the Australian Chamber Orchestra and from various arts groups in Melbourne. The Australian Ballet is also very keen to get the same kind of one-line funding, divorced from the Australia Council, as the Government has arranged for the Australian Opera. So, clearly, it would be wrong to suggest that all in the arts administration garden is lovely.

To that extent I must say that I commend the new Chairman of the Australia Council, Rodney Hall, for his recognition of the need to have a look at the way things are working and at the way things are being done. In the annual report he says:

SPEECH.PARA: At present we are in the process of looking afresh at many of our policies in the light of the need to clarify our role, especially in relation to developments in other sources of public funding for the arts through State and local government bodies.

I commend Mr Hall for recognising the need for that review because, as he knows—and we have discussed this at some length—the coalition is concerned about the cost of the duplicated bureaucracies that are involved in the present arrangements for the funding of the arts. Many arts organisations being funded by the Australia Council also receive funding from State organisations, and some also receive funding from local government organisations. So here we have multiple bureaucracies funding the same organisations.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt, as is evidenced by our Fightback program in which we seek to reduce the administrative costs of funding the arts, that the coalition is determined to see that arts dollars go to arts people and not to competing bureaucracies. We are also of the strong view that arts dollars should be distributed on arts based criteria and not on other criteria.

Having looked through this annual report, I must say that it is quite disturbing to see the number of other activities that the Australia Council has taken unto itself which involve the expenditure of considerable sums of public money on matters not directly involving the funding of arts bodies. It may be that they are very useful functions; it may be that they are an unnecessary diversion of arts money into things which are not of importance and that the money could be better spent by arts organisations themselves. Of course, those judgments can be made only after properly examining the way that the Australia Council conducts itself. Under the coalition that sort of examination will take place.

I must say that I am inclined to the view that the Australia Council's most useful function is in distributing grants to individuals and that it is not useful for it to duplicate the activities of, particularly, State governments in its grants to organisations and bodies such as the Sydney Theatre Company, for example, which is objecting to the nature of its control. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The annual report of the Australian Federal Police is one of the better and more comprehensive reports that have been tabled in the Senate. The report gives a very comprehensive overview in considerable detail of the functions and aims of the Australian Federal Police, the way in which it pursues its objectives and the way in which its functions are being carried out.

PARA.TAB: Following three days of the AIDEX exhibition and related protests, I have some specific interest in matters relating to the Australian Federal Police. In the short time available to me, I have examined the report looking for some trace of training of personnel for dealing with demonstrations and civil disobedience protests—tasks that the Federal Police carried out during the AIDEX protests. Unless it is contained under some other heading, I have been unable to find such a reference in this report. I wish to put on record my concern that this is so. I believe that this is a matter that needs to be followed up. As I have foreshadowed, I will ask the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) to hold an inquiry as a first step in the preparation of a general agreement on some code of conduct to be followed by both protesters and police. I trust that this will now receive some higher priority in the activities of the Australian Federal Police.

In view of the somewhat critical comments I have made in the past, I wish to take this opportunity to also put on record an incident at the end of AIDEX in which the Australian Federal Police was involved and which throws a different light on its personnel. One protester used eleven 44-gallon drums rather colourfully decorated with peace slogans and other graphic motives to take part in the protests. These were thrown behind a cyclone fence by the police. At the end of the three days, the owner, Mr Benny Zable, asked for these drums to be returned. I went with him, met with the sergeant of police and, after some friendly negotiation, that sergeant detailed 11 members of his force to retrieve the drums from behind the fence and have them carried around the building and deposited for protesters to take away. I believe that this was a very fitting and positive conclusion to the protests at the AIDEX site. I wished I had had a camera. It was beautiful to see 11 policemen each carrying a 44-gallon drum decorated with peace symbols. I believe that it augurs well for the inquiry and the future negotiations towards a conduct of civil disobedience demonstrations so that we can not only protect our community's civil rights but also allow the police in a reasonable way to pursue their law enforcement duties.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: POLITICAL BROADCASTS AND POLITICAL DISCLOSURES BILL 1991

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating yet again the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991. The original Bill, which sought to ban at all times, 365 days of the year, any paid political advertisements on radio and television, was introduced into the Senate on 4 June. The original Bill had some 23 clauses and was guillotined through the House of Representatives prior to the winter recess.

PARA.TAB: We have yet again seen the outrageous use of the guillotine. Here we have a piece of legislation which seeks to limit freedom of political expression and freedom of speech in this country, yet the Government saw fit to guillotine the Bill. Not only are those opposite to be castigated for this sort of thing but also, and more importantly, the Australian Democrats who have supported them. It is patently obvious that the Democrats have dumped on their new senator, Senator Sowada, who, on behalf of the Democrats, gave evidence to the Senate Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures that the Australian Democrats recognise the need to contain costs and minimise corruption—with which, I might say, no-one would disagree—but were opposed outright to any ban on political advertising.

One reason the Democrats have a new Leader in this place is that the previous Leader did a deal with Senator Bolkus to support political advertising. In other words, they were prepared to trade democracy for self-interest. I might say that they have not changed their spots one bit, but they have dumped on their new senator.

At about this time last year I asked the Minister, Senator Bolkus, whether the Executive Director of the Labor Party, Mr Bob Hogg, had directed the Government to introduce legislation to ban paid political advertising on television and radio. I further asked him since when unelected Party officials had got to the stage of telling this Government what to do. Senator Bolkus responded that no such legislation was planned or being drafted—just 12 months ago. So much for the honesty of this Government. It is obviously following in the footsteps of its own Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who has a record of having stated that he has lied to the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not saying that was a wrong answer, are you?

— We are not dumb. It was absolutely transparent. This should be called the Hogg Bill. It should be called the Hogg Bill for two reasons. It was promoted by Mr Hogg, the unelected Party apparatchik, and the net result is that it puts the snout of the Labor Party more into the trough of the public purse. It is looking to get more money not only from the taxpayer, but also from sources such as the beleaguered television stations.

PARA.TAB: The original Bill, as I mentioned, was to ban at all times all political advertising on radio and television—365 days of the year. It applied not only to political parties but also to any interest groups in the community. No advertisement could contain any matter which referred to any present or past political party or the actions of a party. No advertisement would be permitted which included matter intended, or likely, to affect voting at any future Commonwealth, State or local government election. In part 3, tacked on the end, were a few clauses relating to disclosures of donations to political parties—four clauses out of 23.

All this hogwash—all this nonsense—from the Minister and the Government about corruption is absolutely phoney. The coalition made its position crystal clear from the outset and we have not deviated from those principles and do not intend to deviate. Firstly, we would not accept any proposition whatsoever which sought to limit in any way freedom of political expression or freedom of speech in this country. There could be no compromise on a matter which struck at the very heart of democracy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note from Senator Cook's interjection that he does not even understand this. What Senator Cook is not saying is that this Government, which has been totally discredited with its handling of the economy and has brought this country to its knees, is not averse to going back and putting its snout in the trough simply to promote itself at the next election without having to seek funds elsewhere. It is going to the taxpayer.

PARA.TAB: Before the interjection I mentioned two principles. One was that we would not support in any way anything that sought to limit freedom of political expression, and the second was that we would support disclosure of donations provided all parties were treated fairly and equitably, there was protection against coercion of a prospective donor and there was protection against discrimination of a donor to a political party by a hostile government or a third party once that donation had been made known. I noticed in the Senate Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures that Senator Schacht tried to discredit that proposition, but anyone—any human being—knows that that can happen.

In view of that position, Dr Hewson wrote to the Prime Minister asking that the Bill be split. At the same time, I approached the then Leader of the Democrats with a similar request. The Prime Minister refused, adopting the Senator Bolkus line that the bans on advertising and disclosure were related. Senator Powell also refused the request, again adopting the Senator Bolkus line. I subsequently moved in the Senate on 20 June that the Bill be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs during the winter recess. This was rejected by the Labor Government and the Democrats. They did not want the content of that Bill aired in the public arena.

It was of concern to the Opposition that the general public did not know what was in the Bill. It is not surprising; no-one in the community would have imagined that a government of this country would introduce such an outrageous Bill. Community groups were informed of its contents by the Opposition and a task force was established under the able chairmanship of my colleague Senator Olsen to conduct its own inquiries. The evidence, with one exception, was overwhelmingly in favour of opposing the ban on advertising because it attacked, in a most unprecedented way, freedom of speech in Australia.

The Democrats were prepared to sacrifice freedom of speech. Senator Powell subsequently wrote to me and requested that we agree to refer the Bill to a committee—a born again—a proposal that she had previously rejected. The reason she made the proposal, of course, was that she was under attack because of the position she had taken of sacrificing her principles simply for self-interest. By this time, the ground swell of opposition in this country was of such magnitude that only a committee of inquiry to look at all aspects of the Bill would be satisfactory. We were delighted to see that, because it supported what we had tried to do prior to the winter recess.

The Labor Party appointed as the Committee's chairman an ex-Party apparatchik, ex-State secretary of the ALP, Senator Schacht. Its other members were Senator Faulkner, ex-Assistant General Secretary of the ALP in New South Wales, and Senator Aulich—the claim to fame of the latter being the inordinate amount of time he spends in Canberra, and holding the record of receiving $15,000 over 12 months as chairman of a Senate standing committee, 10 times more than anybody else.
