TALK.START.PARA: —What allegations are you making? Are you saying that is unfair to you?

—What I am saying is that they are all in the same boat. We have a Minister coming into this place and talking about abuse of the public purse—and we hear it all the time—and one of these people is put on a committee.
—I am glad to have that interjection. I think he lives in Tasmania.
—He was the Minister for Electoral Affairs in the State Government.

—He would have been a beauty over there. The purpose of inquiries by standing or select committees should be to receive evidence and come to a decision based on the evidence. Naturally there will always be different interpretations as to the evidence received.

PARA.TAB: However, the conclusion reached by the Labor majority on this Select Committee called into question the integrity of the committee system. It was a farce. One has only to read the evidence. The conclusion was quite clearly predetermined, which meant that a lot of genuine Australian citizens and community groups wasted an awful lot of time and money preparing submissions. It meant that a lot of taxpayers' money was wasted getting people to Canberra to give evidence. It meant that Hansard wasted its time, as did the able support staff.

The Labor Party has a long history of pulling these stunts. The last one in which I was involved, with a similar outcome, was the inquiry into Sydney Airport. Today the Minister, Senator Collins, signed a majority report opposing the building of the third runway. When I raised it with him and said, `I never expected that you, of all people, would sign a report like that', his response was, `You don't want to stand in the way of a potentially brilliant political career'. He followed the Party line; he did not listen to the evidence.

I made a remark in this Senate at the time that, if that was indicative of the dishonesty which permeated members of the Labor Party on committees, I would not waste my time in the future going on a committee. As I said, it put the whole integrity of the Committee system at risk.

Some 127 submissions were received by that Committee and 38 witnesses appeared before it. From the weight of evidence it was quite apparent that the ban on advertising should have been abandoned altogether and that fair and equitable treatment of donors was required. In addition, notwithstanding comments in the report, discrimination should have been addressed. I notice that, while even the majority Labor report acknowledged that, no attempt has been made in any of the amendments before the Committee to address it.

During the debate on the Select Committee report, Government speakers questioned why I personally put the coalition case at the inquiry. I know this is difficult for the Labor Party because of the control exercised over it by shadowy non-elected figures and the ACTU. But I made it clear that policy is determined by the coalition—by the Liberal Party—by elected members and senators who are ultimately responsible to the electors. The Labor Party, of course, is not. I remember well the leader of the Australian Workers Union in Queensland threatening elected members that if they supported the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) in his leadership bid they would be politically dead. I am sure, Mr Acting Deputy President, coming from the other side, the other faction, you would not have appreciated that remark.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—I was not aware of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You must have been away on one of your many trips, Mr Acting Deputy President. It was my role as the Opposition spokesperson for administrative services to present the coalition view. Other witnesses who appeared included the Federal directors of both the Liberal and National parties, notwithstanding remarks made here by people such as Senator Aulich who intimated only last week that they did not appear or that they had to be forced to appear. Nothing could be further from the truth. It simply reflects the attitude of those opposite to the Senate Select Committee.

PARA.TAB: The Labor Party has now decided it will adopt a back to the wall approach, a desperate measure by a desperate and failed government. It has shown it is totally incapable of managing its own budget, in the same way as it has shown itself to be totally incapable of managing the Australian economy. Is it any wonder that we are in serious economic difficulties in Australia today? If it cannot organise its own budget, how can it organise and manage the Budget of the economy of Australia? Because of its inability to control its own finances, it is in financial difficulties with its Federal Secretariat in New South Wales.

In Canberra it has sold 34 per cent of John Curtin House to a group which initially was called `Second Ox-Tail Pty Ltd'. Have honourable senators ever heard a name like that? It is a subsidiary of the ACTU. Subsequently, that name has come under the direct control of the ACTU. The ACTU bought 34 per cent of John Curtin House for $4m. In New South Wales, the Labor Party managed to invest $3.8m in a building in Sussex Street, which has run it into debt to the tune of $7m. It is pretty brilliant stuff to be able to convert an investment of $3.8m into a debt of $7m. It puts the ALP in the same league as Estate Mortgage and Christopher Skase and all the other failed entrepreneurs. The difference is that the Labor Party has not only failed itself in the mismanagement of its financial affairs but also destroyed the Australian economy.

The coalition is opposed to compulsion. This Bill is all about compulsion. It wants to compel television stations, which have been through enormous difficulties—some are still in the hands of liquidators—to provide free time. We are opposed to that. It raises a whole lot of questions. If we request a television station to provide free time for political parties, why not ask the advertising agencies? Why not go next to the newspapers, and so on? People would argue—and I would be one of them—that this is the probable next step. It is only a matter of time before the Labor Party and the Democrats will come back into this place and say, `Listen, we have done all this, but the cost of running elections is still very expensive. It costs some thousands of dollars for a one-page advertisement in the Australian Financial Review, the Sydney Morning Herald or the Courier-Mail. Let us ask them for free space'. They will not just ask; they will demand it by legislation. It is appalling. It also compels taxpayers to contribute to political parties, and we are opposed to that.

The coalition stated that it would support disclosure provided there was adequate protection against coercion and intimidation, and provided all donors to all political parties were treated equitably. I do not think anybody can argue with that proposition. The claim was made by Senator Schacht that no tangible proof was presented with regard to coercion and intimidation. Mr Andrew Robb, who gave evidence, refused to give specific details on intimidation. Why? The answer is very simple: because it would have been a breach of faith to individuals who genuinely feared intimidation. It is very real. I see Senator Beahan laughing over there. With his background with the trade union movement, he would know what intimidation is about.

Senator Schacht claims to be the great exponent of civil liberties and human rights; he is forever standing up in here and speaking about Myanmar and South Africa. A Mr Sherry gave evidence before the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures. This young man went to do a PhD course. He got the blessing of the trade unions and his tutor at the University of Queensland because he was going to do his PhD on the effects of the SEQEB strike on the people in Queensland who had been put out of work. He was welcomed because the trade unions thought, `Here is one of us. He will give us a great story'. I presume that is why Mr Sherry was called before the inquiry. But it backfired because it turned out, according to the evidence of Mr Sherry, that when he got among the union books and looked at the minutes he found incredible scams where money that had been handed in for the strikers had been diverted by the ALP into election campaign funds for ALP members. He was threatened by the unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did the Cooke inquiry say? Nothing.

—I am glad that Senator Jones interjected. The Cooke inquiry said that $20,000 was diverted from those funds. Mr Sherry showed $40,000 to a particular member, whom I will not name in this place for other reasons.
—Why didn't he put his evidence to the Cooke inquiry?

—Senator Schacht interjects and says,`Why didn't he go to the Cooke inquiry?'. I thought Mr Sherry had made it very clear; it was because he was scared. He had been threatened. He had tape recordings. Senator Aulich said to him, `Why did you take a tape recording? Don't you know it is illegal?'. Mr Sherry said, `Yes, I knew it was illegal, but I thought I was going to be dead and I wanted some evidence to give my solicitor in the event of my ending up in Moreton Bay with concrete boots'. Mr Sherry was nervous and he was not game to go to the police. He gave evidence in front of this inquiry and he was intimidated by Senator Schacht in a way that Senator Schacht should be ashamed of.

PARA.TAB: In my own evidence I referred to remarks made in the Senate by Senator Robert Ray with regard to Mr Lindsay Fox some years ago when Senator Ray—who is a very practical, pragmatic man, and very direct and honest, I would say—warned that a large donation to the Liberal Party by Lindsay Fox could well have had an adverse effect on his harmonious relationships with the unions.

A pensioner who lives in a country town in far north Queensland sent the Liberal Party, through me, a donation of $10. This was passed on to the Queensland Treasurer of the Party, who duly sent her a receipt. The pensioner wrote a letter back to me because she was worried that, if it were known that she had made a contribution, retribution would occur in the street in which she lives. As you would know, Mr Acting Deputy President, that can happen in a small country town.

What about the infamous gold tax lunch? No-one will convince me or anyone else that what occurred at that luncheon with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was not coercion to make a donation in return for favourable treatment of mates within the gold industry. As it turned out—and this is exactly what happened—two years notice of the gold tax was given, thus allowing people who made the contribution the ability to high-grade their mining operations. I can recall commenting on it in this chamber at that time because I thought it was strange that that sort of warning notice would be given of the imposition of a tax which enabled people to high-grade resources. I might say that this is not the way to husband resources in this country. Of course, we now know the reason.

I might also say that it is a human reaction to take a dislike to someone who contributes to another political party and to view with suspicion the reason for that donation. It is a human reaction. All I am saying is that intimidation is a real thing and we must ensure that the amendments to this legislation are such that they protect people against coercion and intimidation.

The next point relates to what is meant by `fair and equitable'. The Australian Labor Party is the political arm of the trade union movement. The majority of funds provided to the Labor Party come from the trade unions in two forms. The first is by way of affiliation fees. The question is often asked, `Why do the trade unions affiliate with the Labor Party?'. Someone interjected here earlier about the Cooke report. Honourable senators should read the Cooke report because it points out why the Federated Clerks Union of Australia affiliated with the ALP at a cost to members of $30,000 a year or $2.05 to $2.10 per head. At a meeting with Premier Goss it was claimed that this was done because it enabled the union to influence government policy and have ready access to Ministers. That is the very thing that I have heard Senator Bolkus claim is a problem with the Liberal Party. That is why the Clerks Union affiliated.

The second form is by way of donations. In both cases the Labor Party has the benefit of obtaining what is virtually tax free money. Union dues are tax deductible. Therefore, any affiliation fees come from tax deductible moneys. Donations from the trade union movement are of a tax-free nature. It is not generally recognised in the community that all income received by trade unions is tax-free money. A trade union would pay no tax even if it owned, for example, the Gold Coast Casino, or a slab of it.

If a trade union sells a major building which it owns in the central business district of Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane or Perth, it does not pay capital gains tax. In my own home State of Queensland and, presumably, in other States, the unions are absolved from paying land tax. They pay none of the taxes that are charged to the ordinary person involved in a commercial enterprise.

Because the Labor Party has this kick start, this head start to everyone else, it is apparent that the only way to move to levelling the playing field in regard to donations to other political parties is to permit tax deductibility of donations to political parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Uncapped for all their rich mates.
—Senator Schacht says `rich mates'. He should look at his Prime Minister hobnobbing with his rich mates. He is famous for his rich mates—a fat cigar in his mouth and the lot.
—You want tax deductibility for your rich mates.
—Order! Senator Parer, you are entitled to some protection.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I think I needed that protection. The Labor Party finds itself in a shambles over this Bill. The Bill initially had 23 clauses of which 17 were devoted to banning advertising and five to disclosure. We now have before us 37 Government amendments to a Bill of 23 clauses. The amendments, particularly those in relation to free time, are an absolute nightmare and they will prove to be if, regrettably, this Bill becomes an Act.

PARA.TAB: If Government senators just read the views of the community as reflected in editorials over the past couple of days in the Sydney Morning Herald, the Australian, the Australian Financial Review and the Courier-Mail, they would abandon this Bill and start all over again. Failing that, the new amendments to the Bill should be referred to where the Bill should have gone in the first place, to where the Government and the Australian Democrats refused to send it—that is, the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.
This Bill was very ably summed up in the editorial in yesterday's Australian, which stated that it is less ominous—which it is—than it was previously. It continued:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is a compromise that contains unacceptable restrictions and too many contradictions.

The editorial quotes the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations as describing the Bill as `disgraceful, of doubtful legality and highly unprincipled'. I note that the Courier-Mail states quite categorically that the television stations have now been conscripted to the cause. That means that the Labor Party wants not only to put its snout back into the public trough but also to go into the trough to get money from commercial enterprises, which is a totally inappropriate way to run Federal election campaigns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Everybody on the Opposition benches seems to ignore the fact that this debate has been going on for an awfully long time. It has been going on in this Parliament for roughly four years and it has been going on for a lot longer in the more general political sphere, as anybody who has been around long enough will recall. But one could be forgiven for thinking that nothing has changed since the initial report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters first examined this issue. The same sort of rhetoric is being used as if a total ban were being proposed. This is despite the fact that the amendments to the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill are proposing something quite different.

PARA.TAB: The proposals emanating from the report of the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters, from the Government response to that report, from the initial legislation, from the Select Committee and its report and from the current amendments to the initial legislation have been variously described by the Opposition as draconian, a threat to democracy and an attack on the basic right of freedom of speech.

Those comments are delivered by Opposition members with all the self-righteous fervour of people who really believe that the proposals mark the end of civilisation as we know it and that they alone are above reproach when it comes to the difficult question, the vexed question, of political fundraising. But those comments ring hollow for those of us who have followed the Opposition responses to electoral reform over the years—an Opposition which has opposed all attempts at reform, not just in this area but in almost every other significant area of electoral reform. They ring hollow for those of us who know about the fundraising record of the Liberal Party of Australia and, more particularly, the National Party in Queensland, New South Wales and Tasmania.

The Opposition has steadfastly refused to recognise the basic problem which was the subject of the initial report, has been the subject of the inquiry of the Select Committee into the Bill and is the subject of these amendments to the Bill now before the Senate. The problem remains one of pressing concern to all who care about the integrity of the political system, which members of the Opposition appear not to. It is against this background that their protests are so much humbug. I take no notice of them. I urge anybody who is bored enough to be watching this debate to do the same.

Let us firstly look at what this Bill and the amendments are trying to do. We need to be aware of what the Bill is now proposing. Some of the comments that have been made appear to have been directed either at the original proposal, at what the report of the Joint Committee proposed or at what the Select Committee proposed. This amended Bill is proposing full disclosure of all political donations. That part of it has not changed; it has been a consistent part of the Bill since it was introduced. In fact, it was recommended by the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters in the first place.

The Bill also proposes the provision of limited free time on commercial and national TV and radio networks, to be funded by those networks as a community service obligation. The free time is for the provision of information in a talking heads style with ads to be run concurrently on all stations. The idea of concurrent viewing is so that the costs overall will be reduced both for the ABC and for the commercial networks. The proposal is similar to current arrangements in both France and England, except for the concurrent running of the ads.

The Government has taken up the broad thrust of the Joint Committee's report and some of the specific recommendations of the Select Committee. The Bill is proposed against a backdrop of an emerging problem, which has two elements. The first is the exponential increase in the costs of campaigning and the second is the potential for corruption as parties are forced to meet these increasing costs.

As an indication of the nature of cost increases, the cost to political parties of TV and radio advertising between the 1984 and the 1987 Federal Elections rose by 137 per cent while public funding, which is indexed and related to the CPI, rose by only 31.9 per cent. In other words, we are facing a situation where the costs of television, in particular, and radio advertising are rising exponentially far faster than the CPI and far faster than public funding where public funding in fact exists.

TALK.START.PARA: —Probably because of public funding.

—It is nothing to do with public funding. These are TV rates comparable with the TV rates charged to other users of TV at the same time. On current prices, a 60-second advertisement in a prime time spot on Sydney TV costs about $12,000, and in fact can cost a lot more under certain circumstances. At the last election, the political parties jointly spent over $19m on broadcast advertising. These figures are staggering but, on overseas experience, they are likely to get worse. The other side of the problem is the potential for corruption as increased pressure is placed on the political parties to raise campaign funds.
—We have found that out with WA Inc.
—The gold lunch.

—Or the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct, the Independent Commission Against Corruption inquiry in New South Wales or the Rouse Royal Commission in Tasmania—all of which involved the Liberal Party. This potential for corruption has already been well demonstrated overseas, most notably as a result of the Watergate scandal in the US and the Recruit scandal in Japan. It has led to a situation where fair observers of those political systems, despite attempts by both countries at regulation, believe that there is endemic corruption in those systems and that, in many cases, political candidates are bought.

PARA.TAB: But what is of more concern are early indications that Australia is not free from such scandal, albeit on a smaller scale. The Fitzgerald inquiry in Queensland uncovered a litany of unsavoury practices and the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption found the same in northern New South Wales. The Tasmanian Royal Commission has not led to charges being laid, but charges have independently and successfully been laid which are related to that Royal Commission. The WA Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters, although it has yet to come down with its final report, has demonstrated the pressures on governments, politicians and parties of all persuasions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of all persuasions! There haven't been too many of our persuasions up yet—nor will there be.

—The Liberal Party has yet to be inquired into; that is the final part of the inquiry. Senator Panizza should not smile too much yet, because that is still to come. While all of this may be of no concern to the Opposition, it is of grave concern to thinking people in Australia—people who worry about the integrity of the political process. It is for example, of grave concern to Tony Fitzgerald who said this in his report:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there is an urgent need to consider establishing a public register of political donations. Lack of such a register has given rise to community suspicion and lack of confidence in the political process.
It is also of great concern to the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales where ICAC Commissioner Rodin said:

So long as substantial donations can be made to political parties or candidates without disclosure, they can be used to purchase influence. The law that allows secret political donations, creates conditions conducive to corrupt conduct.
He went on to say:
As increasingly large sums of money become necessary for successful political campaigns—
he is recognising there the element of cost, which Senator Parer seems to reject out of hand—

the problem will grow. It must be faced and dealt with firmly and openly. To allow large secret donations to political parties or candidates is but one step removed from allowing secret deals with political parties or candidates.

Against this background the Joint Committee, then later on the Select Committee, and the Government concluded that there is an obvious and urgent need for full and effective disclosure of all political donations. But that in itself is not enough. There is also a need to curb in some way the pressure for the exponential increase in campaign costs which are a feature particularly of those democracies which permit the unregulated use of TV and radio political advertising.

PARA.TAB: The case for disclosure has been put by Fitzgerald and Rodin—I have already quoted from them—but perhaps more importantly common sense and I believe public opinion demand it. There is also a need to apply such disclosure in a way which prevents abuses such as have occurred in the United States where political action committees have burgeoned as a way of getting around attempts at regulating political fundraising following the Watergate scandal. Political action committees have been set up to avoid that regulation. The abuse is even more blatant in New South Wales—it is not atypical of the Liberal Party's approach to this whole question—where a company, Community Polling, was set up in order to blatantly disregard the New South Wales disclosure laws by laundering money to independent candidates.

It is amazing that whenever or wherever, and for that matter in whatever form, disclosure is proposed it is opposed by the Opposition. At the Federal level the Opposition opposed the current disclosure laws. It opposes disclosure at every opportunity. Disclosure has been rejected by every Liberal Party in every State.

TALK.START.PARA: —We support your disclosure.
—You are now supporting disclosure? You did not make that clear in your speech.
—I did make it very clear in my speech.
—You are supporting disclosure?
—We support disclosure under the conditions I put in the speech.
—You support disclosure with conditions; I take it you are moving amendments to reflect that?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—Senator Beahan, I suggest you address your remarks through the Chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I beg your pardon. I will do that in future. The public has a right to know who is funding future governments and those who have influence through positions in Parliament. It is not exclusively an issue of the Left: Barry Goldwater, that doyen of the extreme right in the United States, in commenting on what he saw as public concerns arising out of the Watergate scandal said this:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not. . . the people. . . but moneyed interests who are setting the nation's political agenda and are influencing the position of candidates on the important issues of the day.
Even John Hewson has supported disclosure, although he has equivocated under pressure from some of his Party's apparatchiks within the Party proper. Initially, Dr Hewson said:

My disposition is to support disclosure and you know, as long as it is done in an equitable fashion, and in those terms, you know, I've so far not had to comment very much on that particular item of the decision.
Then he flipped from that position and said:
I am worried about the use of disclosure rules, the information that comes. . . as a basis for intimidation.
That picks up Senator Parer's position. I do not know whether Senator Parer or Andrew Robb saw Dr Hewson, but somebody got to him. Later, he flipped again and said:
I have said it very clearly, that my disposition is, of course, in favour of disclosure.

Senator Hill has made similar comments, saying that his predisposition is towards disclosure. When Dr Hewson and Senator Hill have said that, they have made no comment about intimidation, which is one of those shibboleths which Senator Parer and other members of the Liberal Party consistently raise, despite the fact that there is no proof of it and they have been unable to raise any proof, despite their attempts to do so. The attention of the Senate needs to be drawn to that.

PARA.TAB: It seems that everything that Senator Parer and others are saying is suffused with paranoia about unions. He says that they are the major source of fundraising for the Labor Party. They are not. They are a very minor source of fundraising for the Labor Party, and a diminishing one. It is a source which has been diminishing for a number of years now. It is rather like the claims that are made ad nauseam by Senator Bishop and others every time we have an inquiry into an election—about cemetery voting and multiple voting. They make the claims, but they have never yet come up with the evidence. In the case of intimidation, they have not come up with the evidence. They failed to come up with the evidence in front of the Select Committee. They have failed in this, just as they have in all of the other claims that they have made.

There is a need to curb the increasing costs of campaigning, particularly the costs relating to television. I have already indicated the nature of those cost increases. The effect of this is to cut out individuals and most community groups from the political process. At the last election $1.75m was spent by all third parties on television and radio political advertising—only $60,000 of this was spent by community groups. The normal rule of thumb—I was a State secretary of the ALP once, so I have some idea of this—is that, unless on current rates you spend $100,000, you do not get the reach and frequency necessary to have any sort of impact at all on television, so many of those community groups have wasted their money.

It certainly means that many of those groups are unable to be part of the political process. It means that money, not people, is setting the political agenda. In this regard, it is nonsense to talk about the Government's proposal being an attack on free speech. There is nothing free about television advertising, as I have already indicated. Clearly, only the wealthy can afford it and only the wealthy, therefore, can afford the sort of freedom talked about in such pious terms by the Opposition.

It is never conceded by anyone in the Opposition that in the whole question of political advertising Australia, with its current lack of regulation, is the odd one out. There is nothing unusual about it; there is nothing unique about the Government's attempts to provide some sort of regulation to prevent the potentially dangerous abuses of the political system. Regulation is the norm in comparable developed democracies; it is not the exception.

Of the 19 comparable countries that were looked at by the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters and the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures only four permit paid political advertising. One of them—Canada—limits it to the campaign period, but the rest of them have bans of various sorts. Does the Opposition really believe that John Major's England—or for that matter, Margaret Thatcher's England—is undemocratic; or that Mitterrand's France is undemocratic; or that Sweden, Austria, Italy, Norway or Denmark have draconian laws? Yet all of these countries limit in some way, or ban outright, political advertising.

Even the USA, which permits political advertising, has laws regulating the prices charged to political parties—something which might have been a good idea before the networks started taking political parties for a ride, as they have done over the last few years. Recently there have been renewed cries in the USA for further regulation of fundraising, of political advertising, following the abuse of earlier attempts, following Watergate, to cap expenditure—attempts which have been undermined by the growth of political action committees.

Finally, the Opposition argues that these actions are being proposed because the ALP is broke. The ALP has always supported disclosure, not only of political donations but also of MPs' pecuniary interests. Both have been consistently opposed by conservative parties, Federal and State. While the ALP is under financial restraint from the many elections that it has had to face so, too, are all other political parties. I suggest that the Liberal Party and the National Party are in a lot worse trouble than is the ALP. The ALP is not broke. It will be able to fund the next election and it will be able to fund elections in the future.

Furthermore, honourable senators opposite should not forget that the ALP, through this very decision, is denying itself an advantage that it had over the other political parties. In successive elections since 1983 we have consistently beaten the Opposition hands down in the area of television advertising. The proposition that we exclusively are broke is a furphy put around to distract attention from the fact that the Opposition is nervous about disclosing who gives it money.

The Government has introduced this Bill, firstly, to provide a clean political system free from undue influence and the potential for bribery; secondly, to provide a level playing field so that all people can participate in the political process; and, thirdly, to ensure that bank balances do not set political agendas and that the impact of secret donations is reduced. I urge the Senate to support the Bill and its amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991. This piece of legislation has been before a number of committees—select committees and the like. We have a series of amendments to the Government's legislation. The Government keeps claiming in this Parliament that this legislation has been before us for four years—has been before the Parliament since May this year—yet the Bill has come back today with 37 amendments. It is very difficult for the Opposition and other political parties to draft amendments to the Government's Bill. The reason is that the Government is changing the goal posts all the time.

PARA.TAB: Another set of amendments to this Bill is being drafted. When we want amendments prepared to dovetail into the Bill, we have to wait for the Government to get more drafting done. As we are speaking on this Bill today, the Government is again drafting further amendments to the legislation. Does that not demonstrate the absolute farce of this deal and the incompetence of the Government in handling this matter? It has not quite determined which tack it will take. Further amendments are placed on the table at this hour of the night—6 o'clock—and the Government expects other political parties to have looked at the Bill plus the amendments, made a judgment on them and proceeded to have their own amendments drafted as a result of that. It is inefficiency and incompetence to the fore.

This legislation is before the House clearly for the purposes of overcoming the quite difficult financial circumstances of the Australian Labor Party. That is the core of the problem. We are here to debate, and I hope stop, the Federal Government's manipulation of the democratic electoral processes of this country for its own party ends. It is doing so quite brazenly; it is doing so without any compunction; it shows no concern for those it will disadvantage or for the democratic process of free speech which it will cripple. It is displaying for all to see that we have a socialist government in power which totally lacks social conscience, capacity, ability and competence to get a Bill before this Parliament right.

This is certainly a first for Australia and a first step away from true democracy. Until now, Australia has set a proud example of democracy to the world. One has only to witness the hundreds of thousands of migrants who have come out here over the years and sought our democratic shelter from communist regimes and dictatorships. These people sadly learned the hard way the value of freedom of speech; of the right to be politically informed; of the necessity of not stifling political debate; and of the effects of being without such protections. They understand the true benefits that come from a free democratic society.

This Bill is an example of how the abuse of power, created by a desperation to hold on to that power—that is what the migrants overseas walked away from; they came to Australia to get away from that type of country, that type of system—can turn the resources of a decaying government to attempting the passage of manipulative, unprincipled legislation. I say this because, while public debate over the issue has raged for most of this year now, the real reason for the legislation has never been in doubt. I wish to add here that when I say `public debate has raged', I mean that the community and the constitutional lawyers, the Human Rights Commissioner and the Law Council of Australia have raged against this Bill, while the Government alone has kept pushing this legislation.

The real reason we are debating such an appalling piece of legislation—there are 37 amendments to the original Bill and further amendments to this legislation have been put on file within the last 10 minutes—is that, purely and simply, the Labor Party is more than a little short of money. That is the bottom line.

For example, we had revealed to us late last week, with the help of Senator Loosley, that the New South Wales branch of the ALP is technically insolvent with debts of some $7m. That is a lot of prime time television advertising, I might add. All around the country, the Labor Party is on the nose coping with the desertion of many of its major donors, given the policy direction it has taken; the cost it has inflicted on small, medium and large business; and the destruction of jobs in this country. The bread and butter campaign fodder—the donations of the trade unionists—has also fallen away as union membership drops to just 31 per cent of the working population.

Let us not misunderstand what this is all about. The ALP, the political wing of the union movement—the Australian Labor Party was formed by the trade union movement to be its political wing—has contracting membership down to 31 per cent. Donors are walking away and closing up their cheque books. I am sure everyone would understand why it is doing that. So, quite cynically, this Government has suddenly decided that elections are too expensive to fight by the present rules and Australians are asked to swallow that the Government, unexpectedly seeing the light with all the fervour of a born-again Christian, has nothing at all to do with its coffers being empty. That is really starting to test and stretch the imagination. That is about as believable as the tooth fairy, the Easter bunny and Father Christmas all rolled into one.

Of course elections cost all parties far more than they would wish them to. All parties would appreciate less expensive campaigns. However, this side of the chamber is definitely not prepared to throw out something as critical as freedom of speech in a probably useless attempt to achieve such a result. Only the Hawke Government is determined to take this path by banning all paid electronic political advertising during Federal, State and local government elections and by-elections.

To even the most trusting of people, surely this is a highly suspicious and most hypocritical move from a government which has ploughed hundreds of thousands of dollars into electronic advertising, increasingly outspending other major parties in the area? In the last Federal election campaign, which party increased its electronic advertising more than any other political party? Members of the Labor Party did. What hypocrites, given their track record last year, to be in this House now proposing this legislation.

The Government has come to its decision despite much evidence before the Senate Select Committee that campaign costs will most probably remain at the same high level and whatever funds are available will simply be directed to direct mail, print media and telemarketing. So the picture is quite clear. This legislation is a very sudden and far from altruistic decision of the Labor Government. It did not ever hint that it considered electronic political advertising had made previous campaigns too expensive. No, it was far too busy having the commercials produced to keep raising the amount spent in this very area, in contrast to other major parties which are shown to have either contained or reduced their budget allocation for electronic advertising. That is in the report presented to this Senate.

Let there be no doubt, if the Labor Party had the available funds at this moment it would far outspend us again at the next election using its usual massive amount of electronic advertising. If it had the money, it would not be putting this legislation before this House. But it does not have the money, which is the reason for this blatant attempt at changing the rules. In an attempt to muddy the waters, the Government coated the advertising legislation ban with some disclosure clauses and then refused to split the Bill when it was pointed out that the two subject areas stood alone.

Then we had the sight of the Government jumping up and down saying that they were linked to bring an end to political corruption. Unfortunately for the Government, it could produce no evidence of proven Federal political corruption, which apparently so needed stamping out to cut campaign costs, and introducing an advertising ban was the only way, and it did not deliver disclosure laws strong enough or wide enough to stamp out any such corruption.

As we wound our way through the Select Committee hearings, it became abundantly clear that the Government's disclosure proposals were no less cynical than the advertising ban proposal. Disclosure the Labor way is farcical. It naturally leaves the unions and the ALP still hidden from view, with the tax advantage inherent in the union movement there to soothe the ALP's way, while union members—despite only 44 per cent of them voting for ALP—are to remain forced to contribute to it, without ever knowing what percentage of their union levy makes its way into campaign funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—It is a shame. That is not democracy at work; that is compulsion. There is no tax deductibility clause for all donors to political parties, which would go some way to levelling the playing field against tax deductible union contributions. There is no attempt to have the Auditor-General, for example, spot audit third parties involved in the political process who receive government grants. So there has been no attempt to ensure that governments do not provide taxpayers' funds to third parties to campaign on their behalf. No attempt has been made to introduce penalties for intimidation against organisations and persons who do not wish to donate or any attempt to increase penalties significantly in recognition of the severity of that crime.

PARA.TAB: No resolve has been evident on behalf of the Government to tackle full, fair and equitable disclosure. It has run away from delivering that as fast as it is chasing the introduction of the ad ban. This substantiates my earlier point that we are dealing with a government which is completely submerged in the quest of self-preservation, not in delivering government for the good of the community it serves.

If the Government had been fair dinkum about corruption, the disclosure laws would have been drafted far wider than they have been thus far. The penalties would have been far more effective than they are currently. That is the way in which the Government should have focused its attention on corruption of the political process, not by trying to artificially link in a political advertising ban. To save itself it has to eradicate the perceived advantage of the coalition, which is likely to attract a far greater level of donations and aid because of its winning approach—the Fightback approach it will take to the next election campaign. The simple fact is that next time around there will be more people out there willing to support the coalition than the Labor Party—and well the Labor Party knows it. For the first time in decades, the Labor Party does not have the money to outspend its competition. That is a fact, pure and simple. So it seeks to chip away at democracy for its own ends. It could be termed `playing with dirty pool'.

The final offer we have before us, following the recommendation of the Labor members of the Select Committee, is a 17-minute per day, free time proposal with talking heads. But that was changed, as were three recommendations from the majority report on the tabling statement put down by the Chairman of the Committee. This movable feast that we have had on this legislation and the amendments before us go on and on. We now know why the Government did not bring this legislation on last night at 8 o'clock. We were told that this legislation would be brought on at 8 o'clock on Monday night and we were told to be prepared to sit all night. We got to 8 o'clock and there was no Bill to discuss. We continued to debate the sales tax legislation. We now see why the Bill was deferred until today—

TALK.START.PARA: —You asked for it to come on today; you requested the delay!

—And we wanted it deferred yet again. But the real reason that the Government agreed to that is the amendments that were tabled 20 minutes ago in the chamber. The Government did not have its amendments drafted. The Government did not have its act together after four years, to use Senator Bolkus's term. He did not have his act together despite the fact that he brought this Bill into this place in May. He does not have his act together despite the fact that the Committee brought down its report several weeks ago.

PARA.TAB: I am pointing out to Senator Bolkus that his level of incompetence in handling this legislation knows no bounds. Well he might be embarrassed about it, because his track record on this matter has been appalling. It is well recognised by his colleagues on the back bench that Senator Bolkus's handling of this legislation has been appalling, a disgrace and an embarrassment to the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is recognised that you fouled up the Committee.

—Senator Bolkus has been totally inept. Senator Faulkner well knows that, of the people who made submissions to, or gave evidence before, the Select Committee, only a small number actually supported the Labor Party's thrust. The overwhelming majority of those who gave evidence before the Committee took a different point of view to the Government—and well Senator Faulkner knows that.

PARA.TAB: What is proposed by the Government is not as severe as a total ban on electronic advertising, but it is vital that it be understood that it is still an attack on free speech. Neither the Human Rights Commissioner, Brian Burdekin, nor experts in constitutional law have backed away from that point. Third party organisations such as the RAA, the Real Estate Institute and the environmental lobby are totally banned from canvassing their views on the performance of political parties during campaigns.

Why should the AMA not be able to put its point of view on some policy issues in the health area? Why should the NRMA not be able to put its point of view in relation to policies affecting motorists in this country? That is not looking after single, main vested interest groups. Those bodies represent tens of thousands and in some instances hundreds of thousands of individuals who pay a membership fee to belong to an organisation that can represent their view. Why should the NRMA, the AMA, the RAA or whatever organisation that has a wide, in-depth membership not be entitled to put a policy point of view in a free, democratic society and argue its case? What is the Government so frightened of that makes it want to shut the door so that those bodies and organisations cannot participate in the electoral process?

Changes which have been made to the Bill mean that the ban, which was to operate for 365 days a year, will now apply only to election periods. However, as an example of this, in 1988 in New South Wales, by the time we add up Commonwealth, State, local elections and by-elections, there would be no advertisements for something like 16 to 20 weeks of that year. So this nonsense about the ban being applied for only four weeks a year is exactly that—a nonsense. The fact is that this ban is far more wide reaching than the Government wants us to believe, or the perception that it wants to set.

In effect, this ban allows the State to dictate exactly how political information is to be communicated to the electorate through the electronic media. It removes the right of political parties to choose the content and the timeframe of their advertising. It removes the right to choose the frequency of the time slots, and even the placement of them. A crucial factor in advertising reach is having the right demographics; otherwise it is a waste of time. If we want to communicate with one particular section of the electorate, the demographics are important in targeting and directing a message to the people to whom we want to communicate. The Government's roadblock approach removes that opportunity.

The Bill also legislates to force commercial television networks to screen this State-controlled free time. It makes it far from free for them. Over recent years across Australia, we have seen television networks suffering financial struggles. The Government seeks to add to their worries by insisting that they provide the valued commodity of space for nothing, space for which they could be earning much needed dollars. It is quite a ludicrous situation, especially when the print media, direct mail, billboard agencies and telemarketing agencies will be receiving a revenue bonanza at the electronic media's expense as campaign funds are diverted from one area to another. Witness after witness before the Select Committee confirmed the fact that this action will not save total expenditure of dollars. It will be diverted to different areas.

The commercial networks have in fact offered political parties reduced rate advertising. That offer has been ignored. They came before us and said, `Okay, if you want to try to contain the costs of electronic advertising, we will sell advertising space at reduced rates', as happens in many countries, for example, the US. The Government's proposal totally ignores that offer, yet it was eminently sensible. It begs the question why. Why would it ignore an offer from the commercial networks for cheaper rates in advertising? That is not a particularly difficult question, of course, given the current political situation.

Having worked out that it is necessary to ban electronic advertising because Labor has no money, it seems that Labor has also decided it needs to be banned to avoid a memories campaign detailing the economic devastation of Labor. I could well see a coalition advertisement detailing the policy decisions of the past eight years and the havoc that those decisions have inflicted on Australians, but the Government wants to close the shutters on that. It does not want people to be reminded of its activities and its actions. So the networks pay the price which, in the economic crisis created by Labor, is likely to be a very heavy one for those networks. Also, nothing in the Government's legislation, to any significant degree, helps the plight of the more than two million print handicapped; the migrants who can understand but who cannot read English; or the many rural communities that rely almost totally on the electronic media—particularly radio—for news and information services.

The majority report of the Committee accepted in part a carefully constructed proposal of the National Federation of Blind Citizens of Australia to use the parliamentary broadcast network and public radio to broadcast 90-minute loops of party political information during campaigns. But the Committee report did not think that proposal through. The NFBCA itself said that any ban on radio was a problem and that its members did not want to be tied down to specific narrow broadcast times.

The majority report of the Committee did not take into consideration some of the rural areas which have trouble with parliamentary broadcast reception, or the lack of public radio stations across Australia. The report was a quick hit attempt to quieten vocal and articulate critics of the ad ban, such as the NFBCA.

That is not government for the people; it is government against the people, with a few carrots tossed along the way. It is sad that this Government has been so overwhelmingly destructive that it has not been able to concede the intrinsic value of radio to so many groups in the community. Where is the sense, given that radio is cheaper than the print media? The evidence before the Select Committee demonstrated clearly that, in terms of audience reach, advertising on radio is far cheaper than taking out full-page or half-page advertisements in large daily newspapers, such as the Sydney Morning Herald, and other publications.

The Federation of Radio Broadcasters proved beyond doubt just how much cheaper radio advertising was, sometimes even in the capital cities, than the print media and direct mail. Only one witness before the Select Committee—Phillip Adams—put the point of view that radio should be included in the ban. He put forward the argument that image advertising would move from television to radio if it were not. The argument was such that it obviously could not be sustained. Yet because it fitted the Government's agenda, it was latched onto with alacrity and now we see it repeated as gospel.

TALK.START.PARA: —The gospel according to Phillip!

—Yes, the gospel according to Phillip Adams—that would be a new one. Interestingly, Mr Adams—who was one of only four witnesses to come before the Committee who had anything positive to say about a political ad ban—had nothing to contribute about campaign funds moving to the print media or to direct mail.

PARA.TAB: So we are dealing with a situation where we have legislation which meets with widespread condemnation within the Australian community. Of more than 100 submissions to the Select Committee, only seven had anything supportive to say about the legislation. The legislation is in this chamber, not for the reasons of corruption which the Government so loves to peddle, but for reasons of near bankruptcy of both Labor Party funds and ideas on how to continue to cling to power.

To show any support for this legislation is to condone the abuse of power by this Government. The Democrats have sworn to `keep the b's honest'. This legislation is an opportunity to prove what they mean. While, as a party, they may feel somewhat appeased by the Government's back down from a total ban to free time and talking heads, the free time is far from free to the greatly disadvantaged media groups. It is far from providing freedom of access to political information by the disadvantaged in our community.

But even more important than those crucial issues is the fact that this legislation is not legislation for Australia. It is not designed to protect the political process—to keep it pure, as I heard one Labor member say. It is none of that. It is legislation which makes a mockery of what we are here for. It is legislation for the benefit of one political party—the Labor Party, and only the Labor Party. No-one else receives any benefit or any worth from this. If this legislation passes through the Senate, we are stamping our approval on party manipulation of the political process.

Worse still, it is manipulation purely for financial ends: to help Labor balance its sick accounts and to make the next election cost less for the Labor Party. A side benefit is that it thereby denies other political parties, community groups and organisations the opportunity to express their views on the political process through the most successful medium available to them: the right to communicate the message of one's choice through the medium of one's choice and the right of people to receive the message of their choice from the medium of their choice.

We are not here to serve the Labor Party and its vested interests and we will let down thousands of Australians if we allow this twisted rationale to succeed. No-one would disagree about disclosure, and the coalition parties have supported the principle of full, fair and equitable disclosure. This situation was brought about by the Labor Party, which was so embarrassed about Western Australia Inc. that it decided it was appropriate in this climate to move in this direction. It was financially bankrupt and it was being embarrassed in Western Australia. As a result of that, it decided to move in this direction in order to demonstrate and set the perception that it was moving, that it was coming to grips with the problem. But it is not. It is infringing the rights of freedom of speech and infringing the rights of democracy within Australia. We ought not have a bar of it and we ought fight tooth and nail all the way against this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The broad issues involved in the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill have been exhaustively canvassed. I have spoken in an MPI on this matter, as well as in debate on the referral of the Bill to the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures. Most recently, I spoke on the tabling of the report on 28 November. This evening I want to readdress some of the issues that I raised on those occasions and put them in the context of the dissenting minority report of the Opposition members on the Select Committee, Senators Olsen and Kemp.

PARA.TAB: Before I do so, I would like to restate the underlying principle which over recent years has guided my particular interest in the problems addressed by this legislation. I believe I can do this in no better way than by quoting from Elizabeth Drew's book Politics and Money: the New Road to Corruption. She says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is one thing to establish a system that guarantees contending factions an opportunity to express their views, and quite another to auction off the system to those factions that can afford to pay for most of the time to express them—not to mention the secondary effects that such an auction system has. Whether or not the person who has the most broadcast time always prevails, it is demonstrable that the power and the cost of political broadcasting distort the political process.

Elizabeth Drew observed the scene in Washington over a number of years as political correspondent for the New Yorker. She became extremely concerned that pressures brought about by the incessant need to raise funds were distorting the very nature and practice of government in the United States. She observed:

The pressures of money have made it more unlikely than ever that politicians will take difficult positions, exercise leadership. They have distorted the legislative product and the legislative process itself. The role of the legislator has changed. And the methods by which money is now organized and distributed have taken the country far from the way that our system of representative government is supposed to work.

In a nutshell, those two quotes outline why this Government was forced to act. The Opposition constantly says that there is no need to act until our system is demonstrated to have been corrupted and distorted, after the US model. The minority report of Senators Olsen and Kemp said:
. . . there was no evidence of any proven Federal corruption put before the Committee.

By allowing this to stand, as apparently a kind of recommendation, they are implying that this is the end of the matter. In refutation of that self-serving claim, I would like to quote from evidence given to the Select Committee by Mr Henry Burmester, principal adviser of the Office of International Law in the Attorney-General's Department:

It seems to me that the Government is entitled to say that in the interests of public order it should take action in advance to preserve the integrity of a system. If it has evidence that action in a certain way may assist, then it seems to me that would be a reasonable and legitimate way in which to preserve the integrity of that process. In other words, it need not wait until corruption has been proved to take action.
This was the view of the Government when it formulated this legislation, and it is this view that has been endorsed by the Select Committee.

PARA.TAB: The principal complaint of Senators Olsen and Kemp in their minority report appears to be that the report distorts the thrust of evidence by selective quoting. Frankly, unless all evidence to a committee features in a report, quotes obviously do have to be selected. It then becomes a personal perspective as to when `selected' becomes `selective'. I suspect that they are really complaining that the quotes used are not selective in the way they would have wanted; that is, they believe that the quotes should have been chosen from the evidence of some of the witnesses who have a material self-interest in the issues canvassed by the legislation and whose evidence thus suited Opposition senators, instead of from the evidence of a number of witnesses who gave substantive evidence and whose evidence has been used to finetune the legislation to cater for legitimate concerns.

The issue of free speech naturally entered into Committee deliberations, as it has entered into the debate on this legislation all along. The Opposition senators continue to claim that all that we hold sacred in this respect is under dire threat. Mr Andrew Short, of the Law Council of Australia, told us:

SPEECH.PARA: We would say that members of the community have the right to express and communicate ideas and messages through the medium of their choice in the manner they see fit.

Frankly, such evidence comes strangely from an organisation representing a profession which makes a considerable part of its income from representing those using the legal system in various ways to deny individuals and organisations the rights of unfettered free speech. I hasten to add that, like many others, I consider Australian defamation laws to be excessive. I readily concede that the right to unfettered speech has to be weighed against other interests—the right to privacy; the need to preserve social cohesion as in the case of racial vilification laws, and as is the case with this legislation, the right of the population to be protected against a distorted and corrupt political system—but I find it sad that members of the Opposition are prepared to debase the important debate about free speech and human rights for their own narrow and expedient political ends.

PARA.TAB: As part of this tactic they have made much of the ambivalent attitude of the Commissioner for Human Rights and Equal Opportunity, Mr Brian Burdekin, on whether this legislation complies with articles 19(2) and 19(3) of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to which Australia is a party. Article 19(2) requires parties to guarantee the right of freedom of expression. This right is not absolute, as article 19(3) makes clear. It provides that the right may be limited in the interests of political order, which of course refers us back to the quote from Mr Burmester of the Attorney-General's Department.

The Opposition scorns the advice that the Government has received from its official legal advisers in the Attorney-General's Department that the legislation's aim of preventing political corruption falls within the meaning of article 19(3), which means that the legislation does not breach the covenant. All of a sudden the Opposition has preferred to listen to a man, Mr Burdekin, whose job it has vowed to scrap if ever it wins government. Mr Burdekin did appear before the Committee. I do not have time to go into the details of his evidence, but by and large it reflects his opinions, which have previously been widely canvassed in the Senate.

However, to fully understand the expedient nature of the denigration of the advice offered to the Government by the Attorney-General's Department, one has only to go back a couple of years to an interview conducted on the ABC's Law Report with the then shadow Attorney-General, Neil Brown. I have mentioned this in an earlier debate in the Senate. In affirming that the Attorney-General's Department is the pre-eminent source of legal advice for the Government, Mr Brown said in reference to whether the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission would be missed when it came to advice to government on Australia's obligations under international conventions:

SPEECH.PARA: Well I'm quite satisfied that the lawyers of the Attorney-General's Department will exercise their function with true detachment and independence of mind. I think non-lawyers often think that it's impossible for lawyers to do that, but most lawyers realise that it can and is done on a daily basis by lawyers. So, I don't really have any concerns about that . . . I would be quite happy myself, to have the Department itself and lawyers in the Department, look at our international obligations and whether they are being complied with under these conventions.

The story has apparently changed over the short period of a couple of years. Looking on the bright side, the Opposition's new-found reliance on the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission may mean a reprieve for Mr Burdekin and the Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you talk about your new-found disdain for their views?

—That is, should we ever be unfortunate enough to have people such as Senator Vanstone as members of a coalition government. When I spoke on the tabling of this report I referred in particular to the role of Senator Kemp throughout the public hearings. I raise this again only because I believe that certain of Senator Kemp's prejudices and obsessions which have been on display to us since the end of the sittings of the Senate last year, acted to materially distort and devalue his contribution to the Committee. I refer mainly to his religiously held belief that the trade union movement—including officials and members of trade unions—is basically responsible for all evils in Australian society.

PARA.TAB: Out there where Senator Kemp is, on the loony Right, workers are resources, just like the raw materials used in production—just part of the equation—and the unions, in working to protect the wages and conditions of workers, distort the perfection of the market. Because of this belief, Senator Kemp sat through the hearings eagerly attempting to elicit anti-union statements from witnesses—I might say, without much success. His attempts to demonstrate that the disclosure of political donations to the conservative parties is dangerous because of so-called union intimidation practised against donors fell particularly flat.

Ironically, the only time that Senator Kemp really hit pay-dirt in following this tack was with the final witness before the Committee, Mr Mark Sherry. This really is sad and pathetic. Senator Kemp and Mr Sherry are both great denigrators of trade unions, but they approach it from absolutely diametrically opposed viewpoints. Nevertheless, I think Senator Kemp appeared willing to risk the label of a born-again Trotskyite in his obsessive quest.

I mentioned some of the details of Mr Sherry's evidence in my speech to the Senate last week, and I want to expand on that tonight because I personally took great exception to his evidence. His written submission to the Committee raised matters almost entirely outside the terms of reference of the Committee, and his evidence before the Committee on the final day of hearing reflected precisely that. I did not believe that he should have been called to give evidence before the Committee and I voted against him being called. I believe that my stance on that occasion—and within the Committee I was in a minority of one—was vindicated by his evidence, which was almost entirely a diatribe in which he slandered and belittled a whole range of individuals involved in the trade union movement under the protection of parliamentary privilege.

I raise this matter because I believe it is essential that it be made clear that his evidence does not stand unchallenged. It was subsequently refuted in a late submission to the Committee from solicitors representing Mr Ardill of the Queensland branch of the Miscellaneous Workers Union, who was grievously slandered by Mr Sherry. In this response, Mr Ardill was able to demonstrate comprehensively that the claims Mr Sherry made against him were false. That needs to be put on the record in this debate.

Unfortunately, the appearance and leading questioning of Mr Sherry was part of a consistent pattern by the Opposition members, or, more particularly, Senator Kemp. The Opposition members came to the Committee carrying a brief to thwart, delay and sidetrack the Committee. Why? It is quite simple. Issues of free speech, the political process and obviously Senator Kemp's union bashing, were not the main issues that this Committee had to deal with, but the Opposition would bring any red herring into the debate because of the absolute fear and loathing that it had for the disclosure provisions of this Bill.

The Opposition has hidden behind its new trendy phrase of free, fair and equitable disclosure. It does not believe in the disclosure of political donations at all. I do not believe that in the vote on the second reading or in the committee stage the Opposition will be supporting any disclosure provisions at all. The Opposition has claimed total opposition to the banning of advertisements but total support for the disclosure of donations. The Government has always been fully committed to putting the two issues into the one piece of legislation because they genuinely are clearly linked. The Opposition knew of this strong belief, and I suppose that is why it dared to ask for the two issues to be separated. I bet Opposition members had a few sleepless nights, because I can imagine they would have been very worried that the Government would weaken and that they would have to put their money where their mouths were.

Senator Parer made it absolutely clear to the Committee that he supported so-called full, fair and equitable disclosure but he said, `We won't be able to accept anything the Government puts forward'. He suggested that if there was any form of disclosure, donors to political parties would be intimidated. When asked to put up an example of intimidation, not one witness before the Committee, from the major political parties particularly, could come forward with one. There was no example given by any of the major political parties of the intimidation of any donor in recent Australian political history. By `recent Australian political history', I mean in the last 25 years.

The Opposition's case fell down absolutely on this point. There was never any suggestion made by any witness before the Committee that political advertisements in Australia were in any sense a worthy or constructive part of the political process in this nation. There was plenty of evidence, particularly from witnesses such as Mr Phillip Adams and Mr Rod Cameron, about the nature of political advertising and how it debases the political process in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —They're independent, aren't they—both of them?

— They are. Throughout the process of the referral of this Bill to a committee, not one substantive piece of evidence came forward that in any sense added to the arguments that were put forward by the Opposition on this legislation before the Senate. I have always argued that there is a need for us in this country to deal with the sleaze factor in Australian politics. It is undeniable that there is a link between the amount of money spent on election campaigns because of the high cost of advertising on the electronic media, and the nature of the need for political parties to find money to sustain those campaigns.

PARA.TAB: The only way the money can be found in Australian politics is through the corporate sector. All parties have been involved in that sort of fundraising. All parties, in my view, have at times cut corners and as a result the Australian political process has suffered enormously. I believe that the Government's objectives in putting forward this Bill have been taken a very long way towards solving the original reason for—

TALK.START.PARA: —You're sending people in the gallery out, you're so boring.

—It probably is boring to Senator Vanstone because she has never understood the link between the cost of political campaigns in this country, which is predominantly the cost of electronic advertising on both television and radio, and the impact of that on the political process in this country.

PARA.TAB: We have to get rid of the sleaze factor in Australian politics. We have to deal with the problem of corruption of the political process, and the Government's legislation before the Senate will achieve that. The evidence presented to the Select Committee by all witnesses supports that objective. I am pleased and proud to say that I support that objective, and I am in strong support of the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was with some interest, but not a lot, that I listened to Senator Faulkner's speech on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill. Part of my lack of interest was due to the clear indication from his body movements that he was not speaking from the heart. He was, if not reading his speech directly all the time, speaking from very copious notes. He only intermittently broke away from those notes to give us some indication of what he really thinks, or some indication as to whether he is capable of thought at all without some notes in front of him. Nonetheless, it has been an interesting exercise.

PARA.TAB: The first point I would like to raise is one which Senator Faulkner raised: the question of public order. Senator Faulkner said that, unless there is free and proper conduct of elections, public order is destroyed and, because public order may be at risk if elections are not conducted in a free and proper manner, we are justified in limiting the freedom of speech that all Australians now enjoy to protect that public order; in other words, if we think there is some sort of corruption going on in the democratic system, we are justified in limiting freedom of speech in order to correct that corruption.

That is a total non sequitur; in other words, it is just a nonsense. If one really wants to maintain public order in its most general sense, one must have the free and proper conduct of elections. On that much at least I think both sides agree: there has to be free and proper conduct of elections. We differ in that I say that what is essential, more than anything else, to the free and proper conduct of elections is freedom of speech in those elections.

That does not mean speech that is not paid for, as some of the less intellectual members of the Labor Party have chosen to say; it means an unrestricted exchange of views. I want to know what people on the other side of the chamber have to say. They may want to know what people on this side of the chamber have to say. We all want to know what the Democrats will have to say and what Senator Harradine, who is not in the chamber tonight, as an independent, has to say. We want to know what Senator Vallentine has to say.

People casting a vote, especially young Australians casting a vote for the first time who have not yet perhaps built up a voting pattern or a voting habit, will want to know what each person they might be asked to vote for stands for. That does not seem to be an unreasonable expectation. They can find that out only if there is an unrestricted exchange of views.

The Government is seeking to say, `Well, you can have this exchange of views but only through the print media'. There is no sense in that—no sense at all. Why should one have an unrestricted exchange of views through the print media but not through radio and television? I have no doubt you will understand, Madam Acting Deputy President, that this is especially the case when most Australians spend far more time listening to the radio and watching television than they do in reading newspapers. Certainly, single mothers at home with a couple of children have no time to sit down to read the paper to get an idea of different political views. But they can have the radio or television on while they are doing the ironing or any of the range of tasks they may perform, as workers can have the radio on on their way to work. People often have the radio on at work, and certainly some people listen to Drive Time on the way home. But this legislation says that we will have an unrestricted exchange of political views but only in the print media. Of course, it is not an unrestricted exchange of views on that basis, is it? It is not unrestricted at all.

The Labor Party says that we have to have this restriction on freedom of speech because of corruption in the system. Members of the Labor Party might know a lot more than I do about how the system is corrupted. In fact, on the basis of some of the speeches that have been made, I suspect they do. But that is what we really want to know. How will this Bill get rid of corruption in the system?

Suppose the Labor Party were to have a leadership change, as is expected, so that the honourable member for Blaxland, Mr Keating, became Prime Minister. Would anybody in this chamber—you, Madam Acting Deputy President, or Senator Faulkner, Senator McMullan or Senator Aulich on the other side of the chamber—honestly think that Mr Keating would say, `Oh, well, hell, we can't advertise on radio and TV. Never mind, we will just put in a few print ads. We won't spend anywhere near as much as we did, and everything will be okay.'? Oh, no, no-one imagines that. No-one in his or her right mind would imagine that. The most stupid person I have ever met would not imagine that!

Every penny that the Labor Party can lay its hands on will go into the most direct advertising campaign towards Australians that we have ever seen. There will be direct mail funded by the taxpayer, letterbox leaflets—you name it. The same amount of money can easily be spent. Certainly if one wanted to reach the same number of voters through the print media one would need to spend more than is spent through radio and television.

But the Government has not told us how it will ensure that all the money that now goes into electronic advertising will not go into some other form of trying to woo voters. I have never met anybody who imagines that parties in opposition will, all of a sudden, not feel determined to seize the reins of power. Nobody I have met would believe that governments would not do everything they could to keep the reins of power. At very best, all that will happen as a result of limiting the opportunity of Australians to place advertisements on radio and television, and therefore for other Australians to hear those views on radio and to see them presented through television, will be a reallocation of expenses from one area into another.

The opportunity for corruption, the need for money, will still be there. I am amazed that Senator Faulkner, with his great intellectual skills, either cannot see or chooses to bypass that issue. I notice that Senator Aulich was listed to speak earlier, although he was not here on time to make his speech. If he is actually going to speak, he could pop back to his seat and make an interjection if he likes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am actually down on the list to speak after you.

—Not on the list in front of me.
