If Senator Aulich is on the list to speak then, through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, I will make an offer to him to address this question: if the money cannot go into electronic advertising, how does this Bill ensure it does not go into other means of convincing Australian voters which of the major parties they should vote for? How does this Bill do that? I will be very interested to hear what Senator Aulich has to say.

PARA.TAB: One of the other points that Senator Faulkner chose to make concerned the business of free speech. He made some remarks about the Human Rights Commission. He used the typical common parlance of freedom of speech to try to create the impression, I suppose, that he agreed with Senator Aulich's remarks the other day that this Bill does not attack free speech but rather attacks bought speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.

—Senator Aulich interjects `That's right'. As I pointed out to him the other day, at an Estimates committee meeting I asked representatives of the Human Rights Commission whether they employed qualified and decent staff. They said, `Yes, we do'. Then, when I asked, `Would you employ someone who, in response to the question, "What is free speech?" said "Not bought speech"?', they were somewhat embarrassed and declined to answer. All the officers from the Attorney-General's Department behind them were in gales of laughter. Why? The reason the Human Rights Commission declined to answer is that that is what Senator Bolkus, the relevant Minister for this legislation, had been saying. They knew that it was so stupid they could not possibly give an honest answer.

PARA.TAB: No-one who has done elementary human rights law believes that `free speech' means `not bought speech'. Even someone who failed elementary human rights law would understand that. It means `unrestricted speech'. Mr Acting Deputy President, I am sorry to labour that point but it seems that members of your Party have misunderstood that point and need to be reminded of it again and again. `Free speech' in human rights legislation does not mean `bought speech' at all; it means unrestricted speech.

Senator Faulkner then went on to have a cheap shot at a member of the legal profession in my State, Mr Andrew Short. I do not know whether Senator Faulkner has any understanding of how the legal profession works or whether he has any understanding of the legal system at all. If he has, it has not been obvious to me in the time that I have shared a place in the Senate with him.

Senator Faulkner said basically that it was unusual for Mr Short, a member of the legal profession, to come forward and argue in favour of free speech because, after all, the legal profession was engaged in trying to ensure that everyone else does not have free speech. In those remarks he referred to the fact that if I say something about you, Mr Acting Deputy President, which is libellous or slanderous, you may go to a member of the legal profession who would protect you against what I have said and who would give you access to your rights and assist you in putting me back in my box if I have done the wrong thing. That is what members of the legal profession do when they access the laws of defamation and slander. They are not trying to ensure that I do not get my free speech; they are trying to ensure that I have my free speech without unfairly impugning your integrity and unfairly limiting your opportunities.

So to suggest that a lawyer who might work in the area of defamation and slander is out to curb people's free speech is almost a laughable notion. I almost regret having wasted time on this point but, since this member of the profession is from my State and Senator Faulkner chose to make such a cheap point, I thought it was probably worth a couple of minutes. I would be interested to hear any Labor speaker get up and make a case for saying that the protection of their rights and my rights against being unfairly libelled or unfairly slandered is a bad thing. If they are prepared to do that, we might have a better debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe in defamation laws but not the ones we have.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, it is not for me to tell you your job, but I draw your attention to the fact that Senator Collins is not in his correct seat.
—Don't ask me to respond to you then.
—If Senator Collins wants to contribute to this debate, he can get his backside onto his seat; otherwise, he can be quiet.
—You aren't in a real good position to talk about backsides, Senator.
—Everyone has a backside.
—You certainly have.
—And as I have said, it is better to be big in the backside than to have bulldust for brains.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—Order! Senator Vanstone, please resume your seat for a moment. Any honourable senator in the chamber who wishes to interject must do so from his or her own seat.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which means I can interject on you, Amanda.
—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I wholeheartedly support your ruling in that respect.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. You were very strict in your rulings on points of order during the afternoon when I was speaking. I would point out that Senator Aulich interjected across the chamber after you had just given a ruling. I ask you to strictly enforce the Standing Orders as was your practice before dinner.
—I have already commented on this matter. If any senator in the chamber wishes to make an interjection, he should do so from his own seat.

—The point I wanted to make about the matter that Senator Faulkner raised was this: corruption clearly requires two parties. I have made this point before; it is a very simple one which I would have thought members of the Labor Party would have understood. It requires one party that wishes to buy influence, by fair means or foul—I do not suppose that there are any fair means of buying influence—and it requires another party that is prepared to sell.

PARA.TAB: Removing the need for the parties to raise money for electronic advertising will not, firstly, remove the need for them to raise money to persuade in some other way members of the Australian electorate which way they ought to vote. That is the first thing that the legislation will not remove. Because it will not remove that, there may still be some people who, if they already have this view, feel that because they need to raise money they can exchange favours for it.

But more particularly, if those people who want to buy influence are there now, they will be there after the passage of this legislation. People do not care whether they sell their influence for advertising money, a free 12 months test drive of a BMW or some private school fees. People who want to buy influence will not be removed by the passage of this legislation.

To the extent that there are people who are prepared to sell influence, they are also not removed by the passage of this legislation. To the extent that there are still people in the community who want to buy influence and buy it improperly, and to the extent to which there are still people around who are prepared to sell it but should not, those two groups of people will find a way to meet. The passage of this legislation will touch none of them because, as I say, firstly, these two types of people have a natural affection for each other and, secondly, to the extent that advertising costs might play a part in this matter, the parties will simply reallocate those costs to other means of convincing Australians that they ought to vote for one major party or another or for the Australian Democrats.

The fourth point I want to make relates to cost. It is quite understandable that people should talk about millions of dollars, but most of us in this chamber are not millionaires. I say `most of us' because I know that there are quite a few millionaires in the Labor Party; there are far more than there are on my side of politics. They are not big noters about the amount of money that they have but we all know that they are there. There is a general understanding in the community that there are more millionaires in the Labor Party—the champagne socialists—than there are on this side of the chamber. We have had much discussion from these people about the outrageous cost of electronic advertising.

In this chamber the other day, Senator Schacht indicated that the cost of electronic advertising at the last election was $30m. We are all meant to fall about on the floor with gasps of horror. If I had $30m for myself, there would be gasps of delight. I would not know what to do with $30m. But, of course, we are not talking about $30m for one person; we are talking about $30m across the whole nation.
There is a lot of jurisprudence on this matter in the United States, where it has been litigated very fully. The United States Supreme Court—I think it was in the case of Buckley v. Valeo—said—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that a gasp of horror from you?

—Senator Faulkner has had his chance. If he did not get it all out then, he should just button up and let everybody else have a go. The Supreme Court said that this is the price we pay to be informed on the issues. I do not think that $3 a head is expensive at all. As a price to inform us on the issues, I think $3 a head is very cheap.

PARA.TAB: I am familiar with the views expressed—in fact, I concur with the views—that quite a bit of political advertising we have seen from both the major parties, and certainly from the Australian Democrats, has not been what one would call substantive. One would be drawing a very long bow to say that some of this advertising had any real substantive comment in it at all. I can understand that some people ask, `Why do we bother? Why do we allow these people to do this if there is nothing substantive in it?', forgetting that people should be allowed to do what they like as long as they do not offend anyone else.

There is a very good reason why non-substantive political advertising should still be allowed. I think I raised in this chamber the other day—Senator Aulich must be a slow learner if he has forgotten—the matter of the Labor Party advertising in the last election. It was very good. There were beautiful panoramic scenes of the environment. The voters were told, `Vote for us, we are the Party that cares about the environment'. We had Kakadu, Uluru—the lot. It was beautiful, panoramic, wonderful filming, wonderful production artwork, trying to convince Australians that they should vote for the Australian Labor Party because it was the pro-environment party. Of course, we now know what the environmental movement thinks of the Labor Party and how quickly that little deal that was stitched up was sold out on. We know that, and most Australians understand that now, too.

Do I condemn members of the Labor Party for running that sort of advertisement? Yes, in the sense that they never really meant it, in my view. Yes, for saying something that they did not mean. But I do not condemn them for not being substantive, because that advertisement, and any other non-substantive advertisement, plays a very useful role in promoting debate on the issues. When people go into a pub they see such advertisements on Sky Channel. If they asked, `What do you think about that?', there would be a few guys standing around the bar talking about environmental issues. I think that is a good thing. Political advertising does not simply have the role of passing on substantive information; it has the role of promoting debate on particular issues. That is a role for this type of advertising that is often forgotten and overlooked, but it is very necessary.

Most Australians admit that politically we are a very apathetic nation. It does not hurt us at election time to be cajoled into debating some of these issues amongst ourselves by some fairly flashily produced, but non-substantive, advertising. I see no problem in that. Quite the opposite, I see it as being a very good thing.

The next point I wish to make relates to some remarks that Senator Faulkner made about my colleague Senator Kemp. I will just deal with some of these remarks. Senator Faulkner alleged that Senator Kemp had chosen to distort and devalue the outcome of the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures to thwart, delay and sidetrack the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did I say that?
—If you don't know, we can't help you.
—Order! Senator Faulkner, would you address any remarks that you want to make through the Chair?

—Mr Acting Deputy President, before your quite wise intervention—not that Senator Faulkner worries me—I was saying that Senator Faulkner had alleged that Senator Kemp was trying to distort and devalue the outcome of the Committee to thwart, delay and sidetrack this Committee. I was not at the Committee hearing, but on one occasion I turned on the radio in my room to listen to what was happening. I turned it off because of what I regarded as the completely embarrassing, bullying tactics against witnesses by the Chairman of that Committee at the time. I did not want to listen to it, be a part of it or know about it—it was a disgrace. Perhaps that is unfair of me, not having been there. However, I was ashamed to listen to it on the radio. I thought it was a disgrace. Far be it for Government members to raise these matters. Let me further say: if Government members ever want a detailed run-through of how to distort, devalue, thwart, delay and sidetrack a committee—
—We'll get it from you.

—They will get it from me. They will get a very clear outline of how one chairman of a committee—he is obviously a chairman coming from the Government side—has, in my view, done no less than present a complete untruth to the public in relation to a certain matter.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I think it is inappropriate for Senator Vanstone to mention the fact that a chairman, in her opinion, has committed an untruth. That is, in fact, the equivalent of a lie and it is unparliamentary. I ask you to ask her to withdraw.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: firstly, I have not indicated to whom I am referring, although I hasten to add that it is not Senator Cooney. Secondly, I have not said that person has lied. I have said that, in my view, he has attempted to distort, devalue, thwart, delay and sidetrack and, in doing that, has presented to the public what I regard to be a complete untruth. If the Government wants that tested, I am happy to give it a run. I have not made the outright allegation that he has lied. I have said that, in my view, it is an untruth, and I am allowed to say that.
—Order! In my view there would have to be some recognition of a particular person. Senator Vanstone's remarks have not been directed to a particular person.

—The next point I wish to make in relation to this matter is the participation of the Australian Democrats—the Party which is going to keep the you-know-who's honest. That is the role these little people were going to play. These are the people whom Senator Walsh says are the fairies at the bottom of the garden. What do we find them supporting now? We find them supporting something that will give them a big slice of taxpayers' dollars to advertise their own position—a slice of taxpayers' dollars that they could not get by asking the taxpayers for it. There is a little self-interest—quite a large self-interest—motivating the Australian Democrats in pushing this matter through this evening.

PARA.TAB: I have already canvassed my views as to how the abolition of the use of electronic advertising will not remove any opportunity for corruption that now exists—not at all. I also make the point that I do not think the disclosure matters and the advertisement ban matters are related at all. If the Government is genuine about wanting to get rid of the possibility of corruption, it will support full, fair and equitable disclosure in any event. The Government will not make it contingent on getting an advertising ban. These two matters can stand alone, and they should stand alone.

The second last point I want to make relates to intimidation. I am amazed that Senator Faulkner is without such wit as to be able to understand why someone who feels intimidated is not prepared to come forward and say, `Hey, I have been intimidated by these people. They have threatened me'. Does that amaze anyone? It does not amaze me. If someone came and threatened the daylights out of me, I would be a bit careful about fronting up and owning up to it. I would be too embarrassed; I would be frightened for my future. The mere lack of evidence on this matter does not mean much at all.

My last point in relation to this matter is this: this morning I heard some speakers on the other side of the chamber—and I think Senator McMullan was one of them—saying that the matter was not being shoved through, that there has been plenty of time, because the idea has been around for four or five years and we have had various committees looking at it. But they completely overlooked the fact that a significant number of amendments to the Bill have been put in at the last minute. Just before the suspension of the sitting, I heard that the Government is still working on amendments. We still do not know the proper detail of the package we are being asked to support.

If it is the Government's view that, in general, an idea that has been hanging around like a bit of fairy floss for a few years should be supported, then I look forward to when the people on this side of the chamber move over there and get into government. If we have legislation to introduce on proper enterprise bargaining—so that one does not have to go to the industrial commission and say, `Please, sir, may I have this; three bags full, sir'—I assume that the Labor Party will not expect to have time to look at the details. I assume it will be happy with the argument, `The idea has been around for a few years; you've had plenty of time to think about it; you won't need the time for the detail'. That example shows how ludicrous that proposition put forward is.

The idea has been around for a while. But I am not paid to vote on an idea in general; I am paid to vote on specific details. This Government does not even have the details ready. It is an absolute outrage. What it wants to do is use some deal that has been cooked up with the Australian Democrats to shove this through. The bottom line is that it does not have any dollars to run the next election campaign. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is an interesting one. I understand that Senator Vanstone may have wanted to be on the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures which looked at this issue but that Senator Kemp went on it instead. It was interesting to see his contribution from time to time during the hearings, although I will not go into those details. However, one thing that has come out quite clearly in the discussion post the Committee is that a number of vested interest groups have written to this Parliament to give their views about the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991.

PARA.TAB: As I indicated the other day in a previous debate on this issue, those vested interest groups have from time to time been used by the Liberal Party of Australia in various ways. For example, the Liberal Party has sent them draft letters suggesting that those letters could be forwarded to members of parliament. Unfortunately, the vested interest groups have not bothered to change the nature of the letter very much, so basically what has been received by us in this Parliament is a copy of the letter sent out by the Liberal Party. The letters have come back to us saying, `Isn't it terrible that what the Labor Party wants to do is in fact stop free speech'. The interest groups then parrot back to us what the Liberal Party has told them they ought to say. In some cases, those people have been innocent dupes of the Liberal Party: they have been welfare groups who do not think too much about it and who believe what the Liberals told them in their letters.

I received one such letter today, written to a prominent Democrat senator. This letter, dated 3 December, is a perfect example of the ways and means being used by the Liberals and the National Party of Australia to try to undermine this Bill. First, the Opposition has said that the Bill is a ban on free speech and then it has written letters and sent them out to various organisations. Honourable senators will recall that Senator Parer said the other day, `Would the Liberal Party write speeches for people? Would the Liberal Party draft letters for them, send them copies of those letters and then ask them to send them back to members of parliament? No, the Liberal Party would not do that'. Yet here in front of me is a fax of a letter signed by nine people from one particular company based in Hobart, Tasmania. This fax was sent to one of the Australian Democrats and it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator X—
we will protect the identity of the particular senator—

I understand that tomorrow the Federal Government is planning to introduce legislation into the Senate to outlaw the placing of any advertisement which could be construed as in any way political on the electronic media.
That is normal language that people in these companies use. The letter goes on:
I further understand that you will be voting in support of that legislation.
This is pretty quick, considering the letter is dated 3 December. It continues:
I ask you to reconsider your position and vote against the legislation. It is an infringement of the right of any Australian to express views on any issue without hindrance.
Then in upper case, just in case the Democrats do not get the point, it says:
Stick by the Democrats' stated position of open government—don't allow yourself to be bought by the Government.

This letter is signed by these people `All of APPM, Hobart, Tasmania'. It is nice to hear that some people in Tasmania have views about freedom of expression. But this letter, as with other letters we have seen, give a lie to what the Liberals told us the other day during the debate on the Committee's report. The Liberals said to us that they do not write letters for vested interest groups; they do not write letters for various individuals; and they do not write letters to people to inundate this Parliament with faxes. They allow free speech to be just that: the speech of individuals or concerned groups based upon their view of the facts and then to put their view to Parliament.

PARA.TAB: Could anyone in this place—including Senator Parer, who tonight indulged in the typical sort of personal attack that has now become par for the course in this Parliament on the part of the Liberals—say that that is an example of free speech? It would seem to me that that is an example of organised speech where someone in the Liberal Party writes the letter and the individual or interest group sends it to this Parliament, to the Democrats, in an attempt to convince the Democrats that that is an expression of his own views. It is a typical example of the organisation which some political parties use under the guise of free speech to make their so-called views known to Parliament. So much for Senator Parer and his view that the Liberals in fact have never organised vested interest groups or individuals out in the community to write to this Parliament in order to put pressure on the Democrats.

In justification for the way the Senate works, the Democrats have shown tonight that from time to time there is value in one party holding the balance of power. I was a member of the Committee which examined this particular issue, as was Senator Kernot. Senator Kernot and I did not agree entirely on every issue. But we did look at the facts, we did listen to the witnesses, we had no prejudiced opinions beforehand, we were not prejudging the situation; and Senator Kernot basically came up with the same viewpoints as me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Aulich has made some assertions about the drafting of certain letters and I assumed he was going to go on and provide evidence in some form that these letters had been drafted by the Liberal Party. As yet I have not heard any such evidence and he has now moved on to another subject.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—There is no point of order. The Chair is not required to estimate whether it is true or false.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that in fact is a wise decision. There was no attempt to attack any individual in this place, and that is not the way I operate in this place. I have no time at all for political parties which use individuals in the community as dupes in the process.

PARA.TAB: I will move to my next point. The basic question in this whole Bill is how to stop the escalating costs of political campaigns at election time. It is a major issue and I think every party agrees on that point. Some parties have less concern about it than others, but certainly the Labor Party—and I am sure now the Democrats—have indicated quite clearly that the day when we can continue to spend up to $16m each election on electronic advertising alone for election campaigns has gone.

In the next day or so, this Parliament will make the decision to put all of that aside. It will say that the pursuit of that sort of money, to pay for that sort of very expensive campaign, is no longer tenable and acceptable in a democratic system. At the last election all political parties spent more than $30m campaigning, $16m of which went on electronic advertising. That is the problem. How do we stop that sort of expenditure in election campaigns? The major reason why we need to look at this is that there is a potential for corruption in a system in which $16m is going to be spent on one form of campaigning—$34m all-up between the major political parties.

If the political parties are in search of that sort of money to be available to compete with each other, someone has to give them that money. Nobody gives political parties money except, basically, for two reasons: one is that they are absolutely idealistic, they believe in the cause of that political party and they will contribute to the best of their capacity to it. I have been given money at different times in my political career by some very poor people—literally $2, $5 and so on. Once, when I lost my seat, someone who I had never met gave me money out of the blue to say, `Hope you will get through the next few weeks'.

As every member of this Parliament knows, when election day comes, that is the end of our salaries. If we do not have a job after that, it is tough luck. Someone I had never met before in my life helped me out during that time. In one way or another that person must have been impressed with what I did—as was indicated in a letter sent to me. Pensioners give money to individual politicians or parties because they are idealistically impressed by those parties. That is one side of the coin.

On the other side of the coin are the people who have enough money to pay political parties to achieve a benefit for themselves as individuals or the groups they represent. Those people say, `I will buy the best political party I can buy'. We have seen that operating in Australia in the last few years on a fairly systematic basis. It certainly operated in the United States on a very systematic basis for a very long time. It operates in Japan. One Japanese prime minister told me, in a private interview—it is no longer private because he has since published that information—that it cost him $US28m to become prime minister and that he was unlikely ever to be prime minister again because he was never likely again to be able to raise $US28m.

That is the Japanese system, brought about partly by their electoral process whereby there are three people in each electorate and there is a tendency for people to try to work within the dominant political party to get the numbers to become the leader of that party. That costs money. The election campaign is a question of funding the right members of the winning party in order to get oneself elected as leader. Endemic corruption is built into the Japanese system.

Endemic corruption is also built into the American system, where every senator literally has to raise $10,000 per week in order to run a moderate campaign. That is a large amount of their resources, ideas and intellectual energy that should be preserved for other activities going into fundraising. In a sense, they make themselves available for vested interest groups to pay them. What do those vested interest groups want? They want benefits for themselves. If it is not the oil lobby in the United States which is asking for a minimum taxation or, in many cases, tax write-offs, by putting money in the coffers of various senators and members of the House of Representatives, it will be other interest groups.

In some ways, Australia was going down the same road. We are lucky because this Government has made the tough decision. It has said, `We are going to ban paid political advertising during election campaigns'. This Labor Government had the courage to say, `We do not care whether the major television networks in this country hate us because of it, or whether the major television networks of this country lose income because of it. We do not care whether many of the newspapers, misunderstanding this Bill, have said, "We oppose it and we think the Labor Party should be thrown out of office because it has brought in this Bill"'.

We know that a government has to take a stand at this time. We have to make a decision now as to whether we are going to have the best Parliament that money can buy—like the American system or, for that matter, the Japanese system—or whether we are going to have something that is peculiarly Australian which is, on the whole, honest—particularly at the Federal level—and where the Parliament owes very little to outside interest groups.

For example, I want to be able to get up in this place and say that the tobacco industry stinks, it gives people cancer, it deliberately encourages young people to smoke and, ultimately, many of those young people kill themselves. I do not want to get up in this place, as I did one year, and ask a question about tobacco bans and have one of my colleagues say, `Hey! We get money from them and so do the Liberals'. I know that tobacco smoking is a death dealing exercise. It is being pushed on young people in this country by people who are prepared to spend a lot of money, and once they used to give to all political parties.

I want to see those sorts of interest groups thrown out of the political scene. I want to be able to vote freely on that sort of thing. If my vote and my views about tobacco advertising are going to be canvassed, I want to make those views plain in this place. I want to vote in a particular way, without concerning myself about which vested interest group is giving money to my Party, the Liberals or any other party in this Parliament, in order to protect itself.

That is the danger of having election campaigns which cost $34m or more, where $16m is spent on electronic advertising. At the end of the day, you have to get the money to pay for it. That means you have to go to vested interest groups, or they come to you. They say, `Here is the money, but the price of our support is this, this or this'. I do not want to pay that price as a member of a political party. No-one in this Parliament should have to pay that price—to have their judgment and their views about particular issues affected by the people who pay the money.

The Liberal Party seems quite happy to go on with that system because, traditionally, it has always raised more money than the Labor Party. In recent years that has not been the case. In fact, the Liberals are better at rearranging their finances between their Federal office and their State branches. That is the major reason why we appear to be spending as much as, or slightly more than, the Liberal and National parties. That is not the case. The fact is that our accounting system is much more honest and open. We say, `That is what we spent on the Federal election'. On the other hand, the Liberal Party says, `That is what we spent on the Federal election, but we had some administrative costs which came out at the same time as the Federal election which happened to be ascribed to the State branches'. Of course, under the current disclosure arrangements, State branches do not have to tell us what money went through their coffers at that time.

Nevertheless, all political parties will be prisoners of vested interest groups if, in order to run expensive election campaigns, they have to keep chasing money. The potential for corruption is there. When I was a member of parliament in Tasmania, I was the Minister administering the Electoral Act. Down there we had a system that limited expenditure to $1,500 per individual when running for parliament. The situation arose where I had to prosecute members of my own Cabinet, put people into court, because they had overspent and then said they had done otherwise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean you're a $1,500 politician?
—The sum of $1,500 was the limit.
—That was a messy mix up for both sides.

—Yes, but the point was that that Act had never been challenged in something like 70 years. However, about three years later when Robin Gray became Premier, it was very interesting that he immediately dropped all limits on electoral expenditure. I know for a fact that there were three candidates in the electorate of Denison alone—and remember that these are seven-member seats where they are all competing against each other within parties—who spent over $20,000 each to get themselves elected. That is what they spent from their own money—not what their parties spent to get them all elected. In other words, there were certain seats where, if one spent a lot of money—and one was photogenic to back it up and one was relatively well known—
—You were not on the photogenic side.

—Exactly. I am not photogenic and I did not have the money. It was a great shame. Perhaps that is why I did not go back into State Parliament. But Robin Gray was the one, who in government, dropped expenditure controls in Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: Do honourable senators know what that led to? I think ultimately that led to the royal commission into the Rouse affair. A media magnate in Tasmania thought that he could buy a member of parliament to upset the election results. Silver ingots were hidden in Carlton and Hawthorn football socks to be passed to appropriate people as bribes. Bribes were deliberately offered to make people swap parties; bribes were given to various people. All of that to some extent was related to the fact that Robin Gray's was the first government in Tasmania since the turn of the century to get rid of election expenditure controls. He said, `It's open slather'. Everyone was hunting money. The royal commission into the Rouse affair ultimately occurred because the desire to hunt money was absolutely pressing on all political parties.

I am not being party political here because, let us face it, it happened in Western Australia with the Labor Party—and with Charles Court and the Liberal Government before it—it happened in Queensland with the Fitzgerald inquiry; it happened in New South Wales with the ICAC.
Senator Walters interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It happened with ICAC in New South Wales. In other words, people were driven to search for money, as individuals or as political parties, in order to stay in a political system, to win. Let us have a look at secret donations to political parties. We could go on about those if we wanted to. It really is great to see Senator Walters. The debate has been on since about 8 o'clock. She walks into the chamber, she shouts something across the chamber, she walks out through the other door, and that is the end of her contribution to the debate. It is incredible. She treats this Parliament with—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I do not think that any aspersions should be cast on somebody who has just walked into or out of the chamber. I do not think that that is quite necessary.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —The next most important part of this Bill is the question of disclosure. If people give money to political parties, that fact ought be known to the public and certainly to the Electoral Commission or some objective outside body; at any time that body ought to be able to look at the funds of political parties and say, `Yes, you received donations from the following groups or individuals'. That ought to be known to the public.

PARA.TAB: For example—and I use this absolutely as a hypothetical case—if APPM or a major company in Tasmania gives money to any political party, that ought to be known to everyone. Quite honestly, I have no problems with APPM, for example, giving, say, $5,000 to us and $7,000 to the Liberals, or something similar. I have no problems with that, provided it is public, so that everyone knew that the two or three political parties received money from such and such a source. There would be no scandal involved in it. Public companies are entitled to give money to political parties, as long as it is public.

But to move money around between election fundraising and administrative costs so that, for example, it is moved out of what is in effect electoral fundraising into the area of administrative costs—to pretend that the money was never given for election purposes—is wrong. What we really need is a totally open arrangement, and the open arrangement is provided in this Bill: the disclosure is there.

I am sure that no Liberal, National or Labor party member, no Democrat, could object to donations to political parties being made public—no-one. That means all donations. It does not matter where they come from or how they pass through the coffers of those political parties—or even third parties attached to that party. It has to be done.

For example, the Liberals may think at this time that, coming up to this election, they are going to get more money from business But, as with all political parties, the people who are most likely to give money are the people who believe they are going to get something out of it for themselves. What they want sometimes is not in accordance with the notions of good government. It may not be in accordance with what people want to do in terms of their party policy.

Sometimes $15,000, $100,000 or so in a Federal campaign from a particular company may be a handicap for the future. People may not need that money; perhaps they can do without it. But maybe that company is attempting to make sure that its views are being bought, that people are accepting its views on the basis that it has given them money and they are, in fact, going to be influenced by it.

I think this Bill covers both areas. First of all, it cuts back on the whole question of the enormous competition that exists at the moment between various parties in the electronic media—a terribly expensive way of campaigning. If we cut that out, we cut out the search for major amounts of campaign funding. And if we cut out the search for major amounts of campaign funding, we cut out the capacity of dishonest people to corrupt political parties. That is the first issue. On the whole, Australia has been relatively free of this type of corruption, except at State level. I think it is time we got our house in order and I think this Bill is the way to do it.

The second part of the Bill concerns the question of disclosure. It basically says that, if people give money to political parties in any way—whether they give it to their administrative fund, their election fund or whatever fund they care to call it—that must be made public. At any time it is subject to a spot-audit by the Electoral Commission. I do not think there is anyone in this House who would disagree with that.

The trouble is that the Liberal Party has got itself hooked on one ideological problem. I do not cast aspersions on it; I do not say that it is necessarily crooked; I do not say that it is more likely to be influenced by business money; I do not say that it is a party made up of the sort of people who are the creatures of big business. But the Liberal Party has a view about so-called freedom of choice. It says that campaign expenditure, big expensive TV campaigns, are related to the freedom of choice enjoyed by the voter, someone who can choose to vote one way or the other based on the information that is coming to them via paid advertisements. Surely honourable senators opposite cannot believe individually that paid advertisements are the only way to learn the truth about what a political party wants to do.

There must be other ways; there are other ways. The Bill says that there are other ways. It says that there can be free time when, without expensive, glossy advertisements, paid advertisements, honourable senators opposite can put their viewpoint over, we can put our viewpoint over, the Democrats can put their viewpoint over, the Independents can put their viewpoint over, and we do not need to pay for that time; we do not need to go to people and say, `Give us money so that we can buy time on television; give us money so that we can have three advertisements of 30 seconds each, costing us $50,000'—and that is the cost—`on Sydney television'. Let us have free time. It stops the hunt for money.

The views that the Government is expressing in this Bill are generally accepted by most OECD countries. Out of the 19 countries surveyed, 14 do the same sort of thing as that which we are proposing in this Bill. Those countries ask why people should buy votes during campaigns. Why should political parties be able to buy votes because they can afford to buy paid advertising? There are controls over the situation in those countries. There may be no political advertising at all, or parties are given free time, or some other arrangement is in place. They do not say it should be open slather—`You can buy whatever time you like'.

I support the Bill because I do not believe that free speech is bought speech. I do not believe that because someone has money that person should have more influence in this community than anyone else. I do not believe that because someone can raise $50,000 they should have the right to have three one-minute advertisements on television, and that $50,000 is excluding the cost of making them. I believe that free speech is what people say in this place, what people say in the street, and what people say on television when they genuinely get free time. For example, let us say that Senator Walters and I are together on television debating an issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a fraud. You are a real fraud.

—When we are debating the issue together, the voters can choose between the ideas that we are putting forward. But if Senator Walters wants to pay $50,000 for three one-minute advertisements, or 30 second advertisements, and she wants to put her case without my challenging it or anyone in the Democrats challenging it, that is no debate, that is no education—(Time expired)

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Walters has been interjecting from time to time in what I think is the rudest, crudest way, as she usually does. I ask her to withdraw the phrase, `You are a fraud'. That is unparliamentary. If Senator Walters wants to put her case, she can get on her feet and make a speech. But if she wants to walk in here and make noises and walk out the other door, as she often does—and she did again tonight—then perhaps this House ought to do something about it.
—He is going beyond making a point of order.
—I have the floor, Senator, on a point of order. On the point of order, Mr Deputy President, I am asking you to ask Senator Walters to withdraw the word `fraud'.

—When I hear interjections of that nature it has been my practice to ignore them, because if I do ignore them they do not appear in the Hansard. But I did quite clearly hear Senator Walters say that, and it will now appear in the Hansard, so I ask Senator Walters to withdraw.
—I ask whether it is unparliamentary, Mr Deputy President.
—It is unparliamentary.
—Then I withdraw.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the Senate is debating the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991, although after hearing Senator Aulich one would wonder whether that is the case. This legislation is notionally to impose a ban on the broadcast of political advertisements, to strengthen the rules relating to donations received by political parties, and to increase the public funding for each Senate vote. That is how the Australian Labor Party would have us describe the Bill and that is how—albeit rather pathetically, without much gusto—it has tried to sell it to the Australian electorate.

PARA.TAB: But we all know the real story behind this legislation. It is quite interesting to see Senator Aulich leaving the chamber now when he was so critical of Senator Walters earlier for walking out of the chamber and then coming back in. I imagine that Senator Aulich will not return; he will now go back to his office and go to sleep again. The simple fact is that the Labor Party is on the nose around Australia. Even in States in which the Labor Party holds government, it is a fairly tenuous hold. In Tasmania, which Senator Aulich purports to represent, in Western Australia, Victoria and South Australia, the prospect of going to the polls is rather frightening for the Labor Party because it knows it will be resoundingly and deservedly thrashed.

The moneymakers of the Labor Party have either lost enthusiasm for their jobs or they are under scrutiny by various royal commissions and the like. There are no Brian Burkes raking in the lolly over cosy lunches any more. Those days are definitely over for the Labor Party. The local bagmen do not have the charisma to entice too many people to the dinner table.

The hard fact is that the various State offices of the ALP are still trying to pay off the excesses of the last Federal election. Some say that in New South Wales it is $7m in debt. Of course, we know what sort of week Senator Loosley has had. As former New South Wales State Secretary, and now the Federal President of the ALP, he has managed with a little help from his executive to put New South Wales into a fairly tight financial position. Some people, talking in financial terms, would call it insolvency, and many have referred to it as insolvency for the Labor Party in New South Wales. The sum of $3.8m is a fairly large miscalculation in balancing the books, even by ALP reckoning. Senator Loosley appears to have done it with such flair and ease that clearly he realises that he has the financial skills to be Treasurer of this country under the Labor Party.

In light of that degree of financial management and in light of the Burke allegations, is it any wonder that the rank and file of the ALP no longer have any stomach for the lamington and pie drives or the chook raffles of the past? They are not giving money—and why should they, particularly in a recession, when in years past millions could be promised over one lunch and others lost so easily by the Federal President of the Party.

Against that background, we are here today. The Government cannot make up its mind about this Bill. One might suggest that the Bill has had a chequered career. One might also suggest that the Government is so confused and divided on this issue that its on again, off again attitude is merely reflective of who is running the show at whatever time it is.

The last time we were due to debate this legislation, which was in August, we were called back to Canberra a week ahead of schedule because the Federal Government was convinced that it had to have its political broadcasting ban Bill put through parliament. As we all know, the Government changed its mind and agreed to let the Bill go to the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures. Even the Government senators on that committee clearly could not get it right, because we now have 37 amendments, and I think there were some more tonight—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's rumoured more are coming.

—More are coming tonight. We have all lost track of how many amendments there are to the Government's own Bill. Mr Deputy President, help us; help all the Australian people. We have that many amendments to your own Bill before the Bill is even debated. It is bad drafting, bad organisation, or just a bad Bill. I think that when the Australian people see the Bill—and I am quite sure that Senator Kemp and Senator Durack would agree—they will think that it is a despicable Bill.

PARA.TAB: With that many amendments needed to the Bill, it has obviously proved itself on the course here before we even get going with the debate. If the Public Service boffins get it wrong, I suppose we can just call it a typographical error, as Mr Howe did last night. If anything is wrong with the Bill, I suppose those opposite will blame somebody else rather than blame their own Party for drafting the Bill in the first place.

Four months ago, any talk of sending this legislation to a committee or curtailing the ban to an election period only was cynically dismissed by the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus). We were told that we could not do it because the Bill was all about preventing corruption at the Federal political level, remember. Since then, we have had all sorts of changes, and helping them all along in this charade of democracy are the brokers of this Parliament—the keepers of parliamentary morality—the Democrats. So devoid of credibility are the Democrats after their appalling efforts last week with AIDEX that this morning one of my staff had to demonstrate that she was not a Democrat staffer because the taxi driver would not drive her if she were a Democrat staffer. That is what the community thinks about the Democrats. It matters little who is their leader; they are a spent force, as dead as a dead duck in the water.

Of course, deals have been done between the Democrats and the Labor Party and that is what this Bill is all about. When one starts to consider the implications of this legislation, one has to ask oneself why would any party—especially, as I have said, the champion of the worker—wish to deny information to the public. According to the ALP members of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, they were concerned that there was a possibility of corruption entering Federal politics due to the high cost of political campaigns. They argued that, with the increasing use of television and the prospect of $10m or more being spent on electronic advertising, political parties would need to depend increasingly on donations from the corporate sector.

Is this really an admission of the Labor Party's own corruption, as we have not held the purse strings in the Federal Parliament for the last eight years? Is it an admission that the big mates of the Labor Party have now called in all of their favours and are not needed any more? What is the story? Why does the Labor Party want to introduce this legislation? I guess the ALP would know because it knows all about doing favours for the corporate sector. It would also know that those corporate figures who supported the ALP so generously in years past are unlikely to do so in the future. Those who are not in a bankrupt state or in gaol have woken up to the fact that the ALP will not win another term, so why waste their money.

Is the Labor Party so concerned as to the integrity of its own Party members and elected representatives that it has to put in place legislation to remove any temptation to sin? Strangely, no other explanation has been given for introducing this legislation. In fact, little explanation has been given by any of the Labor MPs and senators to sell this particular notion. I have to ask myself, therefore, just how many on the Government benches actually believe in this Bill? I wonder just how many actually believe that to deny one's right to be informed and to discriminate against radio and television is appropriate in this era. The speakers list says it all.

This legislation remains an attack on free speech and the basic freedoms associated with democracy. That is not just my view; it is the view of the Human Rights Commission and the view of many professors of law at several universities around Australia. The Government is again wasting taxpayers' money. All it is doing is shuffling the chairs on the deck of the Titanic. This Bill will ultimately fail, if not in legislation, then certainly in practice, and with it will go the Government and the Democrats. They are looking for issues to give them a reason to exist, but they picked the wrong one in this case.

Let us be under no illusion: this Bill is totally and utterly a Labor Party attempt to ban free speech in this country. It really astounds me that people on the other side of this chamber want to do that, but I can understand the reasons for it, to which I have just alluded. I find it ironic that this champion of the workers' cause finds so much enthusiasm for the denial for such basic freedoms which are enjoyed by every civilised country around the globe. I will quote from today's Sydney Morning Herald, in which Michael Millett said:
The guidelines on content are probably the toughest proposed for any democratic nation.

They exceed those suggested by a Senate committee last week in an attempt to eliminate the "scare tactics, catchy jingles, visual emotional appeals and hot air" prevalent in modern political commercials.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat:

PARA.TAB: The guidelines on content are probably the toughest proposed for any democratic nation.

SPEECH.PARA: Why would people in this place, where we believe in free speech, deny people in the community the right to hear what political parties stand for?

PARA.TAB: If one reads the transcript of the Senate Select Committee, one sees that certainly free speech and democracy were not evident there. The transcript from that Committee has a similarity with transcripts from the Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Airline Pilots Dispute. That was not an exercise in democracy either. I note that Senator Schacht served on both of those committees. Perhaps it was just a coincidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, not at all.

—Senator Kemp says it was not a coincidence. Senator Schacht did not listen to the facts and figures that came through in evidence, but just took a prearranged point of view from the start of the inquiry, stuck to it ideologically on behalf of his own Party and made sure that democracy and the right of people to hear what political parties stand for during election campaigns was snuffed out.

PARA.TAB: When one thinks about it, one realises that the Government has done a pretty poor job of selling this legislation. If one talks to the people in the community one finds that they know very little about it. That is what this is all about: keep the people out there in the dark; do not let them know what is going on. That is what this Government is about. That is what it has done with the economy for the last few years when it said that it was actually doing everything right, and things were turning around and would be right very soon. That is what the Government has been on about all the time.

The ALP probably thought that, if it floated the Bill with the sales pitch that no longer would anyone have to watch boring television commercials about politics, people would be so grateful that they would think the legislation was a grand idea. The Government failed to realise that people in the real world are informed and want to be informed. They do watch more than just Neighbours and E Street, and during an election campaign they like to see what political parties stand for.

This legislation is as much an insult to the intelligence of the electorate as it is to their democratic rights. It is cynical, and the transparent dishonesty contained in this attempt to gag free speech will be seen for what it is. If the Labor Party is so seriously concerned about the potential for corruption in Federal politics, why has it taken it eight years to introduce legislation that will supposedly prevent it? Why is it only now when, coincidentally, the Labor Party faces massive problems financially—not to mention politically—and when its flamboyant fundraisers have shot through, that it decides that this legislation is just what Australians need to keep them politically pure and incorruptible?

Of course, we all know it is no coincidence at all. At the last election the Labor Party saw the impact of advertising on television and radio. It saw that groups such as the Pharmacy Guild of Australia and the National Association of Forest Industries could use electronic advertising very successfully to put the Labor Party on notice. Of course, those groups will not have any chance of advertising in the future.

The Labor Party has rarely been able to run a decent television campaign, but it has spent mega-millions trying to do so. Now that it can no longer afford to play the game, those opposite want to change the rules and take their marbles home like spoilt little kids. The Labor Party is unable to present policies to the voters of this country for scrutiny because it has none; it is bereft of ideas. When we have a situation where the Labor Party is bankrupt, politically and financially, those are, and must be, the overriding reasons as to why in the face of such opposition this legislation is still being pursued.

As we all know, the Opposition senators who served on the Select Committee submitted a dissenting report which left the Australian electorate in no confusion as to how the Opposition feels about the legislation. In their dissenting report, Senator John Olsen and Senator Rod Kemp said:

SPEECH.PARA: We remain implacably opposed to ANY `ban' on electronic political advertising. This position is vindicated by the quality and the strength of evidence against such a ban provided to the Select Committee by all but 7 of its 127 submissions and 4 witnesses.

I ask you: what were the Labor Party members of the Select Committee doing? Did they have their ears closed and their mouths open, which is the traditional Labor Party attitude? Did they have their ears closed to any decent evidence that came before them, or did they just not want to hear it? Had they taken a fixed position before the inquiry even started? I would suggest that their minds were ideologically set before the inquiry even began.

PARA.TAB: In no way is it just the Opposition that is opposed to the Bill. Many others realise its consequences and are as concerned about them as those of us in the Opposition are. Their concerns are not of a political nature; they are concerned with a denial of basic human rights. Professor Philip Alston, the Director of the Centre for International and Public Law and adviser on human rights issues to the United Nations, says:

SPEECH.PARA: What we've got before us is a Bill . . . which . . . in my view can only be evaluated as being clearly, and I underline the word clearly, because lawyers don't normally use it, clearly inconsistent with human rights provisions and provisions which are binding upon Australia.

Let us think about that. Professor Alston is someone who knows a little bit about international law. Of course he is not the only lawyer to dispute the legislation. The Law Council of Australia has condemned it as an infringement of free speech and a contravention of international law. The Council's President, Alex Chernov, QC, has been quoted as saying that it was difficult to see any justification for such a sweeping interference in basic rights.

PARA.TAB: Not surprisingly, industry has been quick to condemn the legislation also. The National Association of Forest Industries has been particularly scathing in its attack on the legislation, and that is not surprising. The Australian Association of National Advertisers is, naturally enough, concerned about the prospect of free communication. The AANA's Executive Director has argued that `opinion is what makes a democratic society'. The Labor Party obviously does not hold that point of view.

Media commentators have also been quick to attack the Bill. The Australian newspaper editorial today is headed, `Political ads Bill built on self-interest'. It summed up this charade so well when it suggested:
Each compromise made by the Hawke Government during the ad bans saga has been an unprincipled appeal for support from the dithering Democrats. . .

SPEECH.PARA: What an appropriate description—`the dithering Democrats'. They are the big winners under this Bill, and I am sure Senator Kemp will elaborate on the gains they will make. They have got their little bit of silver in their hand. I am surprised that some of the better people on the other side of the chamber are lying down with some of the dogs of the Democrats. I am frightened that a lot of them will get up with quite a few fleas on them.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! Senator Brownhill, I believe that calling the Democrats dogs is unparliamentary and I ask you to withdraw.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw the word `dogs'. They are lying down with animals that have fleas that may then lose some of those fleas to the people who are now lying down with them. The Sydney Morning Herald announced today, `The advertising Bill still must go'. It suggested:

PARA.TAB: The latest proposals represent a compromise of a previous, cynical compromise.

SPEECH.PARA: One has to ask whether the Labor Party is genuine in its concern about the potential for corruption in Federal politics as a result of excessive media expenses. Why has it not also legislated to control print media advertising? I wonder whether this has really been thought through by the Government, apart from the political expediency aspect. I cannot believe that a spread in a magazine such as the Bulletin or an insert in the Australian Women's Weekly comes cheaply, but in this legislation there is nothing to stop any political party, if it has the funds, flooding the print media. What about billboards? Can they also be a tool of corruption? Clearly the legislation is shonky, and the premise on which it is being sold to the Australian public is false.

PARA.TAB: What else would one expect from the Government when even one of its more honest Ministers and the third most senior in the pecking order, Senator Button, is moved to remark:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . lying comes with the job. It is a normal activity for politicians.
Let us not forget the role of the Australian Democrats, the honest brokers in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cut it out!

—I am sure that Senator Kemp will have a lot to say about that. I see that the Democrats are very interested in this debate; they are all in here listening very intently! In fact, there are no Australian Democrats here whatsoever.
—They will be watching you on their monitors.

—Obviously they will be at their monitors. One would think that when we are debating a Bill that will give them so much they would be in here listening. It is all right to watch a cricket game on television, but it is nicer to be there in the flesh and to actually see the spoils of the victory. It is just that little bit better. The Democrats apparently now think that the legislation is a good idea, and it just needs a few Democrat touches to ensure they can write it up in the next election campaign as one of their wins. It is a win for them, of course. But what has happened to their support for the concept of free speech? It seems it has gone with their former lamented leader, Janine Haines. She tried to introduce a Bill to protect free speech. The Democrats founder, Don Chipp, suggested in 1980:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if we are genuinely committed to freedom of speech, there is no excuse for this continued political censorship of radio and television before an election . . .
Just how far have the Democrats strayed from that view? I would suggest that they have strayed absolutely from the decent position that was taken by Don Chipp when starting off their party.

PARA.TAB: In all of this great effort to keep corruption out of Australian politics the rights of ordinary Australians and particularly rural Australians seem to have been forgotten. For those who live in places such as Dorrigo, in northern New South Wales, where the local paper comes out once a week, opportunities to learn about any issue in an election campaign are very limited. The Government is denying country people the chance to know what their candidates and political parties stand for. Many parts of that area of New South Wales, in the electorates of Richmond and Page, are quite isolated. There may not be a five-day-a-week mail service; mail is often delivered on only two or three days a week. Bread, milk and newspapers come with the mail. Those people will be denied the ability to sum up what political parties are talking about and what political candidates stand for.

If radio and television are denied political advertising or are so restricted as to render them useless, the only opportunities these people will have of learning about issues is the John Laws show on relay from Sydney to 2GF or Quentin Dempster on the 7.30 Report. What a great deal of responsibility the Government is putting on those radio commentators. They will have to remain very impartial if they are going to be able to sleep with their consciences at night. What right does any political party have to deny rural and regional Australians access to basic forms of communication? That is what Senator Collins and Senator Foreman, all those on the Government side of the chamber, and the Democrats who are not here, are doing: denying those people the right to hear what political parties and politicians stand for. Radio and television are the communication tools for so much of this country. Newspapers are not bought by every Australian household, but the national average of television ownership is about 1.8 television sets for every household.

To push back the clock to the last century is unthinkable and unacceptable, but that is what this legislation proposes. Irrespective of whether this issue is passed or defeated in this chamber, the Labor Party will ultimately be the loser, and the Democrats, the big winners, will be lying in bed with animals that give fleas and will wake up with fleas. This legislation is draconian. It is based on a false and cynical premise and it will be the millstone around the neck of this dead Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991, I endorse the remarks of my colleague Senator Brownhill, who drew our attention in a very effective way to the costs that this Bill will impose on human rights in Australia, the rights of people to partake in election campaigns and, particularly, the rights of rural people. I thought Senator Brownhill made those points well.

PARA.TAB: In this chamber earlier today there was a debate between Senator Coulter and me on the actual effect of this Bill on the capacity of the Australian Democrats to acquire TV advertising during the election campaign. I made the comment that the real winners, as Senator Faulkner has pointed out, were the Australian Democrats. As Senator Coulter disputed my figures, I have taken the trouble to acquire some further facts and figures to help this debate along and to see whether we can trace reasonably accurately the sort of deal that has clearly been done between the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party.

It appears, on the basis of the information that I have received, which I will be giving to the Senate, that the Australian Democrats will be able to acquire more TV advertising in the 1993 election than they were able to acquire in the 1990 election. They will probably be the only political party in Australia which will be able to obtain such a benefit. I am quite happy to provide this information to Senator Coulter. I hope that either he or Senator Kernot, who will be speaking after me, will be able to respond effectively to the information that I have. I do not say that the Australian Democrats have done this in a grossly cynical way, but the effect of this Bill is to hugely advantage the Australian Democrats. If this Bill is allowed to continue in its current form, I suspect the Australian community will draw its own conclusions.

I understand from the exchanges which occurred before I came into the chamber that Senator Faulkner made some comments in his speech to try to attack me as a result of the hearings of the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures into this issue. I do not propose to respond in detail to what Senator Faulkner said. All I ask is that honourable senators interested in this matter look very carefully in the Hansard of the Select Committee hearings at the sorts of comments that Senator Schacht and Senator Faulkner made, and they can draw their own conclusions. Being attacked by Senator Faulkner has been rather like being savaged by a dead sheep. I do not think it was particularly effective.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that sheep has been shorn a number of times.

—I thank Senator Collins for that comment. One of the great ironies of this Committee was the ceaseless requests by Senators Schacht and Faulkner throughout the hearings—the Hansard will show the accuracy of what I say—for information on intimidation. Whenever witnesses who came before this Committee said that they were concerned about issues such as intimidation by friends of the Labor Party and the unions, there was a ceaseless chorus from Senators Schacht and Faulkner of, `Give us the information', as if someone who had that information from people who were generally worried about what may happen to them would give it to a Senate committee.

PARA.TAB: The last witness who came before this Committee, Mr Sherry, had some concerns about what happened to strike funds which were given to workers in Queensland. Mr Sherry was clearly greatly concerned about this issue and wished to put the information before the Select Committee because he believed that some of these funds had been diverted into political activity. It is not possible to tell at this stage whether the information that Mr Sherry gave to the Committee was accurate, but he was asked to speak to the Senate Committee about this matter.

It was a matter which one would have thought would be of particular concern to the Labor Party, as it holds itself out to be the representative of working people. I would have thought that members of the Labor Party would be absolutely outraged that strike funds had not been given to workers on strike. This man who came down to provide the information to the Committee—I think Senator Kernot, who is in the chamber now, can confirm this—was given an abominable hearing, in which he was ceaselessly attacked. I invite honourable senators to read the Hansard—

TALK.START.PARA: —If I agree with you, does that mean we have been bought off by 30 pieces of silver?
—Senator Kernot, I shall be outlaying to you the figures on the effect of this Bill, which are based on figures which have been supplied to me by the industry.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Senator Kemp, would you address your remarks through the Chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point I was making before Senator Kernot chose to interrupt was that it was interesting that these Labor senators who were ceaselessly seeking information on intimidation illustrated very visibly to members of the Committee and the public who were there the intimidation that can occur when Labor senators feel that information may be given which may be detrimental to their Party or the trade unions. As Senator Kernot is in this chamber, I will give her this information: I have had the opportunity this afternoon, as a result of my exchange with Senator Coulter, to seek information from the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations, often called FACTS.

PARA.TAB: FACTS estimates that the cost of free time is in the order of $18m. It has estimated that five-sixths will be in prime time and one-sixth will be in fringe time. I do not know whether Senator Kernot has figures on the cost of free time. In fact, the Government has not specified where this free time will occur. It is a natural assumption that there will be six minutes free time per station with five of those minutes most likely to be in prime time and the other minute in fringe time. If that is not correct and if Senator Kernot has other figures, it would be appreciated if she could lay them before the chamber.

The Bill is saying that free time is needed for the major political parties to put their wares before the public under strictly controlled conditions. According to FACTS, the cost of that free time is $18m. That figure in fact is higher than the one that I gave Senator Coulter this morning. I thought it was of the order of $10m. But, having spoken to Mr Branigan in the course of the afternoon, I have learned it is $18m. I will be interested to see what Senator Kernot's figure is.

The figure of $18m is very interesting. I wonder whether Senator Collins knows that $15m was spent on electronic advertising in the last election. So, under the so-called free time arrangements in this legislation, television stations will be asked to contribute advertising time worth in the order of $18m. I would be very interested, as I said, to know what Senator Kernot's assumptions are. Unfortunately, Senator Kernot has now left the chamber, so it is a bit fruitless to put figures forward but I hope some people will be listening.

Under the Bill the Australian Democrats will receive of the order of 10 per cent of the free time. So 10 per cent of free time will be awarded to the Australian Democrats. If we were to put a monetary value on this, the Australian Democrats would receive one-tenth of the $18m-worth of free time. That works out at $1.8m.

It is interesting to look at what the Australian Democrats spent on television and radio advertising in the March 1990 election. Although the figures are not directly comparable they do, nonetheless, provide a fair guide. We find that the Australian Democrats spent of the order of $300,000 on electronic advertising.

According to the figures supplied to me by the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations, this Bill will enable the Australian Democrats to obtain $1.8m-worth of free time. I think it is quite extraordinary, given the nature of this Bill and given the profound threat this Bill poses to human rights in this country, that the people who in the end will allow this Bill to go through will receive such an extraordinary advantage.

Senator Coulter responded to me this morning by saying, `Well, you aren't actually talking about TV spots, Senator Kemp; you are actually talking about the total cost'. I guess the assumption to be made is that Senator Coulter disputes that figure. FACTS has estimated that in Sydney alone the Bill will mean that there will be some 540 minutes of political advertising on TV during the election period—

TALK.START.PARA: —How many days is that?
—That is 30 days.
—There aren't 30 days in the campaign period anyway.
—Oh, is that so? Is the honourable senator sure of that? Has she read the Bill?
—Yes.
—How many days are there?
—There are 28 days.

—Senator Kernot says there are 28 days; I say there are 30. I suspect that there are many elections where there are 30 days. But, even taking Senator Kernot's figure of 28 days, the amount of free advertising on TV in Sydney during the next election campaign would be reduced to about 500 minutes. From my reading of the Bill, I think I am right in saying that the Australian Democrats will obtain roughly 10 per cent of this time. Is that right?
—It is the same as we get now on the ABC.
—Okay, the Democrats will receive 10 per cent. That works out in the Sydney—
—Order! Perhaps we could have these discussions in the committee stage. At the moment, I believe you should be giving a speech—
—I am trying to give these figures to Senator Kernot, who seems to be very sensitive and whom I suspect does not know these things.
—Order, Senator Kemp! This is like trying to turn a record off. I was trying to make the point to Senator Kernot not to interject. I would ask you to address your remarks through the Chair.

—Can I go through the figures again for Senator Kernot? There are six minutes of free time on each of the three stations per day during the election period. Senator Kernot should write that figure down. There are six minutes and there are three stations. That makes 18 minutes a day. Then, multiplying that by 28, one comes pretty close to 500 minutes during the election period. The Australian Democrats will get 10 per cent of that—and Senator Kernot agrees with that figure. So, in other words, the free time in the Sydney area alone that Senator Kernot and the Australian Democrats will obtain through this Bill is of the order of 50 minutes.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot can get up and dispute these figures. I am telling her that these are the figures which have been given to me by the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations. If these figures are wrong, I would appreciate being told so because this information is very important in an understanding of the Bill. In the Sydney area alone the Australian Democrats, as a result of this Bill, will receive 50 minutes free—free in the sense of being paid for by the TV stations—advertising. And that is only in Sydney. I am prepared to get the figures for the rest of Australia.

I ask Senator Kernot to stand up and say to me that in the March 1990 election she was able to obtain 50 minutes of advertising in the Sydney area. Under this Bill, that is exactly what the Democrats will receive. That is why I say, on the basis of information given to me by the industry, that the Australian Democrats will achieve significantly higher levels of advertising in the Sydney area and right around Australia than they were able to afford at the last election. The great irony of this is that, although the Australian Democrats, on the basis of the figures which I have been given by the industry, are the big winners, every other interest group—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine will get 10 per cent.

—Senator Harradine will get 10 per cent. But how about the 50 other registered parties in Australia? How about the independent candidates? I suspect that Senator Kernot is not aware of these figures and that they have not been given to her.

PARA.TAB: It will be interesting to see whether Senator Kernot will refute, or attempt to refute, these figures when she gets up to speak. If she cannot prove that the information which has been given to me by the industry is wrong, I believe that this will be one of the most cynical and disgraceful exercises that we have ever seen.
