Senator Kernot has said that the Democrats want to control TV advertising. She has said that expenditure on TV advertising must be controlled. As a result, the Democrats will be controlling everybody else's TV advertising. But, boy, will they be getting a big hefty bite of the cake initially!

TALK.START.PARA: —What would they get in your city?

—They would get about the same. If a party spent only $300,000 on electronic advertising in the last election, it did not get that type of coverage. As I said, I will be listening very carefully to what Senator Kernot says. But here is the nub, and this is why I do not think the Australian Democrats are quite as cynical as all that: I do not believe that they are aware of those figures and I do not believe that those figures have been laid before them.

PARA.TAB: I believe that Senator Bolkus—and we have to give him credit for this—pulled one of the greatest con jobs that we have seen in this Parliament. Let me say why I think that. There is a very good chance that the proposal for free time on TV will be rejected by the courts. There is evidence from eminent QCs that it will be challenged in the courts. But Government senators are not allowing enough time for this legislation to be considered; they want to rush it through tomorrow.

Let us look at the dilemma of the Australian Democrats. There is a good chance that this Bill will be challenged in the courts. Certainly the initial information received is that a very likely case can be presented to the courts that the free time proposal which Senator Bolkus has so generously given in this Bill will be thrown out by the courts. Where will we be then? We will be with a Bill that bans political advertising because political advertising will not be permitted under the free time arrangements. Senator Bolkus is not prepared to provide public funds to allow compensation to the television stations. That is why I say that the Australian Democrats have got themselves into a very difficult position.

We then go to the radio side. If someone wants to reach large numbers of people, what is the cheapest form of advertising available to that person? What is the cheapest form of getting a message out to the largest number of people? The answer is that the cheapest form is radio. One reason why Senator Powell was deposed, if we can believe the newspapers, was that she did a deal with Senator Bolkus over this Bill. I repeat that the Australian Democrats policy was not to inhibit election advertising.
What has happened with political advertising on radio? As a result of this Bill, political advertising on radio, apart from the ABC, will be banned.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the way they want it. That is what the industry wants.

—Senator Kernot has asked us to believe the naivety of the Australian Democrats in that the commercial radio stations would reject paid political advertising. If Senator Kernot believes that, she will believe anything. If I can present the information to her that Australian commercial radio stations would welcome paid political advertising and plenty of it, will she change her mind? I wait quietly for her response, but there is none.

PARA.TAB: This really disgraceful legislation has been brought before the chamber. I believe that, unless the Australian Democrats are prepared to allow this Bill to be properly evaluated and not rushed through the Parliament, they will be exposing themselves to a very significant attack from the public at large—and rightly so.

This is a very serious debate. In my view, it is not a debate about political corruption, at least in the narrow sense which has been defined by the Labor Party. This Bill is primarily a way to fund the Labor Party's next election campaign. Make no mistake about it. What those opposite want to do with this Bill is to prevent a significant advantage which would flow to the Liberal and National parties as we go towards the next election and inhibit the ability of the Liberal and National parties to recall to the Australian public the disgraceful policies and broken promises of the Labor Party and the Hawke-Keating Government.

What those opposite have done as a result of this Bill and what they are doing as a result of changes elsewhere in the system will enable the Labor Party to conduct the most massive direct mail campaign that Australia has ever seen. Does Senator Kernot know why we have these greatly increased postal allowances? Why has the Labor Party pushed those changes through? Does she know the public funding involved? I will tell her that that means $9m in an election cycle of three years. In the election year alone it represents an additional amount in the order of $3m over and above the entitlements we used to have.

Why do we have all these new computers in our office? Why have we had these new phone lines installed? Why have these new laser printers come in? They are in order to assist the Labor Party to fund its next election campaign.

Let us put behind us this naive assumption, which has apparently been sold to the Australian Democrats, that this Bill will in some way cut down the costs of Australian Federal elections. It will do absolutely nothing of the sort. It will ensure that the costs of Australian Federal elections will continue to expand. I have already indicated that on the basis of information given to me by the industry there will be the increased costs of TV advertising. But therein lies the real story: the increased costs of the 1993 election will be borne not by the political parties—the Australian Democrats, the Liberal Party or the Labor Party—going out and raising money themselves but by the taxpayer who will be asked to contribute more and more. The election will also be funded by the TV stations that will be ordered by this legislation to provide the free time.

Senator Kernot is speaking next. I request Senator Kernot to tell us and the Australian people in the wider community very clearly why this Bill has to be rushed through in the next two days or even less—in fact, in the next 24 hours. The Australian Democrats even concede that this complex Bill, which seems to change hour by hour, causes concern because of its effect on civil rights in this country. Why is it that we have to rush this Bill through at full speed in the next 24 hours? I shall be waiting in this chamber and listening very carefully for the reasons why the Australian Democrats are not prepared to allow a longer debate so that we can evaluate the winners and losers of this free time proposal and we can carefully look at the sort of formula that the Government is proposing to allocate free time. We can look at the potential unconstitutionality of this Bill and see whether it can be evaluated in these ways. Let us look at all those issues carefully.

In conclusion, I shall be remaining in this chamber and listening very carefully to Senator Kernot to see whether additional figures have been supplied to her which would show that the Australian Democrats are not the big winners out of this Bill. I shall be listening very carefully to hear whether Senator Kernot can tell us why it is so vital that this Bill be pushed through in the next 24 hours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to tone the debate down a little, Mr Acting Deputy President. I was very pleased and relieved to see that the health section of the coalition's Fightback package clearly indicates that the coalition does not want Australia to go down the road of the American experience with respect to health care. Neither do I. Just as importantly, I do not want to see Australia follow the American way of election campaigning, particularly with respect to the amount of money spent.

PARA.TAB: A lot of debate has already dealt with the need to raise large sums of money for election campaigns and, as has been pointed out, a substantial proportion of this is for electronic advertising. Connections have been made between the pressure of fundraising and the potential for corruption. If we take a moment to look at what has happened in the United States—the example I do not want us to emulate—over the past 10 years, we will see that evidence shows there has been a remarkable change in the distribution of the funds raised for political campaigns.

Many people have talked about putting limits on the amounts of money that can be spent on election campaigns. In America it was found that limits or caps have only caused a proliferation of political action committees or PACs. In America it was found that new candidates, independent candidates—those which Senator Kemp just professed to have such an interest in defending the rights of—particularly for the American House of Representatives, have been de-funded over the past 10 years. Over the same period, incumbent candidates—one of the points that Senator Parer raised in his objections to free time—have had a 150 per cent increase in the funds raised on their behalf.

The vital factor in their success has been the political action committees. That is why a campaign limit has not been found to be a suitable way of solving the problem of having to raise so much money for election campaigns. We are talking about tens of millions of dollars. In 1980, PACs in America raised $7.3m for challengers, new candidates, at the same time as raising $25m for incumbents. Just 10 years later PACs raised $7m for challengers and $87m for incumbents.

In the 1988 presidential election, both the Bush and Dukakis campaigns raised tens of millions of dollars in very large campaign contributions. The contributions were channelled to State political parties where they were spent to help the presidential campaigns. These contributions, known as soft money, could not legally be given to the presidential candidates so the presidential campaigns used the State parties as conduits for laundering the contributions, claiming the funds were given by the contributors to help State parties.

We know that can happen here. We are talking of tens of millions of dollars. The Australian Democrats do not believe that is a justifiable social priority. It does not represent anything socially justifiable. In Australia the major parties spent $33 1/2m on the 1990 election campaign; forest industries spent $1m; third parties, in total, spent $6m; and the total is escalating rapidly. The Australian Democrats reject the proposition that Australia should have the best Parliament that money can buy.
Electronic advertising has a very vital role in election campaigns. Nobody denies that, but it is not a positive, constructive role.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you going to ban it?
—It is not a positive and constructive role. Let us examine what typical political advertisements look like and the function they serve. In an editorial in July this year, the Canberra Times said:

SPEECH.PARA: Many in the community rightly think that most political advertisements on radio and television are banal, trivial and misleading and we would be better off without them. The advertisements are also artful, clever manipulations that play on the emotions of unsophisticated voters. They are crafted with the aid of psychologists and market researchers to enable political parties to respond to gut feelings in the electorate and curry favour with those who hold those gut feelings. Any thought of politicians leading, inspiring or persuading the electorate is not countenanced in the mediums of the 30-second grab.
The second person I would like to quote is Mr Steven Robertson, who made a very informative submission to the Committee. He has been a practitioner in the field for over 14 years. He said:
TV (and to a much lesser extent radio) political ads debase and degrade the entire tone of political dialogue throughout the western world.
That is similar to the way in which Senator Brownhill entered the debate this evening with his reference to dogs. Mr Robertson went on to say:

Their content almost never enlightens or informs. They are created by the same people who dream up campaigns for soap and cigarettes. They aim to manipulate the emotions, insidiously working to suspend reason and rationality. Often they pander to the basest and most selfish instincts of the electorate. They twist facts, selectively highlight half-truths, sometimes lie outrageously.
There are some pretty good practitioners of that in this chamber this evening—
At their most benign, they are fuzzy and useless . . . At worst, they drive good people from office and replace them with nice-looking but manipulable hacks.
As Mr Robertson said:
The trouble is, we haven't yet hit the bottom in this country . . . without action now, we will head down the same road to electorate sleaze—
as America has done—
before the century ends.
Mr Phillip Adams, on the same subject, said:

The most effective election ads don't pretend to make a positive contribution to the debate. Nor are they used to put forward policies. At the best, they'll attempt to reduce a complex slogan to an idiot-simple slogan, or they will try to seduce the voters with some surging excuse for an anthem. But their real job is to hit and run.

Mr Rod Cameron, with a background of 20 years involvement in 54 State and Federal elections, gave the Committee an analysis of the tricks television advertising uses to engage and move its audience, noting that the audience to which such advertising was directed was the lowest common denominator in the community, the 40 per cent of the population that he said, if given a choice, would not vote. He described five types of advertisements that work. They did not include any based on substantive facts or information. They depended largely on emotional manipulation and scare tactics. These five were:

. . . the occasionally effective negative ad . . . secondly, the . . . big scare or big lie, usually late in the campaign; thirdly, the 60-second dramatic Thespian appeal, usually rhetorical hot air . . . fourthly, the catchy jingle or slogan; and, fifthly, some sort of visual emotional appeal to the heartstrings. Nowhere in this list of ads . . . is there any reference to information or to content.

TALK.START.PARA: —What can you do in 30 seconds?

—People can tell a lot of lies. We have heard a lot tonight about freedom of speech. We have had various experts trotted out. These days it is very easy to find an expert who seems to agree with a particular point of view. However, I have not heard it argued—I think it could well be argued, as Drs Ian Ward and Ian Cook of the University of Queensland argued in their submission to our Committee—that rather than the elimination of television advertising being a threat to free speech, television advertising is a threat to democracy. I find their arguments quite powerful. In their submission they cite the work of Corcoran, who argues that television spot advertisements are powerful communication techniques which dispense with words and language in the ordinary sense altogether.

PARA.TAB: Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:
That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: POLITICAL BROADCASTS AND POLITICAL DISCLOSURES BILL 1991

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Corcoran argues that televised political communication actually forecloses—not opens up—rational public debate. Its purpose is precisely the opposite of classical rhetoric: its purpose is not to persuade, but to control; not to stimulate thought, but to prevent it; and not to convey information, but to conceal or distort it.

PARA.TAB: Television advertising, the sort of political advertising that we see which is able to engage and move its audience with pictures and symbols, does not encourage voters to make reasoned and rational assessments of politics and policy. If democracy is understood to involve collective decision-making that reflects a concern with the interests each individual has to protect, I think it can be argued that televised political advertising actually interferes with the individual's ability to assess and defend his or her own interests, and it interferes with democracy itself.

We are all vulnerable to being manipulated through the use of the subtle tricks of the advertising trade. Television advertising is especially an area which utilises visual and, therefore, non-rational appeals. The use of televised political advertising is similarly oriented to causing people to make political choices on grounds other than reason. Voters are asked to feel good or bad about parties and to identify with political leaders, and they are not lectured on the merits of the policies they advocate. To allow televised political advertising is to encourage the view that this is acceptable within a democracy and I would argue that that sort of political advertising is not.

The very basis of the rights of free speech and of free press is that these enhance discussion and reflection within the community and lead to more informed decision-making. It is my strong contention that televised political advertising of the type we are accustomed to in this country leads to less informed decision-making, and this is against the principles of democracy. That is why the Democrats have argued from the beginning for the concept of talking heads. At least with talking heads we will have an opportunity to listen to the merits of an argument and to hear politicians canvass policy. Why should voters not have the opportunity of listening to someone they may have to vote for? There is absolutely nothing radical in this proposal. It is done in overseas countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hitler did this sort of thing 40 years ago.

—No, it happens in France right at the moment, but Senator Macdonald probably would not know what happens in France. Let me tell Senator Macdonald what happens in France. In France, the following rules have been established for the televising of election campaigns: each candidate on the opening and closing dates of the first round of the elections would be entitled to five minutes, not two minutes. Between these two dates each candidate would be entitled to four slots of 15 minutes. This is free time we are talking about, and talking heads in French election campaigns. There is nothing radical in what we are hearing. These election broadcast slots could be made up with as much as 40 per cent film footage but they could not use the flag nor any combination of its colours; they could not use the national anthem on the soundtrack; and they could not use archival footage without the consent of those involved.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at what happens in other countries. In the United Kingdom, political advertising on the electronic media is banned by the Independent Broadcasting Authority under the advertising rules. The ban covers all broadcasts of advertisements which are directed—

TALK.START.PARA: —What have they got to hide?

—This was formerly run by the Opposition's great heroine, Mrs Thatcher. I might add that Mrs Thatcher was so enamoured of the work of her advisers that she knighted her advertising agent just before she retired. Mrs Thatcher refused offers of free time, perhaps because she did not relish the thought of standing up and talking for several minutes about specific policy issues. In Britain, party political broadcasts are permitted throughout the year and party election broadcasts at election times.

PARA.TAB: In Canada, paid political advertisements in print and on the electronic media are prohibited after the issue of election writs for Federal elections until 28 days before polling day. Free time for political advertisements is provided on the electronic media. I have mentioned what happens in France. In Norway and Sweden, no political advertisements of any sort are broadcast on the state controlled electronic media.

One of the issues the Democrats have espoused for years in this place has been truth in advertising. I have laid the groundwork for why we oppose the sort of manipulative political advertising that we have been specialising in in this country. Nowhere is there better evidence of the urgent need to address the issue of truth in advertising than the example we have seen in here tonight and in the scurrilous press release of Mr Ashley Goldsworthy.

Why should these people be allowed blatantly to misrepresent the position of the Australian Democrats by publicly stating that we have sold out for 30 pieces of silver, by repeating the lie that the Democrats have agreed to accept an increase in public funding? This is a blatant lie. I have a press release dated 9 April 1991 stating, `Democrats oppose increased public funding for Senate elections'. This is a public press release, and a public statement which was made in this place. There is no excuse for Mr Goldsworthy to continue blatantly to misrepresent the Democrats' position.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats did not accept 30 pieces of silver. The Democrats did not accept one piece of silver. The Democrats did not accept one copper coin from this piece of legislation. There is no connection between this piece of legislation and Senate funding as far as the Democrats are concerned.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Order! Senator Kernot, I suggest that if you direct your remarks to the Chair you will invite less provocation from our colleagues on my left.

TALK.START.PARA: —I doubt it, Mr Acting Deputy President, but I am happy to abide by your ruling. Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, there is a question I would like to ask. It seems quite curious to me that when the Democrats find agreement with a Labor Party proposition it is a deal, it is selling our soul, but, strangely enough, when we find agreement with Liberal Party proposals and amendments, somehow that is not a deal; it is negotiation or some other arrangement we have come to. If, when we see some of the Liberal Party amendments to this Bill, we were to find any common ground, I wonder whether that would be negotiation or a deal.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp raised four questions which he wanted me to address. First, he asked for costings on the proposed free time and how it would affect the Australian Democrats. Senator Kemp said $18m—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what FACTS gave me.

—I have been speaking to FACTS, too, and I have challenged its costings in the same way. I have access to other independent costings. If all six minutes of free time were broadcast during top-rating shows in Sydney, the cost per half minute would be: Channel 9, $2m; Channel 10, $1m; and Channel 7, $2m. That is approximately $5m, not the $18m that Senator Kemp is talking about.
—It is $5m in Sydney alone; is that right?
—I have figures for Sydney only. Senator Kemp can multiply that out; I think he will find that it does not tally. The second point Senator Kemp raised—
—But you haven't covered the first one.
—Order! With the greatest respect to everybody in the chamber, it would be very helpful if greater attention could be given to Senator Kernot by both sides of the chamber.

—The second point Senator Kemp raised was the possibility that this Bill would be challenged in the courts in the near future. I have had the opportunity of seeking constitutional advice on this point as well. I am aware of the section of the Constitution which Senator Kemp claims is being challenged. The advice I have is that that challenge would be dismissed very quickly; it does not hold water.

PARA.TAB: The third point Senator Kemp raised was the fact that commercial radio is not included. The situation with commercial radio is yes, obviously it opposed an all-year round ban and a campaign only ban. At this stage, it is quite happy to be exempted from the free time proposals that will apply to commercial television.

Senator Kemp also asked: why the rush? I do not agree with the proposition that we do not have enough time to debate this Bill. We are devoting more time to this Bill than we have devoted to some major taxation Bills, some major social security Bills and the major telecommunication Bills, which we debated for eight hours in total, changing the entire structure of telecommunications in this country. That did not matter because the Opposition agreed with the Government's view on that. We have plenty of time to debate this proposition by 7.30 p.m. tomorrow. We will have plenty of time for the committee stage. We will then be able to get onto other important legislation.

I refer to the position of the Australian Democrats on this issue. Since we had the first Bill presented, which was referred to a select committee, the Australian Democrats have had the opportunity to survey their membership. The results of that survey do not change the status of our 1988 policy. Nevertheless, the survey was very helpful in alerting our senators to the views held by our members. In the survey, 92 per cent of our members who responded said that they did not support the status quo; 73 per cent said that they supported an option for campaign only bans, replaced by regulated free time, including talking heads, truth in advertising and the whole thing being monitored by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

What we are proposing in this Bill is supported by at least 50 per cent of the community; there is not a massive community campaign against this issue. If Dr Hewson gets 50 per cent of the vote, he is elected—nobody will quibble with that. Fifty per cent of the community agrees, some are undecided, the rest are opposed, based upon what they knew of the last Bill. There is not massive community feeling against this proposal. Indeed, half of them are glad that some change is being effected to the way political campaigns are conducted in this country. A recent Bulletin poll confirms this.

We are talking about 337 days of an election year when political parties, third parties, anybody who wants to, will be able to put paid political advertisements on the electronic media. We are talking about 28 days every three years when these people will have to use talkback radio, newspapers and news and current affairs programs. Political parties and political candidates will have to stand up in front of people who are asked to elect them and say, `Judge me on what I am saying because I actually have something to say. I am not relying on glitzy, subliminal, manipulative images and messages'. The Australian Democrats are not afraid to stand up as talking heads and deliver substance on policy. We are not afraid to do that. We look forward to this change in the way political advertising is conducted in this country.

In the closing minutes, I signal that I do not believe that every law this Parliament passes is perfect. I do not believe that every law we pass should be set in concrete for eternity. I am willing to give this Bill a trial. I am willing to move an amendment to make sure that after two Federal elections this legislation will be reviewed. I do not see anything wrong with that. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a copy of a press release by Senator Powell entitled, `Democrats Oppose Increased Public Funding for Senate Elections', published on 9 April 1991.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: DEMOCRATS OPPOSE INCREASED PUBLIC FUNDING FOR SENATE ELECTIONS

Australian Democrats Leader, Senator Janet Powell, announced today that the Democrats Senators will vote against the Government's proposal to bring public funding provisions for Senate elections into line with the House of Representatives.

Senator Powell said: "The Democrats party meeting today took the decision to vote against this section of the Government's package to provide concrete evidence of our earnest intention to ensure the proposed changes to Australia's electoral system result in the fairest and most honest structure possible.

"Contrary to some Opposition allegations, and media articles in recent days, the Democrats actually receive most of their public funding allocation from our House of Representatives vote. Increasing the amount available for Senate elections will result in a marginal increase of about $500,000 to us, but approximately $4-million to the Labor, Liberal and National Parties.

"The Australian Democrats simply cannot support an extra $4-5 million going to political parties at a time when welfare agencies have only been able to extract an additional $2-million from the Government to cope with the massively increased burden they face as unemployment reaches 9% and rising.
"The challenge has now been thrown down to the Coalition to state their position. Will they make a grab for the increased funds?

"The Democrats have been committed to full public disclosure of all political donations since the party was formed, nearly 15 years ago. We have nothing to hide, and again, we challenge the Coalition to come clean with the public.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have incorporated the press release into the Hansard in order to set the record straight for the benefit of Professor Ashley Goldsworthy, Senator Parer and Senator Brownhill who repeated the scurrilous claims that the Democrats had been bought off on this piece of legislation. We have not. It has always been our position to move towards talking heads and free time. We stand by it. I look forward to debating the proposed amendments in the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The importance of the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill goes to the very fundamentals of our democratic system. That is why the Liberal Party and the National Party will oppose it with every resource that is available to us. That is why, on coming into office, whenever the Australian Labor Party has the courage to call an election, we will repeal this legislation. The Bill strikes at the heart of our democracy.

PARA.TAB: I compliment Senator Kernot on what was, for an Australian Democrat, a very thoughtful and sincere speech. I listened to it with great interest and even pleasure at some points. The speech had a couple of blemishes. One of them was the quite scurrilous attack, under parliamentary privilege, on a great Australian, Professor Ashley Goldsworthy, a person of the utmost integrity and accuracy, as we would expect from a leading mathematician. I will not let that attack pass without comment.

The second point that concerned me a little was the evasiveness on the very clear and repeated questioning from the very articulate Senator Kemp. I would like to repeat Senator Kemp's questions in case other Democrats have the courage to enter the debate. I would ask them: surely, when Senator Kernot says that the value of the advertising in Sydney alone is $5m, this more than proves the point that Senator Kemp was making? That would work out at an equivalent of $18m Australia-wide. Santa Claus has come early if one can get $18m for doing nothing other than running along with the rabble over the road here and voting for a Bill they want.

Senator Kernot is handling this Bill for the Democrats, and we want to know from her how much time the Democrats took in paid television advertising in the March 1990 election. We would also like to know how much television advertising will now be available to the Democrats free of charge in the 1993 election. If Senator Kernot could answer those two questions, we would be in a much better position to judge both the Democrats' credentials and their honesty.

I turn now to matters of relevance to this debate. I am pleased to see that that great custodian of morality, Senator Aulich, is now in the chamber because I have a few things to say about him later on tonight. The Government puts the case that it is attacking corruption, but it is not prepared through any one of its speakers to give a demonstration of corruption in the electoral process in relation to fundraising. This Bill is just a cynical use—or misuse, to be more precise—of power by the Government of the day. It is not about funding; it is not about corruption; it is about human rights and the human rights of Australians to have a free say as to whom they want elected in this country. I will come back and develop this theme later.

TALK.START.PARA: —A free say?

—Free, not in terms of financial restraints but in terms of being able to get up and put a point of view before the public. We take freedom of speech for granted in Australia. It has been with us ever since Federation. I think the reason why we have freedom of speech in Australia is principally that this country has been ruled by governments of a Liberal persuasion for the great majority of the time since Federation. One of the dearest things that a Liberal government and governments of that persuasion have is a basic respect for an individual and an individual's rights.

PARA.TAB: The right to a free election will be put at risk by what the Government is proposing to do. When Senator Kernot was speaking, one of the interjections made on this side of the chamber was to the effect that this Bill is a major step down the path to a one-party State—and nothing would be dearer to the Labor Party's heart. The right of access to political power is being denied because the vehicle—public advertising, putting a point of view to the public—is going to be denied to the parties competing in an election under this system.

It will affect the capacity of ordinary Australian citizens to work for social change through the avenues that are available to them in a civilised society; they will not be able to use the media to get a point of view across. In the State of Queensland, which I represent, that is going to be of particular relevance as we have a very large rural community. The rural community relies very heavily now on the electronic media. In country towns and on properties, most people now have television, an indifferent mail service and an indifferent distribution of newspapers; radio is often unreliable and television provides the medium. By denying the right of political parties to put their points of view on television, we are very much circumscribing the right of rural Australians to be informed of what are the issues of the day.

I briefly revert to a point that was made I think by Senator Macdonald by medium of interjection. There is a very strong case to be made that this Bill is quite unconstitutional, that it will not stand up to a challenge in the High Court and, if we do go ahead and pass it, that it will certainly be challenged at least by one of the State governments. The Government is attempting with this Bill not only to take away the rights of Australian citizens in voting for a Federal election but also to ride roughshod over the sovereign States and say, `You will conduct elections in accordance with these practices', and that simply cannot be sustained.

I turn to the arguments that have been put up by the Labor Party. There has been an awful lot of pious breast-beating, particularly by people like Senator Aulich, about the high costs of campaigns, as if there were something terrible about having an expensive election campaign. I think that is about as relevant a concern as my being concerned about the mates of the Labor Party buying a brand new Rolls Royce. It is simply none of my business what sort of car they buy. If they buy one, I presume they can afford it, and I would think the running up of big bills by any party in an election campaign is that party's concern and not mine if I am not of that party.

This concern about high costs leads inevitably in the eyes of the Labor Party to the belief that principles must be sold out—and that is not a necessary corollary at all. Looking at the history of my own party, the Liberal Party, we have a practice that no member of parliament ever raises funds. I never know what funds are raised in a campaign I am in and I have never in my life collected money for a campaign I have been involved in. We separate the organisational side, which looks after fundraising, from the political side, or the parliamentary wing—those people who stand for election. I do not know what the practices are in the Democrats or the Labor Party, but I would suggest that that is not a difficult principle for those parties to follow if they are not already following it.

I turn to contemporary American practice. There has been some reference to that in other speeches. I saw an article the other day stating that millions of dollars were raised by Republican and Democrat candidates, and a great amount of that money was raised from donations below $20. The fact that we might be spending millions of dollars on campaigns does not mean that we have to go to companies or corporations or individuals and attract donations of hundreds of thousands of dollars. If we have enough people supporting us and putting small amounts in, we will reach an aggregate that is sufficient for the campaign.

Apart from anything else, no-one is forced to spend money in a campaign. The decision as to what is spent by political parties is a decision undertaken by the parties themselves and the individual campaign committees. I have no hesitation in saying that the biggest waste of money in Australia, in my judgment, is that spent on political parties, political candidates and campaign committees at election time, whether State or Federal. The money that is spent is wildly unproductive.

I think back to before I came into the Parliament when, for three elections, I was the campaign manager for one of the State seats in Queensland, the seat of Toowong. The average figure for my campaign expenses in the 1970s was $250 for a State seat. Senator Gerry Jones may think back to what he was spending out at Everton or wherever he was. I would think the median figure in those years was $10,000 to $15,000 for a State seat. Being a good Scotsman, I ran that for around $250 for two elections and, for the final one, inflation caught up and I had to put $450 on the budget line to win the seat of Toowong. I have no hesitation in saying that there is a gross degree of waste in campaigns, but that is a responsibility of the individual campaign committees. It does not mean that there is anything wrong with it. If people are silly that way and profligate, that is their business. It is not a crime against the state, as the Labor Party is trying to make it out to be.

Of course, money is the root of the problem here for both the Labor Party and the Democrats. Senator Loosley was targeted in the press for running the New South Wales Labor Party into the red for $7m this week. It is not right to see it in terms of Senator Loosley's bad judgment. Of course, it was all the New South Wales Right—it was Senator Richardson and it was the world's best Treasurer, Mr Keating. It was the New South Wales Right which made the tragic miscalculation of the market in New South Wales and ran up a debt of $7m.

It is one of the strange ironies of politics that the New South Wales Right has this great conceit that somehow or other it can handle money. It laughs at the New South Wales Left, which it thinks is a bunch of mendicants. It was not the Left that ran up a debt of $7m; it was the bunch known collectively as the New South Wales Right.

It is because the Labor Party is bankrupt that it is desperate to transfer the cost of its campaign to the public purse. As well as being in trouble itself, all its big mates are in trouble. Poor old Laurie Connell is fighting every day before a royal commission. Bondy is trying to live quietly, and pretend he does not know anything about anything. All the money that used to flow in from those people has gone, so the Labor Party is desperate. It wants to bring in a system that will transfer its campaign costs to the public purse, in the way it did with direct mail through the postage allowance for members of Parliament.

There is another pernicious twist to this. The Labor Party wants to bring in a system that will deny anyone else the opportunity to pay for advertising on television, while it does not have the money to pay for it itself, secure in the knowledge that it can swamp the nightly news broadcasts on television with vacuous statements known as `photo opportunities' by the Prime Minister and the more photogenic of his Ministry. Throughout the election campaign it will be doing this and doing that, making statements of national importance and beating the requirements of this Act.

The same sorts of motives apply to the Democrats. They are bankrupt. They have never had any money. As Senator Kemp pointed out, this Bill outrageously advantages them. It gives them something like six times more exposure on national television than they had at the last election and, what is even more galling, at no cost. I estimated before that the Democrats would benefit by $18m in free advertising.

Another aspect of this Bill is the disclosure of funding. As Senator Parer said, we have no problems with this provided it is fair, open and equitable to all parties and provided that opportunities are not presented to the bully boys in the union movement to stand over companies and demand donations. Senator Aulich spoke quite a lot about big business supporting the Liberal Party and the ALP somehow or other having missed out. Having taken the time to access the returns for campaigns through the Electoral Commission, I have positive proof of the huge funding that the ALP derives from the unions. The amount of money it gets from the unions is enormous.

On a couple of occasions previously in this chamber I have spoken about the way the ALP clearly rorts its own legislation. I have spoken about the 1987 election return from the ALP headquarters in Canberra. After hundreds of thousands of dollars declared as gifts from various workers' unions, tradesmen's union clubs, the Canberra Tradesmen's Union Club, the AMWU National Council political fund and the Operative Painters and Decorators Union, we find at the end of the return to the Electoral Commission an entry for ALP Legacies and Gifts Ltd of 22 Brisbane Avenue, Barton, ACT for a donation of $1,946,348.19—nearly $2m.

I have invited Senator McMullan, who was signatory to this when he was the Secretary of the ALP, to explain where that came from. In the absence of any explanation from him, I think I am quite entitled to come to the conclusion that the ALP Legacies and Gifts, with its gift of nearly $2m in the 1987 election, was just a slush fund for the old mates to contribute to the Party without having their names put on the return which went before the Electoral Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's par for the course.

—Senator Short is quite right; it would be par for the course. The Bill which calls for disclosure of donations at the present time was very carefully crafted. One of the things that Senator Aulich had a great weep about was the way that donations could be divided into administration expenses and electoral expenses. Senator Aulich virtually said that the Liberal Party was dishonest and hid donations as being donations for administration and, by inference, took some of its election funding out of the administration donations which were then kept secret. The point I make is that the Act that covers that was brought in by the Labor Government, and it was brought in because the Labor Party could see a way of manipulating the system.
—No, it wasn't. We gave a bit back to you when you asked for it at the committee hearing. It was a compromise that you asked for.

—At that time, in 1983, I was in the UN, so I might stand corrected on that. I never argue with the Minister. Let us move to the heart of the matter. This Bill is a major onslaught to our civil liberties. It strikes very much at the heart of the right to freedom of association, the right to freedom of speech and the right of assembly—all the central points of our political life. It will deny the means by which Australians can be informed by people who are competing quite legitimately and openly for their votes.

PARA.TAB: In 1982, when Senator Evans came up to my own State for the T. J. Ryan memorial lecture, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: As democratic socialists we must strive to our utmost to bring about a society in which the dignity and worth of every individual is fully respected and political and civil liberty in every form is fully protected. To do less would be to dishonour the great socialist tradition to which we belong.
Yet Senator Evans is party to this rorting of the electoral system by denying the right of free speech. Later in the same speech, Senator Evans said:
What we need to do is to make the bonds of freedom wider yet. The wider they are, the safer we are.
Yet now we are being denied the right to put our case to the people by paying for television advertisements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Government by Madison Avenue; is that what you want?

—Senator Aulich seeks to be enlightened and educated tonight, and his own ALP platform says that one of its fundamental principles is the recognition and protection of fundamental political and civil rights. There is some odd protection going on at the moment here when we are being taken down the path of a one-party state.

PARA.TAB: This Labor Party is full of sanctimonious individuals. I am sorry that Senator Schacht has left the chamber. I have been quoting Senator Evans but Senator Schacht, Senator Sherry, Senator Aulich and all of their colleagues pump themselves up over civil rights; however, their concern for civil rights extends only to nations outside Australia. They are not interested in the Australian population at all. They tour the world, posturing about civil rights and perceived faults in other countries, but they are not prepared to stand up for the maintenance or extension of civil rights to the Australian community.

In conclusion, again I refer to Senator Aulich and his comments about funding and that if we raise funds we might be involved in making compromises. I remember the case in the Cooke inquiry of a Mr Nick Sherry—and I am referring to page 209 of the report—who apparently received a donation from the Queensland AWU which, at that time, was a breach of the law. I can understand that Senator Aulich, coming from Tasmania, would know of that. The law has now been changed by the Labor Government in Queensland but this non-declared donation to Mr Nick Sherry—who, at the time was running for the Senate and was, I think, the Secretary of the Liquor Trades Union in Tasmania—was illegal.

Perhaps Senator Aulich's sensitivity to what happens when people are raising funds is a product of his background, but I can assure him that most parties in Australia do not follow the practices that were followed on that occasion. While I am on that point, I can think of the time in Queensland when there was a strike by the electrical tradespeople. There was a great fundraising activity, and $40,000 of the money raised to feed the starving children and wives of the strikers went to the State election campaign fund of a fellow who is now in the Federal House for one of the Federal seats.

This is a very important Bill which is before us. As I have said before, it strikes at the right of any party in Australia to go to the public and to put its case to them so that they can be informed and can make a realistic choice. It takes us down the path towards a one-party state. It is very easy to imagine that this could be extended to the print medium and to all communications at a future date in the guise of cost saving or anti-corruption. After all, when Hitler was elected in the 1930s, he campaigned very strongly on the basis of law and order, corruption and the lack of decency within the community.

It would not surprise me at all to hear Senator Schacht, for example, in a year or two saying, `We really don't need to hold elections any more. We are right; we know what's good for you. Any attempt by you lot over there to put your point of view and take it to the community, either in press releases or articles in the print medium, on radio or anything like that, will be banned. We will put a law through'.
In conclusion, I would like to put before the Senate the words of Woodrow Wilson. When speaking on the same issue, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Liberty has never come from the Government. Liberty has always come from the subjects of it. The history of liberty is a history of resistance.
We in the Liberal and National parties are resisting this outrageous piece of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few comments in this debate tonight on the Political Broadcasting and Political Disclosures Bill 1991. Much has been said about the main part of the legislation and the main reasons for and against it. I want to pick up on the issue of third party advertising, in particular to make a few points that I think go to the heart of the legislation and to comment on some of the points raised by Senator MacGibbon. In the end, Senator MacGibbon having said his words, I say that he is drawing the wrong conclusion. He actually did correct himself when he spoke of people having a free say because the phrase `a free say' is open to misunderstanding. I suppose I am glad that Senator MacGibbon had the chance to make it clear that he did not mean at no cost in terms of dollars but, rather, that the right to have a say is protected.

PARA.TAB: Much of this debate is about misunderstanding, deliberately or unintentionally, what other people across the chamber are saying. Essentially, we are talking about whether it is fair—whether it is a matter of civil rights—that one side, one group or one subset of the community can buy influence at the price of advertising and that this is not able to be countered on behalf of others in the community who would, for a proper examination of the issues, need to hear the alternative view.

I have sought some of the evidence from the election funding and financial disclosure report on the elections for the House of Representatives and the Senate held on 24 March 1990, which is an Australian Government Publishing Service document. The list that particularly interested me—I am sure Senator MacGibbon will understand why—concerned third party advertising. That list included, amongst others, the Australian Association of Surgeons, the Australian Doctors Fund, the Australian Medical Association New South Wales branch, the Private Doctors Association and the Private Doctors Association North Queensland branch.

There are many more; I hope nobody concludes that I am giving a definitive list. Quite clearly, there are others, such as the Royal Automobile Club, as it was running a campaign about taxes on roads. There are all sorts of other groups, including foresters and so on. The allocation of money is particularly interesting. Some of those sums of money are very large, but if one finds a name that quite clearly seems to indicate a citizen—an individual—then one is talking about very modest amounts of money.

But I want to pick up on the medical contributions under this list of third party advertisers. One of those, as I have said, was the Australian Doctors Fund. One of the nice things that happens in this country is that all doctors receive information from time to time. What is nasty is how in fact people know my name and address to send it to me. I have said in this place before that somewhere or other there is a master list of all doctors and we get advised from time to time of all sorts of things.

Occasionally, we get invitations and, under the letterhead of the Australian Doctors Fund, we were invited to contribute to a fighting fund for the doctors to oppose the wicked socialist government—this Labor Government that was going to wreck the world as they knew it or, indeed, was threatening to maintain it as it had established it for the last three elections.

TALK.START.PARA: —They did. They certainly loused up the country.
—Senator Bishop will be pleased to know that I did not contribute to the Australian Doctors Fund.
—I would be amazed if you did.

—I thought the honourable senator would be. But what was interesting was that one of the things it said it would do was fight the election, which it did, according to this document, by buying advertising.
—They are entitled to.

—Of course they are, but nobody from the community has anything like the same amount of money to buy equal time and equal space to counter the claims of the Australian Doctors Fund. That is the only point I wish to make about this advertising. I was interested that Senator MacGibbon said that we were denying access to advertising. Indeed, that is not so. Under this legislation, political parties will have an opportunity of free time to put their message across at no cost to the party. That will be done according to a formula.
—There is no such thing as free time.

—There is such a thing as free time. There is time that is provided in a way that does not allow the prospect of undue influence. My point is that some people who can find the money will be able to have a say, and those consumer and community groups and the poorer people in the community will not have the right to have a say and will not be able to get their message across or balance the claims that have been put by one side only.

PARA.TAB: In short, it is a matter of equity. I am a bit shocked that the Opposition can see no case for equity. It sees no case for saying that, if those people who have a large amount of dollars want to buy the time and put their message across, that is their right but that the right of the community to know the full story, or a balanced view, should also be addressed or provided in some way as a counter to those organisations or groups which can afford the very big dollars.

In terms of health policies, it is quite clear that the Australian Doctors Fund will again be looking for funds. But, after this legislation is passed, we might be able to point out to it that the need is much less. We have seen the Opposition's health document. I have read it very closely. It is a shocking document. It is a return to the 1970s; it is back to Fraser. It is all of those sorts of things that will require a very hard sell, because it is a mischievous, dreadful health policy that will cost individuals and the country more and will add to inflation.

Given a health policy like that, of course the Opposition will want the people who will benefit from that health policy to say that it is a good thing; it will want to advise the citizens in a very prejudiced way—a weighted and biased way—of the virtues of it. The AMA will be delighted with that health policy and it will want to say that it is a good thing because it will get very much richer.

Private hospitals are also very interested, having first of all qualified what they thought would be the benefit from the Opposition's proposed health policy, because they were concerned that people would be encouraged to buy private health insurance and would buy the least level of private insurance in order to exempt them from their surplus tax obligations after the Medicare levy. That minimal private insurance entitles people only to private insurance in public hospitals. So, if one were trying to shift people out of the public hospital system into the private hospital system, that minimum level of private health insurance would not do it. That is the Opposition's health policy. The private hospitals were concerned at first. I do not know what conversations they have had since, but they are now in support of the Opposition's policy.

Of course, the Voluntary Health Insurance Association of Australia is over the moon. This is what it has been waiting 10 years for—to get rid of the current arrangements that provide equity in health, and a return to the days of privilege for those who can afford it. In an election those large moneyed vested interests are going to do as they have done before, and buy advertising. It would be very expensive for organisations like, for example, the Consumers Health Forum to buy equal time—indeed, they cannot. The report on election funding and financial disclosure shows that small consumer groups and community organisations are not represented. They do not have the opportunity to put the counter message or counter claim on behalf of the people they represent. They cannot tell the story because to do so would have too high a dollar cost. They cannot afford to have their say; they cannot afford to have equity of opportunity to speak to people and provide their message.

In this legislation the right of the public to be provided with the political story is protected through the provision of free time, and the right of consumers to have a balanced campaign presented is also protected. In light of third party advertising expenditure in previous campaigns, I think we have great reason to be concerned and great reason to support the intent of this legislation. I find it amazing that the Opposition wants to argue that this is a denial of civil rights. I do not understand how one can possibly claim that. I can understand the political reasons for doing it but it is a totally unconvincing argument.

I have now had another day to listen to the arguments put by the Opposition in its attempt to make the case for civil rights through the opportunity to buy advertising time. I do not know that enabling the buying of advertising time involves furthering civil rights, because it is not an example of free speech—it is an example, as a number of people have said, of very expensive speech. It is also a one-sided story; it seems to me to be quintessentially contradictory. I would be interested to hear whether Senator Bishop might like to refute that with argument, not declamation. I suspect it will be the latter.

It is not possible to argue that having the capacity to pay a very large amount of dollars for advertising should in any way be equated with the right to free speech. That is the crux of the matter here. The Government, by introducing this legislation, is ensuring the protection of people's rights, not denying them. I would be interested to hear the contributions of honourable senators opposite, but I do not believe we will be told anything further that will persuade us of the rightness of their case. They just insist with fury that their case is right but they cannot argue it with logic. I do not believe they will be able to bring anything new to this debate through their contributions.

The philosophical underpinning of the debate is the critical matter, not the furphies being put forward by the Opposition. We know very well how easy it is to buy influence and we know how easy it is to rort ballots and political influence to effect things, particularly through the power of persuasion, and if we are going to go that way we must guarantee equality. That is not possible under the highly expensive arrangements by which we have to pay for radio and television advertising in this country at the moment, and I look forward to a more equitable and balanced outcome as a result of this legislation which will be in place before the next elections.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested to hear Senator Crowley's request that I answer some of the questions she posed. I suppose the point one can best draw a conclusion on is that there are none so deaf as those who will not hear. She said today that she had listened attentively but had not heard anything. I repeat: there are none so deaf as those who will not hear.

PARA.TAB: I say to Senator Crowley, lest we misunderstand each other, that free speech is unfettered speech. Free speech is speech that is allowed to be made and broadcast and published. What this Government is about, in cahoots with the Australian Democrats, is fettering speech, limiting the right to have that speech broadcast and published. Indeed, it is a type of censorship. Let us again be under no misunderstanding: what we are seeing here tonight is a conspiracy between two parties—the Australian Labor Party, which is broke, and the Democrats, who represent only 4 per cent of the Australian population and cannot raise any money. In other words we are seeing a conspiracy hatched between those two parties that are incapable of earning the respect and support of the Australian people and so attract donations in order that they may have their message published and broadcast.

I repeat that the Democrats represent only 4 per cent of the population and yet, under the formula, they will get 10 per cent of the so-called free TV time that will be made available. Earlier this evening Senator Kernot said, with great passion, that the Democrats did not accept 30 pieces of silver. Indeed they did not. They have accepted $1m worth of advertising which is to be paid for by somebody else. As I will go on to point out, there is no such thing as free advertising. Somebody pays, but somebody else gets the benefit. In this case the Australian Democrats, for no trouble at all, for no effort or exertion on their part except stitching up a deal, benefit to the tune of over a million bucks worth of advertising on the media at other people's expense.

Let us examine the whole proposition of this Bill that is somehow meant to bring about an improvement in integrity. I put it to the Senate that we cannot legislate for integrity. What the Australian Labor Party did in Western Australia through its elected representatives there, through Brian Burke and his cohorts, was quite illegal, against the law—but it did not stop them. What was done when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) attended the infamous gold lunch and did a trade-off was highly immoral, but that did not stop him. We have heard a lot of talk in this chamber about brown paper bags—but the Labor Party finds that brown paper bags are not big enough. It is into suitcases—suitcases of money, stamps, gold; you name it. It is all illegal. `Burkegate' has become one of the more infamous things that has ever occurred in this nation.

Let us go back to the concept of what is free. As I have said, there was no such thing as a free lunch and there is no such thing as free advertising. The two alternatives are these: either the advertising on television which is to be made available is paid for by the shareholders, by way of forgone revenue, or it is paid for by higher advertising fees being charged to those people who advertise in different time slots and who in turn will pass on that cost to the consumers. Thus, instead of the advertising paid for by the people who want to donate money to political parties because they believe in what they stand for and they wish to see their ideas propagated, advertised and broadcast, it is being paid for by the consumers who have no control over it whatsoever. As I said, there is no such thing as free advertising because it is ultimately paid for by either shareholders or consumers—certainly not by those people who stand to benefit from the legislation, most importantly the Australian Democrats.

Let us look at what some of the unintended consequences of this ban will be: that visually impaired, illiterate or semi-literate and aged people will be affected; that people in outlying areas and provincial towns will have to depend solely on biweekly or even weekly newspapers; and that print-handicapped radio stations will have to use extreme caution in transmitting information. The ban could well prevent even the advertising of political meetings to which people might go to find out something. Then there will be the magnificent spectacle of the increased power of the political journalists, who will be in a position to interpret the words of political parties without the political parties or individuals having the right to take paid advertising space and refute points of view that are misinterpreted by those journalists.
I think Michelle Grattan put it quite accurately in the Melbourne Age when she said:

SPEECH.PARA: If a party thinks the media coverage is biased, it will have no way of putting its views on the electronic media independently (outside of news and current affairs programs)—
where again they act as a filter of the words that are put forth. That is hardly, I would think, anybody's understanding of what is free speech.

PARA.TAB: The net effect of the Bill, far from decreasing the cost of running elections, is to increase the overall cost of those elections, because the amount of money which has been available to spend will still be available to spend. In the case of the Labor Party, that amount of money will be used in increasing its direct mail program, again very much at the taxpayers' expense, through its policy, which it has finally got through the Parliament one way or another, of increasing the postage allowance of individual members and senators to allow that direct mail to go out at taxpayers' expense. As I have said, the effect of it will be to add $18m of television advertising, the cost of which is being borne either by the shareholders in those television companies or by the consumers by way of added on cost, because other advertisers will have to pay a greater fee to cover the so-called free time or compulsorily acquired time that is going to be used for political messages.

Not only are the Government and the Democrats together in their conspiracy not satisfied with having dictated what time is to be made available, by whom and at what cost; they are also going to dictate the manner in which this information is to be disseminated. We heard a great exposition from Senator Kernot in this chamber earlier tonight in which she told us her vision of how a television political advertisement shall run. These are the sorts of rules that one was used to seeing in place in totalitarian states, in which the government was in complete control of who put what to air, what messages were acceptable and what other messages were not acceptable.

Is it not extraordinary that this Government, which has been pressed time and time again to put some sort of limitation or restriction on the availability of pornographic videos, will not do so and says that they must be freely available, but is frightened to death of a political message which might expose some of the goings on with visible images of the things that the Labor Party has indulged in. Perhaps it would not like an advertisement that said that Mr Hogg had been convicted of false returns. Perhaps it would not like a visible image displaying Mr Burke and his Burkegate frauds upon the people of Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What frauds?
—Many frauds; the channelling of funds into private accounts which were illegal.
—There is no conviction.
—We are waiting for that to arise. We have had Senator Evans cover up for him for so long.
—You hold in contempt the idea—
—I hold in contempt the very idea of what Mr Burke did, yes, and so does every other decent Australian.

PARA.TAB: I take it—through you, Madam Acting Deputy President—that Senator Cook is defending Mr Burke. I think we should note for the record that Senator Cook finds he wishes to stand up for and champion the cause of Mr Burke, who not only perpetrated a fraud on the Western Australian people but also managed to defraud the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade with his telephone account alone, and the bringing in of cars and all the other little rorts and torts.

TALK.START.PARA: —And what has he been convicted of?

—Is Senator Cook standing up for him? Through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, I am delighted to know—and I think the rest of Australia should know—that Senator Cook wishes to uphold the righteousness of former Premier Burke and to uphold him as an outstanding person and somebody who should be lauded. I am glad the Labor Party is proud of former Premier Burke.
—Why don't you tell the truth for a change instead of lying?
—I think it is very important that the Australian people know that. Not only did Senator Evans have to cover up for him; now Senator Cook also wants to—
—Why don't you stop lying and tell the truth?
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Cook referred to my colleague as a liar. I think that is unparliamentary and he should withdraw it.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, if I have said anything that is against Standing Orders, I withdraw it. On the point of order, allegations have been made by Senator Bishop that I have said things that I have not said. The essential point is that in this country there is a right of people to be presumed innocent until they are proven guilty. Senator Bishop is making allegations that people are guilty without due process. She is a lawyer and she knows better than that. To drag the chamber into this disrepute is a reflection on her and she should be made to withdraw as well.

—On the point of order, I think it is important that we understand what the good senator had to say then. Do I understand that he was not saying that he supported Premier Burke? Did he say that he does not support the things that he did? I would like to get it right, because I think the Australian people ought to know whether he is the sort of person who supports the actions of former Premier Burke. That is the important point.
—Senator Bishop, I am not at all certain about what point you are trying to make at the moment.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I think there clearly was an implication by Senator Bishop that there was some form of fraudulent operation in Western Australia.
—You bet I did.

—Senator Bishop has confirmed it out of her own mouth. She has tried to associate other senators in this chamber with what she has described as a fraudulent activity. Senator Knowles said that I said Mr Burke was guilty of some sort of fraud. I have never said that. I want to clarify and ask for your ruling, Madam Acting Deputy President, on the matter that any implications that we support fraud should be withdrawn by Senator Bishop promptly.

—I am in a bit of a quandary. It seems that it may well be within the power of the Senate to give you leave to make a personal explanation either at the end of the debate or at some other time. The point of order that was before the Chair was in relation to Senator Cook's reference to Senator Bishop. He has withdrawn the remark that was unparliamentary and I suggest that Senator Bishop returns to the debate.

—The point I was making was that the Labor Party, while trying to say that it is in favour of having legislation in place that will somehow prevent corrupt behaviour, is in a situation in which it has had representatives in the Western Australian Parliament who have not been prevented from improper behaviour by the legislation being in place. The other point I was making was that there are people in the ALP in this chamber who wish to defend that sort of behaviour, and I think the Australian people ought to know that. I now return to the point I was making that there is no such thing as free advertising.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I resent the allegation that `there are people in this chamber'. It is a jibe clearly aimed at this side, and me in particular. I resent the allegation that I am a person who defends people whose behaviour or conduct is corrupt. That is not true. It has never been true and it is never my intention. It is an allegation against me and I think it should be withdrawn.
—Disgraceful, Senator Bishop.
—It is not unparliamentary against you; she said `people'.
—Then why doesn't she withdraw it?
—Get to know your Standing Orders.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—I think it might be a good idea to give me a chance to rule on this. It was certainly a very offensive remark, Senator Bishop. I think in the cause of an orderly debate I should ask you to withdraw.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. You would be aware that an alleged unparliamentary comment has to be made about an individual, not a number of people, unnamed, or a party. You would be well aware of that, Madam Acting Deputy President, because Standing Orders permit comments to be made against even the group on the other side of the chamber. Senator Schacht would be well aware of that. Therefore, there is no need for Senator Bishop to make any apology.

—In the course of her remarks, Senator Bishop did make some references which I would consider to be certainly bordering on the offensive in relation to members of the Government. I am afraid that I do not recall whether she made that remark specifically in relation to Senator Cook, although I believe the remark was certainly made in relation to Senator Aulich. The suggestion was made that Senator Aulich had the capacity to seek leave to speak in order to defend his position. It has been suggested to me that the remarks that were made by Senator Bishop were in a general sense. I do not think they are at all helpful as far as the debate is concerned. But, under the circumstances, without being able to be more certain than that about the actual words used, I would suggest that we return to the debate.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I think the sensitivity that is shown by the other side on this issue can lead people to draw their own conclusions. One could say if the cap fits, wear it. I was saying that there is no such thing as free advertising. Indeed, the effect of the Bill is not to decrease but to increase the cost of elections. The total amount that will be spent or borne by somebody within the community will be increased by $18m, of which the Democrats will share up to $1.8m. This is not a bad rental fee. It has often been said of the Democrats that one cannot buy them; one can only rent them by the hour. That is quite a rental fee.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot said that she is most concerned that we do not go the way of the United States elections. She was very concerned not only about the amount of money spent but also about the amount of influence that those who provided the money might have over those who were the beneficiaries of it. But the point is, of course, that this Bill does push us down the United States route and the route of the PACs, the political action committees.

TALK.START.PARA: —You must be reading the Bill upside down, back to front and in front of a mirror.
—The interesting thing is that the people who are being exempted—
—You have got to be joking.

—If Senator Schacht would just be quiet a for moment, I will explain it to him so that even he can understand. The political action committees have developed in the United States to fund and look after individuals, not parties. The effect of this Bill is to exempt so-called public interest groups who will be allowed to put advertising to air. In other words, the people who will be permitted to run advertisements, be they defined in some other subtle way, the people who will be entitled to put a message to air, will not be supporting political parties but will be able to have influence over individuals in exactly the way the political action committees in the United States have influence. So there will no longer be that affinity and discipline running within the party system itself, though there will be individuals who are answerable to outside groups.

PARA.TAB: The direct mail program has developed in such a way in the United States that it has further enforced the power of the political action committees. By allowing outside groups to run the advertisements under this legislation—

TALK.START.PARA: —Give us an example.
—If Senator Schacht would be quiet for a moment he might learn something.
—That is the definition of `impossible'.

—I know that it is hard for him to learn. I know it is hard but just try. The outside groups which are being exempted are in the same situation that exists in the United States—the one which Senator Kernot said had become so dangerous and which she did not wish to follow. However, she was prepared to tell us how and where there would be the types of so-called talking heads that would be permitted to put boring messages that are not supposed to be a danger to the minds of viewers and that would not be confused with any political message.

PARA.TAB: But, of course, the Democrats are the real winners in this package because, as I said before, under the funding arrangements that are being put in place this group, which represents 4 per cent of the population, will get 10 per cent of the goodies. That is not a bad deal.

TALK.START.PARA: —A pretty good deal.
—A pretty good deal but then they are pretty good wheelers and dealers. We have also heard quite a lot of talk in this chamber on the question—

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats represent 4 per cent of the Australian population. Labor only got 39 per cent but managed to get over 50 per cent of the seats. A great system!

PARA.TAB: If we can go back to the question of civil liberties and civil rights, let us look once again at what Mr Brian Burdekin—

TALK.START.PARA: —The representative of the New South Wales uglies to talk about human rights!

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I know that Senator Schacht is due to speak after the next speaker in this debate but I would be pleased if you would ask him to wait until his turn or else perhaps deduct from the time available to him the time he is taking up of my speech.
—Perhaps you could address the Chair instead of responding to his interjections.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I am addressing you and I am asking you either to give me some time out of his time or to ask him to wait his turn.

PARA.TAB: I want to return to what Mr Brian Burdekin had to say. He has been quite pre-eminent in this entire debate. He is a man who has been totally discounted by Senator Schacht and his ilk. Of course, Senator Schacht pretends to defend human rights when he is overseas visiting the rest of the world but he has no interest in human rights when he is home here in Australia. So he would not be interested in what Mr Brian Burdekin had to say. He is only interested in `them', not `us'. In his press release of 20 March this year, Mr Burdekin said that he was concerned that aspects of the proposals may be inconsistent with certain—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are quoting on the wrong Bill.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, it is going to be a long night. I would ask you at this stage to make a ruling as to whether I may have at least seven minutes of Senator Schacht's time to totally interject, because that is about what he has taken of my speech.
—You can't take it you mob, can you?
—You bet I can take it. Wait until the honourable senator gets up.

—Order! Senator Schacht, we do note that you are to speak in a short while. I suggest that you keep your response to Senator Bishop until you actually get some speaking time. I would ask you to be a little more orderly, Senator Schacht.

—What do you expect from a man who does not wear a tie except when he is on television? Mr Burdekin said that he was concerned that aspects of the proposal may be inconsistent with fundamental human rights. He said that these are rights contained in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which Australia ratified in 1980. If we take a closer look at that convention, we can see that article 19.2 states:
