SPEECH.PARA: Everyone shall have the right to freedom of expression; this right shall include freedom to seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kinds, regardless of frontiers, either orally, in writing or in print, in the form of art, or through any other media of his choice.

There is quite clearly a statement that we have the right not only to speak the words but also to have them published and spread abroad so that they can be appreciated by all in the electorate and so that they may make a judgment about them. As I have said before, what is the Labor Party so afeard of? We know that it is broke and that it overspent. As I said earlier today, those opposite went to the last election saying that if a party cannot govern itself, it cannot govern the country. Today we have a further dictum: if a party cannot handle its own finances, it cannot handle the country's finances either. There is no way that we can afford to end up in the mess. You have bankrupted the country just as you have bankrupted your own party.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not bankrupted my Party. That is a ridiculous proposition. The country is not bankrupt.

—You have bankrupted the country. We have seen the Labor Party get itself into a huge hole and it will be interesting to see whether the liquidators move in. There is a debt of $7m in New South Wales and what did you do about it? What is the part you will play in the conference on Saturday?
—I don't actually happen to be a member of the New South Wales branch of the Labor Party.
—I am talking to Senator Faulkner, who is a member of the Left.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—Senator Bishop, you really cannot complain about being interrupted if you insist on chatting with those on the other side of the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —One or two points have to be made. Poor old Senator Faulkner in the minority Left in New South Wales has a problem. His branch is in debt to the tune of $7m, it has a building on its hands it cannot finance and it has a meeting on Saturday. As I said, if a party cannot handle its own finances, it cannot handle the country's either. It is the same dictum that the Labor Party put out before the last election.

PARA.TAB: The bottom line is that this country has been made bankrupt and one million Australians have been put out of work because of the Government's policies. Those people are now being told that at the next election the Opposition will not be able to show images of one million people out of work and what it means to be destitute because of the policies of this Government.

This Government has put in place an extraordinary policy. We ask the question yet again: why has this matter become so urgent? Why does the Government keep pushing off, for instance, the wholesale sales tax Bill, which is meant to alleviate some of the imposts on businesses to allow them to compete better? Why is that Bill being pushed back and back while the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill has been brought on all of a sudden in such a desperate hurry? The real reason is that if the Government allowed the broadcasting legislation to be debated in the electorate until sitting time next year, the pressure on the Democrats would be such that the deal it has stitched up would fail. That is the bottom line of why this Bill is urgent. The Government is frightened that, if pressure is put on the Democrats, the deal will fall through.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, really?

—The Government has had to pay dearly for this move. It has cost in excess of $1m in taxpayers' money, consumers' money and shareholders' money for the Government to try to camouflage and hide the fact that it has been a failed, bad, poor government. Irrespective of all the tactics that the Government will get up to, the Australian people will get that message through.
—Lots of spanking is needed.

—I beg your pardon. Spanking! The reality is that this is, as I said right at the beginning, a conspiracy between a party that is broke and a party that is incapable of attracting money to itself. We are seeing perpetrated upon shareholders of private companies and consumers an impost Bill of $18m. We are seeing further put upon us an avenue open to the Labor Party to increase its expenditure on direct mail into an electorate that is compelled to vote so that it can very easily identify those it wants to persuade. (Time expired)
—Before I proceed any further, I raise a point of order. I believe that Senator Aulich called my colleague Senator Bronwyn Bishop by an unparliamentary term. I think he should withdraw it.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—I am unaware of what was said. I am afraid, Senator Panizza, that I am not in a position to help you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Further on the point of order: I believe that someone should listen to the tape and Senator Aulich can withdraw the comment tomorrow.

—On that point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President: Senator Panizza might be having nightmares and hallucinations. I wonder whether he could describe what I said. It seems silly to take a point of order on some sort of aspersion and then talk about listening to tapes. I would be happy to have Senator Panizza point out what he thought I said. We can perhaps clarify that if Senator Panizza is quite happy to give up more of his time on this speech.
—I am not giving up any of my time. I believe that Senator Aulich said that Senator Bishop needs a lot of spanking.
—No. On the point of order: when Senator Aulich made a comment concerning what he felt the Labor Party may require, I said that I did not think it was appropriate for it either.
—I am afraid that it is something that completely eluded me. There is no point of order.

—On that point of order: I said no such thing. Senator Panizza ought to listen a little more carefully. It is a silly thing to raise in a debate. Through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, I suggest that Senator Panizza get on with the debate. I am interested in hearing what he has to say. Let us talk about the Bill rather than minor points of order.
—I will read the Hansard tomorrow and listen to the tape and we will debate the matter further then.
—I call Senator Panizza.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we already know, the purpose of the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill is to modify the proposed moratorium that the Government has previously spoken about regarding political advertising and the provision of free time for election broadcasts.

PARA.TAB: The idea now is that the Labor Party and others are not in a position to finance an election campaign. The Labor Party is looking for $18m of `forcified' donations whereas before it probably got some free flowing donations. We have now got to the stage where those donations will be `forcified'.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is a `forcified' donation?

—What does Senator Cook reckon? If television stations have to give free time to elections for election broadcasting—talking heads—Senator Cook should not tell me it is not `forcified'. Senator Cook ought to go away and learn his terms. After much debate and having been out to—
—It goes to everyone equally.
—I know that it might be treating everyone equally, but it is still `forcified'. If Senator Cook wants to debate the point further, I will debate it any other time.

PARA.TAB: After much discussion in front of a committee, the Government decided to restrict the advertising ban to election periods. The advertisements containing political matter will be restricted at times other than those leading up to Commonwealth, State and Territory elections. With the way that this Government is clamping down on exposing issues in this country, be they wrongdoings or otherwise, it is a wonder it did not also include local government elections in the Bill. The Government has kind-heartedly exempted charitable organisations, public health organisations and that sort of thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you disagree with that?

—No, I do not. My point is that at least the Government went that far. That is what I am saying. I am not disagreeing with that measure in any way whatsoever. I am agreeing that the Government has allowed that those organisations to be exempt.

PARA.TAB: As I said, according to the Government, political advertising would be banned except for the three months running up to an election. We now have the case involving the laughing hyena from New South Wales. When the New South Wales Government sends citizens their water rates, land tax rates or whatever, it sends them a note telling them what a good job it is doing. It is ripping off people's money, using it and then telling them what a great job it is doing with it.

I notice that the hyena from New South Wales has kept quiet on that matter. That is the official reason that the Government has given us. But what is the real reason? The real reason is that the Australian Labor Party is broke. The reasons given for having the ban now cover similar circumstances to those which existed in the 1983 Federal election, the 1984 double dissolution, the 1987 double dissolution and the 1990 election. They existed at the time of all those elections; where was the talk of the ban then?

TALK.START.PARA: —Aren't you glad we are stopping it now?

—I am not glad. Similar circumstances existed at the time of the Western Australian State elections in 1983, 1986 and 1989. All of the conditions that the Government is now putting forward existed then, but there was not a whimper from the Labor Government or the Western Australian Labor Party, in opposition at the time. There was nothing said about it then.

PARA.TAB: The difference between then and now is that money was flowing then from the Labor Party's rich mates for whom it was doing favours. That is why it was not brought up at that time. Now, the money from those rich mates has run out. Those funds are nowhere near as forthcoming as they were. This Government is now trying to prevent the Opposition, the coalition, from exposing the Government to the electorate as the election approaches; exposing it for its wrong actions and its inaction.

This legislation will prevent the coalition from telling Australia of the broken promises of the Hawke Government: that there would be no children in poverty by 1990. Madam Acting Deputy President, do you remember that promise delivered by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself? I think that everyone does. Had the Prime Minister changed that promise to `no child need be living in poverty by 1990', somebody might have believed him. But he said—this is the sort of thing that has to be exposed to the electorate; even the illiterates from New South Wales might learn something—

TALK.START.PARA: —Who are you calling illiterate?

—I am calling some people from New South Wales illiterate. That is what I am doing. If the cap fits, Senator Faulkner should wear it. At the same time I wish he would grow a beard so that we would not have to put up with his stupid grin.

PARA.TAB: One of the broken promises of the Hawke Labor Government was that there would be no child in poverty by 1990. Another was that there would be no capital gains tax. Do you remember that one, Madam Acting Deputy President? All Australians have to be reminded of the promise that there would be no capital gains tax. Another promise was that there would be no fringe benefits tax while another was that there would be no new taxes. Do honourable senators remember all those promises?

TALK.START.PARA: —We remember the consumption tax.

—The former Treasurer, Mr Keating, wanted a goods and services tax or, as Senator Walsh likes to call it, a value added tax. We do not hide the fact that it is a value added tax. We were in favour of it; Keating was in favour of it.

PARA.TAB: We are being prevented from telling Australia where this Government has fallen down. We wanted to tell the people of Western Australia about Burkegate and the Burke Government's deals with its rich mates. We will be unable to remind the electors of the sale of the Midland saleyards—20 acres in the heart of Midland, well developed, which was sold for $420,000 to one of the Burke Government's friends, simply to set up a brickyard which would run in competition with a very efficient one, the owner of which was sometimes known to be friendly towards the Liberal Party.

The Government decided to sell the farmers' stock selling complex at Midland junction. As Senator Cook, who should speak for the farmers, should know, the Western Australian Government sold that complex under the noses of the Western Australian farmers for $420,000. Three years later, the company who bought it wanted to sell it back to the Government for $12m. I will go on a bit further about this deal if Senator Schacht would like to listen. Having gotten hold of the complex for $400,000, within a few months—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. This is a marvellous travelogue from Senator Panizza, but it really has absolutely nothing to do with the matter before the Chair. I ask you to rule that way.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Order! There is no point of order. I have heard this debate ranging far and wide this evening.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner does not want to listen to what this Bill will prevent the Opposition exposing in Western Australia, but others in Australia may wish to. The property was originally sold by the Burke Government for $420,000 and three years later the company wanted to sell it back to the Government for $12m. What did the character who bought the saleyards do with it? Within three months, fittings worth nearly $400,000 had been stripped from the premises. In other words, the original cost was exactly $80,000. It is the biggest daylight robbery of Western Australian farmers that there has ever been, and there have been plenty of them. We will be unable to remind the people of Western Australia of the Rothwell's rescue and how it was carried out. I really do not need to go into it at this stage. We will be unable to remind the people of Burke in Ireland and his telephone bills and also of other disgraced Ministers of the Western Australian Government; that is, if they are not in different places by then. We will be totally unable to remind the people of Premier Dowding's cover-ups. We will be unable to tell the people that the money from the rich mates who backed the Dowding Government has dried up. I remember the Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia at the time, Bill Hassell, trying to expose—
—An outstanding Leader of the Opposition.

—Yes, he was a good Leader of the Opposition and Senator Schacht has not heard the last of him either. When Bill Hassell was trying to expose what the Dowding Government was doing, the Labor Party's mates in the media knocked him down—and now he has been proven to be right. When he exposed the Bond donations, the media tried to iron him out. Of course, it is all history now that the Dowding Government, with its methods, got over the line in the last election by 300 votes. What has that cost Western Australia?

PARA.TAB: The cover-up touches the Hawke Government as well. We certainly know what the Hawke Government has done to ruin Australia. We will not be able to remind the people of the one million unemployed. Fortunately, they will remind the Government in the ballot box. The Labor Party is bankrupt by its own admission and that is why it wants this Bill to be passed: to get the taxpayers of Australia to pay for the election campaign.

The Labor Party in New South Wales, of course, has its own story. It is bankrupt to the tune of $7m. Today it has been issued a demand of delivery for $1m invested in a building plus $450,000 in back rent. It has been mooted that Senator Loosley's investment capabilities have not been too crash hot in the past few years. For his sake and the sake of his young family, I hope that he has not given any personal guarantees. It is probably his first lesson in real estate dealing and it will be a lesson that he will remember for a long time.

Today there is more bad news for the Labor Government in all directions. Why has this piece of legislation been declared an urgent Bill? One of the main reasons, apart from the Labor Party throughout Australia being broke, is that there could be some elections around the corner.

The Government is bankrupt, as well as the Labor Party, so it might not be too long before we go to an election. Tasmania may have one very soon. I know that the Labor Party in Tasmania is broke. New South Wales may also be in an election mood before very long, and the Labor Party is broke in New South Wales. This Bill has been declared urgent because the Labor Party needs the taxpayers to fund the elections.

The Western Australian Government is just hanging on with five Independents. Of those five there is only one true Independent; one person who was elected as an Independent. One abandoned a particular Party and the rest abandoned the Government. There could be an election in Western Australia at any time, and the Labor Party there is broke. Mr Connell is nowhere to be seen to provide funds and Mr Bond is fighting the bankruptcy court, so he cannot provide any more funds. The Western Australian Government overspent in the last State election—just like the Federal Labor Party overspent in its last election. Now the Labor Party is trying to make up ground by getting the taxpayers of Australia to fund their campaigns.

I remember the election in Western Australia with Peter Dowding being touted on television in his short sleeves. Short sleeves is generally a sign of people doing work. That would be the first and last time in his life that he has worn short sleeves. Here he was being shown with his family in the park doing this and doing that. That was all heaped up by the Labor Party's rich mates. It got them over the line by 300 votes but what has that cost the people of Western Australia?

What other tragedies around Australia does stopping this political advertising cause? It stops the peak bodies of industry from advertising to remind the Government of its shortcomings. The NRMA will be prevented from telling Australians about the lack of spending on roads under this Federal Government. Madam Acting Deputy President, you may remember the campaign that the RACs of Australia conducted leading up to the last election, pointing out the state of Australian roads and the lack of spending on them. I remember it very well.

Why cannot the National Farmers Federation spell out how this Government has killed off the rural industry; how it has left rural Australia to die and rot? Why cannot the Chamber of Mines tell of the Government's inaction on Coronation Hill? There was some action but it was the wrong way. Time and time again the Government held out hope to the mining companies, but when it was time to deliver it had to repay its greedy mates for those few miserable preferences that in the last election got the Government over the line.

Why can the mining industry not tell the taxpayers about Yakabindie and the fights going on over Aboriginal heritage with people who are not Aboriginals, holding up another project worth $300m? Why can the industry not tell them about Marandoo where they are holding up a $500m project; a mine needed to keep Mount Tom Price and Paraburdoo viable into the next century? Why can it not tell them about these resources that are locked up everywhere?

Why can the pastoralists and graziers not tell the voters of Western Australia how the Kimberley pastoral industry has been raped? Because of the downturn in prices of the cattle stations in that area, the Government is now using my money and your money, Madam Acting Deputy President, to buy those stations and turn them into national parks. There is no beauty on those stations. I have had the experience of going over them. Why can we not tell the taxpayers that?

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I ask what this has to do with the Bill?

—These sorts of wrongdoings cannot be put in front of the voters when the election comes. That is what it has to do with the Bill. Let us get to corruption. We have been told this evening, and at other times during debate on this Bill, that we need this political ban to stop corruption. Can anyone tell me where there has been any proven evidence or even accusations of corruption in the Federal Government? There is plenty of corruption around the States, particularly Western Australia, but there is none, to my knowledge, in the Federal Government. So why do we need this Bill now?

PARA.TAB: I know that when this Bill went in front of the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures only three witnesses had any idea of bringing this Bill into vogue because of any corruption; only three of all those who appeared in front of it. I believe that corruption, at least on the part of the Federal Government, is a non-issue. As far as the coalition is concerned disclosure was never a question. The only thing we were worried about was the closing up of political advertising to put these things in front of the people.

The Australian Democrats stand to gain $1.8m in free advertising; in other words, 10 per cent of the $18m allocated. I quote from a press release headed `Powell: Victory on disclosure of political donations', issued by Senator Powell way back on 8 August 1991:
The Australian Democrats have forced the Government to compromise on its Political Advertising and Disclosure legislation.

Thanks to continuing Democrat negotiations the Bill will now be split. The Government will proceed with the disclosure of political donations and has put forward a compromise on its advertising ban proposal.
In April, when the Democrats and Opposition urged splitting the Bill, the Government was adamant that it was all or nothing—no ban, no disclosure.

SPEECH.PARA: That was the position on 8 August 1991 but, of course, since then we have had a change in the leadership of the Democrats. Senator Powell paid her price for stating that this political advertising ban would proceed on these terms. As soon as a new leader is elected by the Democrats, here we are back to the same old story—that Senator Powell tried to do something about it way back in April this year. That is how it went. Senator Powell's stand came to an end when she lost her position.

PARA.TAB: With this ban on political advertising we will also not be able to tell Australia as a whole about the little tricks the Democrats have been up to in the last year or so. For example, we cannot disclose their overtime bill. The Democrats now need $1.8m to run a budget for the next Federal election—or whatever other election it may be—because they have been obtaining their funds through the non-payment of the overtime of staffers. There was a case some time ago where a staffer ran up overtime of approximately $59,000 in eight months. In order to qualify for that I think that the staffer would have had to work about 26 hours a day—that was the figure I worked out. We will not be able to disclose that. They cannot fight an election on that issue because someone blew the whistle on their overtime bill.

What the Government wants here is free advertising; that is, the Labor Party wants free advertising because it has run out of money and it has run out of rich friends to get any money from them. However, the Labor Party started up this issue quite some time ago with the postage allowance. That was when the postage allowance increased. It was uncalled for. I do not remember any submissions to increase the postage allowance. Does Senator Walters remember any submissions being received?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—All of a sudden the allowance went from $9,000 to $22,000 annually. In the changeover year we finished up with $35,000. That was put there for direct mailing—which the Government has been a master of—and, of course, that will again be paid for by the taxpayers of Australia. It is talking heads all right!

PARA.TAB: In the short time I have left I will refer to remote areas. The banning of all radio political advertising will affect remote areas the most. Radio is the only true media propagation that can reach every square metre of Australia, the high seas around it and the offshore islands. Although TV may be available through a satellite, the installations must be there or it will not reach those people.

In Western Australia alone 426,000 people live outside the metropolitan area and, of those, 156,000 live in remote areas. Under normal circumstances they probably would not get television. These are the people who will be most affected. Many people live in mobile mining camps. A mining camp has to be set up for a few weeks before we go to the bother of putting in a remote station. There is no political advertising on radio, so nobody will be able to reach these people.

That is why the Government has decided—aided and abetted by the Democrats—to cover up the inefficiencies: the way it has run the country, the way it has neglected the roads, and the way it has neglected the poor and the children who, it was said, would not be living in poverty by 1990. It has done all of those things to cover this up. I will conclude with a quotation from, I think, Senator Kernot, who stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The next election will be won by the politician who is the most honest with the electorate, who is straight to the point and says how he is going to solve the problems in this country as faced. They have to be informative and straight to the point.

That is exactly what the Government is trying to prevent us from doing. The Government may or may not be successful with the Bill in the long run. I believe that even the Democrats, when they hear the public opinion of what is going on here, may change their minds on the action they are taking. They will be to blame, as much as anyone else, for closing up information going out.

PARA.TAB: Earlier this evening, there was mention of how Germany cranked up in the 1930s, leading up to the Second World War. One of the first things that Hitler did was close up the media.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Would that not be correct? I do not think Senator Bolkus would know about that. A late colleague of mine from Western Australia, Andrew Mensaros—he was the first non-British born ever elected to an Australian Parliament, and the first Australian Minister of non-British origin—continually pointed out that we should not give up any of our freedoms in Australia. He was brought up under the German regime; he had a dose of the communist regime; and, fortunately, he escaped to Australia. He told us at every opportunity that we in Australia give rights up far too easily. This is one of the ways we are going if this Bill is passed in this place. I support all of the amendments moved by my colleagues. I call on the Democrats to think where they are going, as their position will be further compromised if they support the Government on this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is about the third or fourth time I have had the opportunity to speak in the Senate on this issue of disclosure of political donations and of controlling the impact of electronic advertising for elections. I, therefore, at some stage may repeat some of the remarks I have made previously, but I think this is a major issue—on that I agree with the Opposition. However, I also want to point out to the Opposition that we have been debating this on and off for nearly four years. It is not an issue that has just sprung up.

PARA.TAB: There has been a level of community debate about these issues that has not been ignored by the Parliament or the Government, and I believe it is ridiculous to suggest that with this debate, which is going to go for something like nearly two days non-stop, we are ramming this Bill through. After nearly four years of consideration, I think it is quite reasonable for this Bill to be debated over the next 12 to 20 hours. I point out to those opposite that this is an issue that many of us in the Labor Party have been interested in for even more than four years. I can remember these issues being debated in the early 1980s at the Labor Party conferences, at both State and Federal level, long before any suggestion—
Honourable senators interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Order! Senator Schacht has the floor.

TALK.START.PARA: —This was long before any suggestion was made that the Labor Party was lacking funds. After the last election, in one of the first Caucus meetings of the federal parliamentary Labor Party, on 15 May 1990, I moved a motion in the Caucus in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Minister for Administrative Services report to the first normal meeting of—

TALK.START.PARA: — Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. If Senator Schacht thinks that this is such an important speech that he is making, and now that two of us are standing on our feet, I do not know who has got the call—

PARA.TAB: One of the things I want to comment on was that during the debate Senator Bishop quoted article 19 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. And she was certainly correct in quoting the paragraph which says:

SPEECH.PARA: Everyone shall have the right to freedom of expression; this right shall include freedom to seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kinds, regardless of frontiers, either orally, in writing or in print, in the form of art, or through any other media of his choice.

That was where Senator Bishop stopped quoting. She failed to mention, of course, that article 19 also provides that this is not an absolute right. It may be subject to certain restrictions which are provided by law and which are necessary either for respect of the rights or reputations of others or for the protection of national security, public order, public health or morals. In any society freedom of speech is already curtailed by such restrictions as defamation laws, laws against incitement to racism, laws making it an offence to write graffiti in certain places, and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not allow free speech but you allow free pornography.
—Order! I would like some order please in the Senate. Senator Schacht is speaking. Thank you.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I just want to point out that I am also on another select committee of this Parliament, which is looking at community standards relevant to such services as Telecom's 0055 services. It should not be a surprise to Senator Bishop that some of her colleagues are very hot to trot to use the telecommunications laws to ban and/or restrict the use of 0055 numbers—a quite legitimate argument in accordance with public morals. I do not know whether I will agree or disagree with what such senatorial colleagues as Senator Walters may suggest on that committee, but we will have that debate.

PARA.TAB: However, it is quite clear that Senator Walters and other Liberal senators on that committee agree that there is no absolute right to free speech. They want to restrict it. They want to restrict it in private telephone conversations between adults. They make that quite clear. I do not know whether it is a major issue of free speech, but I would say that it certainly proves that, when it suits them, those opposite support restricting free speech.

When evidence came before the select committee from very prominent international constitutional lawyers, including people called by the Opposition, such as Professor Alston, those opposite made it quite clear that, though they may disagree with the Bill, they did not disagree with the concept that governments have the right to make adjustments to article 19 about the freedom of speech on issues such as the protection of national security, public order, public health or morals. They made it quite clear that it is legitimate for any government to introduce legislation and enact legislation in those areas. They may disagree on a matter of judgment about the impact of this Bill, but they did not disagree that the Government has the right on the issues of public order and corruption to introduce this legislation; and we have done so. And there has been nothing said.

In all the claptrap from the Opposition I have never heard so many conversions to the issue of human rights and of free speech as I have heard tonight amongst those opposite, who, if they were given a compass, a map and three weeks, would not be able to find anything to do with human rights and free speech. Those opposite have never been noted for standing up on the basic issue of human rights, except that occasionally some of them will speak when it suits them politically. Generally, they do not take a broad approach to the issue of human rights. When those opposite say that, because of my interest in human rights, it is hypocritical to support this Bill, I am staggered. When somebody opposite suggests that the violation of human rights in a country like Cambodia is the equivalent of this Bill as an invasion of human rights, it is absurd. That suggestion is made by honourable senators opposite who would never go near Cambodia if they were paid $1m per minute. They would not have the courage to go to a place like Cambodia or South Africa, except that when Senator Bishop goes to South Africa, she goes as a guest of the racist regime of South Africa, stays at the top hotels and meets the rich whites, but she does not go into Soweto or Alexandra townships to see where the blacks live. She only goes as a guest of the white racist regime. And for 20 years those opposite—

—I accept Senator Bishop's indication that she has not visited South Africa. I am surprised that she has not. It is about the only country with a right wing regime that she has not visited in her career.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. Senator Schacht is trying to draw conclusions which are reflecting on the fact that I have not visited South Africa and he is attempting to cast an unfavourable light on the fact that I have not so visited. I would like him to withdraw that, too.
—There is no point of order, Senator Bishop.

—I certainly accept, as I said before, Senator Bishop's comment that she has not visited South Africa. I was also mentioning that many other Opposition senators have visited South Africa on and off over the last 20 years as guests of the white racist regime of South Africa.

PARA.TAB: I want to tackle the issue raised by honourable senators opposite about the cost of providing free time. I do not think they realise that the allocation of the spectrum for radio and television broadcasting is done by government regulation. The broadcasting spectrum is a community resource. It can be used only if there is government regulation to ensure that it is efficiently used. Nobody in the broadcasting industry—television or radio—dare suggest that there should be no regulation of the broadcasting spectrum, because they know that if there is no regulation there will be jamming, people will cut across each other's signal and there will be chaos. They all want regulation to ensure that their signal, once allocated, is sent out unjammed by any other person.

But, as a consequence, because it is a resource belonging to the community, not belonging in perpetuity to the broadcasting stations—television or radio—it is not unreasonable from time to time that the Parliament of Australia, representing the community, should put reasonable obligations on those broadcasters to provide a community service. We do it in a number of ways, and certainly honourable senators opposite are quite willing to argue that those obligations should be there. I instance program standards. People such as Senator Walters and Senator Bishop are more than happy to have a body that sets standards on the content of program—standards that, it can be claimed, are an infringement of the concept of free speech. I accept that, but I also say that we have every right to set a standard including a community obligation.

If honourable senators opposite read very carefully the Government's propositions, they would see that the allocation of six minutes a day for the period of an election campaign—there will be two every three or four years—is not an onerous cost and, in fact, I think the profitability of the stations would not be affected at all. Even if it were, we are talking about revenue that is probably the equivalent of about half of one per cent of a revenue base of about $1 billion in a three- or four-year period. It is not an onerous cost to the shareholders or whoever owns the television or radio stations. I would point out to honourable senators opposite that, if they read the Government's amendments, they will see that in fact there is no obligation on the radio stations to provide free time. It is only an obligation on the television stations.

—Senator Bishop was trying to make the point that allowing charitable organisations, such as the Salvation Army and the Red Cross, to continue with their range of advertisements in support of the issues and seeking support for their community activities was a loophole in the Bill for bodies like the American public action committees. But, of course, Senator Bishop tackles this Bill from a position of no commonsense, which is not unusual for Senator Bishop on major matters before the Senate. I must say though, Mr Deputy President—and I said this yesterday in the debate over the guillotine—that, as Chairman of the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures, I suspect that Senator Bishop might have made a better fist of being one of the Opposition members on that Committee.
—I agree with that.

—I think it is possible that her colleagues made a mistake in voting her down and not putting her on that Committee. I think they made a mistake in putting Senator Olsen, and particularly Senator Kemp, on the Committee.
—I agree with that.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President.

—Mr Deputy President, every time I open my mouth to interject you are very keen to stop me. Senator Faulkner has been interjecting constantly in the last 30 seconds and you have not even looked at him. I ask, Mr Deputy President, that you show some evenness in your dealing with interjectors. It is fair enough for you to stop me interjecting, Mr Deputy President. That is quite within your right, but please do the same to Senator Faulkner when he interjects.
—Senator Macdonald, you are going very close to being insolent towards the Chair.

—Senator Bishop and other Opposition senators have been attacking the Australian Democrats, saying that the Democrats will get large amounts of free time when they only have the support of 4 per cent of the population. The free time is allocated on votes, not on population. The Democrats, whether we like it or whether the Liberal Party likes it, at the last election got in excess of 10 per cent of the vote. That is the proportion of free time they should get. I should also point out to honourable senators opposite that, if they read the amendments circulated from the Government, they will see that there is provision for new political parties that have not previously stood candidates to get access to free time. It is made quite explicit in the amendments that have been circulated. I only wish Opposition senators would take the trouble to read the amendments. It is not an onerous task to read. It is not an onerous task to read more than a couple of pages, but I am starting to suspect that it is beyond the mental capacity of some honourable senators opposite to read more than about a page every half-hour.

PARA.TAB: I want to conclude on one matter which honourable senators opposite have been conspicuously silent about, and that is the disclosure provision. Other than an attack on the trade union movement, there has not been one suggestion by them that they want to give the shareholders of any public or private company the right to have a plebiscite to indicate whether they want their money in that company given as a political donation to a political party. Honourable senators opposite demand it of the trade union movement, and details are published every year in union annual reports, but such information is not published in the annual reports of most public companies or private companies.

If Opposition senators were fair dinkum about this point on disclosure, not only would they be putting up amendments in the next 24 hours saying that there should be, in their terms, wider ranging provisions on what unions do in providing donations, but they would also be putting up amendments making it necessary for shareholders in public and private companies to be consulted by way of plebiscite or vote to see whether those shareholders want their company to donate money to a political party.

Opposition senators are not game to do that because the real issue with respect to disclosure is not the issue of intimidation; it is the fact that many company executives do not want to face their shareholders at an annual general meeting with the knowledge that they have given money to a political party. That is what Opposition senators are scared of. That is why they are not going to propose those amendments. Their mates in those companies do not want them to do so because they know that their shareholders will take a very tough attitude to the fact that the money has been given to political parties. I look forward to seeing in the committee stage tomorrow Opposition senators putting up these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Later on today.

—It will be later today. I also look forward to seeing some other positive measures put forward by the Opposition in the committee stage. As I mentioned yesterday, in the report of the Opposition senators on the Select Committee, there was not one positive recommendation—not one. There were several pages of negative, carping comment, whingeing and whining against the majority report, but there were no alternative recommendations.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot may have disagreed with some of the majority report, but at least she put alternative recommendations. She actually took the trouble and had the courage to write some recommendations. Not so Senator Alston or Senator Kemp. They ducked, ducked and ducked again the big issues confronted in this Bill because they do not want those issues exposed in the public arena. The Opposition clearly wants defeated not just the advertisement ban side of this Bill, but also, above all else, the disclosure side because it is petrified, on behalf of the people it represents, that there will be public disclosure of where the money comes from and where it goes.

For 90 years Liberal Party supporters have not wanted that in the company area. We are going to have it for the first time and the Opposition is petrified. That is the reason why Opposition senators are whingeing and whining about this Bill and trying to divert attention to concepts of free speech and human rights—concepts which most of the senators opposite would have no idea about, and have never shown any interest in, with some honourable exceptions. Most of those honourable exceptions are being forced out of this place by the Liberal Party, as were Senator Peter Baume and Senator Puplick. They disappeared into the ether because the uglies opposite knocked them off for preselection.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order.
—Is this self-identification?

—A term that Senator Schacht just used is a term that was conjured up by certain people who thought that some people in the Liberal Party had foreign names which were ugly. Hence the term that he just used. He is, in fact, disparaging ethnic minorities. I ask you to ask Senator Schacht to withdraw or desist from using the term, as it is offensive to ethnic minorities.
—I cannot see any point of order there.
—The term `ugly' means the right wing faction of the Liberal Party of New South Wales, and that is the faction that knocked off Senator Puplick, a person committed to human rights.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. As I said before, this is the man who claims to be—
—What is your point of order?

—My point of order is that Senator Schacht is reflecting upon ethnic minorities by using that term. It derives from the fact that people within the Liberal Party had foreign names which some people considered ugly.
—If Senator Schacht is attempting to apply that term to me, I find it extremely offensive and I would ask him to withdraw it.
—My understanding is that Senator Schacht did not mention anything about ethnic minorities and I do not think he mentioned Senator Bishop.
—I would like it clarified that Senator Schacht did not use that term in reference to me, because if he did, I want it withdrawn.
—Order! Senator Schacht's time has expired.
—Mr Deputy President, I heard Senator Schacht apply that term to me. I find it extremely offensive and I want it withdrawn.
—I think the Hansard report will show that he did not apply it to Senator Bishop. I ask Senator Schacht whether he did?
—I said by way of interjection that Senator Bishop was the leader of a Liberal Party faction—
—You did not.
—I said she was a leader of a Liberal Party faction that has the name `the uglies' within the Liberal Party of New South Wales. I did not say that she was ugly.
—Order! There is no point of order. I call Senator Macdonald.
—Mr Deputy President—
—Order! There is no point of order.
—I draw another point of order.
—Under what standing order are you making a point of order?
—Senator Schacht is reflecting upon another senator.
—Under what standing order are you making the point of order?
—I find the statement he made exceedingly offensive and I ask him to withdraw it.
—There is no point of order. I call Senator Macdonald.
—Mr Deputy President, do I understand that you are ruling that a senator may reflect upon another senator? Is that the effect of the ruling?
—I have called Senator Macdonald.
—Is that what you are ruling?
—If Senator Macdonald does not take the call I will have to call Senator O'Chee.
—We will deal with this later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope to introduce some calm rationality into debate on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill, which I might say has been sadly lacking in the speech of the previous speaker, Senator Schacht. I also wish to introduce some fairness into this debate, which is about fairness and allowing the Australian public to speak their minds. The members of the Australian Labor Party have been attempting all day to stop people speaking their minds. They are attempting by this ban on free speech to stop Australians speaking their minds.

PARA.TAB: I am proud to be a member of a party that is prepared to sit here all through this morning and all through tomorrow afternoon to make sure that the people of Australia learn about the scurrilous actions of the Government, of which that lot opposite form part. They are attempting in every way possible to destroy every vestige of free speech in this community. Their actions today in banning free speech, aided and abetted by the sycophants in the corner, is scandalous and it needs to be publicised to the Australian public. I hope that by staying here all night we will get out that message.

I have two preliminary comments to make about the legislation. One is that the lawyers are going to have an absolute field day. Every cent that Senator Kernot and the Australian Democrats think they might save at election time—the Labor Party, of course, does not believe that—will be frittered away in legal costs. This legislation is absolutely fraught with constitutional problems. Senator Tate, the Minister representing the Attorney-General, knows that full well. He probably knows full well that this is all for nought because the legislation will be challenged and it is likely to be found to be invalid in very many ways.

The interpreting of this Bill is likely to fill the pockets of lawyers for many, many years. Senator Schacht will probably be happy with that. However, that is what the Bill is doing, and if the Minister had any concern at all about that particular subject he would bring in legislation that means something and not legislation which the courts will have to spend days and weeks and months trying to interpret. In an election period, lawyers will have a field day with the injunctions on what constitutes an offence under this Act and what does not. It will be an absolute bonanza to lawyers. Government senators are facilitating that, and they will end up with egg all over their faces.

I want to refer now to the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and to the enormous amount of this legislation that refers to regulations to be drafted in the back rooms by the Government in an attempt to sneak them through in the hope that this chamber will not see them coming and will not be aware of them to take the opportunity to move to disallow them. Every single technical part of this Bill is to be subject to regulations. We do not know how the rules are going to apply. I am sure that when the Australian Democrats have a look at them—if they can read them then—they will not understand how they are going to be applied. The regulations will be very, very technical; they are the sorts of things that should be part of this legislation and should be being debated now.

Before making some comments about the Bill, I wish to refer briefly to the quite amazing speech of Senator Kernot on behalf of the Australian Democrats. It was full of convoluted argument and difficult logic. Coming from someone who calls herself educated, it contained some absolutely amazing things. Her speech showed a complete misunderstanding of the legislation, that she has been completely duped by the Labor Party, the Minister and all of those who stand over her and her colleagues every time a vote is taken.

Her speech contained a scurrilous attack on a person who is not a member of this chamber. She used the coward's castle to malign and defame a very prominent Australian, Professor Ashley Goldsworthy, but in doing so she made an interesting point. If, as she said, Professor Goldsworthy was issuing a misleading press statement which she said was scurrilous—I do not agree with her—what will this Bill do to stop that sort of thing? What will this Bill do to stop those sorts of alleged malpractices? Senator Kernot spent half an hour trying to indicate how things were unfair and how they would be better after this Bill was passed. Yet she points out herself that the things that really can in her opinion be misleading are there already and are not even touched by the Bill. That shows the absolute hypocrisy of the Democrats' position.

It is not often that I have the temerity to disagree with my Queensland colleague Senator MacGibbon, but I must in this instance because he said that Senator Kernot's speech was thoughtful, considered and logical. I think it was anything but that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said, `Thoughtful for a Democrat'.

—I thank the honourable senator. That has clarified it for me. Senator MacGibbon also said—and I must take issue with him—that there was no-cost advertising for the Democrats. He may be right that there is no cost for the Democrats, but it is not no-cost advertising, because someone has to pay. I will return to that issue later.

PARA.TAB: In her quite amazing speech, Senator Kernot also talked about all the misleading images that television advertising could conjure up in the last 33 days before an election. But she did not say what was wrong with that on the 332 days before that. How can those television images be dishonest and completely confuse and mislead the public in the 33 days prior to an election but in every other part of the year those images are not a problem? The logic of that is just impossible. It is much the same as the entire argument of the Australian Democrats: completely illogical and without any sense at all.

The Democrats have not yet picked up that the images on television are to stop 33 days before the election, or 28 days or whenever, or when the proposed date of the election is publicly announced. Surely the senator does not think the members of the Government probably will not wait until about two months into the term and then say: `We are announcing publicly that we are going to have an election in three years time', so that there won't be able to be any advertising in that period. So again congratulations go to the Government and the members of the Labor Party: they have completely conned the Democrats again. They have conned them on the sort of thing they were fighting so hard to avoid, so congratulations. The Democrats deserve the odium that they will get from the people of Australia when they hear about it; the Government has done well.

I want to refer to the Committee that looked at this Bill because some aspersions were cast on the Liberal members of that Committee. The Chairman of that Committee was an absolute embarrassment to the Senate. The way he conducted that hearing and intimidated witnesses was an absolute embarrassment and a blight on the Senate's committee system, which over the years has become very well-respected.

I serve on three committees chaired by members of the Labor Party. Senator Cooney is absolutely fair and scrupulous every time he chairs a meeting. It does not matter whether the witnesses are agreeing with him, violently disagreeing with him, attacking the Labor Party or doing anything else, Senator Cooney chairs the meeting in a very, very fair way. Because we sit on the same committee, Senator Crowley knows that.

Senator Foreman is another committee chairman who, when matters arise that his Party does not like, deals with them very fairly in a gentlemanly way, and he allows people to have their say without intimidation and without cutting them off. I also sit on a committee chaired by Senator Maguire. He is an excellent chairman who is very fair and who allows witnesses to have their say without intimidation and without being cut off. I am afraid I cannot say the same for what I saw of the Committee that dealt with political disclosures and the banning of political advertisements.

By contrast, Senator Olsen and Senator Kemp acquitted themselves quite remarkably on this Committee. Their questions were fair and reasonable. They had some very searching and telling inquiries. Their questions were very biting and to the point—

TALK.START.PARA: —I bet you don't vote them on a similar committee again.
—Senator Schacht, order! Have a look at the time.
—Mr Deputy President, am I entitled to any protection from you in this matter?
—Senator, I am trying to give you some protection. The honourable senators on my right will stop interjecting.
—This is the way this very fair chairman went on.

—As my friend Senator Kemp mentioned, the way Senator Schacht is interjecting here is typical and it shows his attitude to people speaking. He wants to try to cut me off, the same as he tried to cut off many of the witnesses.

PARA.TAB: There is the case of Mr Sherry, who gave the disgraceful evidence about the situation in Queensland. I have not very often agreed with the former Premier of Queensland, Premier Bjelke-Petersen, but I will say that it was his finest hour when he saved the people of Queensland from the cutting off of power and from all of the problems that could have happened when the unions tried to hold the country to ransom and keep it in darkness. That was his finest hour. The follow-on from that is that a lot of workers in the unions were told by the bully boys at the top of the union that they must go on strike. The workers did not want to, but they were told to go on strike. As a result, they lost their homes, all their furniture and their cars. They got to the stage where they did not even have enough money to feed themselves. So what happened? The union movement—the bully boys—went around and said: `Right, everybody, we'll take up a collection to save these people, to give them a bit of money to feed and clothe themselves'. That sounded like a good idea to me. Had I been in the situation, I would have thrown in a couple of bob, because I did not like to see the ordinary workers being penalised by the efforts of the union bully boys. But what happened to this money that was collected to feed children?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Chair will not accept language like that, Minister.
—Are you asking me to withdraw?
—No, I am not asking the Minister to withdraw. I am suggesting that he do not use it again.
—I did not hear what the person from the Northern Territory said. It does not worry me; it does not worry me at all. That is the sort of thing you would expect from someone like him.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: could you explain to me why you are not asking the Minister to withdraw that filthy language?
—I am not quite sure what withdrawal of that language would achieve. I have told the Minister that it is not acceptable in the chamber.

—Mr Deputy President, I did not hear the gutter remarks, and it does not worry me anyhow. That is the sort of smart thing that one gets from someone who owes his position to the Prime Minister's attempts to buy some votes for himself.

PARA.TAB: Let me return to what I was saying. It was a disgraceful exhibition. The hat was taken round to buy food for children, and where did that money end up? It went towards the campaign of the honourable member for Bowman. Gee, it hurts me to say `honourable' when that money collected for women and children to buy food was put into his election campaign. What an absolutely disgraceful act from members of that party, yet they come here talking about fairness. Senator Olsen and Senator Kemp performed very well on that committee and showed to all those appearing before it what should happen.

To continue the comments that most of my colleagues have made, we do agree with fair disclosure provisions. We have always said that. Senator Schacht obviously was not listening when many of my colleagues mentioned that we support, and always have done, fair disclosure provisions. They have to be fair, of course. There have to be rules for everyone, not a separate rule for the Labor Party and the Labor Party mates, the people who control the ALP. The rules have to be fair right across the board. We support that, and we always have done.

I now want to look briefly at some sections of the Bill. I note that the Democrats are not in the chamber, but I do hope that someone might pass on to them a couple of these comments, because I do want them to think long and hard about these. They go very much to the root of the question, and they might just spark a light in the Democrats and make them realise that they have been conned by the Government. The Minister, in his second reading speech only a couple of months ago, said:

SPEECH.PARA: While the bulk of expenditure by political parties on advertising occurs during elections, the proposed ban will operate at all times. If the ban were restricted to election periods, parties and others would buy political advertising and would run campaigns outside the ban period. The problems associated with the need to raise the huge sums necessary to fund campaigns would remain, but apply to mid-term and pre-election period campaigns, which could be expected to take on the importance presently attached to election campaigns.

So the Minister was quite outraged about that, and he wanted to do something about it. He wanted to ban all political advertising, not just in the election period. What has happened? Lo and behold, it has all changed in a couple of months. What was bad before, according to this Government and according to the Democrats, suddenly turns out to be okay. So I just wonder what has happened to that, what was so bad before that now is not bad.

PARA.TAB: The Bill goes on to talk about the ban not being intended to include items of news or current affairs, or comments upon the same, or talkback radio. It would almost tempt you to go back into the law, because here is another absolute bonanza for the lawyers. This will certainly be interesting to try to enforce. Can honourable senators imagine all the talkback they are going to get which will not be paid advertising but will be advertising in a different form? All the news items can be free, so you can have all the Labor Party stalwarts in the ABC slanting all the news, as they do nowadays. They will have a great time with this, as will the radio stations the ALP owns. It will be beaut to try to enforce it. The mind just boggles. Government senators are smiling. They understand what they are going to do, and I congratulate them. They have been able to get their way, to make sure they have all the advertising they want. By pulling the wool over the eyes of the sycophants in the corner, they will get it. They have done very well.

I am running out of time, but I will briefly have a look at the charitable organisations. Charitable organisations are defined as public organisations whose objectives are to benefit the public through relief of poverty, the advancement of education, religion, public health or science. Is that not going to be a bonanza for the Labor Party and its lawyers! I will bet that it has already got its lawyers out, setting up a couple of charitable organisations. These charitable organisations will have as their objectives some of those things I have mentioned, but they will be set up as fronts to allow them to get in under this loophole and make a statement about poverty by saying something like, `Look, if you're not forced to be in a union, that may lead to poverty, so, in the pursuit of our objects to stop poverty, maybe we should get on the radio or the TV and advertise that you shouldn't support a party which wants voluntary unionism'. I will bet that the Labor Party has already got the lawyers out looking at that one. Similarly, with the health issue, it will have people out doing that already, and honourable senators opposite will laugh all the way to the election. I think Senator Kernot said that after two elections she might move for something different. Of course, after the next election this will be completely wiped.

There is another provision in the Bill that the amendments will include provisions which proscribe broadcasting of any Government matter on behalf of an incumbent government during the three months preceding the last due date for the expiry of the House of Representatives. So all the Government has to do is call an early election and it can spend all the taxpayers' money advertising all the things that it supposedly has done well—call the election early and we get away from that provision. So there we go. The Labor Party has put it over the Democrats again.

We do not see anything about allocation of time in this Bill. We do not know what that is all about. That is going to come later, in regulations to be prescribed. Who is going to look after it? The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and, I assume, other public servants—people who will be chosen, I suspect, for their views, and one might wonder whether their allocations will be fair. I do not want to impute improper motives to them, but it certainly does leave room for that imputation, does it not? It is going to be very interesting to see who decides the allocation, the times and the amounts.

When the Bill mentions policy launches per party, what does `per party' mean? Does that mean that the Liberal Party will get some publicity for its launch, and then the National Party will get some publicity for its launch? I wonder whether the Democrats have thought about that. Maybe we will even form a Queensland Liberal Party. We might then get a bit of publicity for its launch as well. I wonder whether anyone has particularly thought of that.

Proposed section 95DD says that the Tribunal must within the prescribed period—there we go again—in relation to an election grant a period of free time to a political party that comprises the official Opposition. It talks about a political party, singular. I do not know how that applies when the Liberal and National parties are currently in coalition. But it then goes on in subclause (3) to say that the period to be granted to the political party, singular, under paragraph (1)(b), which is the one I have just mentioned, is to be a period equal to 40 per cent of the time in respect of that election. The legislation then refers to more than one such party. How can we talk about a political party, and then refer to what will happen if there is more than one such party? It is just going to be an absolute bonanza for the lawyers, an absolute bonanza.

What happens—and the Democrats should look at this—if another little political party pops up just before the election? The Democrats' 10 per cent will not be 10 per cent. If a couple of parties do that, then the Democrats may very well find themselves not with quite a lot of money, as Senator MacGibbon suggested, but with nothing. I wonder whether they have thought about that. I wonder whether the Democrats realise that they are going to be sharing with the Green Party, Senator Vallentine's Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a party.

—The Green Party is a registered party. I wonder whether the Democrats have thought about that. Maybe they are not going to get out of this what they thought they might get out of it. I just hope that they will go and have a look at those sorts of things, because even they might start to realise that they have been conned.

PARA.TAB: The explanatory memorandum comments that this legislation will not have any implications for Commonwealth expenditure. That is probably right, but it will have an effect on someone. I do not think people have understood this yet. My history is not very good, but I think it was back in the time of the Magna Carta when expropriation of other people's property was stopped so that a government could not say, `Hey, that is yours but I want it and I am going to take it, and I am not going to compensate you at all'.

I do not think anyone has thought of this yet but, as I understand it—and someone might correct me if I am wrong—what is going to happen is that a government is going to say to these television stations, `Hey, we want millions of your money and we are not going to compensate you for it'. That is an absolute disgrace to the British system of justice—property cannot be expropriated without compensation being paid.

Someone said before that, because television stations get a licence from government, it is not their property and government can take it back. But, as Senator Panizza quite rightly pointed out, what about taxi licences? Does a government give a taxi licence and then expropriate it for free rides on five out of seven days? That is the sort of thing that was done in Nazi Germany. That is the sort of thing that used to be done in Russia. That is the sort of thing that should be scowled upon in this country. That is why this Government did not want this legislation to be viewed by the people of Australia. That is why it guillotined it through, and that is why it does not want anyone to know about it.

Let us take another example. If a government resumes freehold land, it has to pay compensation. But to get freehold land, people need a grant in fee simple from a government. It is exactly the same as this sort of item, but it would be unheard of in any British justice country. Those things should be thought of and I would hope that, in the limited time left to the people of Australia to look at this, they will consider that.

Finally—and regrettably my time is running out—I want to say this to the Australian Democrats: we expect this behaviour from the Labor Party, a party that Tom Burns calls mongrel dogs creeping around the alley, or whatever it was. We expect it from a party that bashes its people in Sydney. We expect it from a party that gaols Cabinet Ministers. We expect it from a party that has Burke and the bully boys of the Labour Council. We expect this sort of thing from a party which has its officers—and I am too polite to mention anyone in this chamber—brought before a court for breaches of the Electoral Act. We expect this from a party that uses the standover tactics that I mentioned in the SEQEB matter in Queensland. We expect this from a party whose Prime Minister tells deliberate lies to Paul Keating, saying that he can lead it into the next election, and then on the same day tells the people of Australia that he will be leader at the same election.

We expect that from the Labor Party. But we do not expect it from a party that was established by Mr Don Chipp to keep the bastards honest. We do not expect it from a party that was principled in the days of Michael Macklin. We do not expect it from a party that was principled in the days of Janine Haines. We do not expect it from a party led by Janet Powell, who, for all her failings, did not come at this sort of rort and was not conned by these people.

The Democrats have proved that they will take more than 30 pieces of silver. They did this when they rejected convention and elected another member of the Labor Party to the Deputy President's position in this chamber. They were bought off then and they continue to be bought off, not for 30 pieces of silver but for some overtime for their staff and for a few extra staff. I have a little speech on that that I will give one day, with a few facts to back it up. The Democrats get the extra staff, they get treated better than anyone else, and one might ask why. He who pays the piper calls the tune—that is exactly it. The ALP Government pays the piper and, boy, does it call the tune when it comes to the sycophants in the corner.

I would have expected better from them. I do not expect better from the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins), who cannot even speak civilly in this chamber. That is what we expect from him. However, I did expect better from the party of Don Chipp. I only hope that, in the last few hours left to them, they will come to their senses and follow the example of Senator Sowada, who has shown a real understanding of the major issues involved. I just hope that Senator Sowada can convince her colleagues of the enormous trap they are falling into, of the absolute disgrace they are going to bring on their party, and the absolute detriment they are going to cause to the freedoms that the people of Australia have come to expect and enjoy.

I just hope that the Democrats come to their senses, remember Don Chipp, remember the dictum `Keep the bastards honest'—and, boy, do they need keeping honest!—and go with Senator Sowada and do something before it is too late.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill is so full of holes that it is almost impossible to work out where I am going to start punching more holes in it.
—Why don't you talk about brown paper bags?

—I will talk about brown paper bags because Senator Schacht is stupid enough to interject even after I looked after his friend Senator Collins this afternoon and reminded him about big black briefcases. Despite that, Senator Schacht is still stupid enough to interject about brown paper bags. It shows that some Labor Party senators are not just thick around the waist; some are thick around the head as well. It is clear they are thick around the head because they just do not understand political reality. If there is an odium in Australia politics today, the odium surrounds nobody on this side, with the possible exception of the Democrats: it surrounds members of the Labor Party. They are in the thick of it, they are up to their ears in it, they are up to their eyes in it, and they are certainly up to their noses in it.

PARA.TAB: The interesting thing is that it is the people who live in the sewer who can never smell the effluent: that is the problem with the Labor Party. Because they live in the sewer and were brought up in the sewer, they can never smell the effluent—the stench of dung that surrounds their shady political dealings. Hopefully, we have had enough of the little boy lost in the corner. Let us get on to the subject of the legislation because, unlike Senator Schacht, I am actually interested in discussing this legislation. I am actually interested in exposing the rorts and frauds of this Government.

First of all, let us have some background on this Bill because I think that background is very interesting. It is a long time since the `Burkegate' inquiry began, but we should just cast our minds back and remember that this Bill was introduced by the Australian Labor Party when the `Burkegate' inquiry got a little hot for it. It was introduced when honourable senators on this side exposed the shady dealings of the Labor Party. The real genesis of the Bill that Senator Bolkus brings before the Senate is not based on some high principles about saving the world from corruption. What it is really based on is the principle of saving the Labor Party from the exposure of its corruption. When we remember that, we start to realise that all of the Labor Party's rhetoric, all its sophistry about how it is going to take corruption out of the political process, is nothing but hollow words.

We hear often from people like Senator Schacht and other Labor senators that this Bill is essential to take corruption out of elections and that this Bill is essential to take corruption out of the political process. But nobody on that side of the chamber has yet managed to find one instance of corruption in the political process in the field of advertising—not one. And they cannot.

Listen to the silence. All the interjections have ceased on the other side because those opposite know that the truth is that there has been no corruption in advertising in the electoral process. They know exactly what I mean. They know that there is no corruption to which they can point and which this Bill will rectify. They know that there is no corruption, save one exception—the exception of Mr Hogg. I will come to him in a little moment. There is not one incidence of corruption in advertising in election campaigns that this Bill would eliminate. They know the truth, but the truth hurts.

Let us just discuss for a moment the one single example of corruption in the electoral process that this Bill would address. It is interesting that this is a government that says it wants to stamp out corruption. The way it stamps out corruption is by making its corrupt activities legal. Those opposite do not make it illegal; they do not make it tougher or more difficult to be corrupt. What do they do? They make their own corruption legal. It is interesting that in this Bill there is a provision for disclosure changes. These provisions are in what I will refer to as the Hogg clause because that is what they are all about; they are about Bob Hogg.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mean they have their snouts in the trough?

—They have their snouts in the trough, indeed—not just their snouts but their paws as well, because they are covered in mud and in the stench of their own corruption. I refer to the addendum to the amendments and new clauses circulated by the Government. At the very last moment the Government thought it might do something about the activities of Bob Hogg and its other unelected mates. It has, in terms of returns on electoral expenditure, a new clause 14A which amends section 309 of the principal Act. This is interesting. The new clause states, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: A person is not required to furnish a return under subsection (4) in respect of an election if the total amount of the electoral expenditure incurred in relation to the election by or with the authority of the person, being electoral expenditure of the kind referred to in paragraph 308(1)(h), is not more than the prescribed amount and if the total amount of the electoral expenditure incurred in relation to the election by or with the authority of the person, being electoral expenditure other than that to which paragraph (a) applies, does not exceed $200.

So what the Labor Party can do is get lots of little Labor Party minions to each spend $199 on an election campaign or portions of an election campaign and it does not have to disclose it. Or it can set up lots and lots of little entities that each spend $199, or maybe even $199.99 if it wants to push it right to the line. Of course, then it does not have to disclose it. It is very convenient for the Labor Party. It is very convenient for its mates. The only possible incidence of corruption in advertising and in the process of the electoral campaign is the one that the Government makes legal. It is its own corruption. There we see the rub.

PARA.TAB: There are so many other flaws in the whole concept of this Bill that I think need addressing here tonight. I want to start with an incredible statement by Senator Schacht. I was almost asleep in my office from the boredom of his speech when all of a sudden this statement woke me up: the airwaves of this country are regulated by the Government so the Government can impose whatever restrictions it wants on the airwaves. That is an extraordinary statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right. That is what they believe, too.
—I know. Those opposite really believe it. Do you know, Senator Walters, why it is such a shame that they believe it?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Senator O'Chee, address your remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, this is the same belief that the communist government had in Russia. It took 70 years, but eventually that collapsed.
—Nazi Germany.

—It was indeed, as Senator Panizza says, the same belief that Adolf Hitler had in Nazi Germany. Fortunately, Nazi Germany fell over a little sooner than communist Russia. But we have seen what an appalling farce communism has been. We have seen what appalling failures the supporters of communism have been. We have seen how shattered their hollow ideology has been, no matter where their supporters have been around the world.

PARA.TAB: What concerns me is that I do not want this country to be hoodwinked by the sort of people who are sitting on the other side and who believe, as Senator Walters said, the same ideological claptrap as was believed by the communists in Russia. This Government has no right to do as it wants with industries, people or businesses simply because it happens to regulate a portion of that industry. Consider the ramifications. The Government regulates most of primary industry. I suppose that the Government, according to Senator Schacht, can march in here tomorrow and demand that every primary producer give two or three days production to the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the taxis?

—I am going to get to the taxis very shortly, because Senator Panizza raises a very important but slightly different point there. I want to discuss this question of primary industry and what the Government can do if the Schacht theory of the world is really correct. The Government can require people to hand over produce and it can require people to hand over assets—that is the Schacht theory of the world.
