Of course, the thing is—and honourable senators on this side of the chamber know it—that the Government is already working towards that with its ridiculous and ludicrous taxation system that takes most of the profit of the labour of ordinary Australians away from them.

PARA.TAB: Let us talk about the profits of people's labour and the very wise and perspicacious interjection by my friend Senator Panizza, who talked about the taxi driver. It is true that, under the Schacht view of the world, the Government can require the taxi driver to give free carriage to people all over the place. This is an extraordinary view, given that, in the ordinary legal understanding of the powers of appropriation and commandeering in this country, those powers are available only in time of war. But Senator Schacht, the great defender of civil liberties and human rights, says, `No, that is all right: provided the Government regulates some portion of the business activity, it can make them do what it wants'. It is interesting, because this Government already tries very hard to make the media do what it wants. We will get to that later.

One can see the intrinsic flaw running through this legislation and running through the thought processes—limited though they may be—of the people on the other side of the chamber: `We are going to require the media industry to do just what we want because it suits us and because it suits our own shabby political end'. I suppose that, if this Government ever decides to make prostitution legal in Australia, it might even require the prostitutes to give the benefit of a couple of days service free of charge. We can see the flaws in the logic of people on the other side of the chamber.

Senator Schacht earlier on today made another incredible observation. He said that, just because there were regulations or prohibitions on certain types of electoral advertising in other parts of the world, it was fair enough to do it in Australia. Senator Schacht chose a couple of examples from the Western world, but one could equally have taken some examples from less satisfactory places in which one can live, such as Uganda or some of the other dictatorships around the world, such as the Soviet Union and Bulgaria before the fall of the communist government.

All of these were perfect examples, perfect cases in point, of the proposition that Senator Schacht was advancing. Of course, they were perfect cases in point because they relied upon the same flawed and failed communist ideology that Senator Schacht unwittingly embraces in what he says here in the chamber. There one sees the ultimate end for this country if we embrace the Schacht point of view or this Government's point of view: there will be no right for individuals to conduct their businesses as they may because they will have to do whatever the Government wants. They will be at the beck and call of their political masters, notwithstanding the fact that they may indeed, as most of the population of this country does, despise those political masters. That is the cruel thing.

Of course, there is a massive provision in the regulations for much of the activity that is created by this Bill to be governed by regulations. The Government, in bringing this Bill before the Senate, asks us to cave in—to sign a blank cheque—and to pass this Bill without seeing what the regulations are.

Those regulations are intrinsic to the operation of the Bill because they will determine and prescribe the manner in which this so-called free political time—and I will get on to that shortly—will be allocated. There is an interesting passage in the Bible about such points of view. In 1 Corinthians 14:8-9 it says:

SPEECH.PARA: 8For if the trumpet give an uncertain sound, who shall prepare himself to the battle?
9So likewise ye, except ye utter by the tongue words easy to be understood, how shall it be known what is spoken? for ye shall speak into the air.

That is exactly what this Government is doing. It is speaking into the air and it is speaking about how it is going to regulate the air. Indeed, the reason why this Government has hidden all the machinery of the legislation in regulations rather than the Act is well explained by verse 8 which says:
8For if the trumpet give an uncertain sound, who shall prepare himself to the battle?

The reason the Government has hidden the machinery in regulations which it has not brought before the chamber at this time is that it does not want the people to see exactly how it will work. The Government wants to try to pull the wool over our eyes. It wants this chamber to pass this legislation without knowing what it is doing. We on this side of the chamber in the coalition parties—in the National Party and amongst our very good friends, the Liberal Party—are not going to do that because we believe in freedom, democracy and in seeing the legislation in full before we pass it. That is why we are so opposed to it here this morning.

PARA.TAB: There is also another interesting matter which relates to regulations. I refer to Delegated Legislation by Professor Pearce at page 10 where he quotes from an article by Jaffe in An Essay on Delegation of Legislative Power (1947) 47 Colombia LR at 361. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Power should be delegated where there is agreement that a task must be performed and it cannot be effectively performed by the legislature without the assistance of a delegate or without an expenditure of time so great as to lead to the neglect of equally important business.

This Government tells us that this Bill is urgent and that it is the most important business that it has to deal with before this Senate gets up for Christmas. So there is no argument that says that the Government should have the right to delegate the operation—the machinery—of its legislation to regulation, because clearly in Jaffe's argument it has to be pushing aside legislation which is as equally important as this. Government senators have told us here—Senator McMullan told us yesterday morning—that there was nothing so important as this Bill. There one sees the rub that they failed to take the appropriate measures to put this through.

PARA.TAB: This Bill is riddled with clauses that give cart blanche to the ABT and to the Government in framing its regulations to do as it wants, knowing full well that it will be more difficult for those of us opposed to this Bill to amend the regulations than it would be to amend an Act, because the Government knows that it can hold a gun to the Senate chamber and ensure that it gets exactly what it wants or nothing gets put in its place at all.

So we can see this whole device of the regulations is a very shameful attempt on the part of the Government to hide from the people of Australia what it intends to do in this Act. For those of us in the coalition who wish to represent the people of Australia, for those of us like my friend Senator Panizza in the coalition who wish to speak up as democratic representatives of our States and say, `We are appalled at this disgusting legislation', the really atrocious crime that is being perpetrated is not, I suppose, the masking of the machinery in the regulations, but it is the fact that this Senate to do its job is sitting at 1.45 a.m. It is the fact that this Senate to do its job has been told it had to sit through the wee hours of the night because the Government members and their friends the Democrats did not want this to be debated in the day. They did not want the press to be able to report what was going on; they did not want the people to know; and they did not want people to be able to protest about what is going on.

I think it is very strange that Senator Burns frequently protests about his supposed lack of freedom of speech and civil rights in Queensland, yet he is participating in a government that is going to single-handedly—with one stroke of the pen—strike a bigger blow to freedom of speech and civil liberties than has ever been done in the political history of this country, with the possible exception of the Eureka Stockade. That is the sort of thing that is going on. Is it not ironic that Senator Burns is not in the chamber? I wish he were so that I could tell him exactly how appalling this legislation is. Those of us on this side perfectly understand what freedom of speech and civil liberty are all about, but this Government does not.

Of course, the greatest joke of all is the Minister who introduced this legislation, the Minister who came in here with sophistry last year about how speech is not free if it has to be paid for. For the edification of the chamber, there is an interesting quote from Byron, and it is a shame that the Minister is not here because I am sure he would be incapable of reading it for himself. I would love to read it to him, but I shall read it instead to the chamber because it aptly describes not only Senator Bolkus but also his apologist, Senator Schacht. I suppose this could be addressed to the media industry. Byron wrote in On a Change of Masters at a Great Public School in 1805:

SPEECH.PARA: Pomposos holds you in his harsh control;
Pomposos, by no social virtue sway'd,
With florid jargon, and with vain parade;
With noisy nonsense, and new-fangled rules,
Such as were ne'er before enforced in schools.
Mistaking pedantry for learning's laws,
He governs, sanction'd but by self-applause—
how true that is—
With him the same dire fate attending Rome,
Ill-fated Ida! soon must stamp your doom:
Like her o'erthrown, for ever lost to fame,
No trace of science left to you, but the name.

Of course, is that not so apt? Is that not such an accurate description of Senator Bolkus with his noisy nonsense and new-fangled rules? Not only did he have to have a couple of goes at his new-fangled rules but the other day he had to introduce 37 amendments to his new-fangled rules.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fourteen today.

—And 14 today: fourteen amendments to the amendments to the new fangled rules and, of course, `sanction'd but by self-applause'. Even his own Labor Party colleagues know what a failure he has been as a Minister. Even some of his own Labor Party colleagues hang their heads in shame, not only at the whole concept of this legislation but at what an appalling job he has done of managing the legislation. I would not trust Senator Bolkus to find his way out of a telephone box, yet he has been given by this Government carriage of this legislation. I suppose what Government members were really after was a patsy and a fall guy. They certainly got one in Senator Bolkus. The problem is that he can fall over of his own accord; he does not need any assistance to fall over. He trips over himself in the way that he introduces the legislation.

PARA.TAB: For the remainder of my speech I want to address some of the particular absurdities that are in this Bill. For example, there is a contradiction in this Bill. Section 95B(1) states:

SPEECH.PARA: A broadcaster must not, during the election period in relation to an election or a referendum, broadcast any matter (other than exempt matter) for or on behalf of the government, or a government authority, of the Commonwealth.
That seems clear enough, except a little further down the page subsection (4) states:
Subject to section 95E, a broadcaster must not, during the election period in relation to an election or a referendum, broadcast a political advertisement:
(a) for or on behalf of a person other than a government or government authority; or
(b) on his or her own behalf.

What is that supposed to mean? Is it saying in one subsection that the Government cannot advertise, then three subsections later that the Government can advertise? This is the absurdity of how poorly drafted this legislation is. It is riddled with holes. I only picked this page out at random and yet I found a flaw leaping out of the page at me. Like some sort of Government Fosbury flop, this flaw in the legislation leapt out at me. In fact, not only is proposed new section 95B(4) contrary to proposed new section 95B(1), but interestingly enough it is also contrary to proposed new section 95A(1), which says:
Subject to section 95E, a broadcaster must not at any time broadcast a political advertisement, whether for consideration or otherwise.
So, of course, we can see that the whole legislation itself is contradictory. One portion of the legislation contradicts another portion.

PARA.TAB: Senator Macdonald was absolutely correct in saying that this is going to be a bonanza for the lawyers, because the number of challenges that will arise to this legislation will be quite incredible. For example, we are going to have awful trouble when we look at regulations for the allocation of the 10 per cent amongst parties other than the Government and the Opposition parties and at what is going to happen if we get five or six or so parties popping up. The Democrats may in fact get their extra $1.5m of free advertising, but then they may not. It is all up in the air. If I were a Democrat, I would really be quite worried about the blank cheque that I was signing.

Of course, there is another group of people signing a blank cheque, and that group consists of the people who conduct the television stations and the radio stations around this country. This is not free advertising; this is advertising that is conducted by the broadcasters on behalf of the Labor Party and on behalf of the Democrats—but particularly on behalf of the Labor Party. It is the broadcasters' money that is being put on the line. Of course, the argument from the Government is that it is terrible that political parties should be able to buy advertising time. We think it is even worse that political parties should be given advertising time at the expense of somebody else. Some of us on this side have enough difficulties, as it is, with the concept of public funding of advertising. But it is typical of this Government to go from socialism to communism and to say, `Public funding is not good enough. We are going to have private funding of the ALP, notwithstanding the fact that the people who are going to bear the cost might not necessarily be supporters of the ALP'.

Earlier this morning Senator Schacht was saying, `If the Opposition was fair dinkum, it would have some amendment in relation to shareholders of a company having a right to vote as to whether that company makes a donation to a political party or not'. Of course, there is no right here for the shareholders in those broadcasting companies to vote whether they are going to give the Labor Party or the Democrats some advertising time at their expense, because this Government is holding a gun to their heads and saying that they must give them the advertising time. We can see there the hypocrisy of people like Senator Schacht. He has popped up down there; he is running away from the heat at this end of the chamber. He is running down to the other end of the chamber. We can see the hypocrisy of the members of the Labor Party and the hypocrisy of their mates, the Democrats.

It has been suggested in this chamber this morning that the Democrats are going to get, as Senator Macdonald said, not 30 pieces of silver but $1.5m worth of silver in extra advertising that they could not afford at the last election. We on this side of the chamber have a very simple view: if the Democrats or the ALP have as much support as they think they have, they might get that advertising money from their supporters. But their supporters will not cough it up. Maybe it is the fact that the Labor Party—

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at Burke in Western Australia.

—Yes, I know that that is how they get their money from their supporters. They get their money from their supporters by telling them that they have to cough up or they are not allowed to do business. It is a sort of particular government tax.
—You ought to talk—belonging to the most corrupt political party in the Western world.

—Senator Faulkner wants to make a comment about corruption. Senator Faulkner comes from the ALP in New South Wales and we know that in New South Wales a particular Labor Party figure, former Senator Lionel Murphy, was implicated in the most disgusting and disgraceful perversions of justice in the history of this nation. We all know about the Labor Party's little mates. Only one thing saved Lionel Murphy, and that was a very timely death.
—A most scurrilous attack.

—Well, how do you like it? I am going to give it straight back to you. It was a very timely death for Lionel Murphy; a very timely death for his mates in the Labor Party. As the death rattle was going out of poor Lionel Murphy's throat, we could almost hear a sigh of collective relief from his mates in the Labor Party because they did not want the sham, the fraud and the disgracefulness of the conduct of the New South Wales Labor Party laundered for everybody in the world to see. That is the hypocrisy of this Government.

PARA.TAB: I want to address some of the other problems here because this legislation will proscribe and prevent individuals and organisations—(Extension of time granted) I thank the Senate, because I think it is important that we discuss the fact that this legislation will deny to individuals and to organisations a right to express their political beliefs. It will deny them the right to say to people what they think about what is going on in this country. I suppose that is highlighted most particularly in the supplementary explanatory memorandum circulated by the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus. The outline in the second last paragraph of the first page says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is further amended to enable advertisements to be broadcast for or on behalf of charitable organisations, where the advertisement promotes the objects of the organisation and does not explicitly advocate voting for or against a political party or a candidate or a group of parties.

That is saying: `You can have a view but in this Labor-run Australia you are not allowed to tell people what your view is'. I suppose that is consistent with a party that runs its own internal affairs by having show and tell ballots so that they can have a secret and personal opinion provided they share it around with their mates. This is Labor Party largess at its best. That is what it is going to do.

PARA.TAB: Another honourable senator on this side of the chamber has briefly discussed the possibilities that are going to arise with so-called sham charitable institutions. In case honourable senators do not believe that there is a fair possibility that we will have sham charitable institutions, I should just remind the Senate of the difficulties that were experienced in this country some six years ago when a scam flourished throughout the accounting profession whereby accountants set up bogus charitable trusts. There were primary beneficiaries of the trust, secondary beneficiaries of the trust and tertiary beneficiaries of the trust. Then there was an ultimate or residual beneficiary of the trust that was made to be a charity like the Royal Flying Doctor Service or the Salvation Army or St Vincent de Paul. What that enabled one to do was to claim that the income of the trust was all charitable income and was not subject to the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

What we are going to see spring up is a whole new spate of bogus, charitable trusts set up by the Labor Party and their mates and—in time they will cotton onto it—the Democrats and their mates. The primary beneficiary of the trust may well be the Australian Labor Party, but the ultimate beneficiary of the trust, after every single member of the Australian Labor Party has been exhausted, will be the Royal Flying Doctor Service. Then this bogus charitable trust can put advertisements on TV and say, `We think that the Labor Party has done a pretty good job for the Royal Flying Doctor Service and other people generally'. Provided the trust's advertisement does not say that people should vote for the Labor Party, this sham charitable trust or this sham charitable organisation can run its sham charitable advertisements. We all know they are not advertisements for a charitable institution; the only body to which these advertisements are charitable is the Australian Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about signs saying `Federal Government Building Better Roads'. Will those signs have to be painted out for three months?

—Exactly. Will they have to paint them out? Senator Panizza's comment is interesting because every letter that every Australian gets from the Australian Taxation Office carries the words: `TAXES—Building a better Australia'.

SPEECH.PARA: The question is: is this the sort of advertisement that might be caught up in the ambit of this legislation. Is a slogan that might appear on TV as part of a community service announcement or part of the logo of a department advertising for the Government? These are the things we have to consider and, of course, this Government has got no answer.

PARA.TAB: The real answer, unfortunately, will be an endless series of High Court challenges, because the Australian population will not wear this Bill. Even if they do not know about it tonight or tomorrow—because 7.30 p.m. is conveniently after the news broadcasts—they will know about it on Thursday night or Friday night, or on Thursday or Friday morning. The inevitable ire and wrath of the Australian people will rise up and overwhelm this legislation, which will be subsumed in litigation, subsumed in challenges.

This next election campaign will be subsumed in challenges and litigation as well, because every single statement that comes up will be subject to a challenge by one side or another. That is not the way to conduct an election, but that seems to be the farce to which this Government has reduced the nation. It is a greater farce when it is remembered that the reason why this Bill has been declared urgent is the Government's desperate lack of cash and the Government's urgent fear—gripping it from goodness knows where —about the possibility of the coalition advertising the benefits of its Fightback package.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are going to have a State election in Tasmania very soon and they are broke there, too.

—The eloquence of Senator Walters is matched only by her perceptiveness. We can see what it is all about; it is about the election in Tasmania. Fool me! I thought it was about a Federal election, but no, of course, it is about a State election.

PARA.TAB: The interjection explains why the Government has gone to such pains to include State and Territory elections in the legislation. The interjection by Senator Walters makes it all clear for me. It has taken the blindness from my eyes and, hopefully, such comments from honourable senators will take the blindness from the eyes of the Australian people. But one thing is sure: blindness and myopia grip the eyes of the Government backbenchers and the Democrats because the principled members of this Government's back bench cannot see what a particular fraud, sham and disgrace this legislation is. This Government, which trumpets its support for civil liberties and its support for human rights, is riding roughshod over the civil liberties and human rights of that group of people whom I consider to be the most important in the world—the Australian populace.
It is fine for Senator Schacht to come in here and talk about South Africa and Myanmar. I do not dissent from many of his criticisms of what goes on in Myanmar or in South Africa.

TALK.START.PARA: —Charity begins at home.

—Charity does start at home. Where is the charity for the poor Australians whose civil liberties and freedom of speech will be subjugated by this Bill? There is none, because this Government is breaking every rule in the book.

PARA.TAB: I will conclude by referring to Senator Schacht's comments the other day in which he said that other countries in the world do it; and why does not Australia? I have already dealt with the fact that the places where this sort of legislation is most prevalent and taken to its logical consequence are in the dictatorships and banana republics of this world. But there is another very good reason, and many honourable senators who are concerned with women's rights would recognise this. If it had not been for countries like Australia and New Zealand giving women the right to vote before other countries in the world did so, women would still not have the right to vote. If one applied the Schacht logic—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, your Party opposed it.

—It is `Schacht' with holes. If one applied the Schacht logic to this argument one would have to say, `Just because nobody else aspires to freedom and to a decent political process, we should not bother either. Let us sink democracy down to the lowest common denominator.' That is what the Government is doing. That is the whole basis of the Schacht argument. It is, in fact, the lowest common logical denominator to suggest that that is the proper way to run this country.

PARA.TAB: We on this side of the chamber in the Liberal and National parties have a vision of a better Australia, a vision of an Australia where people have a right to freedom of speech. We are going to stick up for that now; we are always going to stick up for it. Whether the Government likes it or not, it is just going to have to live with the fact that we are not going to tolerate this. After the next election I can guarantee that there will be a Bill to repeal this legislation, because we are a coalition based on principles and the only principles this Labor Party has are compromised principles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two matters I wish to refer to in dealing with this Bill this morning. I do not intend to argue the whole case as it has been put by members of the Opposition quite adequately during the course of the debate to this point. I agree with the criticism of the Bill, its substantial faults and, of course, the drafting faults that have been referred to.

PARA.TAB: The area that I want to specifically refer to relates to the use of radio and the fact that, along with television advertising, radio advertising will also be banned. I ask the Government to seriously reconsider this. On the financial side alone, of course, radio advertising is less expensive than television, but radio is a very important means of communication for a lot of people in this community. The print handicapped are, of course, foremost amongst those. Without access to radio there is a lot of information that they are not able to get in the way that other people are. That is one reason why information ought to be able to be made available over the airwaves in that fashion.

There are people in remote areas who either do not get newspapers or get them irregularly and who rely on radio for information as well. The Labor Party, perhaps, is not out in the workplace enough to know that many people have the radio on in the places where they work and it is a very significant means of their getting information and finding out what is going on.

There are many people who work the sorts of hours that do not allow them to sit at home reading the newspapers in the morning before they go to work; who do not have jobs where they can sit at a desk for half the day reading a newspaper to find out what is going on; who work hours that do not enable them to get home in time to watch the news and the current affairs programs on television. Some people perform shift work, which means that they are permanently at work at that time and do not get to see television news, current affairs programs and other things that other people might be able to see. For them, in their cars and at their place of work, communication by radio is very important.

What I find absolutely astonishing in this debate is that this Senate, this Parliament, would be pursuing a course which would preclude voters from getting as much information as they can, by way of advertising, talkback, newspapers, television—by any way possible—about the country and about the people whom they are going to vote for. I do not believe that we can have a true democracy if information is cut off from people. It is only by the electorate being well informed that we will obtain a vote that is meaningful.

I find it incredible that we are sitting here contemplating cutting off information to people. If we do they will be less well informed and ignorant of the issues. They will not even be able to have the benefit of the sort of advertising that we can get on radio, which frequently provides much more information than television because we can afford to have longer advertisements. We can have advertisements on radio which can, to a limited extent, even argue a case and put forward a proposition. I would ask the Government to reconsider this aspect.

The cost of elections would be significantly curtailed if we were allowed only radio advertising. I do not approve of the cutting out of television advertising but I think a particular case can be made. I would appeal to the Democrats to consider this. I listened very carefully to Senator Kernot's contribution and she did not seem to declare herself on the question of radio advertising. By the time this debate is completed, I hope that the Democrats will see that it is important and ought to be included.

I am not suggesting that there should be free advertising on radio, because I do not approve of the concept of free advertising. As has been said, there is no such thing as free advertising. I am not advocating that the Bill be amended to require the same kind of requisition of time for radio as is being imposed on the television networks. This is something that ought to be paid for by those who are using it. There is no justification for requisitioning people's property in this way. If property such as dirt and buildings were being requisitioned, there would be an outcry if it were not paid for and the owners properly recompensed. But somehow the Government seems to think that it is quite proper to requisition time for its own purpose.
I would refer you, Mr Deputy President, to section 51.(XXXI) of the Constitution, which I think is particularly interesting. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The acquisition of property on just terms from any State or person for any purpose in respect of which the Parliament has power to make laws:

I think it is generally understood in this country that proper compensation should be paid for property that governments requisition. I do not see how one can then distinguish between the right of television stations and other owners to be properly recompensed for the acquisition of property as a result of legislation passed by this Parliament—in this case, legislation to enable the political parties to obtain free advertising. I would be interested to see whether that particular point is, in fact, followed up. I can see no reason why the Commonwealth Government should be able to requisition the property of the TV stations in this fashion and require them to give free advertising.

PARA.TAB: I have been making two points. Firstly, I challenge as to whether or not it is constitutionally valid to requisition property in the fashion that the Government is seeking to do in relation to television stations. Secondly, I most certainly advocate that those who wish to convey a message by radio should be able to buy the time to do so. It is taking this matter too far to ban advertising on television and radio. I urge the Democrats to think very seriously about what that would mean for a lot of people in our community. Indeed, I think if we are pursuing a path which means that the electorate generally will be less well informed, we are not doing democracy any favour at all. It would be a great pity if that were the result.
As I said, I support the arguments which we are putting. I totally oppose this Bill but at this hour of the morning I shall leave my remarks as brief as that.

TALK.START.PARA: —December 3 and 4 1991 will be remembered as days of disgrace for the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats. These are the days on which substantial legislation, which has not been brought to the attention of the Australian public, was introduced into and dealt with in this chamber. The legislation has been guillotined and two days debate will not allow the kind of consideration that ought to be given to legislation that is considered in this Senate chamber on behalf of the people of Australia. It is a day of disgrace for the Labor Party and for the Democrats. I totally reject the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill and so does every member of the Liberal and National parties.

PARA.TAB: Why the rush? That is the first question that was addressed 24 hours ago when we began this two days of disgrace. I would like to give my views about that. The Government tabled in the Senate on Monday night 37 amendments to a Bill that has been in circulation for some six months—37 amendments to give shape to the significant decisions contained in the legislation. Today it brought down 14 more amendments. Members of the public have not seen one of those 14 amendments and perhaps only a dozen or a score of them would have seen the 37 amendments introduced yesterday. Yet, what we are debating is going to affect every Australian.

Why the rush? I believe that the Labor Party is being totally cynical. It is learning from its experience with the Australia Card. The Australia Card debate began with the Labor Party doing the same thing as it is doing now—pulling the wool over the eyes of the people of Australia. It was only because we were able to refer that proposal to a committee of inquiry and cause some months delay—people were given a chance to wake up to its deficiencies—that the public then started to generate the kind of momentum which eventually saw that measure defeated.

I think the Labor strategists have looked at this measure and seen the same potential for defeat if ever the Australian public were informed about it. So without any warning, the substance of the Bill was brought before us on Monday night. We have to have the whole debate over and done with by Wednesday night.

It is now nearly 2.20 on Wednesday morning on the second day of the debate. I think about 20 speakers have already spoken in this debate—and I see from the list that is in front of me that there are still a dozen to go. All speakers are of the view that this legislation ought to be brought to the attention of the Australian public and that it should not serve the self-interest of the Labor Party, which is pulling the wool over the eyes of the Democrats.

The issue that this legislation has been guillotined is only secondary. About 24 hours ago, Senator Ray argued that all governments have guillotined and `who is going to say whether a guillotine will be used in this chamber or the other chamber in the future'. He was trying to argue that, because the guillotine has been used in all sorts of circumstances, it is right for the Labor Party to use it in this circumstance. I just totally disagree with the use of the guillotine in this circumstance.

If we had legislation which had been widely circulated in the public, which had been widely debated and on which views had been well formed and then there was an attempt by a section of either chamber to cause some extraordinary delay, it would be possible to consider some way to overcome that delay. But in this circumstance to use the guillotine when the matter has not been brought to the public's attention is reprehensible.

Senator Kernot, in her speech, thought that the problem was that the Senate had only two days for the debate. Frankly, that also is secondary, in my opinion. Even if the Senate had three, four or five days for this debate, I would still want to move an amendment, which I hope will still be successful later today, to have this whole matter adjourned for three months to enable the public to understand what is at issue. Three months is the kind of practical period that would be involved if the Senate were to defer this legislation because, of course, the Parliament is likely to rise before Christmas, even though it will come back on 2 January 1992 to meet with President Bush. But it will regularly sit again only in late February and we could only guarantee that this would be dealt with during the month of March. That is a period of three months from now. I am urging the Senate to defer this Bill for three months. I want to make it clear that what I regard as offensive—

TALK.START.PARA: — That is a pretty strong word for you.

—What I find offensive is not just this secondary matter of the use of the guillotine or of the debate being limited to two days, even if the two days include this early hour of the morning debate, but it is the—

—Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I have been up in my room and have watched Senator Schacht and Senator Faulkner interjecting all night. I find it totally unacceptable. I ask you to call them to order while my colleague is speaking. They have been doing it all night and I think it is totally inappropriate.
—We did not complain about people interjecting on us.
—Order, Senator Schacht, you are compounding it.
—I thank Senator Patterson and I think I heard from you, Mr Deputy President, that the interjections were disorderly.
—All interjections are disorderly.

—I have contempt for the Labor members in the Senate chamber on this matter because they are cynically acting in their self-interest in terms of the coming Federal election. They are acting in their self-interest and they are pulling the wool over the public's eyes in order to get this thing rushed through so that they can go into the next election with what they think is a small advantage in their pocket. That can backfire on them and the Opposition will make sure that the Australian public know the circumstances of the disgracefulness of these two days and of the legislation that will be implemented by the Senate if the tactics of these parties are, in fact, successful.

PARA.TAB: I want to make it quite clear that it was to me secondary in offensiveness that there was a guillotine or that this debate has been restricted to two days. What is offensive to me is that the public has not been informed about it and that we do not have the benefit of the public's views so that we can be informed when we debate this matter. I believe that the only way in which we can do that is for the whole matter to be deferred until the February-March sittings.

No-one in this debate has shown that this is urgent. If the matter were deferred for three months to enable public consultation, what would be lost, even to those who are advocating this measure? No-one has told the Senate why this is urgent. Is there going to be a Federal election between now and March?

TALK.START.PARA: —Any election.

—Will there be any election between now and March? Does the Government want to have this legislation in place to clobber a particular local government election or a particular State election between now and March? If so, which one? Why is the Government picking on that particular State or local election to be the trial of the offensive elements of this legislation that the Labor Party and the Democrats want to introduce? There is no urgency for this measure.

PARA.TAB: The public's interpretation of these two days will be, I believe, that the Government has perpetrated a fraud on them, and that it has perpetrated this fraud in its own self-interest. There has been an unheralded introduction of the substance of the Bill on Monday and on Tuesday. There has been a decision to make immediate the debate of this Bill and there has been a guillotine to ensure that the whole debate is concluded by Wednesday evening—all over in less than two days. The public will hear about that.

I now address myself to the essence of the Bill, which is to change the rules for the next Federal election. Senator Schacht has acknowledged that. Everyone that has spoken on the Government side has acknowledged that they are changing the rules for the next Federal election. Why does the Labor Party want to change the rules? I want to suggest five reasons.

The first reason is that Labor is unpopular and needs this kind of circumstance or this kind of rule to give it some marginal redress for its disadvantages. Secondly, Labor is broke and does not have the money to do those things which would be prohibited by this Bill. Thirdly, Labor is extraordinarily exposed to television attack by the Liberal and National parties. Fourthly, Labor has already put in place its switched strategy not to have a television campaign but to use the electoral resources of members of parliament through direct mail, telephone campaigning and printing propaganda.

TALK.START.PARA: —Taxpayers' money.

—All at the expense of the taxpayer and all using the tripled resources that the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, who is in fact in charge of this Bill and in charge of that strategy, has given to those members of parliament.

PARA.TAB: The Government, of course, is crying crocodile tears that, in giving those resources to Labor members of parliament, it would have to give similar resources to other members of parliament. But it is saying, `Well, firstly, we are in a majority in the House of Representatives. We are on the ground in more electorates than they are and we will use these resources because that is the only way that we can get some kind of advantage. Certainly, we cannot get an advantage on television. We are dead unpopular with the electorate; they will never give us the money. Secondly, we are broke, anyway. Even if we did have some success with fund raising, it would only be to pay off our debt; and, thirdly, we fear terribly what the Liberal and National parties would do to us in a television campaign'.

Just think of the advertisements that we would run to expose the way in which the Hawke-Labor Government has failed this country—failed it by a recession; not only a recession that is hurting the people of this country but a recession, the Government says, that we in Australia had to have.

Also, this Government has created nearly a million unemployed. It is a tired government with a divided party and a failing Prime Minister. The huge weakness is that the Labor Party does not want to see the Liberal-National Party having the usual television campaign options for attacking the Government in the next Federal election. So it denies everybody; it denies both sides.

Senator Ray has just come into the chamber at 2.30 a.m. I reiterate for his benefit that I believe that the Labor Party is being cynically self-interested in learning from the Australia Card debate that, if it gives the Opposition a three-month start in getting the real essence of a Bill to the public, the public will wake up to it and throw it out. If this Bill were given a three-month break, there would be the same consequence. That is why the Government is pulling the wool over this Senate chamber and over the public of Australia by getting a debate all over in two days. It is a disgraceful situation because it is directly and cynically serving the self-interests of the Labor Party and, as it happens, of the Democrats.

I will continue with my reasons. The fifth is that the Labor Party has lured the Democrats up the garden path by appealing to their idealism. The Democrats have been on record for some time as wanting to resist and reject United States television excesses in election campaigning. The Labor Government has felt that it can appeal to that idealism and distort it, in the words of this Bill, to try to keep them onside and to form an alliance that will get its purposes achieved with Democrat support.

The Government has also, I think, taken the Democrats up the garden path with an appeal to Democrat realism—that at long last the major parties will not be able to bring onto television the same firepower that they have in the last 20 years of elections, which the Democrats cannot match. The Democrats cannot match it because they are not popular and because they have not got the funds. People do not give them the money. They are not supported by the Australian public to the extent that they can go about a television campaign. So, there is this realism in the Democrats' assessment of the situation that they will be better off by the major parties being pulled back to their line.

There is a sweetener as well for the Democrats; that is, the Government is offering to the Democrats 10 per cent of the so-called free time on television during election campaigns. When that is calculated, it is an increase in television time for the next election compared with the time that the Democrats actually experienced in the last election. That is a sweetener that the Democrats find very hard to overlook. It is why it is felt by so many in this chamber—and I believe there will be an overwhelming roar out there in the public in the coming months—that the Democrats are acting in their own self-interest. I am not saying that they are as blatantly cynical as Labor senators opposite. I believe that they have actually been taken up the garden path by Senator Bolkus and other Ministers of this Government, and that they have been lured to agree to a package, to form an alliance. But it is undeniable that this Bill and the outcome of this alliance are the direct self-interest of the Labor Party and the direct self-interest of the Democrats.

In summary, I will draw an analogy. Yesterday morning when we first began discussing this matter, there were in the galleries large numbers of school children. The thought occurred to me that they would understand what a sprint race at their own sports day is about. When the best runners are preparing for a race, they all start on the same line, they are not allowed to have steroids and other drugs and they are not allowed to have false starts. The starter has two guns, and if anyone jumps ahead of the line everybody in the school knows that they have to have a second start because it is not fair to break such a rule. But they would expect that the first one over the finishing line would be the winner. They would understand the concept of the school bully who, seeing that he does not have a chance of winning the running race but still aspiring to do so, decides to bind his own arms behind his back, to tie his legs together and then to change the rules by all sorts of pressure before the race to ensure that all the other starters in the race, even the ones who are fit and who have been training, will have to have their arms tied behind their back and their feet tied together so that the race becomes one of only hopping down the 100 metres to the finishing line.

Because the Labor Party has made itself so unpopular with the Australian public and would be at such a disadvantage were the contest to involve television campaigning, it has by this Bill adopted the tactic of the schoolyard bully to rig the coming sports day race by getting everybody in the race to have his hands and legs tied so that the race is not a sprinting race at all. It is my view that this Bill is a self-serving instrument of the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats. I urge the Senate to reject it entirely.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill, in its current form, maintains one of the characteristics that it had before it was sent off to the Senate Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures. The characteristic is that it contains a blanket ban and it represents a gross infringement of one of our most fundamental human rights: that is, our right to speak and to be properly informed. This latest proposal does exactly the same thing as the original Bill. The Government's reasoning for this latest revamped proposal also remains unchanged. It is being introduced, as many of my colleagues have said, for blatantly political purposes as part of Labor's desperate and last-ditch attempt to hold on to its power.

PARA.TAB: It is pertinent to assess the political climate in which this Bill has been brought in and is being rushed through the Senate. It is being rushed through in that it has come in with amendments. Had this Bill come to the House in June and not come to the Senate with the amendments that are proposed, then I do not think we could claim in the same way that we are claiming that it is being rushed through the Senate.

But why is the Government rushing it through the Senate? Why does it want this Bill? We have a government which has admitted that, under Mr Keating, it engineered a recession, a recession which we had to have but which is the worst we have had in 60 years. We have a government which is in the death throes of a leadership struggle that has now been going on now ad infinitum for years and has come to a fever pitch in the last 12 months. As a result of the recession that we had to have, we have had a multitude of misleading statements from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)—such as no child would live in poverty by 1990 and there would be no recession—and we have had the Kirribilli deal, to boot.

This Government is on the nose with no re-election prospects and it is grasping at anything it can cling to. We have heard people tonight saying that the New South Wales section of the Australian Labor Party is virtually bankrupt and that, with almost no hope of replenishing its stocks, it has to cling to something; and this is one way it is going to try to cling to power.

Why have the Australian Democrats supported this guillotine? They have moved radically to the left of the political spectrum in a desperate bid to find a political niche for themselves. They have failed to maintain their high profile since the departure of Senator Chipp and Senator Janine Haines. We have seen Senator Powell deposed because she was said not to have a high profile. I bet my bottom dollar that a hundred Democrats will get together and depose Senator Coulter in due course because he has not raised the profile of the Democrats. Like the Australian Labor Party, the Australian Democrats have been hamstrung by internal leadership crises which continue, just as the crises of the Labor Party continue, and which are going to paralyse the Democrats as they have paralysed the Labor Party. With the takeover and the new leadership by Senator Coulter, the Australian Democrats are also going to become a one-issue party, given Senator Coulter's background and interests.

At the end of 1991, both the Labor Party and the Democrats are fighting for their political survival. In this battle the stakes are very high. This advertising ban, both as it was originally drafted and in the current form, is a classic case of the end justifying the means. As the stakes have risen, it has become a case, not of how the Labor Party holds on to power, but of ensuring that it does hold on to power. Labor has become a win at all costs party with its bed fellows, the Australian Democrats, going along with it.

The recession we had to have shows that the Government does not care who gets hurt on the way, as long as it keeps winning. This legislation, which I believe is despicable, shows that the Labor Party does not care what fundamental rights are infringed, so long as it wins. I am not sure now when this latest proposal was introduced—whether it was last night or the day before but, when it was introduced, it had 37 amendments, and I think an additional 14 have been brought in since we have been involved in the debate today. I have no doubt that human rights practitioners such as Burdekin would have expressed the view that this latest proposal infringes the fundamental right of free speech—if the Government had done the right thing and provided sufficient time for effective community consultation on this amended Bill. That is what we are arguing about: the fact that there has not been sufficient consultation.

There are two aspects to the right of free and unfettered speech. Firstly, it assumes that every citizen should have the right and the opportunity to speak. Secondly, it assumes that citizens should have a right to be able to be properly informed about matters that affect them. In short, free speech involves a freedom to hear as well as a freedom to speak. Both these fundamental rights are infringed in this legislation.

There are two effects of this legislation which I find particularly galling. Firstly, this Bill will allow government departments and statutory authorities to continue their multi-million dollar self-serving and self-promoting campaigns which are, in effect, political campaigns for the government in power. The legislation will allow those campaigns to go on virtually unabated. During 1989-90, Federal government agencies spent $232m on these campaigns. I recognise, as we all recognise, that a lot of that advertising is justified. But a lot is not justified, and a lot of it is politically motivated. One has only to look at the $1.4m per annum that the taxpayer spends funding aNiMaLS, the National Media Liaison Service, and its weekly propaganda newsletter `Focal Point' to understand the extent of this Government's propaganda machine and the way it uses taxpayers' money.

When we are debating disclosure, corruption and political advertising, I think we should remember that the National Media Liaison Service was caught red-handed assisting the Queensland Australian Labor Party leader, Mr Goss, in 1989 during the Queensland election campaign. The Treasurer, Mr Kerin, sent a letter to Mr Goss offering the assistance of aNiMaLS in media monitoring during the State campaign. This was a blatant misuse of taxpayers' money in campaigning. I think you would have to agree with me, Mr Deputy President, that that was an abuse of taxpayers' money on a campaigning technique. A similar offer was made for the South Australian campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us all about Vapold in Victoria.

—If Senate Ray wishes to speak on this subject he should get up and speak. The Labor Government has become so brazen with its use of departmental resources for political purposes that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) refused three times this week to tell me unequivocally whether the Government would use Age Pension News to bag and bucket our Fightback package. I bet my bottom dollar that the Government will use Age Pension News in a blatant political campaign against the Fightback package to scare the elderly and age pensioners. It was quite noticeable before the—

—I do not have to tell Senator Schacht that the Government is so low that it would do that. I do not need to teach him dirty tricks. It was quite noticeable before the 1990 election that the Government had decided to step up its ongoing self-promotion campaign. We all remember the sandshoe campaign which showed little children who now could have sandshoes because their mothers had got a family allowance supplement. Bus shelters had sandshoe adds all over them. If that was not political campaigning, nothing was. That was a case of taxpayers' money being used and abused.

PARA.TAB: The Government was even more blatant when it conducted the superannuation campaign in March 1990. This campaign cost $1.5m, yet in the Budget Papers there were no appropriations for it. When I asked the Department of Social Security in the Estimates committee whether it had planned to do this in February, the answer was no. When I asked whose decision it had been, twice Senator Bolkus said that it was the Government's. Because there was to be an election in March, it was the Government's decision in February to tell us about this super superannuation program, which has been a disaster.

The Government spent $1.5m on advertising itself. Yet Government members are here pontificating about how this is going to save the Australian public from corruption and save the Australian public from all the terrible things that are going to happen to it because the granny Government knows best how to save us and how to protect the Australian public, who are too stupid to work it out for itself.

The Government has reached the point where it cannot tell the difference and it cannot discriminate between justified information and politically motivated propaganda. This Bill would have provided an opportunity to set down those guidelines, but it has not. The Government has gone in the opposite direction. By strictly controlling all political advertising during election campaigns, this legislation gives the Government greater incentive to rely even more heavily on departmental advertising budgets. The Bill, as it is currently amended and as I understand it—and if I am not right, I would like the Minister to put me straight—will allow Government departments to continue advertising. Because there is no adviser here taking a note for the Minister I suppose I will not get any advice. I want to know whether this will allow government departments to continue advertising up to three months before the expiry date of the House of Representatives or when an election is called, whichever is the earlier? Since 1970, only one Federal election has been called within three months of the expiry date of the House of Representatives. That was in 1972.

It is obvious how much this provision will benefit the incumbent government. An incumbent government, and only an incumbent government, knows when the election is going to be. Given the longstanding predisposition of Australian governments to call early elections, this gives the incumbent government the undue and unfair advantage of using departmental budgets to promote itself and its policies, without allowing the same leeway and the same information to the Opposition. The Government knows when there is going to be an election, so it steps up its departmental advertising, then calls the election and the Opposition cannot advertise, or it has limited advertising.

Let us not forget subliminal advertising. I want to ask a question of Australian Democrat senators—if any of them are awake in their rooms. They are not here in the chamber. There is not an Australian Democrat here. What is going to happen when Mrs Hawke participates in an advertisement for Greening Australia, or Austcare, or one of the other apolitical organisations that get money—in the case of Greening Australia, $759,000—from the Government? I am not denying Mrs Hawke her right to participate in an advertisement, but if the Government tells me and if the Australian Democrats come down here and tell me that that is not vicarious advertising for the Labor Party, then what is? Yet Mrs Hawke will be allowed to do that.

When we are in government, of course Mrs Hewson will be able to participate, and I do not think she should be stopped either. But that vicarious advertising gives the government of the day, if the Prime Minister has any sort of profile, an unfair and undue advantage because that person can be seen as caring and doing things. We have not thought about that. The Australian Democrats might like to come down and explain to me whether they are going to stop Mrs Hawke or Mrs Hewson participating in those advertisements. That is another avenue for having one's party up on the screen participating and being involved.

One of the other effects of the current proposal relates to electronic advertising during election campaigns. This will be restricted, as many of my colleagues have said, to candidates and political parties. At a time when there is virtually unprecedented public disenchantment with, and suspicion about, politicians this is a totally unsatisfactory compromise. Politicians are often accused of being out of touch with the electorate, yet this proposal means that, during an election campaign candidates, politicians and political parties—and no-one else—will be allowed to advertise in the electronic media. No-one with the expertise, no-one who can present another point of view—no-one—will be able to put his or her point of view.

Pressure groups will be prevented during an election from using the electronic media to convey their opinions on issues relating to that election campaign. This will mean that the only information that the general public will be able to receive through advertising in the electronic media during an election will be information conveyed by political parties. For quite obvious reasons, all that information is going to be politically biased.

This Bill, in effect, will prevent the Australian public from having proper access to objective viewpoints, or at least apolitical or alternative viewpoints, during an election campaign. Heaven forbid, it may be just possible that, in relation to some areas of public policy and concern, some of these independent people may have views that are vitally important for the public to hear. But no, the Government and the Australian Democrats know better. They say that these people should not be allowed to put their points of view because doing so might lead to corruption. But do not worry about the dirty deals that are done with departments using their budgets for advertising government policies. Do not worry about vicarious advertising when a Prime Minister's wife gets on the screen with a sham organisation. It might be the sort of sham organisation that Senator O'Chee talked about. That is the sort of advertising we will get. That is the sort of bias we will get. This legislation is repugnant because it assumes that politicians have some sort of monopoly or mortgage on informed political comment.

I believe two other points need to be made in this debate. Restricting political advertising in the electronic media during election campaigns to a designated amount of free time advertising in a talking heads format makes a number of dangerous and, I think, unsubstantiated assumptions. It assumes that free time talking heads advertising is the best and the fairest way—in fact, the only way—for parties to inform the Australian public about their policies in the electronic media during an election campaign. I do not subscribe to such an untested assumption. There are arguments for and against all forms of advertising. However, I do not believe that any of these arguments are so overpowering that they should proscribe all forms of advertising in the electronic media bar one, as this Bill is attempting to do. It is prescribing exactly the form of advertising that is to be used.

The exclusive reliance on talking heads free time advertising also assumes that all political parties have equal opportunity before the election to sell their policies to the Australian public. As I have pointed out, this is not true when such vast resources are allocated to advertising campaigns conducted by government departments.

I do not believe that the Australian public should ever forget the sly and underhand way in which the Government, in particular Senator Bolkus, has attempted to push this advertising ban through this Parliament. When this legislation was first brought before the Parliament in June, it was obvious that there had been a complete lack of community consultation. The human rights people, journalists and advertisers themselves, as well as a wealth of community organisations, many of which were mentioned by Senator Reid—rural groups; the visually impaired, including the elderly, many of whom take a very active interest in politics but are denied the information; ethnic organisations; and people who have difficulty in reading—voiced their disgust. I went along to some of the private hearings. They voiced their disgust at this legislation.

Knowing it had the numbers, the Government pushed the legislation through the House of Representatives in June and, with its lack of desire for effective public consultation, it did it again later this month when it failed to support the Opposition's motion to send the legislation to a Senate committee. Again it denied the public the opportunity to debate it. Now the Government's true colours have been revealed yet again by the guillotining of this debate. It is not a guillotine like we have had before to rush 20 Bills through in two hours; it is a guillotine related to a particular time frame. The Opposition is quite happy to debate this Bill in February once the community has had time to express its views.

I remember the Family Law Bill coming into this chamber in 1987 at about this time. The Government said that the world was going to fall apart if we did not have the Family Law Bill; that everyone in the world would be divorced. But we said no, and the Australian Democrats agreed with us on that occasion because some sort of little deal had not been cooked up between them and the Government. We left it for the community to discuss. We came back here in February, there were four days, I think, of Senator Durack and Senator Tate debating backwards and forwards across the chamber and we got a Bill that was much better and less likely to have unintended consequences.

But not so now. We are going to rush this Bill through. What is different? There is no election on the horizon? The difference is that the Government has a deal stitched up with the Australian Democrats and it is scared stiff that if the community gets to the Australian Democrats the Australian Democrats will change their mind as they normally do and the Government will not get this Bill. It will not get a restriction on the freedom and the rights of Australians.

Australians give away their rights. They have done it with Medicare; they have done it with the PBS data. And there is not much interest. But one day Australians will wake up and say, `It happened bit by bit. We let our freedoms go and we regret it now'. I suppose some of us will say, `We told you so'. Australians are complacent. Many of us have never had our freedoms denied, or knowingly had our freedoms denied. Those who have come from other countries know, but many Australians have just let it go. I think some Australians will suddenly wake up, maybe too late, in this debate. At least, unlike the Australian Democrats, we in the Opposition can say that we tried.

Just as the Australian public should understand that the disdain with which Minister Bolkus has treated them, they should not forget the sordid role the Australian Democrats have played in this legislation. The Democrats, while refusing to rule out whether they would support the Government's advertising ban, had the gall to take the high moral ground. They do it all the time. They regress to the high moral ground and say, `We are right. We are honourable. We are never wrong'. They claimed mischievously that it was they and not the coalition parties that were interested in ensuring the full disclosure of political donations. That is what they said. They always say, `We take the high moral ground. We were the ones who did it'.

It was the Democrats who, in a failed attempt to hold both the major parties to ransom, refused to split the disclosure and the advertising sections of the legislation, despite the fact that the Opposition had given a commitment to fair, non-coercive and equitable disclosure. It was the Democrats who refused to support Senator Parer's motion of 20 June to send the original Bill to a Senate committee, despite the fact that the Democrats themselves were proposing to make substantial amendments to it. If we denied them the right to send something off, there would be a song and dance throughout the community about what the coalition had done. Two months later, it was the Democrats who, in an attempt to prevent this legislation from dying its deserved natural death, embarked on a complete about-face and advocated that it be sent to a Senate select committee.

I wonder whether honourable senators have seen the program showing Senator Walsh with his dog. He clicks his fingers and around it goes one way; he clicks his fingers again and the dog jumps the other way. That is just what the Democrats do for the Labor Party—just as Senator Walsh's dog does for him out on his farm. The Labor Party clicks its fingers and they run one way; it clicks its fingers and they run the other way.

Finally, the Democrats are the party that was—and I suppose this must be the most overused phrase in political dialogue in Australia—`to keep the "bleeps" honest'. Yet they are the party that yesterday supported a Government guillotine which will prevent virtually any public examination of this amended legislation. That is what we are on about.
Senator Schacht has been interjecting, over and over, `You have had four years. You have had four years'. We have not had four years with 37 amendments. That is the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are extra ones, too.

—I thank Senator Bishop. There are the other 14 that they brought in—this mishmash. I would bet my bottom dollar that as soon as this Bill is implemented there will be problems all over the place—all the things that we have not had time to debate and to look at. The Government will say, `Oh, we will have to rush an amendment through, because this is terrible. A party can do this or a group can do that. We did not think about this at 3 o'clock in the morning, or after we had been sitting all night, when we were trying to do the amendments. We did not think about it'. We saw with the Family Law Bill that when we had time to think about it we could get good legislation. But no, we are going to rush this through.

PARA.TAB: Everyone here knows—we have had lots of examples of it tonight—how much the Democrats stand to gain personally, not individually but as a party, from this legislation. They are talking about 10 per cent of the so-called free advertising. As a number of people have said here tonight, it is not free; it costs somebody. As somebody said, if the Government were taking away property, all hell would break loose in Australia. But, because it is taking away the money of the shareholders or the advertising money of the other advertisers, somehow that seems okay.

I am awfully sorry; I can smell something burning. It is most probably the fire in my belly about this issue, but I do smell something burning. Hopefully, it is only a dead moth. I am going to finish my speech come hell or high water—or fire. The smell is actually quite strong in this part of the chamber.

The Australian Democrats consider 10 per cent of so-called free advertising time sufficient enticement to wash their hands of one of the most fundamental rights—that is, the right of unfettered speech. This legislation will come back—and honourable senators will never, I hope, let me hear them say that I did not tell them so—to haunt the Labor Party and to haunt the Democrats. They will remember tonight for a long time because they have allowed this Bill to go through in this manner. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill that we debating tonight—or this morning, whichever one likes to call it—is all about freedom of speech, freedom of the media and the maintenance of democracy in Australia. Let us have a look at the history of this Government in this regard. I have been here a good while now, and this Government has introduced several Bills. It is determined that it will curtail the freedom of the citizens of this country, because it claims that it knows best.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at what members of the Government have done. We had the Bill of Rights that they had a go at, supposedly legislating to give people in this country certain rights. We had the ID card—and we all remember the ID card; we all remember what they tried on that one. Now we have political advertising.

But first I want to talk about the Labor Party's particular brand of democracy. Members of the Labor Party divide into factions; they have faction leaders; they all decide, in their own factions, just what way they will vote; and then they make each person abide by that decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are pretty jealous about this, aren't you?

—I can assure Senator Cook that we are not jealous of his brand of democracy. We like our brand of democracy, not the show and tell brand of democracy that he has. He has a vote in his party room for his leader and it is a sham—nothing more than a sham. We get all the indications from the various groups of how they are forced to vote certain ways because the unions tell them they will not get preselection if they do not. We know that Senator Cook's form of democracy is not a secret ballot; his Party uses the old-style union system of show and tell. If someone votes in a supposedly secret ballot, he then has to show his neighbour, to make sure he voted the right way. Wonderful democracy! We have had reports in the media of the union movement threatening certain members of Caucus that, if they do not vote the way they are told, they will lose preselection. Senator Cook should not try to tell me that that does not go on, because it does.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the various Bills the Government has tried to get through the Parliament. We have had the Law Council of Australia oppose each one. This is what the Law Council of Australia said, in a letter to us, about the proposed Bill of Rights:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)The Council's concern that the Australian Bill of Rights permits `reverse discrimination' in favour of disadvantaged races and groups. The Council points out that there is no support for this in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

(b)The Council's concern at the wide range of powers given to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commissioner and of the secret nature of its investigations. The Council believes that secret investigations are objectionable especially where, as here, there is no right of legal or other representation before the Tribunal.

(c)The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has the potential to be used as a lever to put pressure upon State Governments to change their laws. This is an aspect of the legislation which the Law Council believes has not been fully recognised in the debate to date. Of particular concern to the Law Council is the fact that before the Commission can investigate State laws, the consent of the responsible federal minister must be obtained. This provision clearly is open to abuse for political motives.
(d)That the right to refuse to answer questions or provide information on the grounds of self-incrimination has been removed—
that is just one little thing the Government did—
from persons who are summoned before the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. This seems to the Council to be the very antithesis of what should appear in a Bill of Rights.
The Council stated also:

PARA.TAB: Although the powers of the Commission in areas other than under the Sex Discrimination Act stop just short of final determination, the powers are themselves so wide-ranging, and the Commission may, in the exercise of them, so seriously affect the position of individual citizens, that the Law Council believes that the legislation in its present form cannot be supported.

SPEECH.PARA: In that debate, in February 1986, I gave a pretty good example of what could happen under this legislation. I would like to repeat that example tonight to remind my colleagues and remind honourable senators opposite of what the Labor Party tried to push through.

PARA.TAB: I took the example of a Mrs Ann Citizen, who received in the mail—out of the blue—a letter from the Human Rights Commission saying that certain allegations had been made against her and directing her to come to the Commission's office to answer them. When she recovered from the shock, she rang the

SPEECH.PARA: Commission to find out what it was all about. She asked who had made the complaint. The Commission officer said that under section 29(2) the Commission had decided that she was not entitled to know who had made the complaint, as this was confidential. Ann Citizen said, `But that is not fair. I will arrange for my solicitor to accompany me to the office'. The Commission officer said, `Oh no, under section 34(4) of the Bill of Rights legislation you are not entitled to have legal representation unless we decide that you can. Just come by yourself. By the way, bring documents A and B which we understand you have in your possession. We understand there may also be certain letters. We believe those will help decide the issue'.

PARA.TAB: Ann Citizen, terrified at this stage, said, `They are private documents and private letters'. `But under section 35(2)(b)', says the Commission officer, `you will be fined or imprisoned if you don't provide the information that we demand even though it may be self-incriminatory'. Ann Citizen then said that she would appeal to the courts because she believed that she was not being shown true justice. Again the Commission officer said, `No, you don't. That's not possible either, because there is no appeal from the Commissioner's decision to a court of law'.

That is the type of legislation that honourable senators opposite started with in 1986. That is the sort of legislation that they wanted to ram through this place in 1986, but the people rose up in wrath against them and they withdrew.

Let us look at the sorts of things they tried to legislate for. They tried to tell us that they would legislate so that we could have freedom from slavery in Australia. They said also that they would legislate to stop us from being tortured. This, in this country, was the legislation that in 1986 they tried to ram through.

Then we came to the Australia Card. I am quite sure all the honourable senators on this side remember the public meetings, the marches in the streets and all of us addressing the people about the Australia Card. The Government wanted to introduce this Big Brother identification system so that a person had a number from birth to the grave—a number that related to one's medical history, all financial dealings, social security record, the state of one's immigration or otherwise, et cetera. What did the people do then? The people said no, and honourable senators opposite backed off on that.

We come to the situation where we have this proposed ban on political advertising. The Senate set up a select committee on political broadcasting and advertising. I accepted Senator Kemp's advice to read some of the Hansard of the evidence that was taken on the last day of sitting of that inquiry. I found that a Mr Sherry, who I gather was a university student, came before the Committee saying that he had decided to do a PhD on the strike by workers of the South East Queensland Electricity Board. He said that money was raised—by the ACTU, by the Trades and Labour Council, by all the union funds—for the families of union members on strike.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very laudable.
—Very laudable, says Senator Cook. Mr Sherry assured the Committee that leaflets were put out by the Queensland Trades and Labour Council saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The sacked SEQEB Workers Distress Fund was set up to try and maintain the workers for the duration of the strike . . . The money is used to purchase food, which in turn is distributed to the families of the sacked workers . . . The fund is there solely for the sustenance of the sacked workers and their families.
