In the Courier-Mail of 15 February—all this happened in 1985—under a heading `Your Financial Support Needed', there was an advertisement put in by the Trades and Labour Council of Queensland. It said:
The Trades and Labour Council has established a special fund to assist those trade unionists who have been dismissed and victimised by the decisions and actions of the Premier.

So money was raised. Mr Sherry told this Committee that there were indeed three funds—a total of over $3.5m raised. What he said was this: he went in to do his PhD because he was sympathetic to the strikers. The union said to him, `Here are the files. You can photostat anything you like. Do a good job'. And he did.

TALK.START.PARA: —I trust this has some relevance to the Bill before us.

—This happens to be the evidence on the Bill—the evidence taken by the committee set up by the Senate to look at this Bill. So it is quite relevant, I would say.What Mr Sherry found when he went through the documents was as follows, to quote again from Hansard:

PARA.TAB: The material I have uncovered during the course of the book on the SEQEB indicates that, while the SEQEB strike funds were collected for the sacked workers and their families, a great deal of the money that was collected simply did not reach the striking families. On many occasions, the money was wasted. More significantly, on other occasions, it was decided that the money would be used for purposes not directly associated with the SEQEB dispute.

The most obvious example of this was when $40,000 from SEQEB strike funds was donated by the Trades and Labour Council of Queensland and the ACTU to assist the ALP in the by-election for the seat of Redlands.

SPEECH.PARA: What a disgrace! How on earth do we overcome this in the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill? How on earth do we overcome that sort of abuse by the Labor Party that is so continual, and that we reach so many times? Bob Hogg has been convicted of an offence; no Liberals have been convicted of an offence. Senator Loosley is being queried; no Liberals are being queried. When it is so deliberate and so underhand, how can this sort of abuse be stopped? How can it be stopped by the legislation that the Government has before the Senate tonight? I do not know.

PARA.TAB: There is not just that sort of abuse. We have been watching what has been happening in Western Australia. We have been watching Brian Burke and his stamps. The whole country has been watching the abuse by the Labor Party. With the sort of political abuse that I have just quoted from Hansard, and with abuse by Bob Hogg, Senator Loosley and Brian Burke and all the shenanigans that went on in Western Australia, how can the Government senators have the hypocrisy to bring up the disclosure of political donations?

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you agree with it? Why don't you come across and agree with it? What are you afraid of?

—It is an absolute disgrace. Honourable senators opposite know as well as I that they can pass any legislation in this place but, if others are as underhanded as the mob opposite, people will get around it. Again I turn to the Hansard which shows that, through intimidation, Mr Sherry was forced to withdraw because he recorded on tape the threats and intimidation used against him. I have never been quite so amused in all my life as I was when I read how Senator Faulkner and—who was the other galah—Senator Schacht asked him whether he knew that it was illegal to tape telephone conversations.
—I raise a point of order. An unparliamentary reference has been made and it should be withdrawn.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen) —I do not really think the honourable senator should be called a galah. It is not unparliamentary, but I think perhaps for—

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly will not withdraw it because it is not unparliamentary; it has not been ruled as such. I again say: what other galah tried to tell this man, who was recording intimidatory threats against him—
—Could I just clarify your ruling on this matter? Are you ruling that this term that has been used by Senator Walters is not an unparliamentary term?
—It is definitely not unparliamentary. It is perhaps not a very polite expression to use. I do not know whether Senator Walters actually referred to any particular senator in that light.

—As I recall, she did. If it is not polite, perhaps we could ask Senator Walters to exercise some sort of gentlewomanly behaviour towards other senators in this chamber and refer to them with appropriate terms, not impolite ones.
—I will continue. These senators tried to tell Mr Sherry that he should not have taped the telephone conversation in which someone was saying to him:

PARA.TAB: `If you're trying to fix the Union, then why should I help you? If I find out you're trying to fix the Union, then don't worry, I'll fix you good and proper, good and proper. If I had evidence of that, that's what I'd do. When I say fix you, yes, I didn't say fix you, I said fit you. F-I-T. And that means fit you. And I mean by fit, I mean, quite bluntly, well, you can work it out for yourself. I used the word fit. And I guess that I'd become, I may become violent. Because I am not appreciative of people doing that'.

SPEECH.PARA: Those were the threats against this man who gave evidence before the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —There's nothing wrong with that. You've done it dozens of times.

—He was told by the Chairman, Senator Schacht, and by Senator Faulkner that he should not be trying to tape conversations over the phone because that is illegal. We have Senator Cook saying to me as an interjection, `What's wrong with that?'. On this side of the House we think there is a lot wrong with that. No-one on this side of the House would at any stage try to intimidate someone like that. We think there is a lot wrong with it. It is a thorough disgrace that the honourable senator thinks there is nothing wrong with it. It is a disgrace not only to the honourable senator but to the whole of his Party. I am well aware that the only way he can work his union is through intimidation, and he is so used to it that he does not even know what is wrong with it. That is the sad thing with this Labor Party.

—I raise a point of order. I now think Senator Walters, in her zeal, has gone beyond the Standing Orders and directly made references directly to me which are defamatory. In these circumstances, she should not only be gracious, but she should also conform to Standing Orders and withdraw those references.
—Senator Walters, I did not catch what you said.

—I said that he said, by way of interjection, `What is wrong with that?'. I said that he is used to using intimidatory language, so he does not know what is wrong with it, because that is the way he runs his union. That is what I said, because he said to me, `What is wrong with that?'. I repeat: if Senator Cook does not know what is wrong with that, I can only presume that that is the way he runs his union, and he has not got a clue what is wrong with it. All the honourable senators opposite are so used to intimidation they have not got a clue what is wrong with it.

—I raise a point of order. As I understand where we are up to, Madam Acting Deputy President, you sought an explanation from Senator Walters as to what she said. She has given an explanation and she is now continuing her remarks. Since she has concluded her explanation, you should now rule and ask Senator Walters to withdraw the defamatory remarks she made about me.
—Does Senator Cook claim that the remarks made by Senator Walters were defamatory?
—I do not believe it was unparliamentary.

—If I may assist: Senator Walters accused Senator Cook of engaging in intimidatory conduct similar to that which she claims has been recorded somewhere as falling from the lips of somebody else and which she characterised in the most extreme terms as being illegal and intimidatory language. She is accusing Senator Cook of precisely the same type of activity with regard to some union he is associated with.
—Senator Walters, I think it could be said that you were imputing improper motives to Senator Cook. In view of that, you should withdraw the statement that he used intimidatory tactics.
—Fine, I will. I withdraw. Nevertheless, I do want the interjection picked up.
—Unconditionally?
—I have withdrawn unconditionally, but I do want to underline Senator Cook's interjection to me.
—You didn't interject, did you?

—He did interject. Do not start that nonsense with me. If Senator Tate does not believe me, he should listen to the tape tomorrow. I happen to tell the truth, which again may be very foreign to honourable senators on that side of the chamber but is not foreign to those on this side of the chamber. Do not accuse me of not telling the truth.
—You just had to withdraw because you didn't tell the truth.
—I did tell the truth. He did interject on me and he did say, `What is wrong with that?' when I quoted the intimidatory language that Mr Sherry was giving as evidence before the Committee.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: the interjection that came across the chamber from Senator Tate was that Senator Walters withdrew because she had not told the truth. That is quite clearly not the case. Madam Acting Deputy President, you eloquently suggested that she should withdraw because there was a suggestion of an improper motive. I suggest that you direct Senator Tate to withdraw his comment because he has accused Senator Walters of something which is itself improper.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Senator Tate, I do not know that you should be accusing a senator of not telling the truth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why does he not apologise?
—I am not apologising, I can tell you now.
—Well, throw him out.
—Oh, I do not think I would like to do that, thank you, Senator Walters, but I do think it would be good if you got on and finished your speech.

—Put it is this way, Madam Acting Deputy President: they really cannot take it. They like to dish out a lot, but give them anything back and they hop up and ask for withdrawals. I do not care whether the Minister withdraws or not. I know that I tell the truth, and I know that that lot never do. That is all that worries me.

PARA.TAB: I have only a few moments left, but let us get onto this Bill, because quite honestly this is the worst Bill that the Government has attempted to bring in. We are presently debating one of the most far-reaching Bills that has ever been brought to the chamber. The crux of the whole Bill is whether the Australian people are going to have the right to voice their concerns about any government, about any opposition, or about any minority party. If they cannot be heard in the media today, they can put in a few bob and they can place an advertisement on the radio or the television. But once this Government's legislation gets through, with the support of the Democrats, they will not be able to do it any longer.

Let us just take an example. We remember Bishop Hollingworth saying that Mr Hawke had abused the street children when he said, `By the year 1990 no child will live in poverty'. We all remember that. That is the sort of comment that the Reverend Hollingworth will be forbidden from using in an advertisement on the television, should he want do so. He will no longer be able to represent the street children of this country because this Government will say to him, `No, we will not allow you to defend them on television or radio. You will not put on an advertisement'. It will say to every charity, `You cannot advertise in future for more aid for the poor because that is seen as a criticism of the Government and it will not be allowed'. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight at 3.35 a.m. on Wednesday, 4 December we are debating the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill. It is a night of infamy for the Labor Party and the Democrats because it is the night that free speech died in Australia. It is a night that will be remembered because something that has been held dear by us in this nation is the right to project our views—
—Come on. Under the National Party in Queensland you couldn't even walk in the streets there a few years ago.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Senator McKiernan, Senator Boswell has the floor.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator McKiernan wants to get into the filthy gutter, I will get down there with him and I will bucket him all the way. If he wants to talk about corruption, I will give it back to him in truckloads. Let us continue with this Bill and calm down—
—You have been there for years. You have been in the gutter for years.
—You are a liar! You are a filthy, rotten, stinking liar!
- Order! Senator Boswell, that is not parliamentary language and I would like you to please withdraw that.

—I will withdraw, Madam Acting Deputy President. I want to stick to this Bill because it is very important to Australia. At a time when all other nations are moving towards freedom of speech and communism is being defeated all over the world, Australia is moving the other way. We have 20 or 30 hours, or whatever the time is, to debate this Bill. Certainly it is sufficient to give everyone time to state their position. But what infuriates me and worries me is that that is not giving the community groups that are affected by this Bill time to have any input to it.

PARA.TAB: Only a week ago the report of the Senate Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures was brought down in the Senate and only yesterday 37 amendments to the Bill were proposed. There were 14 more added today. So 51 amendments have been put before the Senate in the last 24 to 36 hours and the Government has not let any community debate take place on them. I can understand that because, if community debate were allowed to take place, it would build up a head of steam in two or three months and then the Government would have to withdraw the legislation, as it did the Bill of Rights, and it would have to go the other way. That is why we are seeing tonight a debate that is going to take this number of hours to get it through.

It does not really matter what the Government does because, when a government is finished, it will never deceive the people. The people have made up their minds. In effect, this Bill applies to the television stations a bill of $18m. Three of the networks are in financial trouble—Channel 9, Channel 0 and Channel 7—although Channel 9 is trading reasonably profitably. This Government then says to those people who are struggling for existence that it is going to saddle them with another $18m.

It is a disgraceful Bill. In effect, it will not be the television stations that will pay. These costs must get passed on. There is nothing free in this world. Everything has a cost and every cost must be passed on. We are going to see the people who place advertisements with these commercial television stations picking up the Government tab. That is completely unfair and I do not see how anyone who supports justice, particularly Senate Tate as Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, can put his name to such legislation.

The real problems come when we look at the terms of the Bill. The Bill covers not only the Federal Government, but local government and State government also. The Bill gives any government 40 per cent of the free time. It gives the Opposition 40 per cent of the free time. It gives the Democrats 10 per cent, and it gives independents 10 per cent.

I would like to give a couple of examples. I do not know what would happen in these circumstances. Let us take the National Party in Western Australia, which is not in coalition with the Liberal Party there. How are those funds to be distributed there? What does the National Party get out of that 40 per cent? Does it get a percentage of the 40 per cent or does it get a percentage of the 10 per cent?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that would be right. That is what they will give you.

— We could turn that around in Queensland, where the Liberal Party and the National Party are not in coalition. Where does that leave democracy? Where does that leave the two fairly significant parties in the State Houses? Do they get a proportion of the Opposition's share or do they get the 10 per cent? Senator Tate might be able to inform us about that in the committee stage.

PARA.TAB: What happens to Independents such as Senator Harradine and Senator Vallentine if this legislation goes through? It will do so with the support of the Australian Democrats, so what happens to those people? They do not get any sorts of guarantees that they would get a percentage. If 20 Independents stand in Tasmania, Senator Harradine would not get any help at all, yet he is a sitting senator and so is Senator Vallentine. Those people are going to be completely neglected.

What this Bill does, of course, is entrench the larger parties; it does not provide any opportunity for people who may have some political ability and something to sell in the political forum to gain entry to parliament. So that stymies democracy also. No-one has the chance to get his message across to the public and therefore no different ideas can come forward. I dare say that if the Democrats were to launch their party now, they would not have the opportunity to establish a party that would be represented in this Parliament.

There have been a number of suggestions tonight that the Democrats have been led up the garden path. I just wonder who is leading whom up the garden path. We have seen tonight that the Democrats come out of this with free advertising time worth about $1.8m. That is a very significant increase on what they have been able to raise through their fundraising in the past. So the Democrats have come out of this very well, but the rest of democracy has suffered.

Fewer people are buying newspapers and more people are relying on radio and television for their information. That applies particularly to rural people who are unable to obtain their daily newspaper or their weekly newspaper. They rely entirely on information from the radio and television stations. These rural Australians—or new Australians who have difficulty in reading newspapers—will be discriminated against. This Bill does not take into consideration any of those people.

The 18 minutes a day or 500 minutes over the 28 days of the election campaign is going to be distributed in two-minute grabs with people giving a direct message. I wonder whether politicians giving a message for two minutes will be interesting enough for people to sit and watch. I think it will be a giant turn-off.

I am particularly worried about the ability of political parties to get a message across. It is not uncommon in Australia for various newspapers and media outlets to have a bias towards one political party or the other. I see this legislation making the political commentators very much stronger. Their views will carry much more weight and there will be no opportunity for political parties to answer those criticisms, balance their arguments and get their political message across.

The Bill is fraught with all these inconsistencies that go against the very basis of what we hold so dear in Australia—the ability to project and enunciate our political positions. It should be the right of every person in Australia to be able to say, `This is what we are all about. This is what we believe in and this is the message that we want to give to you'.

I am quite worried about this Bill. It is one of the worst pieces of legislation that I have ever had to speak on. In normal circumstances I would not get into a debate at 3.30 in the morning, but I am so concerned about this legislation and the effect that it is going to have on Australia that I have done so.

The added power that radio and television commentators are going to have is going to be so significant in Australia that it will be hard to get a balance of the arguments. I do not believe that putting almost total power into the hands of political commentators is democracy.

A lot more money will be spent on advertising—on newspaper advertisements and, of course, all sorts of direct mailing campaigns and telemarketing—so I do not believe we are going save that much money. The money collected will be diverted into other types of advertising. It is a political fact that when a government is unpopular—this happens to governments of all persuasions—there will be a rush to support the alternative government. That alternative government will collect money because people want a change.

That is exactly what is happening at the moment. This Government has governed for eight years and no-one could say it has governed wisely. It has sown an absolute depression. I suppose that the image that it is frightened to have on television is that of one million unemployed people. I know the types of advertisements that would be run and I know that the Government is fearful that it would never be able to answer them. Just the other day we saw 3,000 people lining up at the Toyota factory for only 70 jobs. The other day 1,500 people turned up for jobs at a nightclub. Those are the images that this Government is frightened that we will project, so it is running for cover. But while it is running for cover it is almost destroying what Australians have enjoyed, that is, the right of free speech.

Once again, rural Australia has been neglected because it will not be able to get the information that it requires to make an informed choice. It will not be able to get it from radio or television. It will not be able to get it from newspapers, because they are not available in the bush. It is a day of infamy; it is a day on which the Government has run scared. If it had not run scared, it would have let debate go on in the community.

One hundred and twenty-seven people made submissions to the Senate Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures, the report of which was brought down only a couple of days ago. Those people would want to see the report, they would want to see the Bill, they would want to see the amendments—and no-one has seen anything. The Government has decided to suffer the pain now, to get the Bill through before Christmas when people's minds are not on legislation or on government, to get it over, to rush it through the House and give everyone here the chance to speak on it but not to give people in the community the right to have a look at it so that they can then come back to their elected representatives and make the points they want them to raise in the Parliament of Australia.

The debate tonight has been a bit of a cop-out. The Liberal and National parties certainly do not have the numbers to defeat the Bill. The Democrats will gain $1.8m, the Government will secure the passage of the Bill and the people of Australia will lose their right to free speech. As I said, today is a day of infamy. What we will have lost when the vote is taken is the very basic right of Australians to say what they want to say and to have their message reach the people. That is going to be lost today when the Government and the Democrats vote for this Bill and deny Australians something that they have had since this country was founded 200 years ago.

I am very unhappy to be in this chamber when such a Bill is being passed. I feel powerless because I cannot do more about it. The decision relies on the numbers in this Parliament. Obviously, we can fight and we can move amendments, but the ultimate decision depends on the numbers. The Democrats have made their decision. They will get their money. The Government will get its Bill, which it thinks will save it at the next election. I can tell honourable senators opposite honestly, because I have been around politics when we have been winners and losers, that once they are out, they are out. Once the tide goes out, there is nothing they can do. They cannot swim against it. It runs faster and faster as the water recedes and there is no way out.

People have had eight years of Labor Party government and they have made their decision now. If the Government brings in this legislation it will stop freedom of speech and stop the Opposition pointing out all the indiscretions, bad decisions and hardships that it has put people through. People do not need to see 30-second television advertisements to know what the Government has done. They know it. They feel it in their pockets. They feel it when their kids cannot get a job. They feel it when they are getting thrown out of their houses because they cannot meet their mortgages. They know it when they cannot make the repayments on their farms. So it does not really matter whether the Bill is going to save the Government's bacon. It will not save its bacon. The Government has gone. It is finished.

It does not matter when the Government calls an election. What does matter fundamentally is that, in its desperation to hold government, it has betrayed the Australian people and taken away from them what is very basic to them, something that they have had for 200 years. Honourable senators opposite ought to be ashamed, particularly Senator Tate, because he is a man who has credibility and a man who would not normally put his name to this type of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it very sad to have the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill put in front of us at such short notice for a full and proper debate. The Government is obviously running scared. Today—I was going to say `tonight', but it is no longer tonight; it is now `this morning'—in the Senate we are seeing the fruits of a typical dirty deal between the Hawke Labor Government and the Australian Democrats to force through a measure of political censorship which Australians do not want but which, of course, serves to advantage both of those political parties.

PARA.TAB: I find it interesting that the Government has done this at such a time. It is not even two weeks since Dr John Hewson released the Fightback package, a program for taxation reform, a program for reform that the Government has not been able to lay a glove on. It has not even been able to get near it. Certain Ministers in their attempts to do so have been described as the Laurel and Hardy of Australian politics. The Howes and the Kerins of this world have been trying to refute what the Liberal and National parties have done.

Quite clearly, that whole program has frightened the living daylights out of the Government.It has now seen fit to gag the Liberal and National parties to make sure that they do not have freedom of speech in the period coming up to the next election. I have yet to figure out what the urgency is, but quite clearly the Government has something in mind. Maybe it wants to go to the polls early or maybe, if Mr Keating decides to challenge Mr Hawke again, it will find a slight glimmer of hope that will enable it then to rush off to the polls. But the Government wants to make sure, no matter which way it goes, that we are gagged.

Of course, the Australian Democrats want to make sure of the same, and they will do that purely and simply because they do not want to be forced into a position of trying to argue against the Fightback package. In their gormless, idiotic, weak-kneed, lily-livered attempts over the last week and a half to denigrate the Fightback package, the Australian Democrats came second only to the Government. Yet their brilliant so-called leader, Senator Coulter, has come out today and made the absolutely inane comment that we should be making sure that food, clothing and footwear are exempt from the GST.

TALK.START.PARA: —And from tariffs?

—That is a very good question, but Senator Coulter does not understand the difference. He does not understand what a tariff is, he does not understand what the GST is, he does not understand the relevancy of exemption from a GST, he does not understand what the wholesale sales tax system is. So the easiest way for the Democrats and the Australian Labor Party to go and hide under a rock is to make sure that they do not have to argue this package in the period leading up to an election.

PARA.TAB: The Liberal and National parties have maintained a very firm stance of principle on this issue right from the word go. We want full and fair disclosure, but what we do not want is censorship. That is a totally different ideal or objective from that of the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats. I am completely opposed even to the compromise legislation of a Minister in a supposedly democratic country, the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), who has stated that:

SPEECH.PARA: Action must be taken now to sanitise the electoral system.

Why on earth would he say that if he did not think the Government was looking down the barrel of certain defeat? The Government does not want a full and proper debate on policy at the next election because it has no policies. Its only reply to the challenge over the last week and a half since the package was released was, `We will give you more of the same'.

PARA.TAB: Today, or yesterday now, Senator West stood in this chamber and said that we lack compassion. Is that not absolutely hilarious, coming from a member of a Government that has made sure that over one million people are unemployed? She does not want that debated in the public arena, come the next election. She wants censorship, she wants to make sure that there is not free and open discussion of issues and policies, because she knows that her party has no policies, no vision, no future and no options; it has only more of the same. It is saying,`We will give you more of the same. We will not be happy until we have two million people unemployed'. Honourable senators opposite want to completely and utterly wreck this country—if it is possible to do more than they have already done.

Nothing better illustrates the equivocal attitude of the social engineers and the cynical numbers men towards the right to disseminate and receive political information. I cannot help finding it ironic that so many of the same honourable senators who less than three years ago affirmed the supposed right of Australians to obtain the grossest kind of pornography, when they defeated Senator Walters's Bill, now combine again to protect the airwaves from political advertising. Is that or is that not some sort of contradiction? That mob over there and the clowns that sit on the cross-benches, the Australian Democrats—

TALK.START.PARA: —Sometimes.

—That is right; they do not often appear. When it comes to a vote to stop the dissemination of gross pornography throughout Australia, they say, `No, you cannot do that'. But when it comes to advertising for elections, Federal, State and local government elections, that is a different story altogether. Yet they do not seem to have a conscience about that. That seems to sit quite well with them. Maybe Senator West would like to tell us why.

PARA.TAB: The political parties, in the view of the coalition, are voluntary institutions with the consequent right to communicate directly with the electorate through whatever forms of advertising are most effective. In putting forward this shabby little deal, this Hawke Labor Government has ignored the mass of evidence that came before the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures. The report of that Committee was an absolute masterpiece of selectivity and evasion. I do not think that Government senators have actually read the report. They do not really care what is in it because they had made up their minds that they were going to gag freedom of speech in this country once and for all. They are also going to make sure that everyone, from small children to old people, will be able to have total access to pornographic material. That is something that still sits well with them.

The great Labor argument for the banning or restriction of advertising was the danger of corruption. What a joke for this Government to be talking about the danger of corruption! If they made the trek across the Nullarbor, they would find all the corruption they would want to find in a lifetime. Messrs Burke, Dowding, Parker, Grill—

TALK.START.PARA: —Terry.
—Terry Burke, yes, I forgot him.
—Mr twenty per cent.

—Yes. All the stamps and the gold that you could think of. Half of them have had to leave. Mr Dowding has had to go to Sydney; he has been chased out of town. Mr Parker has had to go to Hong Kong; he has been chased overseas. It is interesting to think that Senator Aulich last night said, and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: The desire to hunt money was absolutely pressing on all political parties. I am not being party political here because, let us face it, it happened in Western Australia with the Labor Party—
So even Senator Aulich has admitted to corruption. The little sleaze continued on to say—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, that term is outrageous, even from someone as crass as Senator Knowles.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)- Senator Knowles, I believe the term you used was unparliamentary. Would you please withdraw it?

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order—
—There is no point of order. I was going to ask Senator Knowles to withdraw that unparliamentary statement before Senator Collins rose to his feet. Senator Knowles, would you please withdraw?
—It is a pity you called him a little sleaze; he is a big sleaze.
—That is probably true, too.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask Senator Bishop to withdraw that interjection. She is the shadow Minister with responsibilities in the area of Standing Orders. It does her no credit.
—Senator Collins, before you rose I was going to ask Senator Knowles to withdraw that unparliamentary comment. I ask her to withdraw.
—I will certainly withdraw it.
—I do not think there is any need for your comments, Senator Collins, or comments from Senator Bishop.
—I will replace that comment. The little creep has decided—
—I am sorry, I cannot accept that either.
—Is `creep' unparliamentary?
—Yes, I believe it is. I will have to investigate Senator Vanstone's book. It is four o'clock in the morning. Would you mind curtailing your language, Senator Knowles?

—I withdraw the word `creep' as well. It is nice to look across the chamber and see Senator Collins. I think he said that he has had a shower. I hope he washed his mouth out at the same time, because earlier tonight the Deputy President made him retract swear-words in this place.

PARA.TAB: What Senator Aulich did, in his typical fashion of unparliamentary practice, was to say then that Sir Charles Court and the Liberal Government before the Labor Government also had the desire to hunt money which was absolutely pressing on all political parties. How dare someone of Senator Aulich's standing in the community, someone who has had the temerity to claim $15,000 travelling allowance over and above the parliamentary sitting travelling allowance, start slurring someone like Sir Charles Court. What a cheek!

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, Sir Charles Court.

—Senator Collins never even met Sir Charles Court, and that is a blessing for Sir Charles Court and Sir Charles Court alone. Sir Charles Court will never know how lucky he is that he has never had the pleasure of meeting Senator Collins.
—Oh, goodness me.
—Why do you not go and have a cup of tea, a Bex and a good lie down?
—Because I have to be here, Senator Knowles, and for no other reason.
—Order! Senator Collins, please refrain from interjecting; Senator Knowles, please address your remarks through the Chair.
—There is no evidence whatsoever as to corruption in the Federal electoral process—
—Go bag your head, demented old bag.
—Can I please ask for Senator Collins to withdraw the words `demented person'?
—I withdraw unconditionally.
—It is interesting that Senator Collins, as the curator of public morals here, suddenly slips into his normal terminology.

PARA.TAB: This Labor Government, and of course the Democrats who are always telling us of their philosophic and libertarian concerns, very eagerly choose to ignore Professor Philip Alston, who stated that the departmental advice on the international human rights aspect of the Bill was `very superficial'. Does that mean anything to the Australian Labor Party, to the Australian Democrats? Not a thing. Mind you, I doubt whether the likes of Senator West would understand what being superficial would mean. Nor has any notice been taken of Professor Alston's evidence on 26 September that the major political parties should have paid access to the media because they are in effect the voice of those many interest groups which choose to work through them.

Senator Patterson made some very interesting comments earlier this morning about the fact that Mrs Hawke does some charity work and works with various interest groups. How is the Government going to view the work that she does on television and radio?

TALK.START.PARA: —You can guess!
—Senator Walters is ever so right. We can guess. The Government has selective judgment when it comes to things like that.

PARA.TAB: The legislation also ignores the view of Mr Short of the Law Council of Australia, who said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is not really a matter for any government. . . to tell anyone what ideas they can express and how it is that they can express them. . . The quality of that communication is not a matter which affects the principle of freedom of speech. . . We would say that members of the community have the right to express and communicate ideas and messages through the medium of their choice in the manner they see fit.
Does the Government or do the Australian Democrats ever think that the Law Council would have anything of significance to say?

TALK.START.PARA: —No. They only listen to the Labor lawyers.
—The wealthy Labor lawyers.
—In some instances the Labor lawyers also have had trouble with this, but the Government has chosen to ignore that because it does not serve the purpose of its gagging freedom of speech.
—Senator West can explain that to us.

—I would not guarantee it. This compromise legislation disregards the evidence of Mr Maley of the Australian Electoral Commission, who expressed concern at the drafting of exemptions for charities and definitions of current affairs, public organisations and public benefit. Once again, to understand what all of that means is probably beyond the Minister's capability and therefore it is no longer in the Bill.

PARA.TAB: The Liberal and National parties reject the basis of the Labor and Democrat compromise—that limited free time provides a proper substitute for the independent placement of paid advertising. It is so typical of Labor's attitude to the private sector that the commercial media must help to fund its advertising. As we on this side of the chamber have said before and will keep on saying, Labor no longer has the political credibility to raise the funds to pay for its own advertising.

It is interesting to note that Senator Aulich has just crept out of his cot. Before he goes off his brain and says that I misquoted him, let me remind Senator Aulich, before he does his quince, that I have here a copy of his full speech and that is what I quoted from.

I come back to the commercial broadcasters. What we are really talking about at this hour of the morning is the imposition being placed by the Labor Government and the Democrats on the commercial broadcasters to make them pay for this so-called free advertising. They must lose revenue to ease the embarrassment of Labor and its Democrat mates. As many of my colleagues have so eloquently put it, the real winners in this compromise—this dirty, grubby, little deal—are the Australian Democrats, who have not got two beans to bless themselves with and are unlikely ever to have two beans to bless themselves with. The only way they are ever going to get any coverage on any media at election time is to make sure it is for nix.

TALK.START.PARA: —They could get arrested.

—Senator Vallentine is pretty good at that but it has obviously taken a toll on her health because she is having to quit. The Australian Democrats will be the ones to benefit because they did not have very many advertisements in the last election, the election before that or the election before that. That was a blessing, because they never quite know what they are saying anyway. If there are to be talking heads this time, that could be of great benefit to us too. If Senator Coulter is the talking head, that would mean that their grubby little deal with the Government has backfired on them.

PARA.TAB: We should not be surprised that the Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Burdekin, stated that the talking head format now promoted by Labor and the Democrats `may serve to advantage governments', who have a stronger access to authoritative information. At best, this has all the signs of a weak compromise that would be ineffective in practice. We must remember that the advice he gave to the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) on 9 May was deliberately played down by the Labor Government, which has given Mr Burdekin no information beyond a press release.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a disgrace.

—No information has been given to the Human Rights Commissioner beyond a press release. As Senator Walters quite rightly says, that is a disgrace. But Government members knew exactly what Mr Burdekin would say. They knew what his response would be. After all, a man in that position would not be able to go along with the nonsense that the Government and the Democrats are proposing.
—What response have they got? None—never mentioned.
—No, they have not, Senator Walters. You are quite correct.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! Can we have some discussion through the Chair?

TALK.START.PARA: —It was extremely embarrassing for the Government to be told by the Commissioner that a total advertising ban would contravene article 19.2 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights dealing with the receiving and imparting of information. Mr Burdekin also demolished the specious and, frankly, absurd argument being peddled by the Minister that free speech expressed through advertising is bought speech and thus somehow has no validity. That argument could rule out any kind of communication beyond the unaided human voice. Of course, that is beyond Senator Bolkus's ability to comprehend.

PARA.TAB: While the Government does its best to extract as much censorship as the Australian Democrats will allow, it is doing its best to ensure that the disclosure provisions are not tightened so as to cause Labor any disadvantage. Government advertising may be halted for three months before an election campaign but there are to be no tighter controls over the current $232m annual spending of taxpayer funds on advertising and market research; nor will the advertising moratorium be to much avail if a government calls a snap poll. So it is all a bit cosmetic in many respects.

Quite clearly, the Government is going to have all the government departments saying what a wonderful job it has done. It will make sure that there are glossy advertisements mentioning all of the jobs that the Government has created—not talking about the more than one million jobs that it has lost. The advertisements will say what a wonderful health system we have—not talking about all the people who are now off the waiting lists and in the cemeteries. The story will go on. The problem is that there will just be sanitised advertising on one side, paid for by the taxpayer. That is the way in which the Government is trying to hoodwink the Australian public. Nor can we expect any provision for the auditing of grants made to voluntary organisations to ensure that they are not being used for additional political purposes. Such an audit might seriously embarrass Labor and the Democrat mates but, of course, there will not be any provision for such an audit.

Just what will Labor and the Democrats do about intimidation of those firms and other organisations which choose to donate to political parties of which union leaders may disapprove? That, I think, was fairly clearly answered in Senator Parer's reminder to the Committee on 24 September that Senator Ray had implied—with little subtlety, I might add —in Hansard on 6 May 1987 that, if businessman Lindsay Fox chose to donate to the Liberal Party, he might expect a decrease in good relations with the unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was that?

—Does Senator Walters want me to repeat that? It is actually very significant. Senator Ray said on 6 May 1987, as recorded in Hansard, that if businessman Lindsay Fox chose to donate to the Liberal Party, he could expect less than cooperative relations with the unions.
—And we wonder why Senator Cook asked what was wrong with intimidation.
—That is right.
—The problem remains a very real one.

—If Labor is prepared to laugh it off, the Democrats should not. Quite clearly, this Government is prepared to laugh it off. We have had megamouth over there going on and on and on. Quite clearly, he does not mind that type of intimidation. This Government does not care about intimidation. Intimidation is what this piece of legislation is all about. Senator Ray said back in 1987 that it was okay if businessmen were intimidated by the unions because they donate to the Liberal Party.

PARA.TAB: That is what all this is about. Honourable senators opposite do not care and are quite happy to go on fleecing the unions and grabbing money here, there and everywhere. But the Liberal Party will restrict any donations they can get. Then, of course, if we were smart enough we would probably go into gold and stamps as well. But we have a bit of morality that is totally lacking in the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the diamonds? Do you think they have an in on that too?

—I think they are probably in on an awful lot. It is interesting, of course, that one of the commissioners in Western Australia was speaking only two weekends ago about the urgent need for charges of official corruption to be laid in Western Australia. All we could say to that was `Hear, hear!'.

PARA.TAB: On 31 May 1990, former Democrat Senator Macklin stated that, `without information a democracy is dead'. This morning his party will vote with Labor to restrict democratic information. Self-interest has won out over democratic principle and any objective assessment of evidence presented to the Select Committee. It is a very sad day to have this rammed through in double quick time; it is sad that the Government has seen fit to make sure, because it is totally and utterly devoid of policies and options for Australia, that it will now simply gag freedom of speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 4.25 a.m.
—Give us a full half-hour.
—No, I will not go for the full half-hour. I do not intend to take a great deal of the time of the Senate tonight.

PARA.TAB: One would expect that last night was the first time that the Senate had discussed political broadcasting and that type of subject. It has been around since when I was last in here in 1987, prior to the previous election. So it is certainly not new.

I would also like to ask honourable senators: what does a slick 30-second ad on television with lots of glitzy jingles and a bit of a song and some pretty pictures do to outline in detail just precisely what a particular political party's policies are? I do not know. Usually one associates political advertising on television and radio with slick superficial glossy advertising and not much else. It is not very great on substance.

The alternative will at least enable the parties to put forward up to two minutes of constructive thought and information to the people. People are saying that we have to tell them what our policies are. Thirty seconds of slick, glitzy, jingly music does not do that.

What one generally hears from the general public during election periods is that they do not find that they learn anything from the advertising; they get sick and tired of seeing and listening to the advertising and being bombarded with it and having very little choice in being able to avoid hearing it. I have tended not to campaign with glitzy television advertising and radio advertising in rural areas because we cannot afford it and never have been able to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. This is really meant to be helpful: we do want to hear this great contribution that Senator West is making. There may be something wrong with the microphone or something, but we really cannot hear her. Can you ask her to speak up so that we can hear this wisdom.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—You do have a point, Senator Bishop. I am afraid that I cannot hear you speaking, Senator West. I believe it may be something to do with the microphone. It also may have something to do with the interjections coming from the left hand side of the chamber. Whatever the cause—and I do not think that you are speaking in a very low voice—there does seem to be something wrong with your microphone.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I will endeavour to make sure that my voice is loud enough. Normally I do not have that problem.

PARA.TAB: The normal way that I find people prefer to get their information during election periods—in the country areas, at least—is for politicians to go around and visit them, conduct street meetings, stand up in the streets and actually discuss and debate and outline their policies. People can then actually hear you and see you and they can then come up and question you in more detail about what your policies actually are. That is a much more effective and personable way to do it than this glitzy razzamatazz that people seem to think is the appropriate way to go. I do not think, as I have said before, that slick, glitzy, subliminal advertising in any way adds to people's knowledge of the policies of each party.

There has been a lot said about free speech. Under our current system the only way that people can have their `free speech' for any product that they wish to advertise on the media is to buy it. It is not free. There are also restrictions upon what one can say, which undermines the suggestion that it is free. The material is put to air by putting up money.

It has been decided in other places that money is the root of all evil. From discussions in this chamber tonight, honourable senators have heard of the problems faced where the need to provide money for political advertising has become the source of allegations of corruption. Senators have certainly heard of the problems overseas, for instance in Japan, where there have been a number of scandals and people actually admitting that they have to buy their election campaigns. Tonight Senator Kernot dealt with the situation in the United States of America. Senator Kernot and I both had a trip in 1986 to observe the mid-term elections in the USA. We went to Missouri to observe the senatorial race. However, we were unable to meet the Democrat candidate because she was on the west coast actually having to raise money. In 1986 something like $10m was spent in pandering to the need for glitzy television and radio advertisements, when in fact the money would have been better spent by the candidates getting out and meeting the people. That also would remove the taint of corruption. The stories of the PACs over there are legendary. It is important that honourable senators bear these sorts of things in mind.

In the discussion in this place tonight, senators have been saying that this legislation is going to produce a one-party state in Australia. Having observed the system in the United Kingdom, which does not have political advertising on the electronic media, and having been there for an election, I would have to say that the parties managed to get their electoral information across to the general public very well.

Let us also look at Canada, which does not have paid political advertising. In France the political parties receive free time for advertising on state radio and television. In Denmark, Austria and Israel political advertising is prohibited at election time. I could go on. Anyone would think that what we are planning tonight is the end of Western civilisation as we know it. Yet those countries I have just mentioned are not anarchist states; they are not totalitarian states; they are democracies. They are countries where democratic principles are upheld very strongly. It is an absolute furphy to say that the passing of this Bill will be the end of Western civilisation as we know it, or the end of the democratic process.

A few people have been interjecting madly in this place today. Perhaps they can tell me about the community polling issue in New South Wales and about the ICAC reports on the north coast of New South Wales. Such issues, including political advertising, centre on and relate to where money is coming from and going to. That is why disclosure of political donations is of the utmost importance.

Liberal senators have been saying that members of Parliament from their Party do not get involved in fundraising. Why then do their leaders attend $200-a-head dinners or $1,000-a-head dinners? Why did Senator Walters tell me that she had to cook two cakes for a barbecue and auction recently? If that was not for fundraising for the political party, what was it?
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —But the Liberal Party politicians do not get involved in fundraising! Maybe they are talking about fundraising for the much larger figures that you and I, Senator Aulich, would not have any comprehension of, but it seems to me that that sort of money is a pretty significant amount.
—Where is the witty repartee?

—At 25 minutes to five in the morning, the witty repartee has disappeared. However, I have to say that it is very important that this Bill be passed, because it is not going to be the end of Western civilisation as we know it. It is also—
—Why couldn't you deal with it next year?

—Or four and a half years, or make it six years—I suppose that is the attitude opposite. But it is important that details of all funding be made public because it will remove any problems with corruption, it will remove the taint or even the possibility of corruption. It is with great pleasure that I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —That scintillating contribution by Senator West has prompted me to make no response to what she has said, as there is nothing to reply to. But Senator West did say something that was vaguely accurate when she said the time was 25 to five. That has prompted me to deal with a matter of some substance. It is, as I understand it, about 13 or 14 years since the Senate has sat as late as this. I think the previous time might have been in 1978 or 1979. My point is that a special, serious and significant issue has prompted the Senate to respond in this serious way to deal with a matter that is seen as a threat to the democratic process and that is being forced through this chamber without proper and adequate time to consider the significance of the 37 amendments that the Government gave us notice of yesterday—at this hour I can say `yesterday'.

PARA.TAB: The need for proper scrutiny of the legislation before the Senate is compounded by the fact that debate on the Bill was gagged in the House of Representatives. It is now being gagged to get it through the Senate. The point of tonight's debate is to dramatise, hopefully to the media and therefore to the people of Australia, the seriousness with which the Senate views this assault on the rights of Australians.

I bring perhaps a different dimension to this debate. I am a former journalist. My profession was in the media, not only in the print media which, under this quaint Government, is curiously being allowed to continue to have political advertisements. Under the present Government, just as there is good uranium and bad uranium, there are good advertisements and bad advertisements. Under this Government's quaint policies, there is some uranium that is allowed to be mined and some other uranium that cannot be mined because it somehow offends. Here we have a situation where some advertisements are acceptable—the ones in the newspapers—but other advertisements, those on television and radio, are somehow disgraceful and must be banned. As I was saying, I was a journalist for 20-odd years in the print media—

TALK.START.PARA: —A good one.

—I accept that interjection. I thank Senator Kemp. If I had stayed as a journalist, I would no doubt be earning a lot more than I am now. I was a journalist not only in the print media but also on radio and television. So I bring a dimension to this debate that perhaps has not come into it earlier, that is to dramatise the enormous power that the legislation before the Senate will give to some overpaid, over-opinionated gurus in the media, who will have the capacity at election time significantly to influence the votes, the impressions and the attitudes of people without political parties having the capacity to counter the positions that those gurus will be able to take.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me ludicrous that this Government, or any other government, would want, by denying access by political parties to electronic advertising, to give this incredible power to a handful of journalists in current affairs programs. Yet that is exactly what is happening. Under this legislation, at future election times, there will be a capacity for these journalists—a capacity specifically allowed in the amendments we have before us now—to make their opinionated positions clear through their current affairs programs. As we have seen in the past, these positions could be based on whatever prejudices they may happen to have, without any political party having the capacity to address them on the electronic media.

I do not know whether the Hawke Government regards this as a good and cunning device. After all, it does seem to have built up close friendships among the owners of some of the electronic media. Maybe this mateship—Hawke's mates in the media—is the reason that the Government is proceeding in this way, taking the view that the media gurus are capable of being influenced indirectly by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) by way of a mate who is the proprietor.

I have already seen some evidence, at a Western Australian State election, of how a media proprietor can be approached by the Prime Minister in order to make available material for Mr Burke, the Premier of Western Australia, to use in an election advertisement. If there is the capacity for that kind of influence, it is a serious threat to the political process that that sort of power will now be centred in the hands of media owners, at least one of whom may happen to be a mate of the Prime Minister. It just seems ludicrous for this chamber to be presenting this sort of power to these sorts of people.

It is particularly concerning because of the nature of the audiences, particularly of television but also of radio. Surveys have shown that only something like 8 1/2 per cent—certainly under 10 per cent—of people under 25 years read newspapers for their information. Most do not get their views from newspapers. It is actually 8 1/2 per cent of 18- and 19-year-olds and it goes up the scale to 25, slowly increasing as people become more mature.

The significance of that is that something like 90 per cent of young Australians would be depending on the electronic media for their information. The electronic media is exactly the source of information that this Government is going to censor through this legislation, in the sense that advertising material relating to elections will no longer be permitted.

In other words, this vital and large group of Australians—the under-25s—will suffer particularly from a lack of information as a result of this Government's legislation, because this is the group that does not depend on newspapers for information. Yet the newspapers will be the only source of political information via advertising that will be allowed. This Bill is especially discriminatory against the young people of Australia in, basically, denying them access through the media with which they are most comfortable—particularly, radio and television—by denying those media the right to have political advertising. That group will then be denied access to information.

Maybe the Labor Party thinks it is a great idea that it should deny young Australians access to information, because about two-thirds of that age group vote for the Labor Party. In other words, the less one knows and the less access one has to newspapers, the more likely one is to vote Labor. That is what the figures indicate clearly. So it is in the Labor Party's vested interests not to allow information of a political nature—political advertising—to be made available to this group of young Australians who rely on radio and television for their information. If this is as well thought out as I think it must be, this legislation appears to be part of a determined and deliberate pattern to try to keep these people uninformed and therefore still voting Labor.

So we have two potential reasons for the Government proceeding with this. Firstly, it would suit the Government to have its friendly media gurus as the influences at election time, without their influence being capable of being matched by advertising. Secondly, the Government wishes to keep information from members of this vital group which tends to vote heavily its way, and who may well take a different view if they have access to information.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sheer stupidity.

—I do not believe it is sheer stupidity. I think this is far more significant and more serious than that. I believe this is a very well thought out, serious and significant assault on basic democratic principles for a disgracefully self-interested objective: to limit information to those people who may well be influenced by it.

PARA.TAB: The deal with the Democrats is the third leg of this disgraceful and dishonourable device aimed at keeping a discredited Labor Government in power. We have seen the first two legs; the third is the deal with the Democrats. We know, because Senator Kemp outlined it and Senator Kernot was incapable of denying it, that under this scheme the Democrats will get a massive increase in the amount of time on television by way of free time than they could afford in paid time at the 1990 election—in other words, 50 hours of free time during a normal election campaign, when last time they could not afford to buy 50 hours of time. So here are the Australian Democrats getting a clear, distinct and unequivocal advantage which is worth a substantial amount of money; something like $1.8m, I think, was Senator Kemp's figure.

There is a clear element of self-interest in the Democrats agreeing to do this deal with the Labor Party, but why would the Labor Party do it? The answer is simple. The Labor Party would do it because it gets something like two-thirds of the Democrats' preferences, now that the Democrats have clearly identified themselves as the left wing of the Labor Party and are, in many instances, happily prepared to direct their preferences to the Labor Party, rather than do what they did when they were genuinely the Democrats when they used to put out two-sided how-to-vote tickets—on one side, how to provide one's preference to the Labor Party; on the other side, how to provide one's preference to the Liberal Party. So there is a clear and dishonourable deal based, ultimately, on bringing an electoral benefit to the Labor Party, paid for either by the public or by the media industry.

As Senator Kernot said, there is no substance in a 30-second grab—she meant, of course, `ad', but she said `grab'—and strangely, by accident, Senator Kernot was right. There is very little substance in a 30-second grab, but under this system that is all we will get in the news.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right, and edited at that.
—Exactly, or we may even be getting 15-second grabs in the news, and that is going to be the basic way—
—Kerin can't manage even four seconds.

—I take that point. There is no doubt that under this legislation a 30-second grab or a 15-second grab in the news, apart from the guru commentators who will be given free rein, is going to be the way in which political messages are got across. That is the very thing that Senator Kernot says is insubstantial and is not what the Australian Democrats believe is the best way to present a point of view. She goes on to say that the 30-second grab—and I presume she meant to say the 30-second ad—does not provide an adequate point of view.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that at least the 30-second ad does provide what the political parties want to get across, and that can be offset by what the other political party wants to say in reply. In other words, there is a freedom of speech involved in allowing responses. It is noticeable that the 30-second grab in a news item is not capable of being responded to, under this Government's dishonourable legislation, on electronic media. There is no capacity to reply, but that suits this Government because it does not want the capacity to reply. I suppose that when those opposite are so much on the back foot because they have made such a mess of things, the one thing they must do is ensure that the people with a case to put are denied the opportunity to put it. The Australian Democrats have quite happily gone along with this.

However, the vote of the Australian Democrats on this legislation, which has been bought with this offer of a huge increase in the amount of television time which they will get for nothing but which they could not afford before, may well be purchased with counterfeit money if the courts deny the whole question of free time on television—which they may well do.

I now turn to the question of whether the Australian Democrats, who are playing such a key role in this matter, are not only doing it out of crass self-interest but also have, in this self-interest and in this disgusting deal with the Labor Party, totally sold out the party that they belong to, and certainly sold out the principles on which that party was built. Senator Knowles mentioned in passing that former Senator Macklin in May 1990—only last year—stressed the importance of advertising in the political and democratic process. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I made the comment when this issue was first debated in this place that `A democracy relies on two things: The first is the ability of people to have a free vote and express their free determined will as to who shall govern them in the next parliament, and the second, which is equally important and on which democracy stands, is information. Without information a democracy is dead'.

The Australian Democrats are voting on this legislation to destroy access to information. The Australian Democrats are doing so without a conscience because of massive self-interest and because of the deal they have chosen to do with the Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: To give honourable senators a further view of the basic principles the Australian Democrats are now abandoning, ex-Senator Mason, who I think was the Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats in the 1980s—and this is in striking contrast with the attitudes of the people who now, as I said earlier, have effectively become the left-wing rabble of the Labor Party—said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats are in favour of political advertising. We would like nothing more in this country than to see in the newspapers and the media balanced and reasonable advertisements which lay out the policies of political parties and their intentions for the future so that the electors can read them and know before they vote that their content is true.

He was making the case that there should be requirements for honesty in advertising. I must say, having looked at some advertising in recent years from this Government in particular, that there is no doubt some merit in the general proposition that there is a requirement for truth in advertising applying to politics as it applies to everything else. The question of how it is implemented is another matter altogether.

PARA.TAB: I come back to the basic point that Senator Mason made: the Democrats are in favour of political advertising. And Senator Macklin made the point that, without information, a democracy is dead. The Australian Democrats are doing their best to kill it off in this chamber. I have received a fax from a group from the Australian Capital Territory which calls itself the Social Conscience Group `Putting people before politics'. This fax was sent to all Democrat senators. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Following telephone discussions with forty-five members of the Australian Democrats, the following statement has been agreed upon.

`We view with grave concern the fact that Democrat Senators plan to join with the Labor Party in pushing through the Senate a ban on political advertising on radio and television. We see such a ban as being steeped in hypocrisy and contempt. It will serve to alienate many supporters of the Australian Democrats who have links with a wide range of interest groups and companies who, for reasons we support, would forbid freedom of speech. We see nothing in anything put forward by our Senators to change our thinking on this matter. Should our Senators support this ban we in turn will immediately resign our membership of the Australian Democrats and will target those Senators in a forthcoming election as not being men and women of conviction.'.
Released on behalf of Democrat supporters who are members of the Social Conscience Group.

TALK.START.PARA: —They need only another 55 people and they could stay in the party and roll Senator Coulter.

—That is correct. They could do that under the curious rules of the Australian Democrats. No doubt it would be to the benefit of Australia if we could get a leadership of the Australian Democrats which returned to the democratic principles espoused by former Senators Mason and Macklin.

PARA.TAB: I return to the question of the discriminatory behaviour of the Government in denying young people access in the electronic media to political information with which they have a connection. The same is true of the 20 per cent of Australian women who are in the work force as well as having to fulfil what have been described as home duties. Those women are in the work force because of the pressures imposed on families, particularly by this Government, to have two income earners simply to meet their basic financial requirements.

This 20 per cent of the voting population, women in households who also work, do not have time to watch the TV news. According to the surveys, they do not watch the TV news and certainly do not have time to read newspapers, except for the advertisements of the specials on sale in order to assist in stretching out their housekeeping money. Some of them tape soapies and watch them while they are doing things like the ironing. One of the reasons why they do not watch the news is that, quite frankly, they do not want to be further depressed by whatever the news happens to be and they get relaxation by watching soapies. They do not have time, of course, to listen to the radio. In other words, under this ad ban this group too will be denied access to any information of an electoral nature at election time, because television is the only medium that they have time to listen to or to watch when they are doing other tasks.

More and more Australians have switched back to listening to radio. Often it provides companionship to the very large proportion—40 per cent or so—of Australians who are not in families. What is interesting is that radio is the cheapest form of advertising. I know that from the time when I was the member for Macarthur. In a rural area, in particular, radio is the method of access, and it is becoming more so in the cities. To pretend that radio advertising, because of its alleged expense, will lead to corruption is one of the most ludicrous, self-seeking bits of nonsense that this Government has come up with.

It is simply false, but the Democrats are quite happy to proceed with something that is self-evidently false because of the self-interest involved in their agreeing to get paid off in free time for backing this Government. I do not know what the Democrats intend to do in the committee stage with respect to our proposed amendment to exempt radio from this, and I do not know whether senators from remote areas, like the Minister in the chamber, the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins), feel content that their vote is going to deprive the residents of places like the Northern Territory of the right to hear argument and hear a case by way of radio advertising in remote areas. The Minister may feel content with that. Maybe he has a vested interest in a lack of information. In view of his performance, I suppose it would be just as well if the constituents in the Northern Territory were deprived of the capacity for him to put out advertisements protesting his innocence or his purity, because no-one would believe them.

The fact is that radio is a method of communication which is so cheap, relative to other methods of advertising, that to pretend that it should be excluded on the basis that its cost is so horrendous that it will lead to corruption is dishonest and disgraceful. But, of course, that is what this Bill is—it is dishonest and disgraceful. There is no urgency about it and yet we are being gagged. The next election is not due until 1993, yet the legislation has been declared urgent and is being rushed through this place. That is why this protest is going on from the Opposition. It is a protest against dishonesty. It is a protest against an assault on democracy. It is a protest against an incoherent and ludicrous proposition for which there is no merit. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill aims to address a number of problems with the current situation in regard to political advertising. At the same time, it also preserves the important liberties that we have come to accept as central to our democracy.

PARA.TAB: The report released last week was of much interest to me as a person who has been involved in campaigning for many years. Over that time, I have noted the inadequacies of the present system and, along with many of my colleagues, have thought of ways by which the effectiveness of campaigns could be improved.

What the Bill seeks to do is to ensure a limited amount of free television time for candidates to be able to communicate to the electorate. It also deals with the important issue of disclosure in relation to party donations. I ask: what could possibly be wrong with this Bill? Surely the Opposition can see that this Bill will make elections a fairer contest, as people will be far more able to judge candidates on their merits.

The current political advertising that is paid for by parties is often a reflection of what politics should not be about. The advertisements are sometimes extravagant, almost always expensive and at times unrelated to the real issues. I am not denying that over the years there have been some excellent television advertisements. After all, who can forget the most effective political ad of all, `It's Time'? In fact, the Australian Labor Party has been responsible for the best television advertisements. In many respects we have more to lose than the Opposition, because we do the best marketing.

The issue at hand, however, is not based on self-interest, but on what we consider democracy to be. We do not define democracy as an open slather; rather, we define it as a fair go for all. The support that this Government is giving to the entire electoral system cannot go unnoticed. We understand that there are problems within the system that need to be addressed. The status quo will not do. One main problem is that, as costs spiral, more and more resources have to be pumped into campaigns. Smaller parties and independents are left totally out in the cold. Where is their right to get their message across? The campaigning that used to take place before television advertising was the norm included train tours and town hall meetings.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read a bit slower; you are having trouble.
—Senator Bishop, you spoke at about 11 o'clock last night. I think you should leave it at that.
—These methods may have been time-consuming but they allowed people to meet party leaders and candidates in forums that allowed for lively debate.

PARA.TAB: I am not claiming that we should revert to those older forms of campaigning alone, but I am saying that, with a more realistic type of TV ad, we can better show Australian citizens what we stand for. Currently the creations at election time are viewed more as works of art than as an important political contribution to the nation. It is worth examining the way in which politicians communicated before television provided them with large captive audiences.

The Bill in many ways offers a little of the old-fashioned methods of campaigning. By this I mean that in the future elections will focus more on the work of individual candidates than on the advertising agency which has the contract. The future of political advertising is assured through this Bill. Despite the claims of the Opposition to the contrary, the look of advertisements may change but the human touch is revived through the restrictions on the type of advertising that is allowed to be broadcast. I know many senators will join with me in my calls to see political advertising toned down for the sake of our political profession, as well as for financial and equity reasons.

Members of the Opposition point out that they see this as a question of fundamental civil and human rights. Once again the evils of state intervention are paraded around through the use of Liberal rhetoric. Before we know it, they will be pointing fingers at us and calling us socialists. Perhaps the Opposition will even revive the `reds under the beds' story before this debate is through. The people of Australia have far more to fear from the present political advertising situation than they could ever have from the implications of this Bill.

What the population must realise is that elections are no longer a chance for people to choose; rather, they are an exhibition of advertising ability and a competition based purely upon finances. People can also be exploited by advertising of the nature that has occurred in elections. Citizens want factual information of the kind that this Bill provides for. How dare the Opposition deny the Australian people what they really want to see—a decent realistic attempt to communicate policy in a fair political environment?

I often wonder whether the Opposition understands the way that we ordinary Australians think. We do not believe that the wealthy should be automatically entitled to a head start in anything.
