Opposition senators are saying that freedom of speech is restricted by government regulation aimed at making things fairer. They just do not believe in fairness.

The Opposition carries on as though this Bill is going to strip away every one of our fundamental rights and civil liberties. If this Bill, which seeks to restrict the nature and quantity of quality advertisements, is undemocratic, why have so many other liberal democracies banned or placed restrictions upon paid political advertising? I will tell the Senate why: it is the sensible thing to do.

Even the United Kingdom has restricted political advertisements, and the Opposition's parent party, the Conservative Party, has been in government there for over 10 years. Has it dismantled it? No. It has dismantled everything else worth while, just as Dr Hewson would if he were in government, but it has kept the restrictions to party political broadcasts. The UK has a very strict set of regulations, which include restrictions upon the amount of broadcasting time that a particular party can be given. News and current affairs programs are also the subject of scrutiny, and self-regulation by the networks is required to ensure that no particular party is biased. We are not aiming to go as far as that, although such restrictions certainly have merit. Rather, we simply want political broadcasts to be the subject of intense scrutiny.

In 1988 this Government attempted to change the Constitution to establish some fundamental rights that we believed should be laid down in law—enshrined in our Constitution for the benefit of future generations of Australians. The Opposition, being the great upholder of civil liberties and human rights that it is, opposed every proposal that we put up. If this Opposition really believed in rights, it would not have opposed those proposals. It is my opinion that the Opposition is trying to look after itself and its mates because it knows that money is no problem for it, particularly when some interest group or business is only too happy to assist.

The broadcasting stations should also be only too happy to assist the community by showing these advertisements for free. I would have thought that maintaining a fair society and a vibrant democracy would be a priority for Australia's broadcasters.

The political funds disclosure aspect of this Bill is very important also, as we believe that the Australian people should have access to such information. The necessity for third parties or organisations other than political parties to disclose funding is also important, as these organisations clearly play an important part in the political process. With the Australian Electoral Commission overseeing the disclosure of funding information, the public can also be assured of independence and fairness in the implementation of the legislation.

I feel that it is the responsibility of all parties in this country to support the disclosure of funding information. It saddens me that Dr Hewson's initial willingness to support disclosure has been weakened by pressure from the Liberal Party machine and administration. The Opposition has attacked what I believe is an important Bill which addresses many of the concerns of many people and groups in society. It offers the populace the opportunity to see political parties lay their cards on the table, and it calls on candidates to work harder to prove themselves worthy rather than relying so heavily upon the central campaign. It calls on the political actors to prove themselves within the political system, and to do so on equal ground. It is a positive attempt to show the people of this country what we will do to represent them.

To those who attack this Government and say that we are taking away human rights I say, `Go and see what has happened overseas'. As Senator Kernot mentioned earlier, they should look at the United States, which does not have any restrictions, and ask themselves whether they want show business politics or whether they want to fight elections fairly on the real issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not try to be brief tonight; there are a number of issues which, surprisingly, have not been covered by the many speakers in this second reading debate on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill. One of the issues of particular concern to me—one that has not been raised in debate thus far—is what this Bill does in relation to the Commonwealth using its power over broadcasting, I presume, to impose its will on the States in relation to the conduct of elections.

PARA.TAB: I know that people such as Senator Schacht, whom we have not seen in here for a few hours, have very little respect for State boundaries. I think it is fair to say that airwaves and radio waves also have very little respect for State boundaries, but the issue at stake is whether a State and sovereign State governments can be the masters of their own political systems. No matter what anyone can say about the conduct of elections in the States, about the electoral boundaries drawn by some State governments and their electoral commissioners from time to time, the point at issue is whether a government—one located, in the case of Western Australia, some 3,000 kilometres away from Perth—can be allowed to control the electoral system of a sovereign State parliament.

I put it to the Senate, as the States House, that this legislation is perhaps the greatest attack on a State parliament's rights to determine its own electoral system. It is a travesty of States rights for a Commonwealth Government and for this Parliament to be imposing restrictions on the right of any political party in a State to advertise policies and political platforms.

It is an example of this Government's total disregard for the Federation, which is nearly 100 years old. It is a total disregard of the stated objective of the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, of trying to find a new federal compact, of trying to reform Federal-State relations. It makes a mockery of Mr Hawke's stated objective of trying to reform the Federation and, indeed, of his use of the term `new federalism'.

One of the advantages of a federal system, long stated by both the founding fathers of the United States and the founding fathers of Australia, is that where there are sovereign State parliaments and a Commonwealth parliament, both with a separation of powers, there can be a degree of experimentation when it comes to public policy. If there is a unified system and a mistake in public policy is made, that mistake comes to visit every citizen throughout the entire nation.

Most honourable senators would argue—some of us from this side would argue differently from those on the Government benches—that there have been mistakes in relation to the conduct of elections in some States. But the fact is that, through electoral reform, in various States there has been progress and reform. Even though that electoral reform may lag behind in another State, the fact is that there is experimentation and there is progress with electoral reform. With this sweeping overriding of States' rights in relation to the conduct of their own elections, that experimentation cannot continue. The Commonwealth will determine for all time how the use of the electronic media is to be determined and limited within the States.

As someone who is committed to ensuring that significant powers and rights are retained by the States, this offends me. One of the amendments that the Opposition will be moving during the committee stage is for the removal of any reference in this legislation to State and Territory governments. I suggest to the Government and also to the Democrats: if we do need to take on such a radical experiment in the limitation of the use of the electronic media, if we are really forced to do that because the Democrats will not yield to the Opposition's profound and succinct arguments tonight in relation to this limitation of political freedom, let us maintain that experiment at the Commonwealth level. Let us restrict it to Federal elections. Let us not see this strange, radical experiment in limiting the use of the electronic media imposed upon the States. Indeed, I am prepared to say that, if it is a success at the Federal level, let the States copy it. But let those State governments and State parliaments decide whether or not they too want to impose an electronic media ban.

One of the aspects of this legislation is the proposal that political advertising cannot take place during the period of a State election. One of the motivations for the Government introducing this Bill at this time and trying to rush it through the Federal Parliament was pointed out yesterday and today by a number of my colleagues. Although I would admit that, bearing in mind the pace of this debate at this hour of the morning, it does not feel as if the Bill is being rushed through the Senate, it is being rushed through in terms of its consequences.

If we look at when State and Territory elections are to be held over the next three or four years, we will see that there is an incredible motivation for the ALP machine to impose a ban on electronic media advertising. Labor has a government in Victoria that is on its last legs. The government in the Australian Capital Territory is in a mess. A government in Queensland is facing an election in 1993. A government in South Australia is, again, in political turmoil and is a political basket case. In my home State of Western Australia, another political basket case is facing an election prior to May 1993. Honourable senators from Tasmania would be interested to know that they have an election due before 29 May 1993.

So in the next year and a half, Australia will have at least six State and Territory elections. If this legislation is passed, political parties in each of those States and the Territory will not be allowed to advertise during the election period. That would suit the Labor Party because in virtually all of those States the Labor incumbents are on the nose and the polls are down. Most of them have had or have corruption commissions. The Labor Party would not want to see community organisations or other political parties that oppose those governments putting forward their views during an election campaign because that would act to the detriment of those incumbent governments. Of course, that is a restriction on democratic rights.

The more important matter as far as Federal politics go is that Federal political parties will be restricted in terms of advertising during those periods. In the next 18 months, as I have already said, six State and Territory elections are due. There will be a period of at least six months out of those 18 months when Federal political parties will not be allowed to advertise. Of course, that suits this tired, old, worn-out Federal Government led by a tired, old, worn-out Prime Minister. If one takes out a couple of Christmas holidays, when political advertising is not generally conducted, one finds that the number of months in which any Federal political party can conduct a significant electronic media campaign to sell, for example, a Fightback policy will be enormously restricted.

In a federation like Australia there is always going to be an election somewhere around the country. The long term consequence of this legislation is that the right for a Federal political party to advertise will be severely curtailed. To that extent, political freedoms and freedom of speech will be curtailed, no matter how much honourable senators opposite protest.

There will also be a restriction on the rights of organisations which are not exempt. That was referred to yesterday by my colleague, Senator Olsen. There is an exemption for certain charitable organisations and community organisations. During election campaigns a number of those organisations can put onto the electronic media messages that do not explicitly or implicitly have a political message or that ask people to vote in a particular way. However, one does not need to have made much of a study of political advertising to understand that it is quite possible and quite normal for these sorts of organisations, and indeed political organisations, to put on advertisements that do not have a very explicit political message but that still get the message across.

Conservation groups or welfare groups may place on television advertisements that would not contravene this draconian Bill. But the rights of other organisations will be restricted. I refer specifically to industry organisations, professional associations and other groups, particularly groups that represent the interests of the private sector and private enterprise, which even this Government recognises need to expand and create profits to generate the sorts of jobs we need to overcome the terrible malaise that his nation faces at the moment. The legislation restricts those organisations from putting their views, whether those views are considered to be political or not. Messages from groups such as the Automobile Association and the Chamber of Mines, which might advocate the sense of allowing greater access to land for exploration or taxation changes to encourage exploration and mining, will be banned under this legislation whereas the views of organisations that may oppose the views of the private enterprise sector will be allowed. So it is quite biased against industry and against the private sector. That, too, would favour a socialist, anti-development, anti-business government such as the one we have federally and such as the ones we have in Victoria, Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia and Tasmania.

The other matter to which many Government senators refer is comparisons with other nations. Recently in the Senate—I think it was last Thursday; Senator Kemp may remind me—I referred to Senator Schacht's undeniable record of supporting human rights in other nations. Yet, his strange throwing away of those principles on the altar—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is skin deep.

—Indeed, it is skin deep. I do not reflect on Senator Schacht's deep commitment to human rights in other nations. He has deep principles in respect of political freedom and freedom of speech in the nations near to us and in nations such as South Africa. I ask him not to sacrifice those very sound, very strong and, I am sure, deeply held principles on the altar of his own political self-interest.
—Deep, deep down, he is shallow; that is his problem.

—I would not dare suggest that, Senator Kemp, because I have great respect for Senator Schacht. I know that Senator Schacht and I can work together in the interests of a number of causes. In the House of Representatives versus the Senate tennis tournament only a few weeks ago Senator Schacht and I were one of the few Senate teams to bring merit upon this chamber. So I have immense respect for Senator Schacht, but I repeat that it is important that Senator Schacht and his colleagues do not sacrifice their meaningful and sensible political principles in relation to human political rights in Third World nations on the alter of political self-interest when it comes to their political home in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Turning now to the Australian Democrats, I welcome Senator Sowada back to the chamber and look forward to her contribution in a few minutes. But the motivation for the Democrats' deal with the Government needs to be further analysed. My colleagues have already run over the issues relating to how the Democrats seem to be toing-and-froing on this issue. Of course, most of us know that the gathering of signatures in Queensland for the leadership—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are very fickle, Senator Sowada. They will hate you later.

—Senator Collins, I think you should leave Senator Sowada alone. But it is important to note that, in the report on the Bill prepared by the committee of which Senator Kemp and Senator Olsen were members, a rough break-up of expenditure on political campaigns for the last Federal election showed that the Democrats spent approximately (1)/(32) of all moneys spent. The result of the Bill, of course, is that they will be able to spend about 10 per cent of all of the free time on advertising.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp has already brought into this chamber some figures specifically relating to the impact of the Democrats' amount of free time on the electronic media. I do not intend to go over those. But totally ignoring Senator Kemp's figures, my figures show that there will be a 300 per cent increase in the comparative election exposure of the Democrats on the electronic media. I say to the Democrats that when it comes to the issue of political self-interest—and I do not mean this in a demeaning way at all—they really would have to be mad to knock back the deal. If someone offers you a 300 per cent increase for nothing, you really would have to be stupid to knock it back. Having seen the Democrats being formed under former Liberal Senator Don Chipp, and having studied Don Chipp and his motivation for forming the Australian Democrats and his—

TALK.START.PARA: —He got dumped from the Ministry. That was his major motivation.

—That is a good motivation, Senator Collins, but I think we should suggest that Senator Chipp had better motivations than that, because he did have a deep belief in liberal principles and in the values of democracy. Of course, those sorts of principles have been sold out by the Democrats. But if the price is a 300 per cent increase in free advertising time, one would have to wonder at some of Senator Sowada's colleagues who have supported the Bill. I congratulate Senator Sowada on her stand on principle during a number of the divisions today. We welcome her presence because she perhaps is the embodiment of a new style of Democrat coming into this chamber who will make up his or her own mind, who will not caucus, as many of her colleagues seem to have done since I have been here, and who will stick to some of the principles that Senator Chipp founded the party on.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sowada also should consider the effect that the legislation will have on her Democrat colleagues in some of the States in which no Democrats are sitting in the State parliaments. It will be very hard for Democrats running at the State level to get their free time. The legislation also will have an effect on independents and other minor political parties that will really have a job to convince the electoral commissioners that they are entitled to time.

It is fair to say that one of the worst aspects of the legislation before the Senate is that it entrenches the position of the major parties. It is very hard to see how the arbitrary break-up of free time to political parties has been determined, with 40 per cent for the Government, 40 per cent for the Opposition, 10 per cent for the Democrats and 10 per cent for the rest. It must be an arbitrary break-up. I do not know what it reflects. It certainly does not reflect support for the major political parties. The Democrats do not have 10 per cent of the support of the Australian people and have not had for many, many years.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the last South Australian election.

—That is a very good point, Senator Sowada, and it brings me to my next point. If the Democrats did have that support, and I am sure the Democrats have had 10 per cent of support in some elections—they certainly do not in my home State at the moment—and if time were allocated on the level of support achieved by any political party at a previous election, that would only reflect the level of support three years ago, not the political reality at the time. Say the Australian Labor Party were to totally pull itself to bits—if the glue between the factions was to be in the sun for too long, and Senator McKiernan could not communicate with his Centre Left colleagues and his Right colleagues and do this deal to keep the Party sticking together and it all fell apart as it did a few decades ago—and form into a number of other Labor parties such as the DLP, ALP and the Centre Left Labor Party, that of course would make a mockery of this Bill.

PARA.TAB: The point I am trying to make, and I am being very longwinded about it, is that an arbitrary break-up can reflect only the political reality at the time. As we see in the Morgan gallup poll in today's Bulletin, support for the Opposition is nearer 50 per cent and for the Labor Party nearer 35 per cent. So I wonder whether the Senate should not contemplate—Senator Sowada has disappeared again—an amendment to reflect that sort of break-up and to give the Opposition a figure closer to its level of electoral support now.

A more serious point I want to make is that in some of the States support for independents is growing. The entrenched support for existing parties enshrined in this Bill gives an enormous advantage to major parties and to the Democrats. I put to the Senate that, with the Democrats moving further and further to the Left in politics and deserting the centre ground that Don Chipp so carefully chipped out for them, there indeed exists a place in the Australian political spectrum for a true centre party. We see emerging in Western Australia at the moment a group called the Independent Liberals, which has been referred to by unkind journalists as a party with no members and no finance and whose members could fit into a telephone booth—

TALK.START.PARA: —And no integrity.

—Senator Crichton-Browne should withhold his emotion because I know he has little time for the Independent Liberals in Western Australia. But the point is that the Democrats have deserted the centre ground. It could happen very quickly that another group, be it the Independent Liberals or some other group of political activists, could easily create a party of the true centre, not a party like the Australian Democrats that advocates higher taxes, bigger government and more government intervention, but one that seeks a true centre ground between the policies of the coalition as proposed by Dr Hewson and the strange mixture of policies pursued by the present Government. I put it to the Senate that allocating the free time on the basis described in the Bill does not reflect the changing nature of Australian politics and the way that Australian politics could change over the next decade.

PARA.TAB: Another issue that is important to us is the matter of the lack of public outcry over this business. We have had many people coming before the Senate Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures, but it is fair to say that even after this all-night sitting there are not people marching on Parliament House waving banners and marching in the streets to protest against this incredible infringement of political rights.

I think it is also fair to say that there are some very good reasons for that. Most people that I know, when elections come on, get absolutely sick and tired of the bombardment they receive. I think it is also a matter of record that electronic advertising has increased significantly in the past eight years. That is, in my belief, to some extent a product of the sorts of relationships formed by people like the Prime Minister and his friends in the business community. That is well reported and well documented, but by people like John Pilger.

There is the relationship nurtured by Brian Burke, the former Premier of Western Australia and former Ambassador to Ireland as appointed by this Government, with members of the John Curtin Foundation. That has opened up an incredible new source of funds for the Labor Party at both the Federal and State level. And of course this increased the amount of funding available to the Labor Party and increased the amount of electronic media advertising. This Bill is a reaction to that. It is like the Labor Party saying, `Gee whiz, we had better close the gate. The horse has bolted but it does not matter as it was our horse and we are in power, so what the heck'.
To lighten up this debate a little bit, I remember trying to paint my kitchen during the last State election campaign. I remember saying to my—

TALK.START.PARA: —You should have been out on the hustings!

—I should have been, indeed. I had only just got married and I had to paint the kitchen rather than go out on the hustings. I should not really tell that to some of my State colleagues back in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: The point of the issue is I was listening to commercial radio at the time and I remember saying to my wife that it is very nice that a few songs are being played between the advertisements. At the time we had Mr Dowding telling us how it was important that he be re-elected because he had a future for Western Australia. I think the future he envisaged and the future that most Western Australians envisaged was slightly different from the future we got. But I am sure Mr Dowding was also fair dinkum when he spoke about this great future that Western Australia had that so quickly evaporated straight after the election.

The point of the matter is that that serves to illustrate the fact that there was a lot of money flowing into the Labor Party in the last few years. There was the $3m donation to the Labor Party which my very good friend Bill Hassell, the former Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia and prominent and distinguished Liberal member of the State legislature, exposed during that election campaign and which was denied by the Labor Party at the time. This is real true disclosure. This is the Labor Party that talks about disclosure. My friend Bill Hassell disclosed a $3m donation to the Labor Party, and it denied it. This is the efficacy of the Labor Party in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ask Bob McMullan. He knows all about it.

—Senator McMullan knows all about it but he was smart enough to move over here and get away from the stench of Western Australia well and truly in time. But my friend Bill Hassell, the former leader, did disclose this $3m. It was denied by the Labor Party. Of course, the outstandingly interesting leader of the National Party, Mr Hendy Cowan, asked my friend to put up or shut up and, of course, Hendy was proved wrong again.
—That rural socialist.

—Yes, that agrarian socialist, Senator Crichton-Browne, as you quite rightly point out. This brings us to the disclosure issue and people reflecting on the bona fides on disclosure laws of my leader, Dr John Hewson. The Opposition has a strong policy on disclosure. The Government knows it and to say that we do not is totally misleading.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition has said all along that we are very happy to split this Bill and to debate disclosure. We believe that with the excesses brought on by the Labor Party's mateship with big business in the past decade the disclosure legislation is more than desirable in Australia at the moment, and we stick by that.

Another probably less important point but one again for the Democrats to consider is the impact this will have on shifting political advertising to direct marketing and to newspaper advertising. I put it to the Democrats, and I put it to the very green benches of the Government, that shifting advertising towards direct marketing will increase enormously the amount of paper used. We have already seen increased numbers of laser printers and increased photocopying allowances and stationery allowances in our own parliamentary offices.

I used to work in an office in central Perth that employed 45 people, and I now have more laser printers and photocopiers in my office in Perth than we had in a thriving real estate practice in central Perth which employed 45 people. It is an indication of the gearing up this Government is doing for direct marketing.

The paper impact is going to be immense. There will be probably acres of trees chopped down to provide the paper for this onslaught on the poor unsuspecting people in the suburbs of metropolitan Australia. I think this is a very fair environmental issue because electronic media advertising does not use up paper. My friends in the direct marketing world will probably welcome this direct marketing.

I think we need to look finally at the political motivation for this. Why would people want to stop electronic media advertising? If a Labor Party campaign director saw John Hewson—a young, a dynamic, a vigorous political leader, the like of which this nation has not seen for many years—with new ideas, a new vision and a solid policy and who performs well on media against this tired, old, worn out, hunched over Prime Minister—

TALK.START.PARA: —With no vision.

—Yes, with no vision whatsoever. In such circumstances then I too would go for a political ad ban. We must also wonder at the sense of having a guillotine. This has been debated earlier but the fact of the matter is the public should be allowed to debate this long and hard. We should be allowed to debate the impact of these Government amendments which have been dropped on the Senate in the last 24 hours. Time should be allowed for this revolutionary change to be debated in public. There should be time for the State parliaments to debate this because we are taking away their State rights, and that is an important thing. We should also look at a government that has said, `Give us time to read your Fightback package before we—(Time expired).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the time as I rise to speak on this Bill is 5.48 in the morning and we have been going now for nearly 20 hours on Government legislation that we have before us today.

PARA.TAB: I rise to express my opposition to the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill. It is a fundamental and deeply felt opposition to the attack on free speech and the right of people, candidates and groups to express ideas and views during an election.

On 27 September of this year I appeared before the Senate Select Committee established to investigate this Bill and put the position that I did not support a ban on paid party political advertising. Rather, I put forward the view that as a principle of ensuring minimum access to the electorate during an election, paid advertising should be supplemented by free time across commercial radio and television networks by parties and candidates.

This view is, I believe, supported by our party's electoral reform policy which was balloted and declared in October 1990. I have not resiled from this view and stand here as a lone voice on this part of the cross-benches. In so doing I claim my right to vote according to my conscience, a right afforded every Democrat parliamentarian under our Party's national constitution. I place on the record my opposition to this Bill and my right to say so.

That the Government has persisted with this legislation in the face of widespread opposition by community groups and other wiser heads than ours must surely underscore the need on the part of those sitting on the Government benches to deal with their inability, their own indebtedness, their own inability to manage campaign budgets and their own desperate attempts to cling onto power. It is a sorry day when a government finds that the only way it can stay in office is to prevent others, by law, from expressing an opinion. And that is exactly what this legislation seeks to do.

This Bill is based on the premise that controlling electronic advertising, currently a major component of total election expenses, will lead to a reduction in the need for parties to obtain donations and hence a lessening of political corruption. What a joke this is. The connection between the costs of advertising and corruption is a figment of the Government's imagination. It is already evident to serious political commentators that funds will simply be channelled into other forms of campaigning such as direct mail, billboards, newspapers, telemarketing and the like.

Let me turn briefly to the issue of direct mail. In the United States, direct mail is already regarded by many congressional candidates as a more effective and highly targeted method of delivering a campaign message—indeed, more cost-effective than blanket TV advertising. Both parties, Liberal and Labor, are investing considerable sums of money in direct mail and direct mail technologies, as I have already demonstrated through my evidence to the Select Committee.

Indeed, we discovered that, owing to an oversight in the New South Wales State Electoral Office, suppressed personal details of all voters in New South Wales were handed out to the Liberal and Labor Parties on a computer tape. Although these tapes are apparently on their way back to the State Electoral Office, it must surely be impossible to assess or patrol how far this information has now been spread around the State. A company was in the business of selling this database information to Liberal Party members of parliament in New South Wales. Given that the Labor Party is about three years ahead of the coalition in terms of direct mail technologies, it is no wonder that the Government sees some advantage in ensuring that it will have more funds to spend in this area.

All parliamentarians will be spending more money on direct mail. Anyone who thinks that direct mail will lead to a more informed debate, a more educated electorate, less manipulation of the truth, fewer lies and fewer dirty tricks has not understood the American experience where the slogan is, `You can never send enough mail'. Direct mail works. Those who claim that it does not, probably also believe that tobacco advertising only causes teenagers to change brands.

To gain further appreciation of how overall expenditure will be allocated if this ban becomes law, one need only look to New South Wales—once again—and the very expensive newspaper campaign being waged currently by the tobacco companies over plans to limit tobacco advertising. Day after day we have been subjected to full page advertisements and political propaganda designed to influence opinion. One could be forgiven for thinking that there was an election in the air, although I do not think the Greiner Government has quite made up its mind on this point.

Yet, despite this graphic evidence, we see no sign in this Bill of any moves to regulate advertising in newspapers or magazines. It will be open slather for political parties and lobby groups to advertise in the print media without restriction. There is nothing free about that; it will cost considerable sums of money, for which donations will still be needed.

Let us have a look at this ban. The Government is proposing a complete ban on all political advertising during elections, to apply to all parties, candidates and third parties—that is, lobby groups—who wish to express an opinion in the electronic media. In its place, we have free time on television, rationed out to registered political parties and candidates according to a predetermined formula which doles out 40 per cent of the time each to the coalition and the Labor Party, 10 per cent to the Democrats and 10 per cent to everyone else. The Government has decided that there is to be no free time on radio, thereby excluding this medium altogether from political comment, except that which is filtered through the biased judgments of journalists and news editors.

This regime proposed by the Government simply reinforces the status quo. Free speech is severely limited. People who may wish to criticise the Government will have their wings clipped. Independent candidates and new parties will have a very limited opportunity to communicate with the electorate. Candidates in large rural electorates will find it particularly difficult to campaign over a wide geographical area without the aid of the electronic media. Community groups, be they the mining industry, conservation groups, social justice organisations or anyone else, will be frozen out of the process by this legislation.

What is more, every party in this place will be at the mercy of journalists, announcers, television presenters, subeditors, editorial writers and news editors, who will make decisions about what they believe is important news, slanted by their personal opinion or that of their proprietor. What chance will candidates have to respond quickly and effectively to attacks with a message unadulterated by the red pen of a news editor? None. We have all had complaints in the past about the coverage of our Party and candidates at election time, but at least some redress has been available through paid advertising. That will now go out the window.

What about the States? This ban now covers all future State and Territory elections. I asked the Minister: are the States happy with this state of affairs? I am sure the Labor Party in New South Wales is leaping with joy at the prospect of saving millions of dollars at the next State election, which may be earlier rather than later. But what right do we have, sitting here in Canberra, to regulate the affairs of elections in other States, which are governed by their own electoral Acts in every other respect? None whatsoever. It is a stolen mandate, born of desperation.

Some people have suggested that speech is not free if it has to be paid for. There is no question that the current regime benefits those who have more money to spend on advertising. I believe that is part of the cut and thrust of politics. I would also maintain that there are many aspects of our society which are not free. Better health care and education services can be bought at a price. It is no longer possible to get adequate legal representation unless a person is wealthy, because legal aid has been restricted so fiercely. Indeed, this Labor Government has been at the forefront of winding back services and implementing the user pays philosophy over a wide range of programs and activities which it had previously supplied to voters as a public service.

If the Democrats are supporting this Bill because they believe that somehow we will benefit, or that the political process and debate will somehow magically improve, I would suggest to my colleagues that we have been sold a very lame steer. The New South Wales Leader of the Australian Democrats, the Hon. Elisabeth Kirkby, MLC, said recently of this Bill: ` . . . the Federal Government is involved in a very cynical and devious exercise'. There has been a fundamental failure to recognise that in this legislation.

So now we find ourselves banning political advertising in an effort to curb the burgeoning debts of the Labor Party. It knows that it will not be able to compete with the coalition at the next election. Seven million dollars of debt in New South Wales alone, we are told, and I ask what party, already on the skids, can afford to mount an electronic advertising campaign when saddled with that sort of debt.

I suggest to the Opposition and to the Government that, if they want to limit campaign costs, they should look unto their own houses and have the courage to spend less. They should have the courage to reject the overtures of snake oil dealers who would donate money in return for favours on legislation. And they should have the courage to show some moral fortitude by rejecting the temptation to corrupt conduct, as the potential for it will not be lessened by the implications of this Bill.

One has to ask the Government what it is afraid of that such draconian measures have to be taken to prevent public criticism, restrict free speech and stop people from having a say. When the Human Rights Commissioner, Mr Brian Burdekin, came out and publicly repudiated the notion of the ban on advertising as a means of controlling spiralling campaign costs, one has to wonder what is going on.
The list goes on. I quote the International Commission of Jurists, in the document The Rule of Law and Human Rights—Principles and Definitions, published in 1966, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Freedom of expression through the press and other media of communication is an essential element of free elections and is also necessary to ensure the development of an informed and responsible electorate.

I further quote from the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which is in schedule 2 of the Government's Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986. Article 19.2 provides:

Everyone shall have the right to freedom of expression; this right includes freedom to seek, receive and impart information and ideas of all kinds, regardless of frontiers, either orally, in writing or in print, in the form of art, or through any other media of his choice.

I ask the Government: where is its support for international treaties and covenants, signed on behalf of the Australian people and on behalf of this Parliament—covenants, the terms of which are enshrined in our own legislation? I ask the Minister: will this Bill end up in the High Court, to be challenged under the external affairs power enshrined in section 51, clause 39, of the Australian Constitution? A successful challenge would only prove what a sham this legislation really is.

PARA.TAB: As I have already stated, I reject the nexus between the cost of political advertising, corruption and disclosure. Political corruption will not be minimised by banning advertising, but by the implementation of a full, fair, open and transparent disclosure regime—a principle which is fully supported by the Australian Democrats. I have already indicated that it is my belief that this money saved on political advertising will simply be channelled into other forms of campaigning. This is already happening.

I have campaigned long and hard in my own State for strengthened donation disclosure laws. The disclosure side of this legislation goes a long way to addressing concerns expressed by the Australian Electoral Commission and corruption fighters in Australia in respect of parties and lobby groups. The Government is to be commended for having the courage to clean up many of the loopholes that have been identified.
As the Independent Commissioner Against Corruption, Commissioner Roden, noted in his report in North Coast Development:

SPEECH.PARA: The distinction between (donations for administrative, rather than electoral purposes) is illusory.
He further said:
Substantial donations to political parties are as likely to influence, whatever label they be given, and whatever purpose they may have.
This Bill does address some of those issues—but at what price, when the nexus drawn between the cost of electronic advertising and disclosure is totally spurious in the first place?

PARA.TAB: And still there are some holes left in the Bill. For example, there is no guarantee that substantial funding given to independent candidates for election expenses shortly after an election will ever be disclosed, because the disclosure period for them expires the minute the polls close. This means that the Labor and Liberal parties will probably find some mechanism to channel money into the hands of so-called `dummy independents'—who are simply sycophants for their masters—by siphoning money off to those candidates after the election.

Independent members of parliament would escape the annual reporting procedures in a non-election year. What is more, if I read the latest batch of amendments correctly—and they seem to be changing all the time—the public may have to wait months after an election, until the annual reports are released, to find out who funded campaigns, because the 20-week reporting provisions, post-election, will be deleted from the Commonwealth Electoral Act.

Finally, we are still protecting the identity of donors who give less than the prescribed amount. I ask: if a donor chooses to give $999 to a candidate or group, where is the open, transparent nature of disclosure laws which protects donors below a certain limit? If a disclosure regime is to have integrity, any moral force and a shred of credibility, we must have it all on the table where the public can see dollars and see who is attempting to buy political influence in this country.

I have to question the commitment of both sides of this House to full disclosure. How many State governments have followed suit with meaningful disclosure laws? Despite the scandals, despite the public outcry, despite the brown paper bags and despite the fact that 74 per cent of people polled in a recent Saulwick poll said that party political donors should be named, we still have State governments dragging their feet, caught up in committees and trying to wriggle out of meaningful disclosure.

State Premiers all over the country have been put on notice by public demands for action, the advice of their own corruption inquiries and the evidence of scandals in their own backyard. I guess we will not see the loopholes in the disclosure laws until after the next election, when someone has yet again found a way of getting around the law and thumbing his nose at the Electoral Commission, which will stand by helpless and unable to act as it has done so far.

I return to my initial point in respect of disclosure. Is full disclosure worth the price of gagging free speech and debate? People around the world have fought and died for this very right—the right to express an opinion—and yet here, with this legislation, we are throwing it away fundamentally and utterly.

Given the fallacious link between the ban on advertising and disclosure, a link which has been repudiated by most respectable commentators, the Human Rights Commissioner and numerous witnesses before the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures, I call on the Government to do the decent thing and separate the Bill, so that we can debate disclosure and advertising on their merits as separate issues, as they should be debated. This I would be happy to support. A reduction in political corruption is inexorably linked to meaningful and transparent political donation disclosure laws—laws which expose the shady deals, the bought influence and politicians who are simply sycophants for their business mates.

I will support any meaningful and honest attempt to deal with this issue; but tonight the Government has presented us with a cynical and devious exercise to save its own skin by giving away a principle very precious to the political process—principles it has defended in the United Nations and in the international community. I cannot support this Bill, and I urge the Senate to reject it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the risk of giving Senator Sowada a political infection, I congratulate her on a well-informed, well reasoned, logical and persuasive speech, which, by its content alone—not to mention the delivery—was persuasive. In many respects it set out those matters which are attractive to me.

PARA.TAB: One might well ask: why are we sitting here this morning at eight minutes past 6 o'clock? Why can this Government not conduct the business of this chamber in a normal, civilised way? Why do we have to sit all night for legislation which will not prevail in terms of its application until May 1993? I ask Senator Richardson: why is this legislation deemed urgent? What causes us to have this legislation jammed through under a guillotine? Absolutely nothing—except the fact that this Government knows that under proper scrutiny, proper surveillance, proper examination and proper public debate, it would be repulsive to the community at large and, of course, it would ultimately be rejected, as was the identification card.

Once the public got a handle on this legislation, it would be rejected. But under the frivolity of the festive season, the Government wants to slip it through the Parliament as a last desperate attempt to—

TALK.START.PARA: —Frivolity?

—Some of us have a Christian inclination towards Christmas; for others, it is a time of frivolity, gaiety, levity and holiday. However it might strike Senator Richardson, I cannot judge. But the truth of the matter is—
—He does not buy presents. What a scrooge. That is terrible.

—I do buy presents. But, unlike some of Senator Richardson's mates, I do not get too many—and they certainly do not come in shiny briefcases. There is no good reason—and I must register my protest on behalf of my colleagues—to debate this legislation now, except, as I say, because this Government wants to slip it through before the heat goes on in the environment of an election.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself told us on the Sunday program that there would not be an election until towards the middle of 1993. Yet we have legislation which is deemed urgent, for absolutely no good reason other than crude, political expediency. One might well ask why we have this legislation at all. We all know it is a desperate lunge by a failed, corrupt, decaying government seeking, illegitimately, to hang on to government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is very nasty.

—Sometimes the truth is a bit unsavoury; sometimes the truth is a bit difficult to accept; sometimes the reality we are confronted with is not pleasant. But I can only give it as it is, in its pristine, honest form. This Government is attempting to gain a renewed mandate by seeking to have its past record extinguished

SPEECH.PARA: from human sight. This legislation is about divorcing politics from reality and campaigning on perceptions. It is an attempt to have people make judgments on memory, not on fact. This legislation is designed to prevent the Liberal Party, the National Party, the Democrats or the wider public community from scrutinising this Government and from making public utterances, public judgments and public statements about the Government's record and its performance. The legislation is designed to prevent public comment and to stifle public criticism and public commentators.

PARA.TAB: I have to say, as I reflect on my feet, that it is probably the most obscene and obnoxious legislation that this Government has ever introduced and, in my view, is likely to introduce. It is not legislation which is about honesty; it is not legislation which is about integrity; it is not legislation about a high sense of morality or service—it is legislation which is designed as a last desperate lunge to keep this Government in office.

And it begs the question: why is it before the chamber at 12 minutes past six in the morning on 4 December 1991 and it was not introduced in 1983, 1984 or 1985? Why has it taken this Government eight years to decide that it needs legitimate disclosure? Why is it that it needs eight years to decide that it does not want political advertising? Why has it taken it eight years to decide that it wants to extinguish public criticism, public scrutiny, public observation and public examination of its record, its performance and its failed achievements?

Previously the Labour Party had done very nicely. Could we imagine it closing down the radio stations and television stations when Brian Burke was shovelling money into it by the hundreds of thousands, when it was coming over in bucket loads, and when so much was coming over that it could not keep up with it? If I am not wrong, Mr Hogg has been charged with not disclosing some millions, and I make no criticism of that—he just could not keep up with the paperwork. But now, when the Party is absolutely barren, absolutely bankrupt and absolutely bereft of supporters, financial contributions or any assistance of any kind, suddenly the deal is off. The truth of the matter is that it is not going to lose by public disclosure because it will have nothing to disclose, for it will have no supporters.

In 1983 and 1984 and 1985, when money was being funnelled over here in great bucket loads, the Labor Party could not get it fast enough, could not spend it fast enough, could not book it fast enough and could not advertise fast enough. In the last election, in which Senator Richardson played no small part, there were those absurd advertisements about Kakadu— they must have cost hundreds of thousands of dollars—and the Government knew that it needed the advertising to survive. The irony now is that to survive it has got to guarantee that there is no advertising.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is on Saturday, Senator Richardson?
—The conference of the New South Wales branch of the Labor Party and the twenty-first anniversary of my election as an organiser.
—Is that right? And he is going to celebrate it with a public statement that the Party is $7.3m in debt! You collected it, you spent it and you left. Well, we have all been there, have we not?
—I certainly have not been where you have, I can tell you.

—No, that is just an idle wish, Senator Richardson. However this Government argues its position, this legislation has nothing to do with good government; it has everything to do with survival tactics. As I said before in a non-rhetorical way, why is the legislation before us now? Why was it not before us in 1983? It is before us now for a couple of good reasons. The first is that this Government is absolutely on the nose; it is despised; it is loathed. The feeling, the chemistry, in the public is such that it is absolutely loathed. I cannot remember a government being more loathed than this Government. Of course, as a result of that, it wants disclosure. It wants disclosure because it has got nothing to disclose, nothing to hide, nothing to lose. Senator Richardson, who is as good as any at organising these things—we have both been on the organisational side of things—knows that the level of funding is commensurate with the level of popularity. If you are down the tubes you are in the red; if you are riding high you are in the blue—and the Labor Party is deep, deep in the red.
—But you can drive chariots through the disclosure rules.

—You can, but the question I am asking is: what is the moral persuasion in having it before us now? The Labor Party has got nothing to lose, but it hopes that in some obscene way it can intimidate and terrorise our contributors, so that little business people, little corner stores, will not send in their money for fear that they will be identified and targeted and vilified.
—Rocks through the windows.

—Rocks through the windows. The other thing, of course, is that the Labor Party has no natural base of support. There is a sense of irony about all this. The reason the Labor Party is bankrupt and has got no money is that it bankrupted its own supporters. Its own high levels of interest rates sent most of its mates bankrupt. Previously they supported it, but now they cannot afford to fund it. On the question of disclosure, I think it was Senator Sowada who said—
—An excellent speech.
—In a well-crafted, well thought through, articulate, persuasive speech—
—And honest.

—And honest. And not without some courage, I might say. Having joined Senator Hill on more than one occasion in our frivolous young days in crossing the floor, I know what it is like to take on the brutes of one's party.
—I tell you what, it has been a long time since you have done it.

—Malcolm has not been here for a while, has he? It might be cleansing and I might have to try it again some time, just to see that the body still functions. Senator Sowada had the courage to stand up in the face of those in her party and claim that what they were doing was improper. I am not certain that she reflected on their motives—I did not hear that—but she certainly impugned their logic. What she was saying in her own way was: we cannot legislate for honesty. Can we imagine Bill Smith filling in a form saying: `$300,000 disclosure, bribe'? Can honourable senators imagine somebody on the take filling in a form and saying, `I have taken a half a million dollar bribe but, because of the $2,000 fine if I do not disclose it, I am going to disclose it'? Of course not, and that shows the absurdity of the matter.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sowada said that in some way the money will be squeezed into the political process and then squeezed out again in direct marketing or in some other shape or form of political benefit to the political party. As I say, the truth of the matter is that the Democrats are pumped up and cranked up by the Government over big business funding of the Liberal Party. But the truth is to be found elsewhere. Most of big business funding in recent times has gone to the Labor Party because, foolishly, that is where it was perceived that the best advantage was.

In my view, there is nothing wrong, there is nothing improper, with people giving a contribution to the political party that they believe will govern in a way that creates the environment that will best help their business. There is nothing improper or sinister about that. But the truth is that a good government that is doing a good job will get good support. And it ought not to be judged as a sin that any political party is funded to the advantage of any other.

I am pleased to see that Senator Schacht is in the chamber. One thing I love about people such as Senator Schacht is that they have a deep, intrinsic feeling for civil liberties, for the rights of individuals, for the rights of others, for the rights of minority groups. But those rights are extinguished the moment they trespass on or threaten the rights of the Labor Party or the likes of Senator Schacht.Provided they are neutral, provided they are harmless, provided they are frivolous, provided they are not imposing a contrary view, they will go for them. But the moment those civil liberties, those individual rights or the exercise of those rights are likely to cast a shadow upon the Government or members of it, we suddenly see that those rights are extinguished. It seems to be the nature of the political beast opposite us that that is the reality of the matter.
Madam Acting Deputy President, can I say that—

TALK.START.PARA: —You can say anything you like, basically.

—I thank the Minister. I was seeking Senator Richardson's endorsement before I did. There is nothing more obscene, there is nothing more offensive and there is nothing more corrupting in a democracy than to deny public disclosure or public scrutiny of a government. A democracy exists only when the public is able to make judgments and criticisms and raise its voice either in endorsement of or in opposition to government. What this Government wants to do is to insulate itself from criticism. It wants to insulate itself from probing. It wants to insulate itself from examination and from scrutiny. Once we have that, we begin to have political corruption.

PARA.TAB: This evening, over dinner, I had a very cordial conversation with one of Senator Richardson's colleagues about the number of royal commissions taking place in Australia. I said to that person that, in my view, they do not reflect well on Australia, they do not reflect well on the law and they do not reflect well on the body politic. But the reason we have royal commissions is that we have not had proper scrutiny, we have not had proper disclosure, we have not had proper examination, and we have not had proper accountability. The reason why in Western Australia a former High Court judge, a sitting member of the Supreme Court and a retired member of the Supreme Court are sitting as a royal commission, which is going to take 18 months and which requires individual sittings by those commissioners because the references are so extensive, is that there has not been proper scrutiny of the Government.

I make no judgments about corruption or otherwise. I do not approve of royal commissions to start with. But we have them because there has not been a proper ventilation of the processes of government. The actions, the conduct and the operation of government have been disguised and hidden. When we hear Premiers talking about warehousing their operations, we know that there is something fundamentally and intrinsically wrong with the understanding by government of levels of accountability. The truth is that governments ought to invite accountability.

I find it curious that the moment the bastion of support of this Government, which embraced freedom of information, public disclosure and public debate in respect of so many things, is threatened, it has to introduce legislation as a brick in the wall of the foundation for its survival. The moment it is threatened, the moment it is at risk, all those things it purports to hold dear to its heart are absolutely trammelled underfoot. The moment that accountability and responsibility look like leading to the Government's defeat, failure or removal, it changes the goalposts, it changes the rules, it suspends that part of its platform and policy—in fact, the heart of its philosophy. The moment the Government feels that it is going to be responsible and accountable for the liberties it has given, it has to change the rules. That is what the Government is trying to do. I find it breathtaking. I find it audacious that this Government—

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't find anything audacious in politics, Senator Crichton-Browne.
—I do. Madam Acting Deputy President, I am still fundamentally naive. I am still capable of having my breath taken away by the conduct of this Government.
—The problem is that you stacked—

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I find it offensive for it to be put that I stack branches. If I have support, it is natural, endearing and inevitable. It has nothing to do with the crude crunching of numbers, which is the daily pastime of the Labor Party—that obscene practice of collecting people together for the sheer purpose of ramming through one's point of view.

PARA.TAB: Having just been brought up to date with the amendments, I find it breathtaking that this Government wants to do away with public comment, that it wants to do away with advertising. To the extent that we are to have advertising—and I stand to be corrected on this—we are doing away with advertising on radio but we are to have it on television for six minutes a day. I do not know the logic of this. There must be some compelling logic, and no doubt the Minister in reply will explain it to me.

Not only are we to have the box with the talking head but the Government will actually decide how much we can have, as if there is something fundamentally wrong with having more or less. There is to be an arbitrary amount. The Government will tell us how much advertising is good for us. It will tell us how much politics is good for us and the type of advertising that is good for us. It will say, `We are going to tell you. And what is more, we are going to tell you what can be said and what cannot be said'.

If that is not bad enough, for their sins, the television stations get to pay to put the thing to air. I find the very concept of public funding obnoxious. I find it breathtaking that the taxpayers will actually have to pay to have this lot on the other side of the chamber advertise how bad they are. If they were a public company, would honourable senators buy a share in it? It would be in liquidation. But I find it absolutely obscene that taxpayers should have to give this lot money to advertise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you just return your share of the money to the Liberal Party?

—There is one thing I have sought in my political life, and that is an even playing field: both sides to have an equal chance. But Senator Schacht wants all the goalposts down at his end of the field. Those opposite do not want an even playing field; they do not want competition.

PARA.TAB: The problem with the Labor Party—and I know what it is like; we have been there—is that it thinks it has a divine right to govern. The Labor Party has been in government for eight years. Honourable senators opposite have become so comfortable with their backsides in those seats over there that they think they actually belong there. They do not understand that they are just an aberration; they are a fleeting past in the history of Australian politics.

Some hardheads have now come to the conclusion that perhaps they are not as safe as they thought they were. Some, now realising that Bob Hawke's love affair with the public has actually gone stale and is starting to turn nasty, are trying to work out what other tactics they can use to guarantee they survive. We are seeing the grotty, grubby attempts of those opposite to keep themselves in office at any price.

I do not want to take more time than is necessary, so I conclude by saying—and I return to where I started—that I find that having to have this debate at 29 minutes to 7 o'clock on 4 December absolutely obscene, obnoxious and absolute futile.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is because you are always last on the list of speakers.
—I am not last on the speakers list.
—He is not last. You have been asleep; you wouldn't know what was happening.
—I have not been asleep.
—I went to the Whip's office and looked at the board. I tried to figure out how I could speak when Senator Ray would be here; I would not want him to miss a bit!

PARA.TAB: The truth is that it is bad enough that those opposite want to gag the public from knowing what they are doing; I find it a double sin that they want to gag us from telling the public what those opposite are trying to do to it. There is not even a blush these days. Those magic moments of conscience are something of the past for the Labor Party. Its members stoically sit there, battling on, knowing that they are prepared to pay any price to survive. With the greatest of respect I say to them: your conduct will come back to visit you.

When the public, the various bodies in the community—organisations and associations—and political commentators come to realise that they are no longer able, in an open and free society, to express freely and publicly their views about the Labor Party's mandate, its performance, its history and its future direction; when they discover that they are no longer able to say that which needs to be said, they will turn on the Government in a more vicious way than the public has thus far.

I have no doubt that the Labor Party will, in due course, be ignominiously dumped from office. This vain, crude, corrupt attempt to hang on to office will be seen as just another part of its broken record down the ages.
There were some sad moments for the Liberal Party; perhaps one of the saddest for me was retrospective legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Floreat preselection, I would think.
—The Floreat preselection was not my saddest moment.
—Sorry, the by-election, I apologise.
—That was just a blip on the political landscape in Western Australia. Next time the Labor Party will have to run a candidate and the seat will return to the Liberal Party.

PARA.TAB: The tragedy is that this legislation should never have come before us. But the saddest thing for me, as I look back at what the Liberal Party has done over the years, is retrospective legislation; that was the great sin of the Liberal Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —We crossed the floor on that one.
—Senator Robert Hill and I crossed the floor—in the teeth of violent opposition from a very unhappy—
—Whose money were you trying to protect?

—Does it not come seeping out of his pores? There is something foul about Senator Schacht that he just cannot help. He should jump into a bucket of phenol! I comment on a failing of the Liberal Party and Senator Schacht says, `Whose money were you trying to protect?'. Put it on the record. Let us all see it in the Hansard. Senator Schacht is a very unsavoury type. The truth is that that was the blot on the landscape of the Liberal Party.
—That is a terrible attack on your colleague sitting behind you.
—Some of us were enlightened slightly ahead of others; that is all.
—You are a vanguardist; is that it?

—No, I am not. Most of the time I am slower than most. It just happened to be an occasion when I picked up the ball at the right moment. The truth is that that paled into insignificance compared with this. We were only retrospectively changing the law and taking people's tax money out of their pockets; this Government is stifling discussion about those sorts of issues. If this legislation gets through, those things will not be on the political agenda; there will not be criticism of the Government.
—You will not be allowed to do it.
—You will not be allowed to.
—Is this your speech on war crimes or on this Bill?
—I say with conviction and sadness that this is a poor old day for democracy and politics in Australia. (Time expired)

—What we have heard from the Opposition throughout this very long night has, in most instances, been totally irrelevant and not to the point. Claims have been made that things will be done which will not be done and that things will be prevented from being done which will not be prevented from being done.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators have made a considerable attack on the Australian Democrats, an attack which of course is totally irrelevant to the issue before us. It has a lot—in fact, mostly—to do with their presumption that they will win the next election. They are concerned about the position we will take post-1993. That has been the reason for their attack on us throughout this long night.

Having spoken to many members of the Opposition, we know that many of them were drafted into speaking in this debate; they did so unwillingly. The claim that they are making about insufficient time simply rings hollow in the light of that protestation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Those remarks in relation to Opposition senators being drafted into this debate are a reflection on Opposition senators. They should be withdrawn.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Furthermore, Senator Coulter is misleading the Senate in that he is indicating that he has listened to the debate tonight. Clearly, as indicated by the fluff on the right side of his head, he has been sleeping.
—There is no point of order.
—He should at least have had the courtesy to comb his hair before coming into this chamber.
—There is no point of order.

—I am interested that the honourable senator can play Sherlock Holmes and interpret that I have been sleeping by looking on which side the fluff on my head is. In fact, I have been watching the television monitor in my office.

PARA.TAB: I was making the point that there has been more than enough time in this debate and that the claim that the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill has been inadequately dealt with as a consequence of limitation of time is totally without foundation.

There has been, as many speakers have said tonight, a long period extending over some years leading up to this. We have had the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures look at this matter. A number of witnesses have come before that Committee. There have been more than enough opportunities for people in the community to bring their concerns to the Committee and for them to be expressed through the Hansard record of the evidence given to that Committee.

I deal, first, with the matter of the survey which we conducted among Australian Democrat members. While it is certainly true that surveys show that Democrat members are, on the whole, better educated and more intelligent than those who vote for other parties, I think the result of that survey probably does not differ too much from where the public is coming from.

Our survey showed that 92 per cent of our members were dissatisfied with the existing processes of advertising political material. Ninety-two per cent were dissatisfied with the deception, the disingenuousness, the deceit and the superficiality, which were well exemplified and dealt with in Senator Kernot's speech. Only 4 per cent were happy with the status quo, and the other 4 per cent were undecided.

When we asked our members to comment on proposals that are likely to come forward, 75 per cent of them either strongly agreed, or agreed, with a proposal very similar to the one before the Senate now, that is, a ban on advertising during the election period, talking heads and free time. Moreover, specifically dealing with Senator Sowada's claim, an overwhelming majority—nearly 90 per cent of our members—opposed free time plus paid advertising. So what I am saying reflects the results of a democratically conducted survey of our members whose view I believe is not all that dissimilar from the view of those in the general community who would support the other parties.

The issue of the cost of political advertising has been raised. A number of speakers have made the point that the limitation on spending of money by political parties on television advertising will result in a flow of that available resource into other forms of political advertising, particularly postage to electors. I find that passing strange in view of the amount of money which Mr Blunt spent on postage in the last election. The claim by the Opposition, with that very recent experience in mind, simply does not hold up. I find it quite deceptive.

I want now to take a slightly different view. Television is undoubtedly the most powerful and persuasive medium which has ever been introduced into any society. It has the ability to persuade, to deceive and to convince people, not by argument but by all the subtle techniques developed by highly trained psychologists, whom Senator Kernot spoke about so well in her speech.

The television medium has been allowed to be used to determine the government which this country shall have. I simply pose the question: should the allocation of time on that powerful medium be determined by the amount of money available to particular parties and by the very powerful and very influential supporters of those parties, or should it be determined in a democratic manner? I would argue that it is a fundamental plank of a true democracy that it should be determined in a democratic manner. That is precisely what this Bill does. It allocates time in relation to community support for political parties, not in accordance with the amount of money which a party can raise and spend.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are taking $1.8m worth of advertising.
—I think Senator Kernot has totally exploded that claim.
—Even Senator Kernot doesn't agree with you. Her figures agree with mine. You were asleep, Senator Coulter.

—Her figures did not agree with those of Senator Kemp. When we take into account the fact that these advertisements will be talking heads, they will be much cheaper than the sorts of things the honourable senator is talking about.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition, as we know from its Fightback package, is basing all its policies on greed. It believes that everything should be left to the market, everything should be driven by the market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Quite clearly, Senator Coulter is reflecting upon members of the Senate by imputing to them one of the seven deadly sins. We do not appreciate it. We would like him to withdraw.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I am saying that the Opposition's Fightback policy is based on greed. It is basically market driven. I must praise the Opposition for the fact that its attitude in respect of this legislation is totally consistent. The Opposition parties know they will be able to attract the donations. They know they will be able to buy the time. They know that they will be able to put on the expensive and persuasive advertisements.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I have been sitting here all night and nobody has brought up the Fightback package. Although the debate has ranged far and wide, there has been no mention at all of the Fightback package.
—Senator Walters, what is your point of order?

—It is one of relevance, Madam Acting Deputy President. I would be most surprised if you do not acknowledge that the Opposition's Fightback package has nothing to do with the broadcasting advertisement bans. During the night we have not had cause to ask that senators be relevant because they did not go that far.
—Senator Walters, it has been a wide-ranging debate. I am not forced to acknowledge one way or the other. There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I was praising Opposition senators for their consistency. Their policy in relation to this Bill is based on a belief in the market system and so is their Fightback package. That is all I am saying. In both instances the market system is based on greed. It is based on the belief that people should compete simply for material gain; that all our relationships as human beings should be determined by how much we can beat each other over the head with bits of four-by-two.

PARA.TAB: A very good example, which I find absolutely disgusting, relating to Senator Crichton-Browne's State of Western Australia well exemplifies what the Opposition is defending. Some years ago there was an attempt by the then Western Australian Government to introduce Aboriginal land rights. The Australian Mining Industry Council waded into Western Australia with a massive advertising campaign, worth millions of dollars, to defeat a program that every decent, right-thinking person concerned about Aboriginal land rights believed should be introduced. That program was defeated with a deceptive, dishonest, misleading and, in every respect, totally despicable advertising campaign. I want to stress that, fundamentally, this is what the Opposition is defending; that is what the Democrats, with the exception of Senator Sowada, find so objectionable; and that is why we are standing where we are on this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wanted $1.8m worth of free ads.

—Coming specifically to that matter, as I have said privately, it is not really a matter of the amount of money. Looking at the amount of time allocated and the formula used to divide up that time, we calculate that it is remarkably similar to, and possibly slightly less than, that we have had on previous occasions. It is nothing to do with the money. That is the wrong way to do the calculation. It is in terms of the proportion of time.

PARA.TAB: What the Opposition is again attempting to protect is its privileged position with respect to its ability to buy more time because of its rich mates donating more money to it than will be donated to us.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wanted $1.8m of free ads.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Giles)—Order! Senator Kemp!

TALK.START.PARA: —It knows, despite its claim, that we cannot be bought. Unlike it, we cannot be bought. We do not get massive donations. We did not get 4 per cent of the vote in the last election; we got over 11 per cent. It is entirely appropriate in a democratic society that we should have approximately 10 per cent of the time available on this very powerful medium.

PARA.TAB: A highly desirable provision in the legislation needs to be stressed. I refer to the talking heads provision, which was introduced by the Democrats and agreed to by the Government. I think Senator Kernot dealt very well with this.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are one of them.
—There are many people who would rather look at my head than Senator Bishop's head. It is more likely that my head will be on than hers anyway. It will not be on the chopping block as hers will be.
