PARA.TAB: The provision of minimum time and talking heads will go a long way towards rescuing this very powerful medium from the deceptive and misleading type of advertising to which the Australian public has been unfortunately subjected since the advent of television in this country. It will be quite difficult with two minutes of talking heads for people to use that sort of advertising.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much have you got out of this? Come on; tell us. Come clean.
—Order! Senator Kemp, you have interjected incessantly. I ask you to desist.

—I stress again a point made by Senator Kernot and one which we will be putting by way of amendment to this legislation. As this is a complex Bill, as we do not know precisely—as we never know with legislation—how this Bill will work out, we will be moving that after two Federal elections this whole package be reviewed. That is an appropriate mechanism by which this package can be judged.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Kernot indicated in her speech, in France the minimum time has been increased as a consequence of experience with this type of legislation, this type of process. A number of democratic countries around the world which are recognised by the Opposition to be democratic—countries under regimes which for years the Opposition has extolled as virtuous and as the exemplars which they would follow—are working under these sorts of regimes entirely satisfactorily and have no intention of and have made no attempt to change those procedures. No question of human rights intrusion has been raised.

I think it is entirely appropriate that this legislation be introduced, that we give it a good go for a couple of Federal elections, and then review the matter. I am quite convinced that in the long term the Opposition, if it were to form government, would not change this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President—

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I knew that everybody would be waiting for me to speak. I thought I was going to be the last speaker, but it seems that Senator Chapman is going to take the honour from me. At about this time yesterday morning when I was sitting having breakfast and talking to Senator Ray or when I was playing tennis with Senator Brownhill, little did I know that we would still be here now debating this particular subject. Whether this is the Today show or the early morning show in the Senate, it is pleasing to see that so many people have still managed to keep awake. I thank Senator Brownhill, my sponsor, for waking me to tell me that I was to come to speak.

PARA.TAB: I must say that I was amazed to hear what Senator Coulter had to say. We have sat here all night. We have had 27 speakers, most of whom have been from the Opposition and have defended our position on free speech and human rights. The Australian Democrats put their point of view. We just heard Senator Coulter say that after a couple of Federal elections they would review the legislation. That just shows how certain they are about it.

There is no doubt that this whole shemozzle has been going on for something like four years. I have been here for four years. I had not realised that it had been going on for four years, but there is a first time for everything. After four years this legislation has been thrust upon us. There is one thing that I have noticed in the four years I have been here. The only consistent thing I have ever seen is that when the chips are down and the Government wants to deal, we can always bet that the Democrats will take a fistful of dollars and get into bed with the Government. It is the only consistent thing I have seen in this place. Here we have it again, the old story. At least Senator Sowada, who went on record as calling me a `bonehead' in Adelaide—and she might have been right—has the guts to stand up for what she believes in; that is something that the rest of the Democrats have not got—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. We have had some discussions with the Opposition and there are some amendments of theirs which I believe we are going to support. We are not accepting a fistful of dollars from them, I assure you.
—There is no point of order.

—I have been listening to the debate and the figure that I have heard, although Senator Coulter has denied it, is that the Democrats stand to gain about $1.8m worth of advertising out of this. Be that as it may, in the short time I have left before Senator Chapman follows me, I just say that this really is disgraceful legislation. All we have been talking about for the last 24 hours or whatever is the fact that—and it has been said by just about every speaker, but for the record I will repeat it—this legislation is here because the Labor Party is bankrupt. There has been talk about Senator Loosley and the New South Wales branch of the Labor Party, but no-one has said—
—I do not know how he is going, but Robin Gray is looking pretty sick.
—The Labor Party in Tasmania is not in a much better position. It is about $500,000 down the tube. I must admit we are not much better, but at least the Labor Party in Tasmania is being consistent.
—Tell us some of the stories about the Bellerive Oval.

—Do not worry about the Bellerive Oval. Yesterday, when this matter was being discussed before we started speaking about this Bill, someone said that there would be about 20 speakers and we would all be saying the same thing. So I racked my brains—the few I have—to think of something that had not been said. Apart from Senator Panizza in a very short speech, no-one has mentioned the effect that this Bill will have on local government.
—What about the workers?

—No, I am not worrying about the workers. I am talking about local government. The Government has been saying for a very long time that it sees local government as the third tier of government. What it seems to have forgotten in this exercise is that voting in local government elections is not compulsory. They are the only elections in the three tiers of government in which voting is not compulsory. Very few people—Ted Mack, perhaps—spend a lot on television advertising in local government elections. Most local government candidates spend what little money they have on radio advertising and also, if they can afford it, a few pictures and a few words in the local newspaper.

PARA.TAB: The reason that radio advertising is so important to local government is that, because voting in those elections is not compulsory, candidates have to get out and sell themselves and try to get people to vote for them. Also, in the few weeks leading up to a local government election, thank heavens, commercial radio and even the ABC run frequent programs encouraging people to vote. That is what local government is all about. Those people who are interested in supporting their local candidates vote for them because they want to, not because they have to.

If the provisions of this Bill relating to radio come into effect, they will take away a very important part of local government elections. In the one or two weeks leading up to elections, the local radio stations run talkback shows, they promote the local government elections, they fire the local people up with their local issues and they encourage people to vote and to do their bit for democracy.

In North Sydney Ted Mack, MP, as mayor, started citizen initiated referendums in conjunction with council elections. One of them was about whether to ban live animals from circuses. That particular matter became known to the public only a week or so before the election. It was promoted through the media. If it had not been for the media the people in the circuses who were trying to defend themselves would not have heard anything about it.

The issue was publicised in the local media in the week leading up to the election, and I am pleased to say—although it depends on which side of the fence you are on—that 60 per cent of the people who voted in North Sydney, some 8,000 people, voted in favour of live animals in circuses. Had this sort of legislation been in place, not only would the North Sydney City Council have been able to force something on the people or taken away the livelihood of some businesses, but a minority group of businesses in our community, the circus people, would have been denied the opportunity to have their say.

Whilst we are all tied up in party politics in Canberra and in the States, there are local government bodies in Australia that are non-political. In Tasmania, all our local governments are non-political, and they believe in using the media, particularly broadcasting, to promote their cases. If that opportunity is taken away from them, it will perpetuate the sitting members. The new candidates coming along with their local views and their local background will have no hope of promoting their cause. Let us face it—it is only in the last week or two coming up to an election that anybody takes any notice.

Local government candidates do not have the facilities we have to organise large mail-out campaigns. They cannot afford to go on television. They do use radio and newspapers to a certain extent, radio in particular. This legislation will disadvantage new local government candidates right around Australia. It will also reduce the interest that has been generated in local government. It is a pity that the third tier of government is to be affected by this legislation.

Having said that, I will get back on another hobbyhorse of mine—radio broadcasting. I must say that I was horrified to hear that the Government has decided that radio will be treated in a worse fashion than television. Yesterday afternoon I rang a friend of mine who is the manager for Radio 101.7 FM in Hobart, 7HO as it used to be. He is an old rocker from way back, a former member of a rock band, Paul Shirley. I had contacted him earlier in the year. In fact, I have a letter here which I wish to quote from. He put me onto a chap called Geoff Rushton, who is the manager of the commercial radio association in Sydney. I know Senator Kernot would know very well the person I am talking about.

When I spoke to him, I said, `We have got a few problems here. Radio is going to be excluded'. He said, `Oh, no. I have been talking to Senator Kernot and I have been talking to Senator Kemp, and I think Senator Kernot is going to support you and you will have paid ads on radio'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did Senator Kernot say that?
—Yes, she did.
—Who said this?
—Mr Geoff Rushton in Sydney. Does the honourable senator say that she has never spoken to him?
—Yes, I have.

—He is under the impression that Senator Kernot is going to support Senator Kemp's amendment to exclude radio from this advertisements ban. I was talking to him on speaker phone because he had another gentleman with him. I said, `You know what the Democrats are like. They can say one thing and then another. You can only hire them by the minute'. Little did I know that he was given the impression—
—We will not be supporting any of your amendments if you go along that road.
—From what I am led to believe, you—
—Do you not support an amendment because it is the right thing to do?
—Yes, we do, but that is not what he said.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —I know it is early in the morning.
—You cross their palms with silver and they will do anything.
—Order!
—I was given the impression by the manager of the commercial radio association—
—You did not give a parliamentary ruling.
—Senator MacGibbon, yes, I did. I said, `Order!'. Take your seat. I am asking you to keep quiet while your colleague is speaking. I call Senator Calvert.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I am not deaf. If you wish to address me, show some respect.
—Sit down.
—Big boss!

—Senator Walters, when someone is in the chair—it does not matter who—you do not interject when that person is speaking. For heaven's sake, it is now 7 a.m. or later. Could you please allow your colleague to finish his speech uninterrupted. I call Senator Calvert.
—On the point of order: with respect, I think it was your quite sharp rejoinder—
—Sit down, please, Senator. I will call Senator Calvert. You are taking precious time from his speech.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I was enjoying sitting down, actually; I thought you might have left me there for the next hour or so. As I was saying, I will be totally disappointed if what I have been told is true—that the Democrats are not going to support Senator Kemp's amendment on radio broadcasting, because at the end of the day radio is probably one of the most important mediums, come election time. I know that the radio stations themselves are saying, `Why are we missing out?'. After all is said and done, with the advent of FM radio stations there has been some sort of self-regulation whereby they have reduced the number of advertisements they have. Obviously, the time they give to advertising is rather expensive. If they had been put in the same position as the television stations of having to provide free time, that probably would not have been acceptable to them.

PARA.TAB: I will quote from a letter I received back in April this year: it is a reaction that speaks for probably most media outlets around Australia and it sums up what I believe we have been talking about for the last 24 hours. It was from the manager of 7HO FM in Hobart, Paul Shirley. I do not know what his politics are and I do not think he had too many politics until this particular matter arose. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Thank you for your letter of 10 April and the accompanying material.
Might I suggest (with complete goodwill, I stress) that to suggest your expression of concern to myself as preaching to the converted would be the understatement of the year.
But seriously, we are (and I confidently include all of our colleague stations in Tasmania) most appreciative of your affirmative action.
That was back in the days when we thought that the Government, after 3 1/2 years, might have given this fruitless exercise away. He went on to say:

To this extent I have conveyed a copy of your correspondence to Martin Hartcher, Federal Director, FARB, Sydney. I will be adding your points to everyone I talk to and encouraging our colleagues to do the same.
For your information I enclose a couple of press clippings indicative of the position of the Tasmanian commercial stations.
I'd also like to share with you some thoughts I conveyed in a recent interview with an ABC journalist.
This is getting towards the point:

I said amongst other things: . . . who do they think they're dealing with—a peasantry—do they seriously think that they can keep the Australian people in an information background—what are they trying to do? Stage an Atlantic style election?
The connotations are truly frightening. I know that even the newspapers are worried. They see this subterfuge, this hypocrisy, this unmitigated evil as being the thin end of the wedge. . .
I can assure you we will fight this with every means at our disposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —He sees elections as advertising dollars.

—No, he does not. I would say that he, along with all other managers of commercial radio stations, would see it for what it is: an erosion of human rights, an erosion of all the things we stand for, including freedom of speech. It has been said for the last 24 hours in this place that all those people who have a right to speak and put their point of view are going to miss out.

PARA.TAB: I also have a copy of a media release that was put out on 21 March by the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters, Tasmanian Executive. Perhaps I could read the media release:

SPEECH.PARA: At a meeting in Launceston today, members of Tasmania's commercial radio industry expressed anger and outrage at any suggested prohibition of political advertising on the electronic media.
Commercial radio executives believe that through an orchestrated campaign of hysteria the public is being coerced into accepting suppression of information.
How true that is. To continue:
The Chairman of the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters Tasmanian Executive, Paul Shirley, said the industry's concern went far beyond its commercial considerations—
that is for Senator Cook's information—
although the proposal is yet another example of government discrimination against the electronic media.

Mr Shirley said his members would not condone such a totalitarian attack on one of the basic tenets of democracy, that being the freedom of speech, whether on the basis of commercial impact or for any other reason. A ban on political advertisements would not inhibit, and in fact would no doubt greatly accelerate, the flow of political media releases to radio and television stations. Some broadcasters might not feel well disposed to political media releases in circumstances of an advertising ban.
The meeting canvassed a range of other concerns including the disadvantage to persons who were print handicapped—
I believe this has been covered to some extent in the Bill—

or who had literacy problems. Many other sectors within the community including special interest and philanthropic organisations could also be caught by the proposed legislation and prevented from presenting their views by the use of radio or television advertising. Mr Shirley said it was the view of his members that the Federal Government is running scared. As a consequence of its overall mismanagement the Party is broke and faces the next election in abject panic.
This was back in March. How true it was. The release concluded:
He said the proposed ban on political advertising on radio and television was a desperate attempt to prop up the failing popularity of the government and its election prospects.
That was 21 March 1991. What has changed? The Government's prospects have got worse and its debts have got bigger.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some honourable senators might need reminding that the Senate is actually discussing the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991. On the ABC news at 6 o'clock this morning I heard that this sitting is the longest for some 26 years and on the early AM program it was said that it was the longest in 25 years. I have worked out that I am the thirtieth speaker on the list, so very little can be added to the discussion on this particular Bill that is not repetitious. I am going to hold to that and not delay the Senate unduly.

PARA.TAB: Among the 29 speakers before me there were some who made very good, very measured and very thoughtful speeches. I refer not only to speakers from this side of the chamber but indeed some from the other side. There were also some that could be called good speeches. But there were also some very mediocre ones. I think it is appalling that mediocre speeches are given on a Bill as important as this, and there is no question that it is a very important Bill.

I think probably the worst speech that I heard—I did not hear each and every one, but I did listen pretty carefully to the debate and I have spent a great deal of time in the chamber—was the one which emanated from Senator Walters. She spent the first 10 minutes talking about legislation that was before this place in 1985 and then had the audacity to call a point of order on another speaker, raising the question of relevance. But I move on because I do not want to abuse the very great privilege that we have in this place. Indeed, I think that privilege is continually abused by people in this chamber.

The matter of corruption, particularly political corruption, has been raised a number of times, and the finger has been pointed at Western Australia. In my time in this place—seven years, in three days time—I have not cast any stones against any individual against whom allegations have been made in royal commissions that have been conducted in almost every State throughout this land.

Indeed, in my own State of Western Australia at the moment there is a royal commission going on. Some of the accusations being made before the Royal Commission are very disturbing to me. I have made statements on the public record about the consequences if any members of my Party or any other party are later charged and perhaps interned as a result of their actions. I want to make the point as forcefully as I possibly can that in Western Australia no member of the Australian Labor Party in government since 1983, in any government in that time, has been charged in any court of law with any wrongdoing. Nobody has been charged.

It is grossly unfair and a gross breach of privilege for honourable senators to come into this place and raise the names of present and former Western Australian parliamentarians as if they had been charged, tried and convicted. None of them has been. I caution honourable senators that, if they really want to get into dirty tactics, we can all play at that game. There have been no charges laid against any Western Australian currently serving in the Western Australian Parliament or retired from the Western Australian Parliament.

The Royal Commission is still considering the evidence before it, and will be for quite some time. A report will be prepared. It will not be a matter for a chamber such as this, either here or in Perth, to make the charges. It will be a matter for the public prosecutor in the State to lay charges. Even then, if charges are laid against any present or former politician, they will take their chances before the courts according to the system of British justice that we live under in this nation of ours, Australia.

I know that system is a bit flawed because of some recent events back in the home country. Nonetheless it is the system that we operate under and we should not be turning a parliament, even a chamber as grand as this one, into a star chamber and convicting people on allegations, many of which are unfounded and which will, I am confident, be proved to be unfounded.

If, after all the due processes of law are carried through, the Commission reports, charges are made, individuals are convicted and later interned, I will not be one of the people who will be jumping up here and defending them. If they have done wrong and have been proved in a court of law to have done wrong—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I am just wondering whether this is quite relevant to the debate or whether Senator McKiernan wants to make a personal explanation. I believe it is not quite relevant to the debate on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, the matter was raised a number of times in previous debate in this chamber. If it was not relevant then, it should have been called out of order from that side of the chamber. It was Senator Brownhill's side that was making the accusations, and I believe I have the right to put something on the record in response.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—I do not uphold the point of order since that matter was raised in debate on a number of occasions and corruption has been part of the discussions right through this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was making the point that if, after all the due process of law have been gone through, the Royal Commission in Perth reports, charges are laid, convictions are recorded and individuals are interned, I will not be jumping to my feet in this place to defend the individuals who are interned if they have been proved through the due processes of law to have done the wrong thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In its handling of this issue, the Government is the proverbial thief in the night, having through this all-night debate proceeded to steal democracy. A few moments ago, we heard by way of interjection from Senator Cook on my colleague Senator Calvert the comment that naked self-interest related to the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill. I think Senator Cook was referring to some views expressed by radio stations to which Senator Calvert was referring. The only example of naked self-interest in regard to this legislation comes from the Government itself and perhaps its associates over there on the left, the Democrats. It is their naked self-interest that is being served by this legislation. That is why we have seen the legislation guillotined in the way it has been so that we have been forced to debate it right through the night until now, at 7.25 on Wednesday morning.

PARA.TAB: No honourable senators from the other side can ever again trumpet their commitment to democracy—not just because they are supporting this anti-democratic legislation but because of the way in which they have supported this guillotined method of debating it. On both counts, it is the worst trampling on democratic rights that I have seen since I first became a member of this Parliament some 16 years ago.

Undoubtedly, this night has been Australia's Night of the Long Knives. Just as democracy died in Germany under Hitler's jack booted henchmen on the Night of the Long Knives, so over this night an important element of democracy is being killed in Australia on our Night of the Long Knives by Hawke's henchmen in this chamber.

This legislation makes some of the most far-reaching changes that could possibly be imagined to democratic life as Australians have known it for generations. To ban political advertising on the electronic media is a savage attack on democracy. To ram such far-reaching changes through this chamber in less than 48 hours is a travesty of the Senate. To do so in the context of the Government itself tabling some 37 amendments on the eve of the debate and a further 14 amendments during the debate overnight is beyond the comprehension of any committed democrat.

The Government is clearly determined to avoid wider public scrutiny of its proposals. We should ask why. The answer is that the Government now lives in very fear of the Australian public. It knows that Australians, if given a direct choice, would not have a bar of this legislation. It also knows that Australians, if given a direct choice now, would no longer have a bar of the Hawke Labor Government. Today's Morgan gallup poll again confirms a consistent lead of the Liberal and National parties over the Labor Government and indeed John Hewson over Bob Hawke.

Quite clearly, the Government is running scared. It will not allow this legislation proper public scrutiny. But worse, through this very legislation, it seeks to shield its disastrous record in government from proper public scrutiny. Not only does the Government want to shield this legislation from scrutiny but through this legislation it wants to shield its own disastrous public record from proper scrutiny.

Why is there such a rush with this legislation? Is the Prime Minister rushing to an election to forestall yet another challenge from the honourable member for Blaxland, or is the legislation designed to shield one of the Labor State Premiers from proper scrutiny in an early State election? The only purpose of this legislation is to salvage the semblance of an effective campaign for the Labor Party at the next election. It can no longer conduct a successful campaign through the traditional use of electronic media because in previous campaigns it has mismanaged its finances, just as it has mismanaged this country's finances, and so is broke, just as Australia is broke under the Government's administration. Labor is broke because it spent whatever was necessary to win past elections rather than what it could raise in fundraising.

Labor is also immensely and justifiably unpopular because of the havoc it has wreaked on the lives of so many Australians, not the least being the one million unemployed. So it has no hope of raising funds for its next campaign. Hence we have this legislation to eliminate a major source of campaign expenditure. Coincidentally, as I have already mentioned, it eliminates the most effective medium for exposing Labor's failures. So Labor will substitute, at taxpayer expense, other campaign techniques such as direct mail and telemarketing which can be initiated from parliamentary electorate offices. In this it has the acquiescence and support of the Australian Democrats.

All through the night during this debate the Democrats have refused to answer the questions we have put to them on how they would benefit from this legislation. The figures given earlier by Senator Kemp show that the free time available to them under this legislation would equal some $1.8m. That represents six times the advertising expenditure of the Democrats at the last election. Senator Kernot and Senator Coulter, in their speeches on this legislation throughout the night, have not been able to refute in any way those figures given by Senator Kemp. So the Democrats, as well as the Government, gain a massive advantage from this legislation. But that is done to the exclusion of the Liberal and National parties and other interest groups.

This legislation simply seeks to reduce the campaigning capacity of those who wish to be rid of Labor at the next election to the level of Labor's own campaigning capacity. It seeks to hamstring not only the Liberal and National parties but also the growing number of community groups who want Labor thrown from office. Why should any group in our community have its capacity to take its message directly to the Australian people through the most effective medium—television—destroyed? No organisation should be dependent on the interpretive whims of television news editors as to whether its message gets through or whether it gets left on the cutting room floor. It is a travesty of democracy. Freedom to advertise must remain an important element in the democratic process.

In September, I had the privilege of leading the official international observer mission at the inaugural direct elections for the Hong Kong Legislative Council. Advertising on the electronic media was not allowed during that recent campaign. One of the major recommendations of that observer mission—which was an international mission with representatives from a number of countries—was that electronic media advertising should be allowed for elections in Hong Kong to be more completely democratic. Yet we see in Australia this legislation banning political advertising which is heading in the opposite direction.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are heading towards a Third World country.

—It is heading us, as Senator Archer correctly interjects, towards the status of a Third World country. That might be appropriate, because that is where our economy is heading as well; perhaps the Government wants our democratic structures to head in exactly the same direction. But it is certainly not acceptable to the Liberal and National parties, who continue to believe in the democratic processes. This legislation to ban political advertising is indeed a fraud being perpetrated on the Australian people. As it will be amended by the Government's proposed 51 amendments, it is based on a fraudulent committee report. The report of the Senate Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures is a fraudulent report.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! Senator, I draw your attention to the aspersions you are casting upon the chamber via one of its committees. Under Standing Orders, you cannot describe a process of the Senate or its committees as fraudulent. So I ask you to—

TALK.START.PARA: —You might be talking about Senator Kemp or Senator Olsen.

—Senator Schacht, when I am talking to someone in need of some guidance under the Standing Orders I do not need your assistance. Senator Chapman, I ask you to withdraw that remark and replace it with something more appropriate.

—In view of your guidance, Mr Acting Deputy President, I simply submit the fact that the Committee report, certainly upon which the amended legislation is based, is unacceptable to the Opposition. It is unacceptable because it does not in fact reach conclusions which can in any way be justifiably based on the evidence that was placed before that Committee, as I will relate in a few moments.

PARA.TAB: Any reasonable reading of the majority conclusions and recommendations of this Committee confirms quite clearly that they do not reflect the evidence given to that Committee at its various hearings. They reflect neither the written submissions nor, in fact, the verbal evidence presented to the Committee. This can be seen clearly from a perusal of the Hansard reports of Committee proceedings. I was shocked when perusing these Hansard reports not only to see the obvious inconsistency between the evidence and the majority report, but also because of its revelations of the unacceptable behaviour of the Committee Chairman, Senator Schacht. I have to say that this came as an enormous shock and disappointment to me. I serve with Senator Schacht on the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, which is generally regarded as the most prestigious committee of this Parliament. Senator Schacht is Chairman of that Committee, and a more mild mannered and courteous chairman you would not care to see.

So honourable senators can imagine my shock and horror when I compared his behaviour on the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee with his behaviour as the Chairman of the Senate Select Committee in relation to this legislation. The Hansard shows that he rudely interrupted, hectored and badgered witnesses in an attempt to intimidate them to abandon their opposition to this legislation. That is quite unacceptable behaviour from a committee chairman and I hope we never see it repeated.

But even that was not good enough for Senator Schacht. He then ensured that a committee report was presented which, as I have already said, ignored the evidence put before the Committee. Only seven out of 127 written submissions and four out of the 21 witnesses who appeared before the Committee favoured the advertising ban which has been promulgated through this legislation. Yet the Committee's majority report—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quality that counts, not quantity.

—If Senator Schacht reconsiders the evidence that was presented to the Committee and goes back and reads Hansard, I think he will find only too clearly that the quality of the evidence which was presented opposing this legislation in fact could only lead to a conclusion that it should have been abandoned. Despite all of that, the Committee's majority report, in supporting this legislation, ignores the overwhelming evidence against it by the majority of submissions and witnesses. The only conclusion capable of being reached is that the majority report, as I said, was written with a specific goal in mind: the Government's goal of getting this legislation through and giving comfort to this specific legislation, rather than in fact reflecting the evidence that was put before the Committee. It is only the dissenting report of my colleagues Senator Olsen and Senator Kemp which in fact has any credence with regard to this legislation and its associated issues.
—They did not make one recommendation.

—Therefore, it is appropriate to refer to the conclusions which those two senators reached in their dissenting report. Senator Olsen and Senator Kemp have clearly indicated and concluded from the evidence that, by omission of evidence and blatant manipulation of quotes from evidence, the Chairman—Senator Schacht—has created a scenario which simply did not eventuate. They also say in their minority report that were the majority report a newspaper report, its content would have the capacity to be referred to the Australian Press Council and its author to the ethics committee of the AJA. My two colleagues reached the conclusion that the majority report was very inaccurate when compared with the evidence put before the Committee.

PARA.TAB: They have also said in relation to the proposed advertising ban that the reasoning provided by the Government for advocating such a ban—namely, political corruption—was rejected by all but three Committee witnesses as being in the province of disclosure provisions, and not an advertising ban. Furthermore, no evidence of any proven Federal corruption was put before the Committee.

They also refer to the impact of this legislation on minority groups. They conclude that the effects of the proposed bans on the rural community, the intellectually disabled, the print handicapped and our migrant population—many of whom have to rely on the electronic media for information—were reinforced continually by expert witnesses. The majority report has completely avoided dealing with the implications of the advertising ban on the rural community and these other sections of our community.

The minority report also refers to the human rights aspect of this legislation. It refers in particular to the evidence of Professor Philip Alston, one of Australia's top three constitutional lawyers.

TALK.START.PARA: —One.

—One of three, a man whose opinion should therefore be given great weight. He referred to the advice from the Attorney-General's Department which was apparently—and one would question why—favourable to this legislation. This expert in constitutional law said the Attorney-General's Department advice was `very superficial advice'. I quote Professor Alston in full because he is worth listening to. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that is what distresses me about this advice from the Office of International Law—
that is within the Attorney-General's Department—
being the principal and, indeed, the only legal analysis that has been provided in support of the proposal.

My assumption is—and I want to go back and place this on the record yet again—that I do have enormous respect for the qualifications and abilities of the individual who wrote this advice. I do not believe, however, that it was written with a view to being the definitive piece of advice to justify legislation and, if it was, it should not have been.
Again, as I quoted earlier, it concludes:
It is very superficial advice.

So again, human rights are ignored in this report and in this legislation. The majority report also ignored specific difficulties that were raised in evidence about the implementation of this ban in terms of its practicability with respect to being able to corral airwaves, to prevent signals travelling distances far greater than the licence area.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Electoral Commission also stated in evidence to the Committee that there were many problems with definition and interpretation and it had concerns about the drafting of the legislation. Then, of course, there was evidence to indicate that in no way would the abandonment of paid advertising on the electronic media reduce the cost of election campaigns. So, all in all, as I said, the evidence presented to this Committee does not in any way justify this legislation.

My colleagues on that Committee, Senator Olsen and Senator Kemp, in their minority report spelt out very clearly why the Committee should not have supported this legislation. On that basis, and on the basis of the arguments that have been put throughout the night and into the morning—it now being nearly a quarter to eight on Wednesday morning and this legislation having been debated for most of Tuesday and now through the night into Wednesday morning—we can only conclude that this legislation should be thrown out lock, stock and barrel.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe it probably gives some pleasure to honourable senators that I get up at this particular stage to close the second reading debate on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill. We are coming to the end of an unprecedented day's sitting and to use the lines of a song of some time ago, it really has been a hard day's night.
—But you have slept all night. You have not been on the roster.
—Senator Walters, all I will say to you is that—I was thinking about this a few minutes ago—if my mother had known that I would spend a night with people like the ones I have spent this night with—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Minister, address your remarks through the Chair. It would also be better at this stage if we had no interjections.

TALK.START.PARA: —She would have thought she had brought me up the wrong way.

—Minister, please take your seat. I was speaking, so you should take your seat. I indicate to you that if you want to talk to other members, you do it via me. At this stage of the morning it would be most appropriate if you address your remarks to the Chair.

—In short, let me say that I think tonight's sitting has been totally unjustified. There is nothing radical in the proposal before the Parliament and there is nothing new about it. I think the behaviour overnight has really raised the temperature in a way that has not been justified.

PARA.TAB: In terms of whether the proposal is radical, let me just say at this stage very briefly—and I will go into it later—that what has been proposed is something that is common throughout the world; it is common throughout western democracies. We are in fact one of only three countries with absolutely no controls on political advertising. This measure rectifies that in a way which is consistent with international positions. So let us get that straight.

With respect to another reason put forward for the agitation of and the performance put on by honourable senators opposite, I point out that this matter is not new to this place. It has been before the Parliament for some four years now by way of consideration by committees. In fact, two years ago the report entitled Who pays the piper calls the tune was delivered to this Parliament by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters; the reference was commissioned in 1987. So the matter has been before the Parliament for some time with two parliamentary committees.

The point has been made that we are producing amendments at a late stage. Half of the amendments raised for consideration by the Senate were tabled some 3 1/2 months ago on 13 August. With respect to the others, let me also say that the Government has been quite flexible in allowing the Opposition some extra time for the second of those parliamentary committees which I mentioned and, because of that, we have had to shorten the time available to us to prepare amendments.

Despite the fact that we are not talking about anything radical or anything that is new to this Parliament, we have tonight had from those opposite a performance which basically can be likened to the performance of drama queens at a Mardi gras. The longer the night, the more outrageous the performance; the more outrageous, the more tedious. It has been a wasteful, fruitless night, but it is something that they have had to go through to go through the motions.

I think in analysing the debate I need first to go to the motives of each party in the debate. We have been accused of having all sorts of motives. Let me say—and the record shows this—that the Australian Labor Party has been consistent in its approach to the necessity for electoral reform. From 1983 we have had in this area an agenda with two major arms: first, we wanted to contain the cost burden on the political participants; secondly, we wanted to make the process more transparent. A third arm, something very much a part of the agenda which was achieved early in the piece, was to make the system more democratic in terms of numbers in constituencies.

Over eight or nine years, we introduced legislation to try to achieve these objectives. One attempt was for partial disclosure; another was for public funding. In 1987 it was quite apparent that those measures in themselves were not effective enough to handle the problem that was emerging both domestically and internationally, so in 1987 a reference was sent to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. The Committee was to look at both costs and disclosure in terms of the political process. So, as I have said, the process has taken four years and two committees. Both those committees—the Joint Standing Committee and the Schacht Committee, the Senate Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures, which has just reported—have made recommendations in the areas of disclosure and free time.

As I say, this is not a recent development for the Labor Party. For over a decade we have had a commitment to it and have taken measures towards it. The motive has always been twofold: first, to tackle the corruptive influence of the corporate dollar in the political process, recognising at all times that there is a legitimate role for corporate donations; secondly, to ensure that there is equity in the system.

What does the corruption potential mean? In the course of the night I have listened to a number of speakers, but let me just go to one bit of evidence that went to the Schacht Committee. The potential for corruption is there and it is recognised that it is there. We have seen it operate at the State level; we have seen it operate internationally. It was even accepted by David Flint from the Australian Press Council in its submission to the Senate Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures. At point 7 on page 3 of its submission, it stated very clearly:

SPEECH.PARA: The Council notes and fully accepts the concern in the Parliament as to the potential for corruption which could result from large advertising budgets of political parties.

That is very clear, very succinct. That is the point that we have been concerned about. That is the point that has been stressed by not only the Australian Press Council, but also over recent years a whole range of committees at State level.

PARA.TAB: Corruption potential is one thing, undue influence is another. I think I have mentioned a number of times the aspect of undue influence. We have wanted to reduce the situation where, by the provision of money, people buy access into the process. Tony Eggleton is one person from the other side of politics who is on record as acknowledging that in the Fraser days, anyone who donated had a foot in the door much more quickly. In that situation, it is those people without money who are disadvantaged. That is the sort of situation that these proposals tackle.

The third aspect that we have been concerned about is one that Senator Coulter raised a little while ago. What we are concerned about, thirdly, is the influence on directing the political agenda. In our system, the most basic democratic principle is the principle of one person, one vote; one vote, one value. As Senator Coulter said, if we have a situation as occurred in Western Australia a number of years ago when the legitimate voice of the Aboriginals was drowned out by the overwhelming force of misleading racist campaigns, we do not have a healthy democratic system.

So let me just say at this particular stage that we have been intent on tackling both arms of the problem at the same time, both the disclosure aspect as well as a reduction in the reliance on corporate dollars—in fact a reduction in the need for parties to raise campaign funds. We need to do it now. Essentially, this is our last chance before we go down the way of other countries such as Japan and the USA, before the Federal system takes the turn that has happened in the States.
Those on the other side do not recognise it as a problem, but there is a problem and it is a big one.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hang on; Bob Hogg agrees with us.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, we have allowed Senator Macdonald to go on all night. I just want another 15 to 20 minutes to finish this and I just ask for some protection from the jackals on the other side. It is a big problem within Australia but we also have to assess it internationally. We spend more in Australia for our Federal elections than is spent—
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Is the word `jackals' parliamentary?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—No. I ask the Minister to withdraw that and I also ask people to stop interjecting. This is the summing up. We have had words like jackals and galahs used. Quite frankly, I just think they are unparliamentary because they are meant to be a personal reflection.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw, Mr Acting Deputy President. The point I was making is that we do have a big problem in Australia in terms of the costs of election campaigns. I was just about to say that we spend more per capita on a Federal election campaign than is spent on a US Congress election and there has been an enormous blow-out over the last three elections, from $5m to $10m to $15m on electronic advertising over those three elections. The point has been made from time to time that it is the Labor Party that outspends the other parties in the process. But, if one looks at the amount of money that was spent in the 1990 election, Labor spent in fact $14.7m all up; the Opposition, the Liberals and Nationals and CLP, spent $15.5m all up. That gives the lie to Senator Olsen's claim that the Labor Party spends more on election campaigns than does the Opposition. The Opposition parties spent almost one million dollars more than we did at the last election.

PARA.TAB: As I said earlier on, there is a problem. It has been recognised by this Government, but it has also been recognised internationally. As I have said, we are not standing alone in what we are doing. We are one of three countries that have a situation which the conservatives in this country want to preserve. The rest of the world, liberal democracies and the like, has taken some action to ensure that the process is regulated in the way that we are seeking.

It is not just an internationally recognised problem; it has been recognised domestically as well. The ICAC in New South Wales had this particular issue before it and what it recommended was what this Government is doing. It recommended that you cannot tackle one part of the problem on its own; you have to tackle both costs and disclosure in order to ensure that the system can be protected.

There has been a lot of rhetoric over the last few hours about what we are doing and the democratic or otherwise nature of it. I refer the Senate, and anyone else who would like to take an interest in this, particularly our friends in the gallery, to page 111 of the report of the Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures, the Schacht report, where Appendix 5 is headed, `Political Advertisements: An International Comparison'. There one finds that what we are doing is very much in step with the rest of the world. The United Kingdom, for instance, has had and does have provisions that ensure less access to radio and television advertising than is proposed in this measure. Canada has regulation of it. France provides that political parties receive free time for advertising on state radio and television stations and a limited time thereafter for presidential campaigns and whatever. New Zealand, of course, is out on its own but it also allows for paid political advertisements. As we go down the list, we see that Sweden, Norway, Denmark, Austria, Israel, Japan and the Netherlands all provide in one way or another for free time and for regulation of political advertisements. We are not doing anything here that is out of the ordinary in the international agenda.

Let me also at this stage tackle the point on motivation which I started to address earlier on. We are motivated by an international recognition of the problem, by the fact that State royal commissions have recognised the problem and by the fact that we have to act to ensure that the system stays democratic. I think Senator Macdonald made the point that we have been driven by the fact that we are broke. I say to Senator Macdonald that on 9 July this year the newly elected Liberal Party President, Paul Everingham, admitted that the Liberal Party is almost broke and its election campaigns have been ineffective. That was the headline in a Brisbane newspaper.

The point of the matter is that, if the two major political parties in this country have problems financing their campaigns, what chance have the minor parties got? What chance have new players in the process got? They have absolutely none at all. I go back to that particular point: whether in Queensland, Victoria or nationally, the Liberal Party is well and truly strapped and the Labor Party is having difficulties meeting the costs of campaigns. Both of us will be able to do it in the end; there is no doubt about that. But how democratic is it when we can hardly afford to pay for campaigns and the rest of the players in the field who want to play are denied access to the whole process? It is very undemocratic to the extent that it has been recognised by main players in the game in the US. Senator Barry Goldwater of the US Senate made it very clear—and this is the particular point that we are trying to address—when he said that it is not the people but the monied interests who are setting the nation's political agenda and are influencing the position of candidates on the important issues of the day. What we are doing here by this measure is ensuring that the situation that Barry Goldwater describes as operating in the US, and the situation that operated in Western Australia a number of years ago, does not repeat itself.

It is no surprise to us that the Senate has been forced to sit for the number of hours that it has been forced to sit overnight. There has been one thing that has been consistent about those on the other side when it comes to issues in this area: whether it has been disclosure, public funding or measures to contain costs, they have shown absolutely no responsibility in addressing those issues. From day one, from March 1983 when we came into government, they have resisted every measure put up by this Government. On a State level they have resisted every measure put up by Labor governments and Labor parties. Even recently we had the promise from Nick Greiner—tricky Nick Greiner. He promised a number of years ago that he would introduce disclosure before the next election. Well, the next election has been and gone. We have not seen disclosure. We have seen a framework of committees set up. But, now that the election is over, he is running away from the issue—as he was always going to, and as those opposite have done historically over the last eight years. They do not want to grapple with the issue. They want unbridled, unregulated access in this area in a way which is most undemocratic. What drives those opposite? They come in here claiming a commitment to human rights.

The Opposition's human rights record is one that is littered with, and permeated by, hypocrisy. In 1985-86 the Opposition parties opposed measures to enshrine the International Covenant of Civil and Political Rights in the Australian Constitution. Their record has been consistent since then and before then. Their record on the Human Rights Commission has been to abolish it. That policy changed a fortnight ago. It is no longer to abolish it, it is now to create a shell out of it by reducing its funding by some $4m. In respect to the most recent attempt by this Government to entrench in the Constitution human rights and civil liberties—

TALK.START.PARA: —You just ignore it.

—What did they do? A proposal was put forward by a committee chaired by the former Premier of Victoria, Sir Rupert Hamer; what did they do, they opposed it. They have no consistency, no regard, no respect, and no track record on human rights. Their track record, in fact, is littered with hypocrisy.

PARA.TAB: A couple of weeks ago they came up with a promise for the future in human rights. They mentioned HREOC, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, which is an important mechanism in this country to monitor and protect human rights. It gives advice, and that advice has to be respected, although not always agreed with. But what are the Opposition parties going to do there? They are going to reduce it in a way that Jack Waterford in the Canberra Times says will reduce its funding by $4m from a current figure of $9m. The funding used to be $6m before it gained responsibility for matters concerning privacy. So what they are doing with the Human Rights Commission is gutting it. All those people with whom they have been working on this will be sold down the drain.

There are two arms which are used by government to keep us in contact with international civil rights and human rights mechanisms. The other one is the international law division of the Attorney-General's Department. What does the Opposition intend doing with that? It will shut that right up. It will flick the function off to DFAT, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. That is the sort of respect the Opposition has for human rights in this country.

But it does not end there. The most basic human right in this country is access to law. So what are Opposition members doing for those people who do not have access to law because they cannot afford it? They will cut back on legal aid by $10m. What will they do with protective security and the administration of justice? They will cut that back by another $17m. That is the sort of commitment the Opposition made to human rights in this country. It is totally cynical; it is totally hypocritical.

Let us not talk about the human rights of sole parents and migrants, or of Aboriginals, whose funding will be cut back by $90m. Let us not talk about the rights of community lobby groups whom the Opposition is targeting in this place. The Opposition's approach has been one of hypocrisy, but why should we expect any better. Opposition members have no respect for human rights. In February 1986, Senator Durack, the former Attorney-General, said, `We will not join in any international covenant to bring human rights to everybody'. What has the Opposition done in the last few months? It has cited a covenant that Senator Durack would never pay any respect to.

Also, in terms of the hypocrisy, let me make another point. Opposition members are claiming that advertising is sacrosanct. Is it not strange? On 26 November 1990 it was John Hewson who made it very clear what he thought about advertising. He said, `I have no personal disposition against advertising'. He made it very clear. But it was not just him. Senators on the other side who have been bleating overnight about advertising had this to say in the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters entitled Who pays the piper calls the tune:

SPEECH.PARA: We reject as absurd the assertion that political advertising is a social good.
They went on to say:
We have seen no convincing evidence of any correlation between election results and either the quality or quantity of political advertising on the electronic media.
They also said:
It seems likely that it is the news and current affairs programs and not the party advertisements that provide the information which makes TV a significant influence on individual political choices.

They are on the record as saying that, but they come in here overnight claiming some commitment to human rights—newborn though it may be—but at the same time having absolutely no respect for the medium that they are wanting to protect. What is their real reason? They want to maintain a system. They want the right to buy influence; they want the right to corrupt; they do not want a level playing field, they want the strength of one's voice to depend on the balance of the bank account.

PARA.TAB: The Bill has had a gestation period of four years—two committees, a plethora of hearings, and hours of evidence from witnesses. Over that process there has been only one force that has been prepared to negotiate and that has been the Democrats, and they have been pretty good at it. I must say that at this particular stage though that it is not as the Opposition expects—there is not a deal in this respect. There is no guarantee that this legislation will come into law. It is going to take a number of hours during the course of the day to ensure that the legislation that is passed by the Senate is acceptable to the Government. At this stage I cannot say with any degree of certainty that what is going through this place will be proclaimed at the end of the day. The Bill has to go through the processes of the next few hours. The Democrats have at lease recognised the problem and they have been prepared to negotiate in a constructive manner.

The proposals, of course, lead to a new era in political advertising, which will be informative and substantive. At this stage, before time runs out, I want to thank a number of people. I have already mentioned the Democrats' current leadership. I should also mention the role played by Senator Powell and her former staff member, Lesley Vick, over a period of time. The Senate Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures, Rosemary Laing and her secretariat, have to be recognised, and the Labor and Democrat senators on that Committee deserve particular mention. We had a great degree of work done by and support from the Office of the Parliamentary Counsel, the Electoral Commission, the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Transport and Communications, which should be recognised, as should the work of my staff and in particular John Richardson for the work he has committed to this over the last year or so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very poor work. I would not try to blame him. It is appallingly drafted material, but you are an inept Minister.

—It is not uncommon for Senator Bishop to come in here and slag individuals. Her reputation has been built on doing that. That is precisely what she is doing now. I reject any criticism of individuals from outside this place.
—You are an absolute disgrace.
—Order!
—Could you please tell me, Mr President, whether or not you consider the word `slag' is parliamentary. I consider it most offensive, but it is the sort of language I expect from that Minister.
—I do not think it was used in the personal sense to apply to you, Senator Bishop.
—It was used as a verb.
—Sit down, you grubby little thing.

—Mr President, it was used as a verb. If you have a look at his sentence construction, you will see that he used the term as a verb. As such it is necessary for you to look at the context in which he used the term. I find it an offensive term; I am sure most Australians would. As I said, it is the sort of language he chooses to use.
—Order! As I heard it, Senator Bolkus used the term that Senator Bishop was slagging people. I really do not think that that is unparliamentary.
—There was a comment made by Senator Macdonald which I do ask to be withdrawn.
—I think he means `grubby little thing'. I withdraw that.
—That is the sort of behaviour that we are used to from this side.

—Mr President, I do think it is rather unusual that you find the term `grubby little thing', which is quite a commonplace term, unacceptable, yet you find the term `to slag' acceptable. I find that a very curious ruling. Could you tell me how you came to that conclusion?
—I said earlier that I did not think it was applied to you personally. If Senator Bolkus—

—Mr President, in the middle of the night, or the early hours of the morning, your deputy was most offended by a term that Senator Collins used. Senator Crowley later let us know what the term was. It was not applied to anyone in particular, but it was a piece of language which was found to be offensive and Senator Colston dealt with it and asked for it to be withdrawn.
—Order! Senator Bolkus, it might be better for the general running of the chamber if you withdraw it.

—I withdraw, Mr President. There is one point that I do want to go to—in fact there are a number—before I run out of time. But there is one aspect of this which still remains to be tested. As I said, the Bill is not through the Parliament yet and we do have to go through a number of processes during which we will find out whether the Liberal Party is serious on disclosure.

PARA.TAB: The basic principle governing the Government's position on disclosure is well and truly summarised in ICAC, where it says:

SPEECH.PARA: If there is a conflict between the public interest and the convenience of the major political parties, the public interest must be allowed to prevail. What disclosure is about is fairness and openness between the political process, the political parties and the public. It is the public's right to know.

The Liberals have tossed in a number of smokescreens. Statements have been made by party apparatchiks, whether it be Goldsworthy or Robb, and we remain to be convinced that it is possible to draft legislation to meet the fairness and equity test they propose. The test is not a question of fairness and equity; the test is whether it is transparent or not to the public. And that is what dictates the Government's position.

PARA.TAB: We have got to see, and we will wait to see, how the Liberals line up on the question of income and expenditure as opposed to donations, which is what they have always talked about; how they line up on spot audits, which they have opposed by legal and other measures in the past; and how they line up on the question of discrimination—and there are measures in the Bill to handle that—and so on. The simple, basic thing about disclosure is that it is the individual's right to know, the public's right to know; and we will see how those opposite line up on that.

Mr President, in conclusion, just let me make one point. The package, as I said, does lay the basis for a new era in campaigning. In doing so, it protects the honest donor, it provides a transparent system for the public and it provides information for the public. It is not there yet. The next 11 hours or so will show how the Bill finally comes through the Parliament and whether it is in a form which is acceptable to the Government.

The basic thing has probably best been put by Michael Gawenda in Time Australia magazine on 13 May when discussing this issue. His article was entitled `The Price Tag for Free Speech'. I think Gawenda in the last paragraph sums up the motivation of the Government and also the motivation, from what I can elicit from Senator Coulter's statement earlier on, of the Democrats. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: But in the end this issue is a council of despair. Sometime soon governments must do something about an electoral system in which increasingly money decides who is and who is not heard. Ultimately, this renders meaningless the right of free speech, which is one of liberal democracy's central features.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That consideration of the Bill in Committee of the Whole be made an order of the day for a later hour.
